HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Gives Firmest Support Yet for China Bill

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
As the Congressional vote on permanent normalized trade relations for China draws closer, Vice President Al Gore is stepping up his activities to promote it. 
 He spoke more forcefully yesterday for the agreement than he usually does. And today he plans to attend a White House meeting with President Clinton and former Presidents Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter, among others, to lobby for the measure, which Congress is to vote on later this month.
Mr. Gore has been tepid in his support so far for the agreement, largely because organized labor, which backs him, opposes it. But speaking up for it serves Mr. Gore's political purposes now by helping to counter the impression, reinforced during the controversy over Elian Gonzalez, that he does not take principled stands and instead panders to those whose support he seeks.
At the annual meeting of Associated Press publishers and editors yesterday in New York, Mr. Gore did not raise the China issue, but was asked about it in a question-and-answer session. Uncharacteristically, he delved into the reasons he believed the trade bill should pass; normally, when he mentions the issue at all, he gives it fairly short shrift.
"This doesn't reduce any U.S. tariffs; it only reduces Chinese tariffs," he said at the Associated Press meeting, which was held at St. Bartholomew's Church in Midtown Manhattan.
"If we turned it down," he added, referring to the World Trade Organization, "it wouldn't keep China from coming into the W.T.O.; China would come into the W.T.O. anyway."
Failing to approve the trade agreement, he said, would not hurt China but would put the United States at a "severe disadvantage" with its own trading partners.
Today, the vice president will appear in the East Room at the White House with President Clinton, former Presidents Ford and Carter, and two former secretaries of state, Henry A. Kissinger and James A. Baker III.
A White House spokesman, Jim Kennedy, said that former President George Bush, the father of Mr. Gore's Republican rival, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, was invited, but "due to a scheduling conflict, he is not able to attend." Governor Bush supports the trade agreement.
Mr. Gore's commitment to the matter has been in some doubt since he won the endorsement of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. last fall. He said then that he supported it, leading two of the organization's most powerful members, the Teamsters and the United Auto Workers, to withhold their endorsement of his candidacy.
Mr. Gore has tried to win over James P. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters union, but Mr. Hoffa, who is up for re-election and faces his own internal politics, has recently expressed more interest in the third-party candidacy of Patrick J. Buchanan, who also opposes the treaty.
Mr. Gore has said he has called some members of Congress to push them to support the treaty, but has not said how many. Aides say he has made calls from his campaign plane and from his office and that if the vice president did not want to appear in the East Room today, he would not do so, suggesting that he sees some political benefit in standing with President Clinton on an issue that the administration has advanced as important to the economy.

HEADLINE: State Dept. Faults U.S. Aid For War Refugees as Inept

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Although the Clinton administration has made "humanitarian intervention" a centerpiece of its foreign policy, it has done a poor job of delivering emergency aid to the people who need it, an internal State Department report says.
The "humanitarian factor has become central to senior policy makers' deliberations over U.S. foreign policy priorities," the report states. But the officials who are responsible for easing human suffering in foreign crises have little influence over high-level decision making, and in some cases are deliberately shut out, the study says. 
 The report, written by a top adviser to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, chronicles the billions of dollars in emergency assistance that have been sent to Afghanistan, Kosovo and Sudan to help people whose lives have been disrupted by war and to Honduras in the aftermath of a big hurricane in 1998.
Last year, when Serbian forces began expelling ethnic Albanians from Kosovo several days after the start of the NATO bombing campaign, senior administration officials publicly insisted that they were prepared for Serbian actions. Despite that, there was little food and shelter on hand as hundreds of thousands of refugees flooded into Macedonia and Albania.
The report describes the administration's main funnel for assistance to the expelled Kosovars, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, as suffering from "weak leadership" in the region and adds that the administration was unable to change this.
In Sudan, where the United States has spent more than $1 billion in the last 10 years trying to ease suffering in longest-running civil war in Africa, the report says the assistance has become so routine that it now appears to act as a substitute for peacemaking efforts to resolve the conflict.
The report, initiated by Morton H. Halperin, director of policy planning at the State Department, and based on interviews with senior administration officials, is an unclassified document. But it was not made public until now.
It was obtained under the Freedom of Information Act by the National Security Archive, a group that specializes in collecting government documents through requests and suits. The report was completed in January and has been submitted to Dr. Albright's office.
In outlining options for improving response, the report suggests that the relief programs run by the Agency for International Development could be folded into the State Department.
This is one step short of what Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, has been recommending since he took charge of the panel in 1995.
Mr. Helms, who favors abolishing the agency as an independent entity and putting it into the State Department, said he believed "bringing A.I.D. into the State Department will mean more effective use of the aid," his spokesman, Marc Thiessen, said.
On the campaign trail, the two presumptive presidential candidates have differing views of the "humanitarian intervention" policy. George W. Bush Jr. has said he would be much more selective in deciding where and when the United States would intervene. Vice President Al Gore supported the interventionist policy in a recent major speech. Mr. Gore was instrumental in preventing the agency from being melded into the State Department years ago.
In its account of how unprepared the administration was to meet the needs of the Kosovo refugees, the report points to shortcomings by American intelligence officials.
Instead of anticipating an outpouring of refugees, the administration was expecting the opposite, that nearly a million people would be displaced in Kosovo in the bombing.
"The prevailing worst-case scenario was that one million Kosovars would be displaced internally, prohibited from exiting, and remain largely inaccessible, in the context of an ongoing air war and a NATO determination not to launch a ground invasion," the report said.
As for Sudan, the report added, many in the administration believed that top officials had exerted too little effort to resolve the conflict. That has been partly caused by deep divisions in the administration on Sudan, with some favoring total isolation and even more help to rebels in the south. In addition, officials responsible for the large assistance expenditures have been excluded from crucial decisions.
Officials from A.I.D. and the State Department who managed the assistance program were not consulted when the administration decided to shut the American embassy in Khartoum in the mid-1990's because of security concerns. The closing undermined Washington's ability to talk to Khartoum about helping civilian war victims, the report said.

HEADLINE: Year Later, China's New View of U.S. Bombing

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 8

 BODY:
One year ago today, university students were hurling bricks at the American Embassy in a rage over the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade that killed 3 people and injured 20. Today, they spent a balmy Monday attending classes or playing soccer.
The Chinese government, which last year railed against American perfidy and imperialist ambitions, commemorated the bombing in a low-key manner, as well. A government spokesman restated China's position that the American explanation that the attack resulted from targeting errors remains inadequate. An editorial in the People's Daily called on Chinese to channel their continued anger into strengthening the economy. 
 Many Chinese say they still believe that the bombing had to have been intentional, meant to warn or punish China, and resentment persists. But now, the government and people want most to see the China trade bill pass Congress this month.
Conversations with students at People's University here today found no sentiment for renewed rock throwing in any case.
Zhou Jiubo, 21, who is studying management, was at the American Embassy in May heaving bricks. "We were all hot-headed and angry," he recalled. "But now we've taken to heart the government's advice to study hard and make China strong. We need to make our country stronger so it won't be subject to bullying any more."
Zhao Bingling, 22, a law student, said, "We haven't forgotten about the bombing."
What worries her more today, she said, is the Congressional trade vote, which many here see as a litmus test of American attitudes. If the bill is defeated, she said, "I think there will be a very strong reaction."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
America's Labor Pains

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
What's going on with the American labor movement?
In March the Teamsters started lobbying the Clinton White House to award one of the Teamsters' largest employers, UPS, a much sought after new air route for landing cargo planes in China. At the same time, the Teamsters have been lobbying against the administration's effort to grant China permanent normal trade relations or entry into the World Trade Organization, which would actually spur U.S.-China cargo trade. "It seems that the Teamsters want us to have more cargo flights to China, but no cargo," said one U.S. official. They want more trade in empty boxes. 
 This is almost as interesting as the dockworkers' union marching in Seattle against more globalization and free trade, which is like the milkmen's union coming out against cows. No trade, no dockworkers. No milk, no milkmen. But then you also have the United Auto Workers opposing the trade deal with China, which is strange since today virtually no U.S.-made car can be sold in China, but under the Clinton-negotiated W.T.O. deal all U.S.-made cars can be sold, financed and distributed in China.
And then, of course, there was the lovely scene during the recent anti-I.M.F. protests in Washington when that hate-mongering isolationist Pat Buchanan joined forces with the Teamsters and their boss James Hoffa. Mr. Buchanan told cheering Teamsters that as president he would tell the Chinese to either shape up or "you guys have sold your last pair of chopsticks in any mall in the United States," and that he would appoint Mr. Hoffa as America's top trade negotiator.
How did the U.S. labor movement go from being a progressive force to being the leading opponent of free trade and pal of Pat Buchanan? I posed that question to the former Labor Secretary Robert Reich, now a Brandeis University professor.
His short answer is that U.S. labor unions have come to totally distrust U.S. business, and are convinced that free trade is simply a vehicle for moving manufacturing jobs abroad.
"I believe the labor leaders today are being pushed by their rank and file, who never liked Nafta and who do not trust American business to keep jobs in this country," said Mr. Reich. "Even though the business cycle in recent years has improved things for the country as a whole, labor does not feel that it has really shared fully in the expansion. It feels that manufacturing jobs are still vanishing -- whether because of technology or globalization and free trade."
Labor's response, therefore, has been to try to slam America's doors shut, even though it is obvious that globalization and free trade have contributed mightily to America's economic expansion. What to do? Congressman Sander Levin's thoughtful proposal for better monitoring of China's worker and human rights behavior is laudable, but I don't think labor really cares about either.
What we need is a business-government-labor summit that tries to defuse at least some of labor's real concerns in return for a tempering of its opposition to trade.
"If the business community is really serious," says Mr. Reich, "it should combine the China trade deal with legislation that would give labor a ban on the permanent replacement of striking workers, something labor has sought for years, and it would also treble the fines against any company that illegally fires workers for trying to form unions. In recent years more companies have been using the threat of permanently replacing striking workers, and the practice of illegally firing workers for trying to form unions has been on the rise, because the penalty structure is just a slap on the wrist."
This is worth considering. Free trade and the new economy have been very good for the U.S., but the gains have been unequally distributed, particularly when it comes to blue-collar workers. My attitude toward labor is: Tell us what we can do to ameliorate that -- short of putting up walls and closing doors that will only hurt us all in the long run. Sure, we could redistribute income through tax policy, but that isn't going to happen. So why not try Mr. Reich's idea: Strengthen workers' ability to negotiate wages, severance and security on their own behalf within the new economy.
Pie-in-the-sky? Maybe. But some way has to be found to persuade labor to loosen its grip on the door, and one way could be this bargain: You let go of the door and we'll empower you to better thrive with it open.

HEADLINE: Ground Broken for Light Rail Between Camden and Trenton

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 8

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman officially broke ground today on a much-debated light rail line between Camden and Trenton that will initially carry about 4,150 riders a day.
The $603 million cost of the project is to be paid entirely by the state. 
 Officials said they helped keep the cost down by designing the line to share all but 4 of its 34 miles of track with Conrail at a cost of $67 million. Conrail will continue to use the track from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m., when the light rail line will not operate.
Officials estimate ridership could double within 20 years.
The project, expected to be finished in 2002, was promoted more as an economic development tool for Camden and Trenton -- largely bypassed by nearly a decade of economic growth -- than as a solution to heavy commuter demands in Mercer, Burlington or Camden Counties, where trains are to run on a route roughly along the Delaware River.
Mainly because of its high cost relative to the modest number of passengers it is estimated to serve, the project has attracted widespread criticism in its several years of planning. Local officials and citizens groups in Delanco, Riverton, Pennsauken and other communities along the route have had concerns about safety and property values.
Unlike a light rail line in Hudson County, where an initial phase linking Bayonne and Jersey City was completed last month, the Trenton-Camden project is not receiving any federal financing, nor did the state ask for it.
The reason, said Penny Bassett Hackett, a spokeswoman for New Jersey Transit, is that officials did not want to jeopardize financing for the Hudson-Bergen line.
But a transportation professional who is close to the project said the Trenton-Camden line would not be likely to meet criteria for federal help because of its cost per rider.

HEADLINE: Nationwide Drop in Murders Is Reaching to Small Towns

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
High Point, N.C., has not had a drug- or gang-related murder in the past 18 months, after a stunning surge in homicides in the years before that. 
 In Natchez, Miss., the number of murders dropped to one in 1999, after reaching a dozen a few years before.
And in Oceanside, Calif., where there were as many as 25 homicides as recently as 1995, there were 7 last year.
These drops in murders are an important indication that the decline in the nation's murder rate since 1991, long driven by decreases in homicide in the big cities, is now starting to take hold in small cities, suburbs and rural areas across the country.
This trend was underscored by the release on Sunday of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's preliminary crime report for 1999, which showed that while homicides dropped 2 percent in cities with a population of half a million or more, they declined 10 percent in cities of 100,000 to 250,000, 12 percent in cities of 50,000 to 100,000 people and 14 percent in communities of 10,000 to 25,000 people. Over all, in suburban counties, the number of murders fell 12 percent, and 14 percent in rural counties.
In fact, the smaller the community, the bigger the decrease in murders, according to the F.B.I. study, known as the Uniform Crime Report, which is based on figures supplied by police forces around the country.
Just as in big cities, officials in these smaller communities attribute the decline to a mix of factors, including their own innovative programs, an improved economy and longer prison sentences.
In High Point, a city of 76,000, federal, state and local law enforcement agencies, drawing on a program pioneered in Boston, worked together to focus on drug dealers who had moved in from as far away as Los Angeles and Mexico. In Natchez, an antebellum tourist town of 19,000, officials say a strategy of community policing and four new officers financed by a Clinton administration program helped cut crime.
In Oceanside, a community of 160,000 north of San Diego, the waning of the crack cocaine epidemic, a healthy economy that reduced unemployment and California's "three strikes and you're out" sentencing laws all contributed to a reduction in crime, local officials say.
The reason behind the trend, said Prof. Alfred Blumstein, a criminologist at Carnegie Mellon University, is related to the reason the murder rate first increased in the mid-1980's. It was the major cities that were initially hit by crack cocaine, and then by the infestation of semiautomatic handguns and gangs that accompanied the crack epidemic, he said. The smaller cities and rural areas were slower to become involved in the crack problem, and just as they lagged behind in the growth of crime, "they are slower to come down," Professor Blumstein said.
In fact, some smaller cities and rural areas have been victims of the success the larger cities had in suppressing crime. This led drug dealers and gangs to move to the small communities.
"What we saw in North Carolina, as law enforcement picked up the pressure in the big cities in the mid-1990's, was that the gangs purposely moved out to smaller places," said Walter Holton, the United States attorney for the Middle District of North Carolina, in Greensboro.
Mexican gangs arrived at the same time as an influx of Hispanic families moving to North Carolina to work in the state's rapidly expanding industries, disguising their illicit activities, Mr. Holton said.
In addition, some gang members traveled back and forth from Los Angeles to High Point, bringing drugs to sell. "They infiltrated the local market, becoming the major suppliers, and in the process used violence for intimidation to take over the city," Mr. Holton added.
But while the sharp decline in homicide in smaller communities now is seen as a positive sign, several experts said they were concerned that the slowing of the decrease in murder in big cities could mean the country is nearing the end of the remarkable fall in murder after eight consecutive years. "The big cities are signaling the end of the downturn is near," said James Allen Fox, Lipmann professor of criminal justice at Northeastern University.
Professor Blumstein has calculated that with the huge reduction in murder in the past few years, "If the trend continued, we would have a negative homicide rate, and that would occur in 2007."
Equally worrisome, the experts said, several big cities actually had increases in murder in 1999 for the first time since 1991, including San Diego, up 35.7 percent, St. Louis, up 15 percent, Phoenix, up 14.6 percent, Milwaukee, up 11.7 percent, and New York, up 6 percent.
"We have been getting at the easy problems, so now that we've gotten the easy gains, there should be a flattening out" in the overall decline, Professor Blumstein said. Among these gains, he said, were a shrinkage in the crack market and successful police tactics aimed at persuading young people not to carry guns.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
The Muted Effect So Far Of Rate Rises

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The cost of financing is on the rise for consumers and companies.
The benchmark fixed interest rate on 30-year home mortgages, at 8.65 percent, is the highest since early 1995, and the yields on junk bonds, at an average of 12.79 percent, are well above their levels then. Corporate bond yields, at 8.89 percent, are also approaching early 1995 marks. 
 These are all signs that the Federal Reserve's interest rate increases, five moves of a quarter-point since last June, are beginning to have an impact on the financial markets.
But the higher rates have not yet led to a significant drag on the overall economy, in part because market rates have risen to their five-year highs very recently and in part because stocks have been strong enough that consumers have not been discouraged. Although growth has slowed somewhat since the fourth quarter of 1999, the economy grew at a 5.4 percent annual rate in the first quarter of 2000. And in the most significant data since then, 340,000 jobs were created last month as the unemployment rate fell to a 30-year low of 3.9 percent, the government said on Friday.
This lack of bite in monetary policy, even more than recent suggestions of some inflationary pressure in wages, has led many analysts to predict that the Fed will push up its target for short-term interest rates much further then the current 6 percent before the economy will slow to an acceptable pace. With Fed policy makers scheduled to meet next Tuesday, the debate has shifted to whether they will raise their target rate by half a percentage point instead of the familiar quarter-point steps.
A recent rise in the yield on the futures contract of federal funds shows that many investors expect the central bank's target rate to be 7 percent by November.
The Fed has moved cautiously until now partly because it saw few signs of inflationary pressure other than the spurt in crude oil and gasoline prices.
Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor, said in a speech last month that "the current episode is the smallest and most gradual tightening" since the late 1960's. "So the modest effects on aggregate demand to date," he said, "perhaps only confirm the relatively modest and extremely gradual nature of the current tightening."
In addition, Mr. Meyer said, "some developments suggest that the recent policy moves may have had a more limited effect on aggregate demand than would have been expected."
To measure the impact of monetary policy, one has to look at what effect a rise in the federal funds rate, which is the rate on overnight loans between banks, has on broader financial conditions including interest rates, stock prices and the dollar's exchange rate. Mr. Meyer said one gauge, the Goldman Sachs financial conditions index, "is not only at the very low end of historical experience, but is nearly unchanged" since June.
"So a second conclusion about the current experience," Mr. Meyer said, "is that the increase in the funds rate, to date, has had a smaller effect than usual -- nearly zero -- on overall financial conditions and hence on aggregate demand."
Comparisons to the Fed's last episode of tightening help make the point. From February 1994 to March 1995, policy makers raised the federal funds rate target to 6 percent from 3 percent. By December 1994, new mortgage applications had fallen 20.3 percent from their year-earlier level, according to John Lonski, senior economist at Moody's Investors Service.
Rather than slowing, the rate has increased recently. New applications rose 9.2 percent in the 12-month period ending in April, despite the increase in the interest rate on a 30-year Fannie Mae mortgage to 8.65 percent from 6.90 percent during that time.
Even though mortgage and corporate rates are rising, they have not yet reached the high points of the 1994-95 Fed tightening. The Fannie Mae 30-year rate reached 9.29 percent in December 1994. The rate on long-term industrial company bonds rated by Moody's as Baa, its lowest investment-grade rating, reached 9.37 percent in November 1994. (But the yields on bonds below investment grade -- junk bonds in market parlance -- are more than three-quarters of a percentage point higher than their 11.98 percent peak in January 1995, according to Chase Manhattan's high-yield index.)
Probably the most important reason that the Fed's interest rate increases have had little impact is that stocks in general have not crumbled, another factor noted by Mr. Meyer. "Equity prices have been unusually resilient in this episode," he said, "rising by an amount near the maximum during the first nine months of significant tightenings over the period studied." While the Dow Jones industrial average is down 3.3 percent since the end of June 1999, the Nasdaq composite index is up 36.6 percent, and the Wilshire 5000, which includes all domestic stocks, is up 5.4 percent.
William Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs, said yesterday that the central bank would have to raise the Fed funds target to 7.5 percent next year, which means an additional 1.5 percentage points, to slow the economy. Like several economists, he raised his projection last week.
Mr. Dudley said the Fed's moves so far have had so little impact because "the bond and stock markets are so trusting" of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman. Investors, he said, believe that the Fed will keep inflation in check, but not push interest rates so high as to cause a recession. "So they are not worried about inflation and they are not worried about a hard landing," he said.
Neil M. Soss, chief United States economist at Credit Suisse First Boston, said, "we haven't seen much effect in the real economy yet" because consumers, who have powered much of this record economic expansion, have not received a signal from the financial markets to slow down.
But the surge in mortgage rates in the last two weeks, to 8.65 percent from 8.09 percent, he said, may show that the Fed's message is finally coming through.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
More Offense Bringing More Fans to the Park

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
Stop. Just stop. Cease and desist. Enough already. Let the concern and consternation over the increase in home runs and runs end here and now. Instead of tearing out the hair and gnashing the teeth, sit back and relax and enjoy what we have. It's a new era for baseball.
It has happened before. The advent of Babe Ruth marked the beginning of an era that made baseball the country's sport of choice. Without Ruth and the home runs he produced, baseball would have withered and died eons ago. If an escalation of the Ruthian experience is occurring now, let it be. Don't look for ways to stifle it. 
 Fans evidently don't find fault with the outbreak of scoring. Attendance is up 5.8 percent over last year, and they may attend games this season in record numbers. That possible development is what Major League Baseball anticipates, at least, so why would anyone want to do anything to take away from the fans something they appear to like.
"Our fans are enjoying it," Commissioner Bud Selig said yesterday. "Did we design this? No. We aren't that smart. We ought to watch it and analyze it, but is it necessarily bad? No."
Last Friday night about 39,000 fans sat at The Ballpark in Arlington and watched a game that could become the signature event of the new era. Oakland led Texas, 15-7, after six and a half innings, but the Rangers won the game, 17-16, scoring 10 runs in the last three innings. The fans who were there were ecstatic and will talk about the game for months, if not years, to come. No one asked for his money back. It was 4 hours 1 minute of great entertainment.
The purists, of course, cringed. The purists, however, are not paying the players' inflated salaries.
Teams played 457 games in the first five weeks of the season. They averaged 10.76 runs and 2.59 home runs a game. Pitchers compiled a 4.96 earned run average in that period.
Conspiracy theorists suspect that the ball has been doctored to make it easier for batters to hit it out of the park. The fact is home runs and runs have increased nearly every year since the first of two expansions that added four teams in the 1990's. In 1992, the year before the first expansion, teams averaged 8.39 runs and 1.45 home runs a game, and pitchers compiled a 3.80 E.R.A. in the first 457 games.
With the postexpansion proliferation of scoring and home run hitting, new standards have to be established. The new era, for example, needs a new E.R.A. A 3.00 earned run average used to be considered good for a pitcher. With the average E.R.A. up by about a third, that standard has to be raised to 4.00.
Last season the American League had only eight starting pitchers at 4.00 or lower. Pitchers are the players who are affected most adversely in the new era. For the most part, they are fodder for hitters who have become stronger and in parks that have become smaller.
Roy Halladay is supposed to be a good young pitcher for Toronto, but in seven starts this season he has an 11.53 E.R.A. Jose Lima, a 21-game winner for Houston last year, has a 9.53 E.R.A. in seven starts and has been battered for a major league-high 16 home runs.
It is middle relief pitchers, though, who deserve hazard pay for their efforts. With pitching staffs short on talent generally, if the starter is knocked out early, his departure triggers a parade of ineffective relievers who should still be learning their craft in the minor leagues or who never demonstrated enough ability to pitch in the majors.
Tanyon Sturtze is a reliever for the White Sox whose professional career spanned the 1990's. In that decade, he spent all but 110 playing days in the minors. This season, in eight relief appearances and one start (last night against Boston) he has a 10:43 E.R.A. covering 142/3 innings.
Home run standards, too, must be raised because of inflation. From 1976 until 1995, excluding the strike seasons of 1981 and 1994, the American and National League home run champions averaged 42 home runs. In the last five seasons, their successors have hit an average of 53 home runs a year. Using that 26 percent inflation rate, if 30 home runs had been considered a benchmark for sluggers, that number should now be at least 38, if not 40.
Baseball's new era, however, has not eliminated low-scoring games. This season has already produced seven 1-0 games and 14 2-1 games. Boston has lost a pair of 1-0 decisions; Los Angeles suffered two 1-0 losses in consecutive games with different teams. Cleveland lost two consecutive 2-1 games to different teams. The Mets have won three 2-1 decisions.
Each day or set of days can still produce vastly different results. Colorado scored 43 runs in three games against Montreal last week, then went to San Francisco and was shut out twice in two games.
A premium is placed on good pitching more than ever in the new era. But the success of Pedro Martinez (1.22), Randy Johnson (0.93), Tom Glavine (1.73) and some others shows that hitters haven't assumed command completely.
"Are Pedro Martinez and Randy Johnson using a different ball?" Selig asked. "Of course not."
Baseball officials are nevertheless studying developments in the new era. They are having the balls tested, they will go to Costa Rica and tour the Rawlings factory where the balls are made, they will study bats, they are considering raising the mound in a couple of rookie minor leagues to see what effect such a change could have on hitting.
Officials met yesterday with Rawlings people, who for the 972nd time vowed that they had made no change in the balls. If that is so, let the new era continue and take baseball wherever Mark McGwire and friends lead it. Just leave a few 1-0 games around for old times' sake.

HEADLINE: City's Rent Board Recommends Increases of 4% and 6%

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Clearing the way for the highest rent increases since 1996, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board gave landlords preliminary approval last night to raise one-year leases by 4 percent and two-year leases by 6 percent for the one million apartments covered by rent stabilization.
Leaders of both landlord and tenant groups voiced dissatisfaction with the action and vowed to press the board to revise the numbers at its final vote on June 22. But historically, the board rarely makes major changes in its initial position. Once the increases are final, the new rates will apply to leases renewed between Oct. 1, 2000, and Sept. 30, 2001. 
 For five of the last six years, the board had reflected the low-inflation era by adopting increases of 2 percent for one-year leases and 4 percent for two-year leases. The exceptions, after a spike in fuel oil prices four years ago, were increases of 5 percent for one-year leases and 7 percent for two-year leases.
"It's much too high," said Michael McKee, associate director of the state's largest tenant group, the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition. "It's going to greatly overcompensate landlords more than they need, and it's going to increase their net income."
Tenant advocates argued that only a minimal increase was called for. Owners are making record profits, they said, because inflation is low, rent collections are up and the rent increases granted in recent years have been greater than needed.
But the landlords, whose advocates had requested increases of 9 percent for one-year leases and 15 percent for two-year leases, said they were still recouping from the lean years of the recession. They called for higher rents to offset rising operating costs.
"The vote today is in the right direction, but a higher increase is justified," said Joseph Strasburgh, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, the biggest organization of owners of rent-stabilized buildings.
Noting that the two tenant representatives on the board voted for the compromise, he said: "I'm surprised, honestly surprised, because tenant members have never voted for increased rent guidelines before. They recognized that a higher rate was justified."
Although Mr. Strasburgh said his group would appeal to the board for higher increases, he conceded, "I do not have high expectations" of succeeding.
The focal issue was a 54.8 percent rise in the last year in fuel oil costs for heat and hot water, which the landlords said justified their call for sharply higher rents. But tenant leaders said the rise in oil prices was temporary and should not be the basis for permanently higher rents.
According to studies by the rent board's staff, general operating costs had undergone almost no increases for two years -- 0.13 percent in 1997 and 0.03 percent in 1998 -- but last year jumped by 7.8 percent, mainly because of oil prices. Another board study, however, also showed that net income, from which profits are drawn, had risen to its highest point in the 10 years that those statistics had been compiled.
The impending rent increases would have been higher, Mr. McKee said, had it not been for organized tenant pressure that included numerous calls to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's office in recent days.
"It's all a political process anyway," Mr. McKee said, "and thank goodness he's been running for the Senate." He said the mayor was balancing his popularity among renters with the desires of his landlord campaign contributors.
Putting their political views on display, a few dozen protesting tenants carried signs at the board meeting, in Lower Manhattan, with slogans like "Rudy Giuliani, the Landlords' Candidate for Senate" and "Rudy, Don't Raise Our Rent."
Before its final vote, the board is to hold its annual public hearing on June 15 at Cooper Union, at Seventh Street and Third Avenue. Testimony on apartment rents will be from 1 to 5:30 p.m. and 8 to 9:30 p.m. Testimony on residential hotel rents will be from 10 a.m. to noon and 7 to 8:30 p.m.

HEADLINE: Republicans Debate Gently In Senate Race

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 8

 BODY:
After languishing for months in the shadow of their better-known, better-financed Democratic rivals, New Jersey's four Republican candidates for the United States Senate had their first debate today, with all four brandishing their conservative credentials while avoiding the harsh attacks they had leveled at each other in recent campaign mailings.
With only regional political bases and limited name recognition, the four used the forum to make broad appeals to the 300,000 voters expected to decide the June 6 primary, describing their views in favor of tax cuts, free trade and severely limiting the use of American military troops abroad. 
 The format did not allow for give-and-take during what was largely a genial debate, with the candidates mentioning each other's names only when they agreed on various issues. Their only critical words were aimed at Democrats, specifically President Clinton and New Jersey's two Democratic Senate contenders, Jim Florio and Jon S. Corzine.
Representative Robert D. Franks, a four-term congressman from Union County, called himself a common-sense conservative and said that he and fellow Republicans in Congress deserved credit for the robust economy because they had helped "to drag Bill Clinton kicking and screaming down the path to fiscal responsibility."
James W. Treffinger, the Essex County executive, described himself as an "unabashed conservative" and proposed replacing the income tax code with a flat tax.
William L. Gormley, a state senator from Ocean County, said he was a fiscal conservative because he had voted for 37 tax cuts since Gov. Christine Todd Whitman took office in 1994. In an unusual move for a contestant in a Republican primary, however, Mr. Gormley also said he had become a target for the National Rifle Association because he was the only Republican state legislator to vote for New Jersey's assault weapons ban in 1990.
The most conservative candidate in the race is Murray Sabrin, a college finance professor who ran for governor as a Libertarian in 1993. Mr. Sabrin called for the abolition of affirmative action, the Departments of Education, Energy, and Housing and Urban Development, the capital gains tax and the estate tax. When asked whether his platform might be too extreme for New Jersey's historically moderate Republican voters, he beamed. "That's what they said about Ronald Wilson Reagan in 1980," Mr. Sabrin said.
The debate, sponsored jointly by The New York Times and The New Jersey Network, was taped at 1 p.m. and broadcast at 9 p.m. The Democratic candidates are scheduled to hold their first debate on Thursday, and both debates will be broadcast back-to-back on Sunday at 2 p.m. The Democrats have agreed to four debates before the primary. The Republicans are scheduled to hold two more.
The tranquil tone of today's debate was a departure from the increasingly heated campaign. In recent weeks, Mr. Gormley's campaign has called Mr. Franks a "Clinton Republican," saying that the congressman voted to impeach the president but days later urged the Senate not to remove him from office. Mr. Franks has branded Mr. Gormley a "Florio Republican," and accused him of cooperating too closely with Mr. Florio during his four years as governor.
As if bracing for such a criticism, Mr. Gormley began the debate with a one-minute opening statement in which he described his votes against Mr. Florio's tax increase. But an attack from Mr. Franks never came. Instead, Mr. Franks talked of his own efforts, when he was a state legislator and Republican state chairman, to block Mr. Florio's 1990 income tax increase and deny his re-election.
Mr. Treffinger predicted that Mr. Corzine's programs would bankrupt the country. Referring to Mr. Florio's $2.8-billion tax increase, he said, "There are at least 2.8 billion reasons not to vote for Jim Florio."
However, most of the debate emphasized the similarities between Mr. Treffinger, Mr. Gormley and Mr. Franks. All three said they favored limited gun control, campaign finance reform, expanding trade relations with China and federal tax credits to help working families afford health care and higher education.
Mr. Franks and Mr. Gormley described issues in which they broke ranks with their party leadership. Mr. Franks said he defied Republican leaders in the House of Representatives when he voted to support campaign finance and the patients' bill of rights.
Mr. Gormley described his vote for Mr. Florio's assault weapon ban as an act of conscience.
"I had the opportunity as a United States marine to fire an M-16, and I know what damage they can do," Mr. Gormley said. "We need to send a message to the N.R.A., and the special interest groups who don't care about our children and don't care about the future of our state, to tell them we're not going to stand for it."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 10, 2000, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the first debate by New Jersey's four Republican candidates for United States Senate misidentified the county represented by one of them, State Senator William L. Gormley. He is from Atlantic County, not Ocean County.
The article also misstated the year in which another candidate, Murray Sabrin, ran for governor as a Libertarian. It was 1997, not 1993.

LENGTH: 1752 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
A Temple of Modern Art and Spectacle

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
What are people going to say in 100 years about all these new museums for modern art that we're building, which seem to be getting almost as big as the Met?
The latest behemoth is the new Tate Modern, across the Thames from St. Paul's Cathedral in the former Bankside power plant. The fashionable Swiss architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron have done the renovation -- lovingly preserving the brick exterior with the big chimney in the middle -- at a cost of $200 million, half in government grants, half private money. Queen Elizabeth II inaugurates the place on May 11. The next day the public arrives. 
 First things first: the museum is of course a contribution to contemporary art not just here but throughout Europe; a boon to Southwark, the run-down borough of London that it is in; and a major achievement by Sir Nicholas Serota, the quietly subversive Tate director who miraculously overcame decades of reluctance among stodgy British officials to finally establish a proper modern art museum.
Proper but problematic. The Tate is in part a temple to vanity, the vanity of a culture that equates spectacle with substance, with half the building devoted to a vast entranceway, the museum's deeply gloomy signature space -- and with an installation that is occasionally eccentric to the point of distraction.
To Britons who for decades got admirable but tepid Ben Nicholson and Barbara Hepworth when they went to the old Tate for modern art, the new Tate must seem like a revolution. Dozens of living artists of different generations and nationalities (Bruce Nauman, Matthew Barney, Juan Munoz, James Coleman, Ilya Kabakov, Tatsuo Miyajima, Rebecca Horn -- the list goes on) are mixed in among the British. No doubt the choices will cause grumbling because such choices do, but they seem fine. All this comes when London is suddenly vying with New York as the mecca for contemporary art. British art's rising fortunes in the 1990's helped the Tate come about. Now the Tate will surely raise those fortunes more. Whether there will be enough money to run the museum is an open question, which is partly why the Tate has just begun a for-profit on line collaboration with the Museum of Modern Art in New York. But that is another matter.
You may recall that the old Tate upriver mixed British and modern art. The arrangement made no sense. Renamed Tate Britain, the old building, a handsome gallery, has become a museum just for British art. Gainsborough has been liberated from Duchamp.
This solves one problem, but museums of national art are suffering identity crises in the new global culture. Contemporary art, a global phenomenon, exists uneasily in a traditional nationalist context.
So Tate officials, evidently trying not to prejudice the public against one museum or the other and wanting to make living artists and their audiences feel at home in both places, have settled on strategies to mix new art and old art. Mona Hatoum, a young British star, has enormous sculptures (a giant vegetable grater the size of a truck, among them) in the main hall at Tate Britain -- ridiculous work but new and conspicuous, which is the point.
At the same time, both Tate Britain and Tate Modern are showing works not chronologically but according to themes, as the Museum of Modern Art in New York has been doing lately but with art from much more limited periods of time. Contemporary work is cheek by jowl with early 20th century art here.
"Landscape, matter, environment" is the title of one section at Tate Modern, "nude, action, body" another. The pretentiousness of the titles should tell you something. The museum says the goal is to avoid the old "isms," but it's also, no doubt, to disguise gaps. At this, the strategy is a failure. Compared with the holdings of the Modern or Pompidou in Paris, the Tate collection is spotty before 1975, the legacy of previous British unease about modernism. Much of the best of what's on view comes from the last 25 years.
There are some clever conjunctions that do result from the thematic installation: a room called "Subversive Objects" mixes Salvador Dali and Hans Bellmer, early Surrealists, with living artists like Sarah Lucas and Rosemarie Trockel; another room, "Structures for Survival," puts together Andrea Zittel, Mario Merz and Franz West, unusually.
But it's a parlor game trying to figure out why a Monet hangs next to a Richard Long, art being forced to play second fiddle to curatorial concept. A Cezanne is orphaned beside Minimalist sculptures. Kandinsky is demeaned in a room titled "Manifestoes."
And a room of nudes by Picasso, Lucian Freud, Bonnard and others is upstaged by Sam Taylor-Wood's video of a naked man dancing to Samuel Barber's Adagio for Strings in the next gallery, the collision of media inevitably skewing the relative impact of the works.
Suffice it to say that the collisions are even more startling at Tate Britain, where the 16th century and the 20th century meet. Museums should make it easier for people to stand in front of a work of art unencumbered. The Tate's installation makes a case for a return to the old chronological approach, or for a blend of old approach and new, time being a cruel master but at least a reliable way to get a handle on the past.
And the building itself? A London journalist joked that the new Tate is the Millennium Dome for the educated class -- a nasty remark considering that the dome has become a $1.3 billion joke, but looked at a certain way, not wrong. Both are celebrations of national pride, colossal and populist, the Tate being more upscale but still based on the economy of tourism and on a cocktail of boosterism, urban renewal, youth culture and unexceptionable programs of cultural uplift. Art is part but only part of what the new Tate is about.
There is sheer theatricality, for example. Modern art museums serving among other things as highbrow amusement parks these days, Tate officials working with Mr. Herzog and Mr. de Meuron have made sure to provide the expected thrill. The lobby, the former plant's turbine hall, entered from the west down a 75-foot-wide ramp, is nearly two football fields long and 12 stories high, an industrial St. Peter's with the original cherry-picker cranes left overhead.
Awesome. Memorable.
And dour. The natural point of comparison, the Orsay in Paris, also an industrial conversion and a museum with its own problems, is airy, not austere. But this is England and that is France. No frills here.
Perhaps the impression that the place is grim is exaggerated by the presence of several giant new sculptures by Louise Bourgeois: a spider and three 30-foot steel spiral staircases, like prison guard towers with enormous mirrors on top, plunked at the east end of the hall. The sculptures are awful. Previously a neglected artist, Ms. Bourgeois is now vastly overrated.
The quality of art improves episodically in the galleries. Tate officials (who can blame them?) have generally avoided art that would be too controversial. No decapitated cows. Nothing really risque. Nothing that might overshadow the experience of wandering fresh galleries for the first time.
Occupying three floors on one side of the building, these galleries wrap halfway around escalator landings, a layout akin to the Modern in New York. Wending from one end of a floor to the other can feel like going through a rat's maze. Time will tell whether the choice of unfinished wood floors (they will become increasingly marked up by footprints) will seem smart or lunatic.
The rooms otherwise are minimal boxes, varied in size. Plain, clean and useful, they won't please acolytes of Frank Gehry, but artists should like them. They are not temporary and partitioned, as at the Pompidou, or precious, as at the Getty.
It's only too bad more of them don't have natural light, although a few have great views of St. Paul's and the river, the views breaking up the monotony of consecutive white spaces. Towering galleries suit enormous sculptures. Others do for drawings, photographs and documentary material. (There's an excellent Fluxus room, for example.) Much of the inaugural display consists of recent installations and videos, big works that had been difficult to show off in the old building.
Two of the three floors of galleries will be for the permanent collection, sandwiching a floor for temporary exhibitions; this is less space for temporary shows than at the old Tate, apparently, gallery space having been sacrificed to the lobby. The exhibition rooms are nonetheless much better. At the moment they have sculptures and videos from the permanent collection: works by two dozen artists getting a room apiece, more or less. A few rooms on the permanent collection floors, interludes in the thematic display, are monographic, too.
This is where the value of the new Tate becomes clearest. British artists, including Bridget Riley, Anthony Caro and Anish Kapoor, are stressed, but there's plenty of room for foreign artists like Mr. Nauman, Mr. Kabakov and Mr. Coleman to be prominent. Mr. Kabakov's Soviet hallway is a miracle of nostalgic re-creation, deeply ironic, and Mr. Coleman's video about a photographer is alarming, vivid and very funny. They stay in the mind.
The new Tate's capacity to accommodate different art flexibly is its asset at a time when contemporary art seems to be moving in divergent, unpredictable directions.
But the question lingers: Must a museum of modern art be quite this gigantic? Is the tradition that begins with Cezanne so important historically that it demands a building as big as the National Gallery?
Maybe this seems odd to ask. The more room the better, especially for previously underprivileged new art. But the question might be asked differently: Will the tradition of art post-Cezanne still seem coherent in a century? The kind of person who became an artist 100 years ago is not the same person who becomes an artist today. What is defined as art and the people who make it are changing all the time.
Maybe video and installation will come to belong to different stories, disconnected from Cezanne. Maybe Cezanne will no longer seem like a beginning of anything but a middle, or an end. Maybe, God forbid, no one will want to show Richard Long or Louise Bourgeois in 100 years.
One thing is certain. This moment, the turn of the 21st century, will be remembered as a time when a rich and egocentric culture saw fit to memorialize itself on an incredible scale.

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
A Symbol Issue

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
You could argue that the question whether to grant China "permanent normal trade relations," or P.N.T.R., is mainly a procedural issue. The United States won't be reducing any existing trade barriers; all the concessions in terms of opening markets will come from the Chinese side. Nor will we in any way be dropping our guard against Chinese espionage, abandoning our commitment to the defense of Taiwan, or otherwise pretending that the Chinese government is any better than it is.
But the debate over P.N.T.R. isn't about the literal content of the measure itself; it's about the symbolism. For labor, blocking P.N.T.R. would be a demonstration of clout -- even though the trade arithmetic suggests that union members as a group would if anything benefit from China's offered concessions. For those who understandably abhor China's current rulers, blocking P.N.T.R. would be a slap in the face of undemocratic regimes everywhere -- even though nobody really thinks that a rejection would drive those rulers from power. 
 There is nothing wrong with taking symbolic stands in politics -- and China's government has done nothing to merit kid-glove treatment. The trouble is that whatever symbolism a defeat for P.N.T.R. might have here in the United States, it would have even more powerful symbolism elsewhere -- and in a way that would ultimately hurt the very causes the opponents of trade normalization say they hold dear.
The reason I support P.N.T.R. -- not with a completely clear conscience, but because the alternatives seem so much worse -- is that I remember what the world was like a couple of decades ago. Back then, the tide seemed to be running against everything we stand for; khaki-clad dictators, who ruled their nations' economies as well as everything else with an iron hand, seemed to be the men of the hour. The idea that by the year 2000 Western ideas -- not just the ideology of the free market, but the principle of liberal democracy -- would have spread farther than ever before would have seemed implausible. But it happened, largely because governments in the developing world became aware of how well some countries had done by opening themselves to the world market.
After all, Deng Xiaoping didn't decide to liberalize China's economy because he was a nice guy, or a secret admirer of Adam Smith; he looked at Taiwan and South Korea and realized that their export-led, market-driven growth was delivering something Maoism never could. And post-Deng China -- for all its ham-handed repression -- has become a far freer, more open society than anyone could have imagined 25 years ago, mainly because all-out totalitarianism and a market economy don't mix. You don't have to be a disciple of Friedrich Hayek to believe that free markets and a free society have some affinity, and that the world has become more democratic over the last two decades partly because it has also become more market-oriented.
So think what a rejection of normal trading relations with China would in effect say to governments -- China's government and others -- that are still wavering in their commitment to freer economies and their willingness to accept the loss of political control that such economic liberalization usually brings. It would be as if the United States, the home of the free-market/free-society ideology, were to say "Sorry; markets and democracy work for us, but we aren't letting any more countries into our club."
Of course, the opponents of normal trade relations insist that they don't mean to convey any such message. Of course, they assure us, the door remains open to countries with sufficiently democratic regimes and with adequate labor protection. Give us a decent government in China, they say, one that lets labor unions organize, and we'll open up the door. But few people in the developing world -- or for that matter in Washington -- think that such assurances are sincere; they believe that anything short of political perfection will be used as an excuse to block exports, that any labor protection that does not price developing countries out of world markets will be deemed inadequate.
So the opponents of normal trade relations with China are right -- it's an issue whose symbolic importance is much larger than its direct economic implications. But that symbolism is a reason to vote for normalization, not against it.

HEADLINE: Profits Posted By Wal-Mart Beat Forecasts

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BENTONVILLE, Ark., May 9

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said today that its fiscal first-quarter profit rose 19 percent and that earnings this quarter would be near the highest Wall Street forecasts.
Net income in the quarter that ended on April 30 rose to $1.33 billion, or 30 cents a share, from profit from operations of $1.11 billion, or 25 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 24 percent, to $43 billion, as international sales more than doubled. 
 Sales at United States stores open at least a year, a key indicator for retailers, rose 9.1 percent in the first quarter, and Wal-Mart said it did not expect consumer spending to slow.
First-quarter profits were a penny higher than the 29-cent average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks earnings.
In the corresponding quarter a year earlier, a charge of $198 million, or 4 cents a share, for an accounting change, resulted in net income of $916 million, or 21 cents.
"Wal-Mart is a good, solid growth company that could gain a lot of attention in an uncertain market," said Dan Eagan, manager of BlackRock Inc.'s Select Equity Portfolio, which held 868,900 shares as of September.
The company's shares have tumbled about 25 percent from a high of $70.25 in December on concern that five increases in interest rates by the Federal Reserve since June, higher oil prices and rising inflation would crimp consumer spending in the second half. Its shares rose $1.125, to $53.4375 in midafternoon trading.
Wal-Mart is expected to earn 33 cents to 36 cents in its fiscal second quarter, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. In the period a year earlier, it had profit from operations of 31 cents a share.
"Looking ahead, I believe Wal-Mart's going to be a riskier proposition," Bob Buchanan, an A. G. Edwards & Sons analyst, said on Monday, after he cut his rating on the stock to "maintain position" from "accumulate."

HEADLINE: Bethlehem Journal;
For Palestinians, O Little Town of Business Plans

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, West Bank, May 6

 BODY:
With scores of pinstriped businessmen milling about the hotel ballroom, it looked like any other shareholders meeting.
Auditors from Arthur Andersen hovered in the background, while stockholders called brokers on mobile phones and scrutinized the figures in the glossy annual report. 
 But when the meeting was called to order, the first piece of business was a song. A sheet of lyrics in Arabic was distributed for the few who did not already know the words. Everyone rose, and with swelling emotion sang every verse of "My Homeland," the unofficial Palestinian national anthem.
"This is our first annual meeting on Palestinian soil, and I tell you it is giving me goose bumps," Munib Masri, the dapper chairman of the Palestinian Development and Investment Company, or Padico, the fastest-growing Palestinian business conglomerate, whispered before the assembly began.
The hotel ballroom opened onto the elegantly reconstructed rear plaza of an Ottoman merchant's villa, which in its century-long life has also served as a school, a hospital, and a tear-gassed battleground between Israeli forces and rock-throwing Palestinian youths. The building, long known to Bethlehemites as the Jasir Palace, has been transformed by Padico into an Intercontinental hotel, the first five-star hotel owned and operated by Palestinians on Palestinian-governed territory.
"This hotel is not just for this company, but for all of our people," Ahmed Qurei, the former Palestine Liberation Organization guerrilla leader better known as Abu Ala, proclaimed to the Padico stockholders. Now the speaker of the Palestinian Legislative Council and one of Yasir Arafat's closest confidants, Mr. Qurei joined the board members on the dais and praised Padico for "imposing its private sector style on the development of Palestine."
Evidence of the company's endeavors was everywhere around him. The ubiquitous cell phones operated on a network run by Paltel, a private telecommunications monopoly that is 25 percent owned by Padico. The investors assembled in their new hotel were a cross-section of the emerging Palestinian business elite, some of whom had traveled from Jordan, the United States and the Persian Gulf. (Padico's biggest stockholder, Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, the Saudi mega-billonaire, who did not show up, is one of the few non-Palestinians.) They have made Padico and Paltel the largest companies on the nascent Palestinian stock exchange -- which itself is one of Padico's several subsidiaries.
This was perhaps not the Palestine of the future envisioned by either critics or champions of the P.L.O. when the Palestinian National Authority came into being six years ago. But in what Mr. Masri proudly described to shareholders as "a partnership" with Mr. Arafat's state-in-waiting, he and his colleagues have turned the autonomous Palestinian territory into the most privatized economy in the Middle East. The phone company, the airline, the new power company, the banking and insurance industry -- all are privately owned, and most have some connection to Padico.
Despite flat profits, it was been a good year for Padico. Share prices climbed steadily after a stock split. The number of shareholders doubled, to 1,700. New enterprises got under way, ranging from housing projects to factories to a Gaza Strip power plant. But when executives reported on those ventures they stressed not profits and losses but their contribution to the creation of a Palestinian state. And while shareholders quizzed board members on what they saw as the peculiarities of Padico's dividends policy, discussions dealt as much with politics and national aspirations as with finances.
Mr. Qurei particularly congratulated Padico on its expanding network of industrial parks, noting that they have been built as close as possible to the green line -- the boundary between Israel and the then-Jordanian West Bank before the 1967 war. "Putting industrial zones on the borders of the green line creates political and economic facts," he said.
The Bethlehem Intercontinental, just minutes from Israeli West Jerusalem, is the company's latest showcase. Previous stockholder meetings were held in Amman, Jordan -- in part because of Israeli visa difficulties for some Palestinian investors, and in part because the company did not believe that it had an adequate local site. This was the first chance to show off the new hotel to investors.
Inside the cool interior plaza, with a new fountain burbling beneath ancient shade trees and waiters serving Middle Eastern sweets, the memory of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule seemed almost impossibly distant. But immediately behind the hotel -- within full view of its $200-a-night rooms -- are the rutted roads and ramshackle dwellings of the Ayda refugee camp, long a locus of Palestinian unrest. Just down the street is Rachel's Tomb, a Jewish pilgrimage site heavily guarded by Israeli soldiers in one of their few remaining enclaves in Palestinian-ruled Bethlehem.
This combustible combination still occasionally erupts into confrontation, sending wafts of pepper spray past the Jasir Palace's sand-blasted stone facade.
The classic third-world contrast of a deluxe hotel abutting an impoverished neighborhood seems not to faze local residents, for whom the project provided construction jobs, or the Palestinian leadership, who laud it as a symbol of national achievement. A bit behind schedule -- Mr. Arafat once hoped to be host to the pope here -- the partly opened hotel was the scene of a reception last month for Jiang Zemin, the president of China. "This creates a good impression for Palestine among world leaders," Mr. Qurei said.
The company's next luxury hotel project is a beachfront resort in the Gaza Strip, not normally thought of as a tourist destination. As in Bethlehem, the hotel will rise next to a United Nations-administered Palestinian refugee camp.
"I hope to welcome you all there in two years," Mr. Masri told his shareholders.

HEADLINE: Official Defends Call for Breakup of Microsoft

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
Responding to Microsoft's public criticisms of the plan to break it in two, the assistant attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division said today that the actual result would be "exciting new products, with more choices and lower prices for consumers."
The official, Joel I. Klein, added that Microsoft's key argument "is wrong as a matter of fact, and wrong as a matter of history as well." He was speaking at a forum on the new economy at the University of California at Berkeley. 
 Late last month, the Justice Department and 17 state attorneys general asked a federal judge to break Microsoft into two companies. One would hold the Windows operating system, the other everything else, including the Office suite of application programs like Word and Excel.
Over the last 10 days, Microsoft has responded publicly with blistering criticism of the plan. On Wednesday, its legal response is due in federal court.
Microsoft has asserted, among other things, that the integration of its operating system and applications software divisions into one company produces efficiencies that bring innovation. Mr. Klein said that argument "is wrong as a matter of fact, since the two companies would be free to exchange technical information, as long as that information was made available to third parties."
He added that Microsoft "has long claimed that it provided third-party applications developers all the information about its operating system that those developers could need" to write software programs for Windows. If that is true, he said, "there is no real loss of efficiency in the reorganization."
Mr. Klein also said that opponents of the breakup of AT&T in 1984 "made the very same claim, arguing that the divestiture would imperil the efficiency of the telephone network." He said "that argument has failed the test of time."
Elaborating on the AT&T comparison, Mr. Klein disputed another Microsoft argument: that it was not the breakup that freed AT&T to compete, but the order to deregulate it.
But Mr. Klein noted that AT&T and the Baby Bells were left with restrictions prohibiting them from entering one another's markets. Under the plan to break up Microsoft, he said, "the separated companies would be entirely free to compete with each other in all lines of business."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Drop Amid Concerns About Technology Issues

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks dropped yesterday on continued concern that technology issues were overvalued and on fears about the impact on earnings growth of an expected increase in interest rates next week.
Volume remained light, and analysts warned against making too much of Wall Street's moves before the Federal Reserve decides whether and by how much it will raise borrowing costs at a meeting next Tuesday as it seeks to head off the threat of accelerating inflation. 
 The Nasdaq composite index dropped 84.37 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,585.01, after dropping 147 points, or 3.86 percent, on Monday.
Technology stocks rolled back nearly across the board, also dragging the Dow Jones industrial average lower. It closed down 66.88 points, or 0.6 percent, at 10,536.75. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 12.03 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,412.14.
Investors also were on the sidelines ahead of economic data expected at the end of the week and quarterly earnings reports from Cisco Systems, which was released after the market closed, and from Applied Materials and Dell Computer, which will be released later in the week, traders said.
"There are valuation concerns, which was brought on by Cisco, the granddaddy of all valuation concerns," said Barry Hyman, market strategist at Ehrenkrantz, King Nussbaum Inc.
Cisco failed to recover from its decline of more than 7 percent on Monday, ending unchanged at 62 3/4. Last weekend, the financial weekly Barron's published a report questioning whether the network equipment company's large market capitalization was warranted.
Among the technology stocks to slip most was the online auctioneer eBay, which dropped 7 5/16, to 12 13/16.
Banks and other financial issues contributed to the weakness amid concern that rising interest rates would cut into loan demand. American Express dropped 4 1/16, to 148, and Citigroup slipped 7/8, to 59 5/16.
"There is no appetite for stocks right now; we are just kind of drifting," said Larry Wachtel of Prudential Securities.
Analysts said Wall Street was in a defensive mode, preparing for what could be a full-scale assault on inflation by the Fed. Many strategists and economists now expect the central bank to raise interest rates by half a percentage point next week.
"Investors are marking time in front of the meeting," said Mike Feeney, an editor at the independent research firm Wall Street Strategies. "It seems that the wisdom on the Street is that a 50-basis-point hike is a lock." A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
The menu of economic data was light early this week, with more key figures on retail sales and inflation pressure at the wholesale level due out on tomorrow and Friday.
But several Fed officials spoke yesterday. In one speech, Robert Parry, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said he saw inflation threats from strong domestic demand and a tight labor market, and Fed inaction on those threats would be risky.
Edward Gramlich, a Federal Reserve governor, said the central bank was not trying to influence stock market levels.
"We're not explicitly targeting for any set of stock market values," Mr. Gramlich told a group of accountants. "Most of us think that we're managing the whole economy and we're trying to target inflation, unemployment. Period."

Treasuries Post Gains
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices rose yesterday as yields at three-month highs lured investors who seemed confident the Federal Reserve would slow growth and curb inflation.
The yield on the most actively traded 10-year note dropped to 6.52 percent from 6.56 percent on Monday. The bond's price, which moves in the opposite direction from the yield, rose 8/32, to 99 27/32.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 15/32, to 100 19/32. The bond's yield fell to 6.21 percent from 6.24 percent on Monday.
The five-year note rose after the Treasury sold $12 billion of the security at a yield of 6.789 percent, above the 6.772 percent expected by bond dealers before the bidding deadline. The bid-to-cover ratio, a gauge of demand, was 1.98 times the amount of notes sold, above that of the last seven sales.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
The World Bank gauges the toll travel takes on employees and looks for ways to soften the effect.

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey; Business Travel appears each Wednesday. Joe Sharkey's e-mail address is jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
MY husband missed our son's high school graduation due to business travel. None of us has ever forgotten."
A lot of words were spoken at the World Bank's two-day symposium late last month Stress, the Business Traveler and Corporate Health in Washington. But those two declarative sentences, among the many responses elicited by World Bank managers who surveyed traveling staff members and their spouses, packed real wallop. "None of us has ever forgotten." 
 Corporate America, which often prides itself on the supposed invincibility of the legions of men and women it dispatches around the world, could learn a few things about employee health and welfare from the World Bank. The last two years, the bank has sponsored seminars intended to make employers think more responsibly about the effect ever-increasing travel has on employees and on the people closest to them.
The World Bank, an international organization based in Washington, sends nearly 5,000 employees on international business trips each year, for a total of more than 250,000 days away from home. In 1997, the World Bank sponsored a detailed clinical study that discovered that significantly higher rates of health insurance claims were filed by employees who traveled compared with those who did not. Even more remarkable, frequent travelers, who typically regard themselves as tough and resilient, also account for three times the claims for treatment of stress, anxiety, depression and other psychological-adjustment disorders attributable directly to the demands of being on the road.
This year, prompted by that 1997 study, the bank convened health professionals and managers from 50 corporate and government organizations to discuss follow-up research that was commissioned to examine more closely the psychological impact of frequent business travel.
"We asked our colleagues what's going on?" said Bernhard H. Liese, a senior health adviser and the former medical director of the bank.
The answer that came back, Dr. Liese said, was that adverse effects from travel were "mirrored in the family" as well as in the workplace.
The 1997 clinical study compared health insurance claims filed by 4,700 World Bank managers and professional workers who had taken international business trips with claims filed by 6,000 World Bank employees who did not travel. Across the board, the survey showed a strong correlation between frequency of travel and higher reports of respiratory infections, gastrointestinal distress, skin disorders and back pain -- all understandable, if somewhat surprising, consequences of heavy travel to a wide variety of places.
But the survey's findings of far higher rates of treatment for psychological disorders were especially startling, Dr. Liese said. That is because only about a third of the World Bank's employees in Washington are from North America. The rest come from countries where there is far greater reluctance "to seek treatment from a psychologist," he said.
The follow-up survey on the risks of that psychological stress was by the same team of clinical researchers, which reported: "As international business travel grows, increasing numbers of travelers will be exposed to health risks, including widely varying physical and psychological stressors." In the their report, published in the scientific journal Occupational and Environmental Medicine, they added that "business travel is a unique challenge to the health of employees, which to date has not been studied extensively."
High on the list of emotional stresses for heavy business travelers is worry about personal and family lives, including adjustment problems suffered by spouses and children of an employee who is often away from home. Anxiety about the workload piling up back at the office also ranked high on the stress list.
Typically, the researchers said, traveling employees are disinclined to take time off to rest from a tiring business trip. "Although most respondents think it is necessary, very few of them reported that they actually take rest days after business travel," the study said.
Of course, some corporations and bosses pride themselves on instilling a gung-ho workplace culture that presses worn-out corporate travelers to hit the road on demand and show up at the office bright and early on return, no matter where they flew in from the night before.
"Two-thirds of all respondents reported that their managers rarely or never formally grant" a day off after a long trip, reflecting a perceived lack of sanction for taking rest.
Participants at the symposium heard a lot of practical advice on making life easier on traveling employees: train managers to be aware that changing travel dates at the last minute can adversely affect people's lives; be more flexible in allowing travelers to make their own arrangements and to exercise more control over their lives when they are on the road; compensate traveling employees for their weekends; let them call home daily on the company's nickel.
But the most resonant message came from Dr. Liese, who said more attention must be paid to "corporate responsibilities" in employee travel, an area that lies beyond the reach of any governmental workplace or health-and-safety regulator.
Corporations should be accountable, Dr. Liese said, "to their most valuable resource -- their staff."
