HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: Breaking Out of the Back Room;
Chief Information Officers Get New Respect and Power

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
For years, H. John Lochow felt as though the word "techie" were practically branded on his forehead. As a computer systems manager at the AT&T Capital Corporation and at the CNA Insurance Companies, and later as the chief information officer for a succession of corporations, he says he was never allowed to run other departments, let alone serve on high-level management teams at these firms.
For him, things have turned out well. But Mr. Lochow's lurch up the corporate ladder is not an isolated case. In corporate America, an increasing number of chief information officers -- basically, they are the folks in charge of the computers -- are amassing greater power as top bosses and company boards realize how crucial technical expertise is in staying ahead of the competition. 
 Mr. Lochow (pronounced LUCK-oh) got his chance to break loose from the techie label last year. Opportunity called in the form of a mini-crisis at his current employer, the Tech Data Corporation in Clearwater, Fla., a giant computer distributor that was growing so fast it could not hire enough people to keep up with orders. Its warehouses were bulging with products that could not be shipped.
Mr. Lochow, whose main responsibility as C.I.O. until then had been to maintain the smooth functioning of the company's computers in 35 countries, believed he was the man to break the logjam. So he asked Tech Data's chief executive, Steven A. Raymund, to put him in charge of the company's supply division. After all, he told Mr. Raymund, he had already turned around the information technology operations to make them more efficient, and at no additional cost to the company.
He got the assignment and threw himself into it with tasks like picking apart and mapping every process that Tech Data used in its warehouses to receive and ship its products.
He emerged a hero: within three months, Tech Data had almost doubled its shipments and had trimmed inventory. Now Mr. Lockow reports directly to Mr. Raymund, and earlier this year he was given responsibility for managing yet another department, the one that assembles the company's products.
Mr. Lochow clearly savors his new role at Tech Data. "Now my responsibilities cross many lines of business," he said. "Before, I felt like I was up against a glass ceiling."
A recent survey by Egon Zehnder International, an executive search firm, found that companies are increasingly looking to a new generation of chief information officers to be business strategists, and that these "new" C.I.O.'s spend at least half their time outside the information-technology department on efforts like developing and incubating new prospects for electronic commerce.
The survey found that 15 percent of new chief information officers now serve on the boards of their companies and 70 percent are on their companies' high-level management teams. Those numbers are up sharply from a decade ago, industry specialists say, when 0 percent and 10 percent would have been more likely figures.
The information officers are reveling in their elevation from back-room tinkerers with fancy titles to strategic thinkers on an equal footing with corporate presidents, chief operating officers and chief financial officers.
"We're in the third generation of C.I.O. now," Mr. Lochow said. "The first generation was made up of techies, like data center directors. And although the second generation was more vocal in terms of becoming part of corporate planning, its members were still one level below directly reporting to their chief executives. Now, however, thanks to the Internet, C.I.O.'s are moving directly into corporate decision-making."
Executive recruiters say the trend is the inevitable fallout of the Internet revolution, which has recast the dynamics of the marketplace of almost every industry overnight and forced companies to react with equal speed or face extinction.
"It used to be that companies would say, 'Find us a C.I.O. who will take care of our computer systems,' " said S. Ross Brown, the director of the high-technology and telecommunications recruiting practice at Egon Zehnder. "But now they're calling to say, 'We need a C.I.O. who can help us define our whole way of doing business.' "
Those new responsibilities require new duties, of course, including spending more time with both the corporate brass and customers.
Cecilia Claudio, the chief information officer at the Farmers Group, the Zurich Financial Services subsidiary based in Los Angeles, says her new travel schedule takes some getting used to. In March, Ms. Claudio spent three days crisscrossing Indiana to meet with more than 60 sales agents, something that chief information officers like her would never have done five years ago.
"People don't look to me as just being a C.I.O.," she said. "I'm expected to bring wisdom, to understand all aspects of our business, as well as not work in isolation."
Before Ms. Claudio joined Farmers two years ago, she said, her job at a former employer was focused entirely on the information systems. But now she is asked almost daily for her views on questions like whether to increase the company's sales staff and how to sell multiple products to existing customers.
Because technology now touches every corner of almost every company's business, Ms. Claudio said, chief information officers are probably better prepared than other top managers to assume new responsibilities -- including the mantle of chief executive. "I know of quite a few situations where this has already happened," she said.
Patrick J. Zilvitis, the chief information officer of the Gillette Company, says his expertise is sought out because technology touches every aspect of Gillette's operations, even product design. "I tend to be involved in change management in everything I do," Mr. Zilvitis said.
It is not as though C.I.O.'s are on an unstoppable march to the top at every corporation in America, of course. One school of thought is of the opinion, in fact, that as a group they retain a detail-oriented mentality that can miss the big picture.
Paul Bernard, who founded his own consulting firm in Manhattan, for example, says that for all the changes wrought by the Internet, too many chief information officers continue to "worship" technology, while all but ignoring both the strategic and the customer-service aspects of their jobs.
"The issue for C.I.O.'s and their staffers is that no one has articulated to them how much their jobs have changed," he said.
Some do grasp those changes, of course, and are leveraging their new stature to shop themselves around.
Chris Hjelm left his job as chief information officer at Federal Express in January to become chief operating officer at the Zoho Corporation, an Internet vendor in Sunnyvale, Calif., that caters to hotels and casinos.
After 14 years at Federal Express, Mr. Hjelm said, he had become tired of endlessly reinventing the giant company's computer systems and yearned for a more expansive role.
"I was ready to try something different, as well as be a part of the Internet economy," he said. "Now, I'm creating something new, as well as an entire business model in an industry that's ripe for it. That's why a lot of chief information officers like me are leaving."

HEADLINE: Coke to Advertise on Channel Owned by Lawyer in Bias Suit

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Adding a new twist to the already complicated racial discrimination lawsuit brought against Coca-Cola by a group of its black employees, Coke said yesterday that it was becoming a major advertiser on a cable channel owned by a Florida lawyer who last month began representing four of the plaintiffs.
Coke signed a five-year agreement with the Atlanta-based channel, MBC Network, which plans to broadcast children's shows, movies, cartoons and sports programs specifically for black families 24 hours a day, according to a statement from MBC. 
 The channel, owned by Willie D. Gary, was formed in 1998. It is backed by Evander Holyfield, the boxer; Marlon D. Jackson, one of the original Jackson Five; Cecil Fielder, formerly of the Detroit Tigers; and Alvin D. James, a longtime broadcaster, as well as Mr. Gary.
Coke's name will appear on print and electronic announcements connected with the channel, which will advertise all Coke brands, according to the statement.
Mr. Gary represents four of the named plaintiffs in the lawsuit against Coca-Cola, which was filed 13 months ago and contends that the plaintiffs were denied promotions, raises and other advancement at the company because of their race.
The deal with Coke could raise questions about a conflict of interest between Mr. Gary's role in the lawsuit and Coke's support of his business venture. Mr. Gary could not be reached last night for comment.
Cyrus Mehri, the lawyer who originally represented the four and continues to represent four other current and former Coke employees in the lawsuit, said the arrangement "is an issue between Mr. Gary and the four individuals he represents."
"My team's focus is on fighting for the best possible resolution for the class," Mr. Mehri added.
A Coke spokesman said the company's discussions and final negotiations occurred before Mr. Gary announced his intention to get involved in the lawsuit, which is seeking class-action status for as many as 2,000 Coke employees,
"We're making the ad buy because it gives us an opportunity to support what we believe is some very meaningful programming and connect our advertising with African-American consumers on a frequent and consistent basis," said the spokesman, Ben Deutsch.
Mr. Gary, who is best known for obtaining a $500 million award in a 1995 case against the Loewen funeral home company, was introduced to Coke's former chairman, M. Douglas Ivester, by the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Mr. Gary is Mr. Jackson's lawyer. The Loewen award was eventually settled at $175 million.
Coke and the employees named in the lawsuit began court-ordered mediation last month.

HEADLINE: South Carolina House Debates Options for Moving Rebel Flag

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., May 9

 BODY:
On the tense opening day of what may be the final debate over flying the Confederate battle flag on the Statehouse dome, an all-white majority of the South Carolina House of Representatives appeared to be willing to accept a compromise that would move the flag to a Confederate monument in front of the Capitol.
The final vote on the proposal, which passed the State Senate last month, will probably come on Wednesday. But in a preliminary vote, 72 of the 120 House members accepted an amendment that would move a smaller version of the flag on July 1 to a pole in front of the Capitol's main entrance. Supporters of the flag, all but 11 of whom were white Republicans, succeeded in passing the amendment, which would make the flag more prominent, raising the size of the pole to 30 feet from the 20 feet proposed by the Senate. Another amendment passed today provides for illuminating it at night. 
 But in a sign of the body's deep racial divisions, none of the House's 26 black members supported the amendments. Many black members already opposed the Senate's proposal, saying that it kept the Confederate flag in a position of prominence, and were even more vehemently against the idea of making the flagpole taller and lighting it up. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which is conducting an economic boycott of the state, also opposes the plan to move the flag to the Confederate Soldier's monument.
Black members, joined by many white Democrats, did support two plans that were voted down by the majority: one to put a bronze relief of the flag on a granite slab near the monument, and the other to fly the flag on an "avenue of flags" adjacent to the Capitol along with other flags that have flown over South Carolina.
White supporters denounced the bronze-relief plan as an "insult" to their heritage, and mustered the votes to defeat it, 65 to 43.
"The Civil War was a big part of the history of the state, not a small part, but huge," said Representative William F. Cotty, a Republican from Columbia. "But this tombstone monument type of bill, you might as well lower it down and give it perpetual care. You're saying, 'Bury that baby, get rid of it.' " About 40 white members were opposed to moving the flag at all, and one member, Representative John Milton Knotts Jr. of West Columbia, said he would prefer that the Confederate flag fly above the United States and South Carolina flags.
Black legislators, all of whom are Democrats, said it was clear that the Republican leadership of the House was doing everything possible to make the flag extremely prominent once it came down from the dome, making the entire exercise of moving it essentially meaningless. They said that putting a symbol of slavery at the entrance to the Capitol was nearly as offensive as flying it on high.
"They voted down every suggestion we made to put it in historical context, and they're just trying to ram it down our throats," said Representative J. Todd Rutherford of Columbia. "If they try to pass this without any of our votes tomorrow, it will once again be a case of the great white fathers knowing what's best for the African-Americans of this state."
Speaker David H. Wilkins, a Republican, said it appeared that the House was moving toward the 30-foot-flagpole provision, which he supported. But Mr. Wilkins said Republicans in the House would not bear all the weight of moving the flag; they will not support it in a final vote if Democrats, and particularly black members, remain opposed, he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Behind Painting Sold Online Was a Partly False Story
The man who sold a painting on the Internet for $135,805 acknowledged that he concocted part of the story he used to describe the work, which bore the initials "R.D.," creating speculation that it was painted by the California artist Richard Diebenkorn.
Far from being a married homeowner who cleaned the painting out of his garage, the man is a single lawyer who has sold paintings on eBay before. But he said that he did not fake the painting or add the signature and that he would cancel the sale if experts determine that the canvas is not by Diebenkorn. Page A1. 

Striving to Make Copyrights Moot
While courts struggle over the recording industry's challenge to digital music-swapping, software is being written that could make it impossible to control the traffic in any kind of digital information -- whether it is music, video, text or software. A1.
 
Bestfoods Hints Deal Is Possible
When Bestfoods rejected a takeover offer from Unilever last week, it seemed emphatic. But over the last few days, senior executives at Bestfoods have talked with the company's largest investors, discussing their reasons for turning down the $18.4 billion offer, saying that Unilever has underestimated the savings of such a deal. The executives' position hints that Bestfoods would consider a merger at the right price, analysts said. Shares of Bestfoods fell $1, to $63.50. C2.
 
Profit and Revenue Rise at Cisco
Cisco Systems said that its third-quarter profit beat expectations while it posted a 55 percent gain in sales as the leading supplier of hardware for the Internet. C2.
 
Stocks Slide on Rate Concerns
Stocks dropped on fears about the effect of an expected increase in interest rates. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 84.37 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,585.01. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 66.88 points, to 10,536.75, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 12.03 points, to 1,412.14. C10.
 
No Phone Offer Seen in Hong Kong
Singapore Telecommunications probably will not make a rival bid for Hong Kong's flagship telephone company, Cable and Wireless HKT, executives close to the company said. They said Singapore Telecom was balking at the price it would have to pay. C4.
 
Janus to Close Three of Its Funds
Under an onslaught of money from investors, the Janus mutual fund group said that it would close three funds: the $42 billion Janus Worldwide, the Janus Olympus Fund and the Janus Global Life Sciences Fund. C2.
 
Journey From Boredom to Bossdom
As preparation for the executive suite, it may be hard to beat the combination of boredom and curiosity. Sunny Vanderbeck, the head of Data Return, which runs business software on the Web, recalls experiences that began as intense curiosity or efforts to relieve boredom. Probably nothing prepared him better for what he does now, he says, than training as an Airborne Ranger. The Boss. C6.
 
NTT DoCoMo to Buy Dutch Stake
NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile phone company, agreed to acquire a 15 percent stake in the Dutch mobile phone operator KPN Mobile for about $4.5 billion. C4.
 
Coke in Deal With Lawyer's Channel
Coca-Cola said that it was becoming a major advertiser on a cable channel owned by a Florida lawyer who represents four of the plaintiffs in a racial discrimination suit brought by the company's black employees. C10.
 
Th Psychological Toll of Traveling
Research by the World Bank has shown that not only can extensive business travel take a physical toll, being on the road can also take a psychological toll on workers and their families. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C8.

HEADLINE: PATAKI PROPOSES A FISCAL BAILOUT OF NASSAU COUNTY

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, N.Y., May 9

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki went to Nassau County today offering a $100 million state bailout to help one of the nation's wealthiest counties avert financial ruin.
In return, the debt-ridden county has to allow the state to monitor its finances and future budgets and agree to make large spending cuts over the next four years. 
 If the county fails to make the required spending cuts -- $50 million this year and an additional $70 million in each of the next three years -- the state will withhold the aid and impose a more powerful financial control board with the power to tell the county what cuts to make and even to abrogate civil service contracts.
"It is a carrot and stick," Governor Pataki said as he announced the plan, which he said could restore the county to fiscal stability without raising taxes. His proposal requires the approval of county officials and the State Legislature; leaders of both parties on both levels of government reacted favorably to the plan today and said they expected it to pass.
The governor took the extraordinary steps of intervening in the affairs of a local government -- and of pledging millions in state aid to the wealthy county -- after years of unbalanced budgeting left Nassau County running out of money during one of the longest periods of economic prosperity in the nation's history.
The plan would include $100 million in state aid spread out over five years and would set up a financial authority with the ability to sell new bonds, guaranteed by the county's sales tax revenue. That would allow Nassau County to borrow money at a lower interest rate than the county, whose bonds are hovering just above junk status, can now get on its own. The arrangement is intended to buy the county time while it makes severe, long-term spending cuts.
In announcing his fiscal recovery plan, the governor said that he wanted to ensure that a county of vital economic importance to the state did not go bankrupt. Credit rating agencies have already threatened to reduce the county's bond rating to junk status if it does not put a financial plan in place by June 30.
Wall Street reacted guardedly. "This gives them more time, but it highlights the necessity to come up with real, ongoing changes in the fiscal operation of the county," said Steven Murphy, a managing director at Standard & Poor's, the credit rating agency.
But the governor's actions have a political impact as well: the fiscal crisis already led Nassau County, long one of the state's most solid Republican bastions, to elect a Democratic majority to its County Legislature in November. And Republicans fear that continuing anger over the county's finances could mean more losses this November in races for the State Legislature, the United States Senate and the presidency.
The plan that was announced today has been in the works since March, when Governor Pataki appointed Frank G. Zarb, the chairman of the group that runs the Nasdaq stock exchange, as his special adviser on Nassau County. Mr. Zarb found that the county's 2000 budget of $2.2 billion was $178 million short, and that if no action were taken the deficit would balloon to $233 million next year and $321 million by 2003.
Mr. Zarb painted a grim portrait of Nassau's fiscal practices, noting that the county had become increasingly dependent on selling off its assets and borrowing money through bonds to meet its expenses, which have grown drastically as its spending far outpaced the rate of inflation. The county is now $2.7 billion in debt; Mr. Zarb found that the county spent roughly one out of every five dollars servicing its debt.
And he noted that Nassau's antiquated property tax system -- the county has already agreed to overhaul it -- had forced it to borrow $800 million to pay refunds to people who successfully challenged their taxes, and to pay interest on that money.
To put the county back on its feet, the governor proposed the creation of the Nassau Interim Finance Authority, which would sell new bonds backed by the county's sales tax at a lower cost to the county and refinance the county's existing debt so that it could be paid back in smaller installments over a longer time.
In return, the authority would have the power to monitor the county's finances.
If the county met its obligations, it would get $100 million in state aid over the next five years, and the state would give the county an additional $5 million to hire lawyers and assessors to help the county reduce its backlog of tax refund claims.
But if the county failed to immediately cut $50 million in spending and adopt a balanced four-year financial plan, the state would appoint a control board with the power to tell the county what cuts to make.
Just where the county's cuts would come from -- $260 million over four years -- was far from clear. In recent days Democrats and Republicans have met to discuss possible cuts, including $10 million to the county's Police Department, reductions of county contracts, the abolition of one county agency and the mergers of others.
Such plans are unusual. Noting how rare it is for a state to bail out a foundering local government, David Liebschutz, an adjunct professor at Rockefeller College at the State University at Albany, invoked the other famous case of a wealthy suburb in distress: Orange County, Calif., which went bankrupt in 1994 after losing $2 billion on bad investments. "They asked for help and the state basically said to them, 'Tough, you work it out, you have the resources,' " he said. "That tends to be the approach."
New York State came to the rescue of New York City in 1975, Yonkers in 1975 and 1984, and Troy in 1994. But the scale of the assistance proposed for Nassau County is unusual, and it is even rarer for the state to establish a fiscal monitor and create a new agency to help the county borrow money.
Mr. Pataki's plan was generally welcomed today by the Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, and both Democrats and Republicans on the County Legislature.
Nassau County Democrats have called for a fiscal monitor for more than a year, even after they won control of the County Legislature in November. This year, at their urging, the Democratic-controlled State Assembly passed a bill that would have created a fiscal monitor with powers similar to the finance authority the governor proposed today.
Judith A. Jacobs, a Democrat who is the presiding officer of the County Legislature, said that while she would still need to see more details of the plan, she approved of its broad outlines and expected it to pass.
"It gives us good outside help putting Nassau County back on sure footing, but it doesn't remove from us the responsibilities of good government," she said of the proposal.
Peter J. Schmitt, the Republican leader, said unequivocally that his caucus would support the plan. And Mr. Gulotta, the county executive, said that if he were given one word to describe the plan, the word would be "perfect."
Once the County Legislature and the executive formally ask the state to adopt a proposal, the plan will go to Albany for approval.
Sheldon Silver, a Democrat who is the Assembly speaker, said he was favorably disposed to the plan, noting its similarities to a bill calling for oversight that the Assembly had already passed. And he said that while the prospect of giving $100 million to a wealthy county might raise eyebrows, he thought it could be worked out.
"Obviously, there are other parts of the state that are in need of assistance as well," he said, "but we pull together for people who are in need."
State Senator Dean Skelos, the deputy leader of the Republican majority, praised the plan as well.
Privately, some county leaders wondered where they would find $260 million in recurring spending cuts over the next four years.

HEADLINE: Montana Town Grapples With Asbestos Ills

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: LIBBY, Mont.

 BODY:
When W. R. Grace & Company sold them the 21-acre site along the Kootenai River seven years ago, Mel and Lerah Parker were ecstatic. They finally had a tract large enough to build new quarters for their thriving nursery business and a new home.
Now, the business is closed, and bulldozers will soon raze everything on the land, forcing the Parkers to find a new place to live and work. In recent months, tests have revealed that their property is contaminated by a toxic form of asbestos called tremolite, the result of years in which Grace used the site as a transport center for the vermiculite ore the company mined nearby. 
 Tremolite, a microscopic fiber that causes lung disease and several forms of cancer, occurs naturally in vermiculite, which is used in insulation and dozens of other products.
"Katie, my 7-year-old granddaughter, is asking me if I'm going to die," Mrs. Parker said, sobbing. "Why should children that age be thinking about things like that?"
The Parkers knew of lawsuits linking the mining operations to illness. But Mrs. Parker said no one from Grace ever told them that ore dust -- all over the property when they bought it -- posed any lingering health threat from asbestos.
As a result, the Parkers are among a growing list of Libby residents reeling from the medical, psychological and financial consequences of the mining operation, which over its 67 years provided desperately needed high-paying jobs here in the vast stretches of northwest Montana.
Though Grace shut it down in 1990, the mine is being blamed for scores of cases of respiratory illness and death from exposure to the tremolite. The problems in Libby, a town of 2,700, represent the "most significant single source of asbestos exposure" in the nation's history, said Paul Peronard, a coordinator for the Environmental Protection Agency.
The area contaminated by the mining operation is now the agency's first priority for cleanup, which will probably take six months and cost $3 million, Mr. Peronard said. Who will pay for the cleanup is still in dispute, but the agency said it would proceed while negotiating with Grace.
In the last 15 years, scores of local residents, armed with medical opinions linking their relatives' deaths to asbestos exposure from mining, have filed lawsuits against Grace, charging negligence and deceit.
Without acknowledging any deliberate wrongdoing, Grace has settled dozens of cases out of court, largely to avoid expensive litigation, company lawyers said; other cases are still pending. Meanwhile, the company has also offered medical coverage for people who were exposed.
Aside from exacting a human toll, the mining operation has raised questions for people here concerning how much Grace knew about the dangers of asbestos and whether state supervision was too lax.
The story has also caused deep divisions in Libby. Some residents welcome the recent publicity and governmental attention, but others fear they are the new millennium's version of the 1970's environmental disaster in the Love Canal neighborhood of Niagara Falls, N.Y. The story here, they say, might do irreversible damage to a town struggling to share in the nation's economic good times.
While acknowledging the problem, Grace executives said that little was known at the time about the effects of asbestos, and that as knowledge grew, they did their best to comply with the safety standards of the day.
"There is no question in my mind that if the company knew how to do it, if anybody knew how to do it, it was done," said Harry Eschenbach, the company's director of health and safety for 20 years, through 1997.
Mr. Eschenbach insisted that Grace violated no laws, provided annual chest X-rays and updated technologies in Libby. "Sure, the state would come in and tell us to do more," he said. "But do what? The technology wasn't always there. If it was, we'd have used it."
Mr. Eschenbach also denied that Grace hid anything. The workers, he said, had "a right to know the hazards to which they are exposed. I always told them, one on one and in groups of one on two or three."
For the most part, the rising incidence of illness and the ensuing legal battles have played out in relative obscurity. Then, in November, articles by The Daily Inter Lake in Kalispell, Mont., and The Seattle Post-Intelligencer brought new focus to the mining operations and caught the attention of the E.P.A. Tests of air and soil since then found several areas still contaminated by asbestos.
As a result of the review and lawsuits, a fuller picture of the operation and its effect on Libby has emerged.
For as long as the mine operated -- 40 years under the now-defunct Zonolite Company, its last 27 under Grace -- workers, as well as company and state officials, recognized illness as an occupational risk. Nor did anyone especially fear any deadly impact of asbestos in the early days.
In fact, the residue containing asbestos was so abundant and powdery that Libby children were invited to play in it. Many did. Other people took bags home to use as insulation, mulch and cat litter.
Joan Runyan, 73, a former office secretary for Grace, said she used the dust as filler in recipes for muffins and bread and ate it. "At the time, nobody made the connection to any problems," she said, adding that she suffered no ill effects.
But as the years wore on, the mine workers suffered various respiratory illnesses, and deaths from them slowly rose. By the early 1980's, doctors were seeing the same illnesses in the workers' wives and children; family members had been exposed when the miners returned home, still wearing dust-covered workclothes.
Nearly 200 deaths were attributed to asbestos exposure by lawsuits and newspaper studies of medical records and death certificates; no one disputes the figures. And more could be coming. Research shows that asbestos-caused diseases like asbestosis, a fatal scarring of the lungs, can take 30 years or more to develop.
As the pattern became clear, the first of scores of lawsuits was filed in the mid-1980's, asserting that company officials ignored warnings by state agencies to clean up the mining operations. By Grace's own count, it is now a defendant in 121 cases from people exposed in Libby. In 72 previous cases, Grace paid $15.6 million through 60 settlements and 4 jury verdicts against the company. Eight other suits were dismissed.
For Grace, a giant chemical and packaging company based in Columbia, Md., this is another unwanted environmental fight. The company was the focus of the book and film "A Civil Action," about lawsuits by eight Massachusetts families accusing it of dumping chemicals that leaked into wells and caused leukemia.
Indeed, Grace is a defendant in asbestos-related lawsuits from 105,000 plaintiffs around the country, including those in Libby. But company officials contend that Grace did nothing wrong in Libby.
Jay Hughes, a lawyer for Grace, said he believed that many of the lawsuits had been filed at the urging of personal injury lawyers. Grace, he said, offered to settle cases to avoid "the risks of a trial."
Some lawsuits, however, include as evidence extensive material -- much of it from Grace's own files -- that shows state and federal agencies warned the company often, and as early as the 1960's, that conditions at the Libby mine, the transport center and Grace's processing plant posed health hazards.
More than 15 years ago, one local doctor, Richard Irons, was so alarmed by the growth in nonoccupational cases of asbestosis that he traveled to a Grace division in Cambridge, Mass., to request money for pulmonary equipment to study the impact of the disease in Libby.
"He was told to leave it alone," said Dr. Brad Black, who was Dr. Irons's partner at the time. "They just dismissed him and did nothing."
Mr. Eschenbach, who met with Dr. Irons, said Grace had already undertaken the study he was suggesting.
Grace has pledged $250,000 a year "for the foreseeable future" for a screening program in Libby and proposed a long-term health care plan.
But local health officials, residents and their lawyers have criticized both as inadequate; many contend the health care plan enables people to qualify only after they have grown seriously ill or close to death. Dr. Black, who is trying to help establish a trust fund in Libby for asbestos victims, claimed the plan's eligibility requirements would exclude 85 percent of people who are now affected.
Nor have state and federal agencies been especially helpful to Libby, according to the lawsuits. In response to a 1983 inquiry, from Representative James A. Courter of New Jersey, an E.P.A. official, Don R. Clay, said that tests of the mine found only minor problems with asbestos and that the vermiculite industry had improved worker safety.
As a result, Mr. Clay wrote, the agency would turn its efforts against asbestos elsewhere.
Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana, a two-term Republican who grew up in Libby, said the apparent lack of oversight by governmental agencies over the years mirrored times when the country knew little of the hazards of asbestos and when workers happy to have good-paying jobs rarely complained about the inconveniences of any respiratory ailments.
For many years, Mr. Racicot said, state inspections included confidentiality agreements that no information could be made public.
Additionally, by the 1980's, a new era arrived in Washington, a pro-business, anti-regulatory attitude championed by the Reagan administration that believed government should get out of people's lives.
"For many of these people, working was more important than safety," said Mr. Racicot, who recalled playing in piles of asbestos dust as a child. "And in all the conversations I had with family and friends in Libby I've known for years, I never heard one complaint about asbestos."
That all changed in November. The E.P.A. announced a plan to test air and soil samples well into this year and found, initially, two "hot spots" -- the Parker property and the area around what was then the ore processing plant near downtown.
The agency has pledged to clean those sites first, but is also conducting tests in other states where Grace shipped vermiculite over the years.
The growing realization about the damage left by the mines has stirred anger and resentment toward Grace among many local residents. But it has also inspired sympathy for the company from residents who recall how it once made the town thrive.
Some also complain that news coverage has scared off companies that might have relocated here. "I've literally had people on the phone say to me that their doctors have told them it would be suicidal to move here," said Russell S. Barnes, president of the Lincoln County Economic Development Council.
Mr. Peronard, the E.P.A. official, said the area was generally safe. By year's end, he predicted, all remaining problem areas will be eliminated.
But legal fights will not go away. "It's depressing," said Roger Sullivan, a lawyer who has handled 150 Libby suits, "because none of these stories really has a happy ending."

SECTION: Section B; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 787 words

HEADLINE: LESSONS;
Education and the Economy

BYLINE: By Richard Rothstein 

 BODY:
UNEMPLOYMENT is now only 3.9 percent, its lowest level in 30 years. A dozen years ago the economy was in bad shape, with widespread unemployment. The United States could not seem to compete with other industrial nations.
Schools were widely blamed. The prevailing view was that high unemployment was mostly due to high school graduates who lacked the skills of German or Japanese workers. 
 Today the crisis is a dim memory, and America's economy is the world's envy. Yet schools are, at best, only marginally better, so prosperity cannot be the result of school reform. That means schools were not to blame for the nation's earlier doldrums.
If we had recognized sooner the limited role schools play in determining economic success, would we have embarked on identical reforms? Or would education policy have been less politicized, with more tolerance for experimentation?
As late as 1994, unemployment was still over 6 percent, and the dropout rate was twice that. Black and Hispanic workers were most severely affected.
At the time, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, insisted that schools were the problem. He said those without jobs lacked the skills employers need.
Most economists then feared that attempts to lower unemployment would spur inflation. President Clinton's first appointees to the Federal Reserve, Alan Blinder and Janet Yellen, supported Dr. Greenspan's tighter money policies, aimed at keeping joblessness from falling.
Their logic was this: some workers had left jobs and were seeking new ones, but would find work soon. Faster growth could not eliminate such transitions. Other workers wanting jobs were too poorly educated to be hired. Growth could not help them either, because they lacked minimum skills.
Because, the reasoning went, no adequately educated workers were left when joblessness fell to 6 percent, efforts to create new jobs would only cause companies to bid for those already employed, by offering them higher wages. Inflation, not more jobs, would follow. Unemployment could drop further only if schools improved to make graduates more attractive hires.
Today, with unemployment less than 4 percent, many formerly jobless high school dropouts have found jobs. Unemployment has plummeted, even for the most vulnerable, black teenagers.
Perhaps America has now reached a point where growth should be slowed. But it was a huge mistake to have believed that 6, not 4 percent unemployment (or less) was the target rate. Some three million Americans suffered prolonged joblessness because policy makers wrongly assumed they were too poorly schooled to work.
Economists attribute today's growth with mild inflation not to improved schools, but to factors like greater efficiency, downward price pressure from growing imports and a willingness to experiment with lower interest rates.
But Dr. Greenspan has not wavered. Before initiating the current round of interest rate increases last year, he told the Congressional Joint Economic Committee that "we fall far short" in public education. The nation cannot maintain prosperity, he said, if schools do not improve. Nobody asked why the chairman's earlier "blame the schools" approach was flawed, and whether the error was now being repeated.
A decade ago, the views of Dr. Greenspan, Dr. Blinder and Dr. Yellen were commonplace. In 1992, Prof. Lester C. Thurow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology published the best-selling book "Head to Head: The Coming Economic Battle Among Japan, America and Europe" (William Morrow). It predicted that Europe would "own the 21st century," partly because poor schools make America uncompetitive. "To create the productivity that can justify high wages," Dr. Thurow said, "American K-12 education will have to improve."
But since then, American productivity has soared, wages have recovered and America's economy has left Japan's and Europe's in the dust. It seems that today's productivity growth stems from years of accumulated innovation, and that American schools do, after all, produce a work force with adequate skills to use new technologies.
Those who blamed schools for earlier economic stagnation were well meaning. But curiously, reputations of mistaken analysts have not been sullied, while the damage they did to the reputation of education's role in the American economy has endured.
Perhaps we would have wanted similar cures, even after diagnoses were altered. Even in a healthy economy, we should improve the ability of less advantaged students to compete for better jobs. But we might have approached reform differently had we known we were trying to raise achievement beyond levels required for economic growth alone.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
$30 Million Upgrade Set For a 42nd St. Building

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
The owners of the Lincoln Building, a 1.2-million-square-foot structure diagonally across 42nd Street from Grand Central Terminal, have had a close-up view of neighborhood improvements in recent years. Now they are beginning their own renovation, a $30 million program that includes preparing space to attract office users larger than the small tenants who have long occupied most of the building.
The program includes wiring for the Internet, replacing all single-pane windows with more energy-efficient double-pane units, adding computer controls for the elevators and remodeling the interiors of the cabs, adding new bathrooms and air-conditioning the hallways. 
 The intention is to make the 70-year-old building, which has 600 tenants at 60 East 42nd Street, attractive to tenants who want all the amenities and services of a much newer building. Some small tenants in the building who occupy just a few hundred square feet may be forced to look elsewhere; the owners are assembling blocks of 5,000 to 10,000 square feet of space that could attract larger tenants who may be better able to pay annual rents that are now about $50 a square foot.
The investment in the Lincoln Building was prompted by a $300 million renovation of Grand Central Terminal and the general improvement of the neighborhood, said Peter L. Malkin, the chairman of Wien & Malkin, a law firm and real estate asset manager, and the general partner in the syndicates that own the building and the master operating lease. Mr. Malkin, who is in a legal dispute with Helmsley-Spear, the building's manager, is acting as the owners' representative. "We want to reposition the building to be No. 1 in an area that is a hub of transportation," said Mr. Malkin, noting that plans are under way to have Long Island Rail Road trains stop at Grand Central.
In fact, the building has underground access to both the rail terminal and the Lexington Avenue and Times Square shuttle subway lines. The door between the building and the passages leading to Grand Central and the subway was reopened about a year ago after having been closed for 25 years, said Kevin J. Driscoll, the building's general manager. Mr. Driscoll said the decision to open the door came as crime and the number of homeless people living in the area were both reduced.
Mr. Malkin, whose office is in the building, had something to do with the changes in the neighborhood. He was one of the founders of the Grand Central Partnership, a business improvement district that provides cleaning and security services on the streets and offers consulting to small businesses in the district.
Mr. Malkin quoted his late father-in-law, Lawrence A. Wien, as saying the law firm believed in "enlightened self-interest." When Mr. Wien led the group that bought the building in 1954, he installed a law library that was available to anyone in the building and has a full-time librarian. Not surprisingly, 92 lawyers and law firms are tenants.
Part of the renovation is to move the library from a lower-level concourse to the lobby level and combine it with a conference center equipped with advanced communications equipment. The conference center will be on the Madison Avenue side of the building, which has an entrance on the avenue as well as on 42nd and 41st Streets.
Since rents in the building have risen to about $50 a square foot from the high $20's and low $30's per square foot annually as recently as five years ago, Fred C. Pozniak, director of marketing for Wein & Malkin, said some tenants may want to economize by eliminating seldom-used conference rooms in favor of renting the center as needed.
All bathrooms in the building are being renovated at a cost of $80,000 each, Mr. Driscoll said. Because of the building's age, much of the plumbing had to be replaced.
Security is also being improved with the installation of a computerized system that will read coded cards issued to tenants and their employees. The system will record the names of people entering or leaving the building and how long they were inside.
Mr. Malkin said the building's managers had been coordinating the expirations of leases so that those on each floor of the 55-story structure will roll over at the same time. The seventh floor on the Madison Avenue wing has been assembled into an 11,000-square-foot space. "When the time comes we will evaluate the market for 5,000-, 10,000- and 15,000-square-foot units, and we will be free to do that if appropriate," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE PRIMARIES;
West Virginia And Nebraska Chose Slates For Elections

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: OMAHA, Neb., May 9

 BODY:
Attorney General Donald B. Stenberg of Nebraska took the first step today toward reclaiming Senator Bob Kerrey's seat for the Republicans, easily defeating the secretary of state and two other candidates in the Republican primary.
With 38 percent of precincts reporting, Mr. Stenberg had 43,168 votes, or 50 percent, far more than Secretary of State Scott Moore's 20,737 votes, or 24 percent. 
 Mr. Stenberg will take on Ben Nelson, a popular former governor, who left office in 1999 after two terms. Mr. Nelson easily beat his only opponent in the Democratic primary for M
r. Kerrey's seat.
Mr. Kerrey, the only Democrat in Nebraska's congressional delegation, decided not to run for a third term and will instead become president of New School University in New York City.
Mr. Stenberg recently defended Nebraska's ban on what it calls partial-birth abortions before the United States Supreme Court. He beat Mr. Moore despite the secretary of state's edge in fund-raising.
In other primaries today, Tom Osborne, a former University of Nebraska football coach, routed his two opponents in a Republican congressional primary. Mr. Osborne is adored in Nebraska, though the struggling farm economy and other issues have dominated his campaign.
With 64 percent of precincts reporting, Mr. Osborne had 32,303 votes, or 71 percent. John Gale, a longtime state Republican leader, followed with 7,993 votes, or 17 percent, and Kathy Wilmot, a member of the state Board of Education, had 5,489 votes, or 12 percent.
There were presidential primaries in Nebraska and West Virginia, but both were essentially meaningless since Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore have sealed their parties' nominations.
Gov. Cecil H. Underwood of West Virginia, who was elected to his first term as governor in 1956 and to his second term in 1996, easily won the Republican nomination for his third term. At 77, Mr. Underwood is the nation's oldest governor. He is also the only Republican in a statewide office in West Virginia. He will face Representative Bob Wise, who won the Democratic primary.
Four Democrats vied for Mr. Wise's seat, including Secretary of State Ken Hechler, 85, who spent 18 years in Congress, from 1959 to 1977. Mr. Hechler finished third, well behind the winner, Jim Humphreys, a lawyer who spent $3 million of his own money.
Mr. Hechler spent about $300,000 of his own money and said spending anything over $1 million in a primary was "overkill."
With 43 percent of precincts reporting, Humphreys had 14,861 votes, or 41 percent, while State Senator Martha Yeager Walker had 10,744 votes, or 30 percent. Mr. Hechler had 8,704 votes, or 24 percent.
West Virginia is a heavily Democratic state so whoever wins that race will be favored to beat Shelley Moore Capito, a Republican, this fall. Ms. Capito, a member of the state House of Delegates, is the daughter of a former governor, Arch Moore Jr.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Aid on New Jersey Exports

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Under an agreement signed yesterday, New Jersey businesses could get more help selling their products to foreign countries.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the Export-Import Bank of the United States formalized a relationship that, over the last five years, has helped bankroll $2.2 billion worth of business in New Jersey. 
 The agreement basically says the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission will work with the bank to make businesses more aware of export opportunities.
The Export-Import Bank is a federal agency that guarantees loans made to other countries so they can buy American-made products. The bank also lends money to other countries to buy American goods.

HEADLINE: Transforming Theater Row;
An Unlikely Urban Drama Heads for a Happy Ending

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
Some of the prostitutes had Actors' Equity cards. That, at least, was a point of connection for the theater people and other dreamers who 25 years ago thought they could reclaim perhaps the seediest sex strip on wild West 42nd Street.
There was another link to culture. The International Body Rub Institute, the French Palace and other massage parlors that lined the block between 9th and 10th Avenues were decorated with murals: nudes, many painted by a quixotic Israeli artist who waited on tables down the block at the Hello Deli. 
 "It was like the Bloomsbury Group goes porn," recalled Andre Bishop, artistic director of the Lincoln Center Theater and one of the founders of Playwrights Horizons, a pioneer in the ultimately successful effort to turn the block into the flourishing Theater Row, which prefigured the far larger revival of 42nd Street and Times Square.
Now the eastern half of the enclave, between Ninth and Dyer Avenues, is poised for its own transformation. With the stroke of a pen -- lots of strokes of lots of pens, actually -- the biggest Off Broadway theater redevelopment project in New York City history has taken final form.
Contracts for a new 499-seat Shubert theater, five new or rebuilt smaller theaters and a 40-story apartment tower overlooking the Dyer Avenue exit from the Lincoln Tunnel were signed on April 14, supercharging a renewal that until now has been makeshift.
There was no self-congratulatory announcement but relief that the complex series of closings had survived. Participants looked back at what some called an unlikely urban drama, largely unscripted, with (so far anyway) a happy ending. In all, from pornographic past to high-rise future, the resurgence became, quite literally, a groundbreaking story of urban renewal through the arts.
It even drew praise from an unlikely quarter: Martin Hodas, known in his heyday in the 1970's as "the peep show king" and the entrepreneur behind many X-rated storefronts that have since been driven from the area.
"I think it's a wonderful thing they did," said Mr. Hodas from his home in Queens. "I never liked the idea of massage parlors."
The strip, a theater locale in decades past, entered the 1970's so tawdry that some visitors preferred to come and go walking down the yellow line in the middle of West 42nd Street, far from the soliciting women and the string of menacing sex boutiques and grungy groceries.
The "Live Burlesque" house, where women strolled around talking off their clothes and pointing absently to parts of their anatomy, ignored its electrical bills, so Con Edison finally ripped up the street and disconnected the power cable to the building.
The cellar of another club was home to a reclusive old woman with an enormous wardrobe who emerged intermittently in full makeup and laden with jewelry to roam the block shrieking at passers-by.
Into this mix in 1975 stepped Playwrights Horizons, a four-year-old company that had just lost its home in the West Side Y.M.C.A. Its artistic director, Bob Moss, took one look around and decided, "Sometimes you have to do things that don't make any sense, and this is one of them." He took quarters in an abandoned pornographic movie house at 422 West 42nd Street for $1,200 a month and rechristened it the Judith Anderson Theater, then soon expanded Playwrights' stake on the block by moving down the street to the former burlesque house at No. 416, at twice the rent.
The company appealed for help from Broadway luminaries, among them Richard Rodgers. Instead of cash he sent a contribution more to the point: $500 worth of paint, Lysol and cleaning equipment.
Even the streetwalkers pitched in, Mr. Bishop recalled, with those holding union cards asking for parts. "There was an odd camaraderie on the block," he said, "particularly when the fleet was in."
The company soon put itself on the map with hits like "Vanities."
A second brave troupe, the Lion Company, arrived, and others, including the South Street Theater, Intar and the Acting Company soon followed. Mr. Moss, who left Playwrights to become artistic director at Syracuse Stage, a leading outpost of regional theater, dated the turnabout from the day in 1975 when he looked out of his window and saw strangers, including one out-of-place interloper in a business suit, surveying the strip for who knew what.
They included Fred Papert (the suit), who had founded the nonprofit 42nd Street Development Corporation during the successful effort to save Grand Central Terminal on East 42nd Street from the wrecker's ball. (His compatriot in the effort, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, later wielded a shovel in the Theater Row groundbreaking.)
Mr. Papert's group had bought the block of West 42nd Street between 9th and 10th Avenues from desperate landlords who had been losing money and faced mounting tax bills while playing reluctant host to sex establishments. By holding a mortgage on the properties of the nonprofit group, they at least had a chance for some financial recovery if the renewal took, which is in fact what happened.
Looking at the unsightly buildings, Mr. Papert wondered what it would it would take, short of demolition, to turn the neighborhood around.
Mr. Moss told him: "I have a better idea. This can all be turned into theaters."
By picking tenants who changed the "urban vibrations," as Mr. Papert put it, his group turned the trickle of new theaters into a boomlet, which he hoped to advance with his relentless promotion of a 42nd Street trolley line.
The failure of the new Manhattan Plaza housing towers across West 42nd Street to draw sufficient tenants to the wasteland produced another opportunity: 80 percent of the units were earmarked for low-paid people in the performing arts. That idea proved a bonanza.
"I remember the first lights going on in the apartments," Mr. Bishop said. "It was an outstanding moment. Suddenly we didn't feel as desolate."
Now the last links with the gritty past are about to be severed. Demolition for the new apartment tower and theaters began last week by the builders, Daniel Brodsky, Robert Quinlan and Michael Field. They said the $75 million job, which includes 260 rental apartments, 20 percent of them for low- and moderate-income tenants, could be completed in 18 months.
The Shubert organization is spending $6 million or more on its new theater, its 17th wholly owned establishment in the city and the city's first commercial stage built specifically as a transfer house for productions that start modestly off or off Off Broadway and then, on the strength of reviews, seek to make the leap to theaters large enough to earn money or even, if lightening strikes, to Broadway. The new theater will be run by Ben Sprecher, who owns the Variety Arts and Promenade Theaters and manages the Lucille Lortel.
The project also includes two theaters with 99 seats and one with 199 seats on a 41st Street parcel acquired from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. They will replace three 99-seat theaters that now occupy the Shubert site. Two other theaters of 83 and 99 seats, the Harold Clurman and the Samuel Beckett, will be rebuilt in place, and support space, including new rehearsal studios, will be provided.
In addition Playwrights Horizons, which sold its air rights and made it possible for the new Shubert theater to be unobstructed by columns for the apartment tower over it, is expected shortly to announce the rebuilding of its two theaters of 141 and 72 seats. This makes a total of eight new or rebuilt theaters seating 1,291 patrons. The number of seats in each theater is determined by contract provisions setting minimum union pay scales for houses of various sizes.
The work, designed by the architect Hugh Hardy of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, is to be financed entirely with private money, said Mr. Papert of the 42nd Street Development Corporation.
A project has yet to be developed for the western half of Theater Row, between Dyer and 10th Avenues. The site includes the Douglas Fairbanks and John Houseman Theaters, among others, and the National Video Center in the former West Side Airlines Terminal. The block, bought for its tax deductions by investors nearly 25 years ago for $500,000, is now worth $60 million to $80 million, said Mr. Papert, whose group is a minority partner.
After paying its costs, the 42nd Street group expects to emerge with about $2 million for its foundation, which supports early music education from kindergarten to second grade. Mr. Papert's group will also do the bookings (but not determine the content) for all the theaters except the Shubert house and Playwrights, a role that had been envisioned for Art New York, a service organization for nonprofit theaters. It and Mr. Papert's group, however, could not agree on terms for a deal.
Among those looking back in wonderment is Jean-Claude Baker, proprietor of Chez Josephine, the restaurant at 414 West 42nd Street, between Playwrights Horizons and the Clurman Theater. Mr. Baker, who was adopted by Josephine Baker, the flamboyant black entertainer, plans to buy its building from the 42nd Street group and turn part of it into a museum of black entertainment.
While the building, once a coffee roasting business, housed a restaurant when he took it over in 1986, it also used to be home to the French Palace, which beckoned customers with a window sign promising, "$10 Complete Satisfaction." One of the nudes painted by the women at the massage parlor survives in the restaurant, covered by a slightly less revealing painting of Josephine Baker wearing bananas.
Mr. Bishop, too, marvels at the developments. "This story is so small time," he said. "Modest theaters, modest budgets, modest aspirations, but big time in terms of human richness."
"Urban renewal," he added, "was the last thing on our minds."

HEADLINE: When Peace Is Worse Than War

BYLINE: By William Reno; William Reno, who teaches political science at Northwestern, is the author of "Warlord Politics and African States."

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
Sometimes it is better to wage war than to agree to an unstable and unworkable peace, a proposition that the current crisis in Sierra Leone bears out.
A peace agreement signed in July 1999 was supposed to help rebuild Sierra Leone by installing a coalition government, composed of the current president, Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, and Foday Sankoh, the ruthless leader of the main rebel group. 
 Under the accord, Mr. Sankoh became a vice president and commissioner of diamond resources, the country's main source of income. Three of his lieutenants became ministers of government. All were offered a blanket amnesty for past crimes. In exchange, United Nations peacekeepers were to take the weapons of all combatants. Instead, the rebels have captured and disarmed 500 peacekeepers, and the country is in chaos once again.
This agreement failed for several related reasons. It mistakenly assumed that the rebels were interested in peace, let alone had an interest in real governing. It assumed that there was a civil war and treated Mr. Sankoh as a legitimate champion of the rural poor, whose interests he claimed to represent. In reality, Mr. Sankoh is not rebelling in any political sense. He has been interested only in taking advantage of a corrupt state that had collapsed.
So, from the rebels' point of view, why have peace when it is the absence of law and order that enables one to loot? Why let peacekeeping troops enter the country's diamond mining area if one is profiting from the sale of these riches on the black market?
In fact, the rebels never had any intention of honoring the peace accord; they were only interested in waging war and looting the country. The United Nations, so reflexively attached to the mantra of peace at any price, sent peacekeeping troops when there was no peace to keep. The United Nations and the State Department, which helped negotiate the peace accord, should have known better. As recently as March 1999, the United Nations Security Council had threatened to prosecute Mr. Sankoh for war crimes. Earlier, a State Department report on Sierra Leone had noted the discovery of civilian mass graves in areas where the rebels had attacked.
Why would the United Nations and the United States agree to a power-sharing agreement with Mr. Sankoh, whose forces have killed, raped and maimed tens of thousands of men, women and even children?
The answer can be found in President Clinton's statement during his April 1999 visit to Rwanda, when he lamented the lack of United States action to stop the genocide there. After this speech, the Clinton administration wanted to show that it cared about human rights in Africa. Engineering a peace accord in Sierra Leone, however slapdash, sent the desired message.
In the last few days, Nigeria has agreed to send its own forces back to Sierra Leone, provided the West pays their costs. The West should jump at this, not only because these soldiers are likely to be better equipped and trained than the United Nations forces, but because they can fight back.
Unconstrained by the rules of peacekeeping, the Nigerians can wage war against the rebels. And Nigeria, unlike the West, has national interests at stake. Trouble anywhere in West Africa is a threat to its stability.
The peace agreement in Sierra Leone was quick and cheap, but doomed. Let us hope that the West now recognizes this -- and doesn't opt for a second try at an accord.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Agency Takes Over Camden's Troubled Finances

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 10

 BODY:
New Jersey's fiscal oversight agency today formally took over the financial operation of Camden, the state's poorest city and one that has for years, over several mayoral administrations, defied efforts by the state to correct fiscal abuses.
Camden's municipal lawyers complained halfheartedly that the state, too, was to blame for the city's ills. But the Local Finance Board, an arm of the Department of Community Affairs, brushed those objections aside. Instead, it voted without dissent to invoke a Depression-era state law that allows the state to assume supervision of cities that demonstrate a high level of mismanagement, including recurring deficits, and that fail to fully collect taxes because of that mismanagement. 
 More than 70 percent of Camden's income is derived from state aid, and its managers have for years been found by state investigators to have failed to keep coherent fiscal records, while engaging in questionable spending.
This spring, Camden's mayor, Milton Milan, was indicted under federal racketeering and corruption laws, becoming the city's third mayor in 20 years to be indicted. The federal action, part of a continuing investigation into mob influences in Camden and Philadelphia, spurred New Jersey officials to take a harder stand on Camden's management style.
On Friday, Judge Francis J. Orlando Jr. of Superior Court ruled that Camden met the standard for state supervision, and today Jane M. Kenny, commissioner of the Community Affairs Department, told the Local Finance Board that it was time to act.
"The court has recognized that the state needs to have a more direct role in the city's operation," she said. "We stand ready to take a proactive approach to managing the city's finances and setting the city on a course of economic recovery."
Al Steinberg, chairman of the Local Finance Board, said state auditors would spend the next few weeks "surveying the landscape" of Camden's fiscal condition, including reviewing staffing levels and personnel qualifications, and determining whether any current fiscal managers need to be replaced or new ones hired. The law gives the state one year to complete its supervision.
East Orange is the only other city now under state supervision, and the state was all but welcomed there by Mayor Robert L. Bowser, a civil engineer who was elected in 1997 in a campaign to reform the city. The mayor said in a recent interview that his city had to get state approval for any spending over $4,500, and that the state moved swiftly to pare the city payrolls.
"They've laid off about 70 people, which saves us $455,000 this year and about $1.7 million next year," Mayor Bowser said.
In contrast to East Orange officials, Camden's leaders have fought Trenton's takeover at each step.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Aided by Auction And a Flight From Equities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were up sharply yesterday, lifted by a successful government note auction and steep losses in the stock market.
The Treasury sold $8 billion of new 10-year notes, an auction that market participants said had results in line with expectations. The notes were awarded at a price to yield 6.475 percent. 
 In when-issued trading leading up to the sale, the notes were being offered at a price to yield 6.48 percent, down from 6.52 the previous day. The actively traded 10-year note was yielding 6.42 percent yesterday, down from 6.52 percent on Tuesday. Its price, which moves in the opposite direction, increased 23/32, to 100 18/32.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was up 26/32, to 101 13/32. The bond's yield fell to 6.15 percent from 6.21 percent.
Kim Rupert, economist at Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm, said "the weakness in equities gave a boost to Treasuries."
With most participants expecting a tightening of half a percentage point next week by the Federal Reserve, Ms. Rupert said the market will quickly turn its speculation to the June and August meetings. A tame Consumer Price Index report next Tuesday could diminish thoughts of a similar increase in June.
Eric Cheung, vice president at the Asset Management Departmant/ Fixed-Income Division of Wilmington Trust in Wilmington, Del., said the bond market had incorporated an aggressive Fed move into its rate structure. "Equities have pretty well passed the height of earnings releases and are likely to seek a trading range while waiting for the Fed to hand out its next batch of medicine," Mr. Cheung said. "We will just have to wait to see if it is a single dose or a double shot."

HEADLINE: Horse-Trading (and Pork) on Trade Bill

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
There are 10,000 miles and not much trade between China and the anthracite coal region of eastern Pennsylvania, but for Paul E. Kanjorski, a House Democrat, the two are inseparable.
Mr. Kanjorski said he told President Clinton and House Republican leaders that he would support extending permanent trading rights to China if they would offer "assurances" that his proposed tax breaks to encourage investment in Pennsylvania's distressed coal region will become law before Mr. Clinton leaves office. 
 "It's a very tough vote for me and these issues must come together," Mr. Kanjorski said flatly this week. "It's not a vote I'm just going to throw away."
President Clinton has stressed for months that Congress must grant China permanent trading rights or risk damaging the competitiveness of American companies and relations with the world's most populous country. But not unlike other high-profile trade votes, this one also involves a host of issues that are purely local, like job retraining and development aid.
Administration officials warned early this spring that they could not dole out favors for votes, not at the end of Mr. Clinton's term and with Republicans in control of Congress. Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, who is leading the administration's lobbying effort, said lawmakers must make a straight choice or, as he put it, "walk the plank."
But that has not stopped members of Congress from demanding life preservers. With the administration still short of the 218 votes it needs in the House two weeks before the scheduled vote, at least some of the Democrats and Republicans who remain officially uncommitted want pet projects financed.
The requests may be one reason that 30 lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have been coy about how they will vote, a remarkably large number of undecideds given that Congress has had to choose whether to renew China's trade privileges annually for two decades. The administration is now asking Congress to give up that annual review, fulfilling a promise it made to Beijing last year when it negotiated the terms for China's accession to the World Trade Organization.
Several Democrats who represent districts with a heavy trade union presence have been especially demanding. They argue that they need some political cover to vote for a measure that unions steadfastly oppose. The administration, if not yet making firm commitments, is at least listening, they say.
"The industrial unions are vehement about this," said Representative James L. Oberstar, a senior Minnesota Democrat. "They say they'll picket me. I'll take the heat if I can get something done for the people I represent."
Mr. Oberstar says he wants the administration to amend the Trade Act of 1974 so that imports of steel slabs can be treated as a direct threat to the taconite miners of northern Minnesota. With Russian and Brazilian slabs flooding the market, Mr. Oberstar said, American blast furnaces no longer use as much taconite, a low-grade iron-ore, to produce raw steel. Several thousands jobs are threatened, he said.
"Now they have something they really want," he said, referring to the China trade bill. What he is asking now, he said, is that the law be modified "to serve the needs of these people who are hurt."
The requests for aid come as the administration and Republican leaders in Congress are locked in a furious battle with opponents of the China trade measure, including senior Congressional Democrats and politically powerful labor unions.
The House majority whip, Tom DeLay, Republican of Texas, warned today that he would have to engage in "traditional hand-to-hand combat" to round up enough Republican votes to pass the measure, dismissing reports that his party already had 150 secure votes. Another Republican leader said that a recent head count of House Republicans found only 120 solid supporters, though administration officials said they still expected at least 20 more Republicans to vote in favor.
The pendulum swung slightly in favor of opponents today when Representatives David D. Phelps of Illinois and Gene Green of Texas, both Democrats, declared they would vote no. The administration says that it needs a minimum of 70 House Democrats to vote in favor and that it remains 10 to 15 votes shy.
Whips on both sides of the aisles have been publicly discouraging their caucuses from using the close vote as a chance to extract benefits for their home districts. Asked about Republican pork barreling today, Mr. DeLay said sharply, "We don't do that."
Represenative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat and his party's chief supporter of the bill in the House, also urged lawmakers to make their decision on the bill's merits. "You can't get cover from labor from a bridge project," he said.
Another of Mr. Clinton major trade priorities, the North American Free Trade Agreement, which Congress approved in 1993, became a political pinata when scores of lawmakers on both sides of the aisle demanded -- and often received -- benefits in exchange for their votes, administration officials acknowledged.
The China trade measure is not Nafta. It does not require that the United States open its markets wider to imported goods, as Nafta did, and the Congressional demands for district-by-district benefits are much less intense this time, many people involved in the lobbying process said.
But the lobbying, if less high profile, is hardly invisible. Commerce Secretary Daley flew to Texas late last week to hear more about Representative Ruben Hinojosa's proposed Cross-Border Institute for Regional Development, a plan to create a Silicon Valley in southeastern Texas.
Mr. Daley and Mr. Hinojosa, a Democrat who has yet to say which way he is voting on China trade, declined to comment on the trip. But a Congressional aide said that Mr. Hinojosa hoped that a public-private partnership could bring high-tech businesses and jobs to the area.
