HEADLINE: Russia's New Prime Minister: A Tested Economic Liberal

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 10

 BODY:
President Vladimir V. Putin named as prime minister today a chief foreign-debt negotiator and a liberal economics expert. The long predicted move, some experts said, bodes well for efforts to tame Russia's feral style of capitalism.
That view was bolstered by a separate report today that Mr. Putin might abolish the Fuel and Energy Ministry as he reorganizes the cabinet. The immensely powerful agency has often been attacked as a seat of corruption and a brake on capitalist reforms. 
 Since January, when Mr. Putin became acting president, the new prime minister, Mikhail M. Kasyanov, has held the post of first deputy prime minister, which was the government's No. 2 position. He frequently stood in for Mr. Putin as the acting president campaigned for the full four-year term that he won in elections in March.
But Mr. Kasyanov, 42, is best known as the pragmatic and savvy negotiator who persuaded private Western creditors in February to agree to a reduction of nearly $32 billion in Russian debt.
The creditors, known as the London Club, agreed after months of talks to accept bonds worth as little as 62.5 cents for every dollar owed. That now seems an exceptionally good deal for Russia, which was -- and is -- reaping an unexpectedly large income from a rebounding economy and high-price oil exports.
Klaus Regling, who negotiated with Mr. Kasyanov as the German Finance Ministry's chief international officer in the 1990's, called him an extremely tough bargainer who won the respect not just of the Germans, but also of the Americans in the Treasury Department, as well.
"When he signed off on something, you knew it was really a done deal," Mr. Regling, now a finance expert in London, said. "There are always all these advisers around. But he didn't need that. You could really do it with just two persons in the room."
The nomination of Mr. Kasyanov, a tall, beefy man with a gravelly voice and a crushing handshake, goes to the lower house of Parliament, the Duma, which plans a vote next Wednesday. The speaker, Gennadi Seleznyov, a Communist, predicted that he would be confirmed easily, even though the Communists have serious questions about the Kremlin's economic bent.
"Most Duma members are not allergic to Kasyanov," Mr. Seleznyov said.
The consensus among experts was that Mr. Kasyanov would continue to have a strong hand in fiscal policy, pushing to streamline tax and regulatory codes.
The chairman of the Budget Committee in Parliament, Aleksandr Zhukov, said in a radio interview the government was preparing "drastic changes to some of the main taxes," including the income and excise taxes and the payroll tax for welfare funds, which could change the landscape of the budget and economy.
Separately, the semiofficial Interfax news service quoted a government source as having said Mr. Putin is considering eliminating several cabinet-level agencies, including the Economics and the Fuel and Energy Ministries. Their duties would be folded into the Finance Ministry and other departments.
The Fuel and Energy Ministry has been marked by liberals as a test of Mr. Putin's willingness to confront entrenched interests.
Although much of the oil industry is in private hands, natural gas remains more or less a government monopoly. And the ministry wields enormous influence -- much of it for the benefit of special interests, critics say -- through its control of pipelines and the pricing of oil products.
In recent weeks, the critics have demanded the ouster of Energy Minister Viktor I. Kalyuzhny, who they say has imposed new production quotas and tariffs that insiders can easily manipulate.
Mr. Kasyanov hedged when asked about a cabinet shake-up. "It is necessary to make some adjustments in the structure of the federal organs of power," he said, adding that those changes "will not be global ones."
Some express doubts -- similar to those expressed about Mr. Putin -- as to whether Mr. Kasyanov is willing to free the economy from the grip of the financial-industrial combines that dominate several industries and their government regulators.
Some racier muckraking newspapers have called Mr. Kasyanov "Misha 2 Percent," contending that as Finance Minister he gave well-connected bankers inside information about the terms for the resale of old Soviet-era debts. Mr. Kasyanov has flatly denied that.
Like Mr. Putin, Mr. Kasyanov is also pegged by Moscow's rumor mill as close to two tycoons, Boris A. Berezovsky and Roman Abramovich, who have amassed huge stakes in Russia's oil, metals and media industries.
This year, the two have cornered 70 percent of the aluminum industry with the blessing of the government.
Mr. Berezovsky and Mr. Abramovich raised eyebrows by showing up at invitation-only events that surrounded Mr. Putin's inauguration on Sunday.
One of the best-known liberals of President Boris N. Yeltsin's government, Boris Nemtsov, warned this spring that Mr. Kasyanov's elevation to prime minister would mean a continuation of the robber-baron capitalism that helped ruin the economy. Mr. Kasyanov scoffs at that. "I don't have any concrete ties to any particular financial-industrial group," he said last month. "I maintain contacts with everybody. I meet with Berezovsky very rarely, perhaps once every six months."
In fact, Mr. Kasyanov is credited with supporting a one-third increase in oil-export taxes and a requirement that oil companies pay their taxes in cash rather than through barter, two measures opposed by the so-called oligarchs.
He rose the hard way. A graduate of the Moscow Automobile and Road College, he worked at the old Soviet central planning committee before switching, with the government, to a free-market economic philosophy after the Soviet Union died in 1991.
Mr. Kasyanov spent two years at the Economics Ministry before joining Mr. Yeltsin's Finance Ministry, where he held several posts before becoming finance minister.

HEADLINE: Saline Breast Implants Win U.S. Approval After Studies

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Seven years after it first questioned the safety of saline breast implants, the Food and Drug Administration decided today to permit the two largest makers of implants to continue marketing the devices, despite new scientific evidence that they pose a significant risk of infection, tissue hardening and pain in the breast, as well as repeat surgeries.
The government's approval of implants made by the McGhan Medical Corporation and the Mentor Corporation, both of Santa Barbara, Calif., came after five studies of more than 9,000 women documented what the drug agency described as relatively high rates of complications and rupture. The agency said it would require the companies to inform women of the risks. 
 "Although there is benefit to some women from having breast implants available, there is now a much clearer understanding of the risks involved," said Dr. Jane E. Henney, commissioner of food and drugs, in a statement announcing the agency's decision. "With the data that has been presented, women and their physicians will be able to make informed decisions about whether the benefits are worth the risks."
Saline implants have been sold in this country without Food and Drug Administration approval for more than three decades, long before the passage of a 1976 law that gave the agency authority to regulate medical devices. They have been the only type of implant commercially available since 1992, when the agency took silicone implants off the market amid great controversy about whether they caused autoimmune disorders. (An Institute of Medicine study concluded last year that they did not.)
The saline implants were generally presumed safer than silicone implants, because they leak only salt water, as opposed to silicone gel, when they rupture. But while there has been an abundance of anecdotal evidence that all breast implants can cause hardening of breast tissue and other problems, until now there has been little scientific data about the extent of the risk from saline implants. So in 1993, amid questions about their safety, the drug agency announced it would require the companies to study the implants and apply for government approval.
The studies by McGhan and Mentor made clear that many women who have saline implants will have to undergo additional surgeries because of rupture or other complications. McGhan's primary study involved 901 women who received saline-filled implants for cosmetic reasons, and, like all the studies, looked at the various short-term or "local" complications that have long been known to be associated with breast implants.
After three years, 689 women were still in the study. About one-fifth, or 21 percent, required additional surgeries; 9 percent suffered a hardening of the tissue around the implant (a condition known as capsular contracture); 16 percent experienced breast pain; 8 percent asked for their implants to be removed and 5 percent experienced leakage or deflation of the device. The rates of complications were roughly the same in a study of 1,264 women who received Mentor implants.
But the risks of complications were higher for women who received implants for reconstruction after breast cancer surgery or other medical problems, in part because the lack of an intact breast makes it difficult for doctors to put the implants in. Among 416 women receiving Mentor implants for breast reconstruction, 40 percent needed additional surgeries, 27 percent asked that the implants be removed and 9 percent experienced leakage and deflation. In all the studies, some women experienced more than one complication.
An estimated 150,000 women obtained saline implants last year; McGhan, a subsidiary of the Inamed Corporation, and Mentor, sold the vast majority of the devices. Three smaller implant manufacturers are also seeking agency approval.
Officials at Mentor declined to comment on the agency's action today. But Scott Eschbach, the president and chief executive of McGhan, said he was pleased with the agency's decision, and characterized it as a determination by the government that the implants are "safe and effective." Mr. Eschbach said, "I think they made a wise decision."
But Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of Public Citizen's Health Research Group, a Washington advocacy organization that had petitioned the agency to regulate saline implants, said the studies conducted by McGhan and Mentor hardly prove safety and effectiveness. He strongly criticized the agency's action today.
"One can't think of any other medical device that has been allowed to stay on the market with such a high failure rate," Dr. Wolfe said. "It is yielding to the device companies and guaranteeing harm to women."
Dr. David Feigal, director of the agency's Center for Devices and Radiological Health, defended the decision today, saying women are capable of reviewing the data and making their own choices.
"This is a product that there is a strong consumer interest in," Dr. Feigal said. "If you look at the kinds of problems that we have characterized as complications, they are cosmetic complications. That's not to say that they aren't important or distressing. But now we have the ability for people to actually see what they are getting into, and make the choice in that light."

HEADLINE: China Arms Expert Warns U.S. Shield May Force Buildup

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 10

 BODY:
China's chief arms negotiator said today that the American proposal to build an anti missile defensive shield posed an unacceptable threat to China's security and could force Beijing to significantly expand its own nuclear forces in response.
The Chinese find it hard to believe American claims that the proposed "national missile defense" is intended only to counter threats from small "rogue" states like North Korea, said the official, Sha Zukang, in an interview. But whatever the intention, he said, the systems under discussion would destroy China's ability to deter nuclear attack by neutralizing its relatively small force of nuclear missiles. 
 That would leave China dangerously vulnerable to bullying or attack, said Mr. Sha, the Foreign Ministry's director general for arms control. If that appears likely, he added, "we will not sit on our hands."
Mr. Sha and other Chinese officials have frequently voiced their strong opposition to American missile defense plans, but in the interview today, Mr. Sha, who spoke in English, gave the most detailed public warning yet of China's possible military responses, ranging from producing more nuclear warheads to devising ways to undermine the American missile shield.
"How can we base our own national security on your assurances of good will?" he asked.
Mr. Sha said that a "balance of terror" had kept nuclear peace for decades and remained the only realistic course until such weapons are phased out. The American proposal, he said, would spark a new global arms race and possibly what he called a "nightmare scenario" of weapons proliferation.
Although the feasibility of the shield is not yet proved, President Clinton is under pressure to decide soon whether to embark on a crash program costing tens of billions of dollars to develop and deploy a system of sensors, missiles and futuristic weapons that could destroy a small number of incoming missiles.
The proposal has been vehemently opposed by Russia, which like China fears the system would blunt its power and, like China, wants to avoid a costly arms race. In the debate in Washington so far, the Russian objections have received far greater attention than those from China, in part because deploying the defensive system would violate the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty signed by the United States and the Soviet Union.
The Clinton administration has tried to persuade Russia to accept changes in the treaty that would permit a limited missile defense even as the two countries negotiate deeper, money-saving cuts in their huge nuclear arsenals.
American officials have also sought to convince Russian military planners that the system contemplated, while adequate to stop a few missiles from a nation like Iraq or North Korea, could quickly be overwhelmed by Russia's missile forces.
But the Americans cannot make that argument convincingly to China. Since China developed nuclear weapons in the 1960's, it has avoided trying to match American and Soviet arsenals, instead keeping a small number of missiles as a minimal deterrent, able to retaliate in the event of attack. Western experts believe that China has no more than about two dozen land-based missiles, with one warhead each, capable of reaching the continental United States -- compared with thousands of warheads the United States could deliver by land- or sea-based missiles or bombers.
American officials have not said how, in the event the missile defense plan goes ahead, they will deal with Beijing's objections or any major changes in its nuclear forces.
In Washington, a State Department spokesman restated today the American position that national missile defense is not directed against China, but rather against the threat from countries with developing or potential missile programs, like North Korea, Iran and Iraq.
"We've held meetings with the People's Republic of China," said the spokesman, Philip Reeker. "They have expressed their concerns. We will continue our dialogue and efforts to explain the basis for any decision to deploy national missile defense."
Western intelligence agencies say that China is already developing newer, mobile ballistic missiles and improved warheads, but that they do not know whether it already plans a major expansion of forces.
If the American missile defense plan proceeds, Mr. Sha said, "We'll have to do something." The options, he said, include a significant increase in the number of nuclear warheads that China would field, improvements in the accuracy and other traits of warheads, and the development of methods to destroy or frustrate the missile shield.
He said that China and Russia were discussing possible cooperation in developing techniques "to restore strategic stability," including methods "to defeat your system," but he declined to be more specific.
"To defeat your defenses we'll have to spend a lot of money, and we don't want to do this," Mr. Sha said, adding that China's greater priority is economic development. "But otherwise, the United States will feel it can attack anyone at any time, and that isn't tolerable."
China's equally fervent opposition to American and Japanese research on a "theater missile defense" for East Asia, which China fears might be extended to protect Taiwan, which it views as a breakaway province, has received considerable attention among Western military experts.
Less widely understood, Mr. Sha said, is that an advanced missile defense in Asia would also serve as a forward line for the continental defensive shield. Putting long-range radars and other advanced devices in East Asia would give the United States the ability to detect and destroy Russian or Chinese missiles as they were launched, he said.
"So this theater missile defense could be even more dangerous for Russia and China than the national missile defense," he said.
Mr. Sha described American fears of nuclear attack from countries like North Korea and Iraq as "ridiculous." He said China estimates that it will be at least 15 years before North Korea can develop a missile able to reach the United States. He said that North Korea has no nuclear weapons and that strong diplomatic efforts can keep it that way -- and that in any case, North Korea would never launch an attack while it faces the certainty of massive retaliation.
"The U.S. is a huge superpower and you're afraid of little North Korea?" he said. "Is it convincing?" What is more plausible, he said, is that "American strategic thinkers may have China in mind" as they promote the missile defenses.
Mr. Sha noted that even Washington's European allies are against the apparent American effort to insulate itself from nuclear dangers, fearing it could divide the alliance. "Not a single significant country in the world supports this plan," he said.
"We hope you'll give this up," Mr. Sha said. "If not, we'll be ready."

HEADLINE: S. Carolina House Backs Plan to Move Rebel Flag

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., May 10

 BODY:
The battle flag of the Confederacy, which has divided South Carolina from its perch atop its Statehouse since 1962, will come off the dome on July 1, under a tentative compromise reached late tonight by the state House of Representatives.
The bill, which the House passed by a vote of 63 to 56, has already been approved with minor differences by the Senate. It calls for a smaller, square version of the flag to be placed on a flagpole near the front of the Capitol, adjacent to a Confederate soldiers' memorial. House leaders and senators predicted few difficulties in ironing out the differences, and Gov. Jim Hodges has said he will sign the bill. 
 But the bill will by no means end the racial acrimony that had created such pressure for a compromise in the first place. Only 3 of 26 black members of the House voted for the bill, and many denounced it furiously as a plan that would make the flag an even more prominent feature of the state's official landscape. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which since last summer has been conducting an economic boycott of the state to get the flag moved, has said the plan is unacceptable, and has vowed to continue the sanctions.
Once the flag comes off the dome and out of the spotlight, however, it is unclear how effective the boycott will be. The N.A.A.C.P. had originally said the boycott would continue until the flag was lowered from the dome, and its opponents are now accusing it of changing its goals because it was not a participant in the compromise.
Many of the flag's longtime supporters said the move was a historic step forward for the state, which saw its reputation severely tarnished by the flag's presence in such a prominent position.
"This is a defining moment for our state, a giant step forward," said Speaker David H. Wilkins, a Republican, who had pushed hard for a compromise.
"This plan received support across party and racial lines," said Governor Hodges, a Democrat who was clearly relieved that the support for the plan in the House was not entirely white. "I believe South Carolinians will join together and embrace this compromise as an honorable way to resolve this debate once and for all."
He said he could not control what the N.A.A.C.P. did, but highly praised to the three black legislators who supported the bill.
Six of seven black senators had originally supported the bill, and one of their leaders, Senator Darrell Jackson, predicted that their votes would not change once the differences with the House bill were worked out. But Representative J. Todd Rutherford, a black House member who opposed the bill, predicted another debate over the new flag in next year's legislative session, vowing to propose legislation himself to move the flagpole away from the entrance.
"It's a historic occasion, no doubt about that," Mr. Rutherford said, after tonight's vote. "I'm just sorry that something this momentous has to occur without African-Americans being in the compromise."
The bill failed to get much black support precisely because it was designed to win the votes of white Republicans who had previously refused to even consider a vote on moving the flag. On Tuesday, Republicans angered black legislators by voting to make the flag even more prominent, raising it to 30 feet from the 20 feet in the Senate bill, and illuminating it at night. Those changes made it into the final House bill tonight, along with a provision mandating stiff penalties for anyone who vandalizes the flag or the monument. (This morning, officials had to remove spray-painted graffiti from the monument.)
The bill also removes the Confederate flags from the House and Senate chambers, where they have appeared next to the United States and South Carolina flags for decades.
The vote today came after nearly 10 hours of debate that starkly revealed the deep mistrust and animosity between the races in the House. Black leaders had hoped to support a plan that would move the flag from the Confederate memorial, but would also erect flagpoles bearing military banners to honor soldiers who fell in four 20th-century wars. Republican leaders would accept the plan only if it would fly the flag from the dome on Confederate Memorial Day every year, which by coincidence was today.
Hardliners on each side found those aspects unacceptable.
"To fly that flag for a day, even for an hour, even for a minute, is unacceptable to us," said Representative Joseph H. Neal, a black Democrat who said he would have supported the plan if not for the one-day-a-year provision. "It is not a sovereign flag, and it is an insult to people of color."
White Republicans who want to keep the flag on the dome picked apart the plan from the other end of the spectrum, criticizing it for not honoring soldiers in the Revolutionary War, or for being vague on which flags which symbolize certain wars. The majority leader, Richard M. Quinn Jr., a Republican who supported the proposal, said it was hurt when black members compared the Confederate flag to a swastika, and when a protester burned the flag in front of the Capitol shortly after noon.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
KEYNOTE WILL BUY VELOGIC SERVICES FOR $50 MILLION

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Keynote Systems Inc., which sells a service that gauges the performance of Web sites, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Velogic Inc. for about $50 million to add load-testing services for Internet sites. Keynote, based in San Mateo, Calif., is the largest provider of Internet performance-measurement services for electronic commerce Web sites. It will pay 850,000 shares for Velogic and will pay more cash or stock if certain performance goals are met. The acquisition price is based on Keynote's closing price on Tuesday. The shares of Keynote fell $5.75 each yesterday, to $43.25. Velogic provides a service that allows companies to determine how to reduce site shutdowns and improve performance during high-traffic periods.

HEADLINE: Take My Bills, Please;
Web Services Collect Those Painful Notices And Pay Your Debts, With Your Money

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT 

 BODY:
SUSAN MAC TAVISH BEST, a Webmaster in San Francisco, had a routine for paying her bills. She let them collect in piles, then dealt with them when the spirit moved her.
"I am incredibly unorganized and always pay my bills late," Miss MacTavish Best said. But she knew that she could not indulge her penchant for disorganization and procrastination during a three-month trek to India that began last September. 
 Then she heard a radio advertisement promoting a bill aggregator, a term that is coming into use to describe services that receive customers' bills, display them online for their customers to view and pay them from the customers' bank, savings or investment accounts.
Miss MacTavish Best used the advertised service, Paytrust, while she was away and continues to use it now, receiving an e-mail message when each bill comes in. She can look at any bill online, but she has told the service to pay some of them whether she looks at them or not, provided they are below a figure she has set for each. Other bills she reviews, then pays according to her old routine: when the spirit moves her.
"They send reminders, 'Bill due in three days,' 'Bill due in two days,' 'Bill due today,' " Miss MacTavish Best said. "Then -- I am so lazy -- I figure I'd better take care of it. I hit the link, and it's paid." Despite toying with fate, she said, she has not incurred a late fee since joining.
Bill-paying services are a step toward the day when everyone will receive and pay all their bills electronically. That day once seemed a long way off, when the concept of electronic billing was caught in a kind of economic Catch 22. Companies did not offer it because they did not see customers lining up to sign on. Customers did not sign on because there were no services offered. While online banks and other Web-based services developed to offer bill payments, most just write and mail checks in response to a customer's request that a payment be sent to a particular place. Few actually receive the bills for the customer.
Aggregators are taking the risk to develop the market. Companies like Paytrust (www.paytrust.com), PayMyBills (www.paymybills.com) and CyberBills (www.statusfactory.com) arrange to receive a client's bills, which they scan so clients can see them on the Web. They then organize the bills and pay them as directed. The companies charge users a monthly fee that ranges from $3.95 to $29.95, depending upon the number of bills paid.
Even with the fees, the companies are not yet making money. Handling people's bills is expensive; an army of employees opens envelopes by hand, puts the bills on a scanner and converts them into digital images. The companies are calculating that if they can deliver the customers, more merchants will automate the way they send out bills and collect payments, and the cost to provide the service will come down.
That possibility is enticing enough that online financial service providers like Quicken and portals like AOL say they plan to offer bill aggregation before the end of the summer. Others, like Spectrum EBP, a joint venture of Chase Manhattan, First Union and Wells Fargo, are working to develop a closely related service called bill presentment. In bill aggregation, paper bills are mailed to agencies; in bill presentment, all incoming bills are handled electronically.
Bill services' customers, like Miss MacTavish Best, can pay any bill at any time from anywhere. "I was in Delhi and I couldn't remember my password," Miss MacTavish Best said, "so I sent an e-mail and got an immediate response. I was sitting there in the cafe and we were e-mailing back and forth, having a conversation. There is a 12-hour difference so I was thinking, 'It's like 4 in the morning.' "
Bill-paying services do have their critics. Because the services need access to users' bank accounts, banks have raised privacy concerns. Union Trust once filed suit against an aggregator, Paytrust, to keep it from asking bank clients to share their online identification and passwords.
"If they have an unscrupulous employee, they could execute a trade, move your money, they could wipe you out," said Kellie Scott, senior vice president and director of eChannels, the e-commerce division of Union Trust. The suit was dropped, and now many banks and aggregators are working together to establish safe procedures for sharing information.
As with any new technology service, there are glitches. When a San Francisco public relations firm, pr@paiz.com, failed to put the proper code on a bill a client wanted to pay through PayMyBills, the firm never received the money. "We called over there and the bill was just sitting there," said Damon Paiz, a part-owner of the agency. "They didn't try to call us to say our bill was just sitting there. It was just very unprofessional." Since then, Mr. Paiz said, there have been no problems. A PayMyBills spokesman said the company had added a research team to handle payments for bills with incorrect codes.
The sites are not completely seamless for consumers. There are only about 30 companies -- most of them utilities and phone companies -- that accept electronic payments so to pay any other bill, the user must authorize the aggregator to make the payment at least five days in advance to give it time to go through the mail.
And although banks and bill-paying services are working on ways to share information, few arrangements have been set up. Most people who use an aggregator's services still have to visit their banks' Web sites if they want to check their balances before they approve a payment.
"I can't check my balances real time," said Brad Winney, who banks with Citibank and pays bills through Paytrust. "I have to go to my banking application." Mr. Winney said he was satisfied over all because he estimated that the service was saving him more than $1,000 in late fees each year.
Aggregators and banks say they are trying to make it easier for people to use bill-paying services.
"This is taking off faster than anyone expected," said Ms. Scott, of Union Trust. "I think it will all be pretty seamless by the end of next year."
Signing up with a service is fairly simple and takes about an hour overall. Most require a user to fill out an online form with information like the billing address, the bank account number and a password. Most then send a package in the mail with a form to sign that will allow the aggregator to take money from an account at a bank, savings and loan or brokerage. Most services allow multiple accounts, and payments can be drawn from any of them.
Paytrust has an accelerated sign-up system that lets users download a permission form and fax it back.
In a test, the form was processed and the account activated online in about four hours. Users can determine which bills are to be paid through the site.
Some companies say they have a similar automated system to change the address back if a client wants to go back to receiving bills at home.
Others, like CyberBills' Status Factory, leave it to the customer to alert billers to a change of address.
To save the user keystrokes, sites have compiled lists with the addresses and payment information for many banks and savings and loans, credit card companies and insurance and mortgage companies; those names can be added to a consumer's list with a few mouse clicks.
Paytrust notifies the companies sending bills that they should send them directly to the site. Some sites require users to mail change-of-address notices to billers, using stickers and envelopes included in the sign-up packages, to tell them to send bills to the aggregators.
The sites let users set up rules for paying each bill. For instance, a user can tell the site to pay the phone bill automatically on the 25th of each month if the amount due is less than $100. If it is more, the system will alert the user, who can then manually authorize a payment.
Check writing is not limited to financial companies. People can have checks sent to anyone by typing in the relevant information, just as they would for online banking.
"That lets us be the 100 percent solution for your monthly bills," said Tom Lazaroff, marketing director for PayMyBills.com. "You can pay your gardener, your dry cleaner, or send a check to Aunt Sally in Minnesota."
When a bill arrives, the user gets an e-mail notice. Reminders are sent by e-mail for unpaid bills that nearing their due date. A confirmation is sent by e-mail when a payment has been made.
Check information can be exported from the Web site into financial management programs like Quicken and Microsoft Money, as well as directly to spreadsheets.
The sites also archive payment information. Most said they would keep two years' worth of records on hand. And at the end of each year, the sites offer to sell clients their records on a CD. The CD's have scans of all the bills, a summary of billing categories and in some cases, feature a rudimentary ability to search for specific bills or information. The CD's are usually priced at $15 to $30.
The sites are sometimes a little quirky. The Paytrust site could not find an address for USAA Savings Bank, with USAA capitalized, but it found the name when it was lowercased. Also, the site would not allow two transactions in which the same amount was to go to the same biller on the same day so a user could not make two car payments with separate checks in one day.
The services are popular with technophile "early adopters," but they are still far from ubiquitous.
Paytrust, which says it is the largest of the aggregators, said it had 30,000 active members. PayMyBills and Status Factory declined to cite customer numbers.
Some potential customers may be concerned about security. "I was leery of Paytrust because you have to send to the bank letting Paytrust take out money," Mr. Winney said. To calm those qualms, Paytrust and PayMyBills are both insured by the Travellers Insurance Group Safeweb program, which protects users against unauthorized transactions up to $100,000. Status Factory, the retail Web site of CyberBills, promises to refund twice the amount of any loss to any customer using a 128-bit encrypted Web browser, like recent versions of Netscape's Navigator or Microsoft's Internet Explorer.
If payments are late because of the sites's errors, the companies will pay any late fees and get in touch with creditors. CyberBills' Status Factory will pay up to $1,000 for any bill that is late due to its error.
If nothing else, the sites offer one attractive and unadvertised bonus: they handle those advertisements that are sent along with your bills. "They are shredded," Mr. Lazaroff said, "and you don't have to look at junk mail."
 
What Does It Cost?
Bill-Paying Services Offer Consumers A Variety of Plans
Users like to say that bill aggregation services cost less than the stamps they used to mail out payments each month. That is not quite true -- but it is close. Here is what some services charge:
 
PAYTRUST: www.paytrust.com
Users can get started within hours. The cost is $8.95 a month for 25 transactions, 50 cents for each additional transaction and an optional $14.95 for a year's financial records on a CD.
 
PAYMYBILLS: www.paymybills.com
In addition to paying their bills, users can also analyze their spending habits, a big help when budgeting. PayMyBills charges $8.95 for 25 transactions a month, 50 cents for each additional transaction and $24.95 for a year's financial records on a CD.
 
CYBERBILLS: www.statusfactory.com
CyberBills offers double your money back for an unauthorized transaction, provided you use a secure browser. It offers three levels of service, starting at $3.50 a month for five transactions. The mid-level service costs $8.95 for 30 transactions and 75 cents for each additional transaction. Basic plan users who exceed five transactions are automatically switched to the mid-level service. The premium service is $29.95 a month for unlimited transactions. A year-end CD is $49.50 for the low- and mid-level service, and free with the premium service.

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART;
Barkless Puppy In Tree's Place

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
Rockefeller Center is famous for the 100-foot Christmas tree it installs every year. Now, over the next few weeks, another large but definitely cuter silhouette will take its place: a 43-foot terrier puppy made of flowers will go up in front of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, in the same spot where the tree stands.
"Puppy," by Jeff Koons, the 1980's art star, was created in 1992 for a temporary exhibition in Arolsen, a small town about 40 minutes by car from Kassel, Germany, where it stood in the center of a courtyard of a Baroque palace. It was shown in Sydney in 1996, and an identical puppy (with different flowers suitable to its climate and location) stands in front of the Guggenheim Bilbao in Spain as part of the permanent collection. 
 "Puppy" has never been seen in New York until now. The installation, -- a three-week process that involves about 100 people, ranging from riggers to planters and engineers, all directed by Mr. Koons -- begins early next week. "Puppy" will be on view through Labor Day.
"We continue to look for ways to enhance the public space at Rockefeller Center," said Jerry Speyer, president of Tishman Speyer Properties, which is co-owner and manager of Rockefeller Center. "It's a great work of art, and I thought it would be wonderful to show it here."
Last year Rockefeller Center presented an outdoor exhibition of Rodin sculptures. It has also had a car show and a flower show. "This is a different kind of flower show," said Mr. Speyer, adding that he expected about three million visitors to view "Puppy."
Putting the sculpture together is no easy task. Rockefeller Center asked the Public Art Fund, a nonprofit group that puts together exhibitions around the city, to organize the project. "Puppy" had to travel by ship and train from Sydney, a journey that took about a month and a half.
The installation is so complex because the work is formed from a series of stainless-steel armatures built to hold more than 25 tons of soil. An internal irrigation system waters more than 70,000 flowering plants, including marigolds, begonias, impatiens, petunias and lobelias from different nurseries on Long Island.
"We think this is one of the great sculptures of our time," said Susan K. Freedman, president of the Public Art Fund. "Rockefeller Center is the perfect backdrop to show it."
 
The Mass MOCA Boom
When the $37 million Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, known simply as Mass MOCA, opened about a year ago on a 13-acre campus in the depressed town of North Adams, in the northwest corner of the state, it was understood that the project would create about 100 new jobs and attract scores of visitors to a blue-collar town that had always been overshadowed by neighboring Williamstown. But a year after its opening, the boom created by the arts center has far exceeded expectations.
"This is certainly an example of how a cultural institution can lead the charge," said Joseph C. Thompson, director of the museum. Besides attracting more than 100,000 visitors, the interdisciplinary art center has created more than 200 jobs, he said.
When Mass MOCA opened, the site, once the home of the Sprague Electric Company, was so large that the institution could develop 20,000 square feet of office space, which it has rented. It has added 15,000 more square feet of office space over the last year. Because its tenants, primarily fast-growing technology companies, are attracting like-minded businesses to the Berkshires, it is renovating an additional 34,000 square feet, all of which has already been leased. Rents have more than doubled.
"Berkshire County has become a hotbed for e-commerce," Mr. Thompson said. "It's known as Silicon Village." One attraction, he said, is that these office spaces were purposely outfitted with what he described as "plug and ready" equipment to attract e-commerce companies. Downtown has benefited from Mass MOCA's presence, too. The business district had a 70 percent vacancy rate before the museum opened; now, the rate is 30 percent, Mr. Thompson said. Developers plan to take some of the land adjacent to the museum and erect more offices and a hotel.
All the tenants on the museum's campus are helping to raise revenues, which are channeled back into the arts complex. That is the difference between Mass MOCA and other cultural institutions that have helped economically depressed areas, like the Guggenheim Bilbao, which has given a boost to the Basque region of Spain, or Dia Center for the Arts in Manhattan, which has contributed to the boom in Chelsea. "The difference is that we benefit directly from our real estate," Mr. Thompson said. "It's our endowment."
 
Tony Smith Estate
Tony Smith died 20 years ago, but his estate still holds a significant body of his work. Smith, best known for his huge black modular sculptures, began to exhibit these works in the mid-1960's, when he was 48. Before that, he was both an architect and a painter.
For years Paula Cooper represented his estate, but it will now be handled by Matthew Marks, the Chelsea dealer, and Lucy Mitchell-Innes, whose gallery, Mitchell-Innes & Nash, is on the Upper East Side.
"Jane Smith felt it was time for a change," said John Silberman, the estate's lawyer, speaking for the artist's widow. Mr. Marks and Ms. Mitchell-Innes also represent the de Kooning estate, which he handles.
"Considering he was not a prolific artist and died relatively young, the estate is surprisingly rich in top-quality work," Mr. Marks said of Smith. He organized a show of the artist's drawings five years ago. "There are lots of wonderful paintings, some dating from the 1930's, and a surprising number of sculptures, too."
Both galleries plan to organize shows over the next two years.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Declined 0.2 Percent Last Month

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Sales at the nation's retailers fell in April for the first time in a year and a half as consumers took a breather after three months in which they spent at the fastest rate in 17 years, government figures showed today.
Retail sales decreased 0.2 percent last month, to a seasonally adjusted $266 billion, as gas stations, clothing stores and building material suppliers reported declines in purchases, the Commerce Department said. The drop, the first since August 1998, came after a 0.5 percent increase in March that was stronger than the government had estimated. 
Still, April sales were 9.7 percent higher than those in April 1999, suggesting that consumer spending will continue to power the economy in the months ahead.
Federal Reserve policy makers have expressed concern about the strength of consumer demand and are expected to raise the overnight bank lending rate by half a percentage point when they meet on Tuesday.
Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of economic output in the United States and has fueled an expansion that is now in its 10th year. Spending has been bolstered by a 30-year low in the unemployment rate, by consumer confidence close to record levels and by rising incomes.
A separate Labor Department report today added evidence that jobs are easy to find. The number of workers filing new claims for state unemployment benefits fell 7,000, to 297,000, last week after rising 22,000 the previous week.
In another report today, the Labor Department said that prices of imported goods fell 1.6 percent in April, the first decline in 10 months, paced by lower oil costs. Prices of imports excluding oil rose 0.1 percent. This is the first of three price reports to be released before the Fed meets, and it suggests that declining oil costs could start to ease inflation concerns.
The April decline in retail sales was a surprise to economists, who had forecast a 0.5 percent increase. Still, the level of sales was close to the $267 billion analysts had expected.

HEADLINE: U.S. Growth of 4.5% Projected in 2000

BYLINE: AFX News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
In its annual review of the nation's economy, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that it expected annual growth of 4.5 percent this year -- above the 3.5 percent pace that it said the economy could grow without leading to higher inflation.
A number of indicators have already suggested that price increases are picking up, including higher import prices and labor costs, the organization said. 
 Because of this, it said that the Federal Open Market Committee should raise short-term interest rates by at least 1 percentage point by the end of the summer to avoid sending inflation higher.
"With demand growth remaining well above the enhanced rate of growth potential, some further tightening of monetary policy is needed," the organization said.
It said it expected the Federal funds rate, the benchmark interest rate on overnight loans between banks, to rise to 7 percent from 6 percent by the end of the summer. But the organization noted that it was still uncertain how high interest rates would need to rise to slow the economy, given that gains on investments continue to provide incentives for businesses to borrow.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Report on Retail Slowdown Calms Nerves of Investors

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks rose broadly yesterday after a report of a slowdown in retail sales calmed investors who have been selling stocks amid fears about rising interest rates. Blue chip shares led the advance.
The Dow Jones industrial average was up 178.19 points, or 1.7 percent, to 10,545.97. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 114.85 points, or 3.4 percent, to 3,499.58. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 24.76 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,407.81. 
 But volume remained light, leaving market analysts unconvinced of the rally's underlying strength.
"We had a really rough start to the week," said Bob Dickey, managing director of technical analysis at Dain Rauscher Wessels. "So at this point, calling this an oversold bounce is about as bullish as we can get."
Still, the market's gains were sparked by good news on the economic front. Stocks rose after the Commerce Department said retail sales fell 0.2 percent in April. Economists had expected an increase of 0.4 percent.
Analysts were quick to cite bad weather in April that kept many Americans out of the stores. But the decline raised some hopes that the Federal Reserve's series of interest rate increases is succeeding in slowing consumer spending.
The Fed is widely expected to raise interest rates again at its meeting on Tuesday. Economists are divided on whether the central bankers will stick to their strategy of raising rates by a quarter-percentage point at a time or whether they will opt for an increase of half a percentage point this time.
The retail sales report alone will not dissuade the Fed from the half-point increase, analysts said.
"It appears that the volatile stock market and higher interest rates have started to slow consumer spending," said Stan Shipley, senior economist at Merrill Lynch. "However, this one-month slowdown should not derail the Fed."
Rate-sensitive stocks rose after the retail sales report was released. J. P. Morgan increased 5, to 127 5/8, and Citigroup rose 2 1/2, to 58 15/16.
Intel, which fell sharply on Wednesday, rebounded, with the strongest gain among all 30 Dow components. Intel soared 9 1/2, to 115 9/16.
Bargain-hunting opportunities lured some investors into the technology sector, which has been battered in recent sessions.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Mixed
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices were mixed yesterday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 3/32, to 101 16/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.14 percent from 6.15 percent on Wednesday. The price of the 10-year note rose 3/32, to 100 22/32. The bond's yield fell to 6.40 percent from 6.42 percent on Wednesday. The two-year note fell 1/32, to 99 7/32, while its yield rose to 6.80 percent from 6.79 percent.

HEADLINE: Union Leader Warns Gore On Support For China Bill

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
The president of the United Steelworkers of America, one of the nation's most powerful trade unions, said today that organized labor's support for Vice President Al Gore could be hurt by his recent lobbying for the China trade deal.
George Becker, the Steelworkers' president, who played a pivotal role in getting the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to endorse the vice president, said he was angry that Mr. Gore was lobbying hard for the China deal after telling labor leaders that his views on trade would differ from President Clinton's. 
 "We are not going to be forgiving on this," Mr. Becker said. "Our members are not."
Mr. Becker declined to say what action, if any, his union might take because of its unhappiness with Mr. Gore's trade stance, but he said the vice president's position might alienate many supporters in his union.
Most labor leaders have not publicly criticized Mr. Gore's support of the deal, which calls for permanently normalizing trade relations with China. Many labor leaders say that while they disagree with the vice president, they agree with him on most other issues and do not want to undercut his chances in November.
Organized labor has made defeating the bill its top legislative priority, arguing that it would be wrong to normalize relations with a country where there are widespread human rights and labor rights violations.
Douglas Hattaway, a spokesman for the Gore campaign, said the vice president is sympathetic to the Steelworkers' concerns and plans to continue working with the labor movement on a range of issues that affect working families. "At the same time, he's been very clear about his position on this issue from the day he was endorsed by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. last October," Mr. Hattaway said. "He believes the agreement is good for workers and good for the economy."
Mr. Becker made his remarks on a day when President Clinton predicted that the House would approve the China deal. Mr. Clinton told a radio interviewer, "I think we'll get the votes, because I think it's the right thing for the country."
The House is scheduled to vote on the China bill the week of May 22, and the Senate, which lawmakers say will easily approve the measure, is expected to vote next month.
Republican leaders in the House sought yesterday to bolster support for the bill by saying they were likely to back a bipartisan proposal that would set up a commission to monitor human rights in China. Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, an Illinois Republican, and Majority Leader Dick Armey, a Texas Republican, said they were close to a deal that would enable them to support the proposal.
Representative Sander M. Levin, a Michigan Democrat, working closely with Representative Doug Bereuter, a Nebraska Republican, proposed such a commission as a way to secure more backing for the trade deal.
Mr. Becker said he believed that the China bill would have a far more difficult chance of gaining House approval if Mr. Gore were not lobbying for it. "This is a pretty close vote, and if he makes the difference in this, and we lose, I think there'll be a hell of a price to pay," Mr. Becker said.
At the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention last October, he said, many labor leaders felt more confident about endorsing Mr. Gore after he promised, if elected, to place more emphasis on worker rights in negotiating trade agreements than President Clinton has.
"I would have expected him under the circumstances to keep out of the way on this," Mr. Becker said. "He's twisting arms. He's putting himself in a position where he's directly opposed to where we're going."
Mr. Becker voiced a concern that many labor leaders have been murmuring for weeks. Many say they are finding it hard to excite union members to vote for and campaign for Mr. Gore when he is battling them on labor's No. 1 legislative issue.
One House Democrat whom Mr. Gore has lobbied, Bob Clement of Tennessee, announced today that he would vote against the China bill. Another Democrat, Juanita Millender-McDonald of California, also announced her opposition. But Representative Ken Bentsen, a Texas Democrat, announced his support for the bill, saying he was encouraged by a White House plan to set up a commission that would study the problems of displaced workers.
Some opponents assert that Mr. Gore is lobbying so hard to show that he is willing to take a stand unpopular with many supporters.
In an interview with Diane Rehm, a Washington-based talk-show host, Mr. Clinton said yesterday that Mr. Gore's stance on China would help the vice president politically.
"Even though some of the strongest elements of the Democratic Party and some of our best friends are on the other side of this fight, it shows he's willing to take an independent stand to do what he believes is right," Mr. Clinton said.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Rental Tower Seeks to Ride Times Square Wave

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
When leasing begins tomorrow for the 921 rental apartments at the 40-story brick-and-glass tower at 42nd Street and the Hudson River, it will be a milestone in the 16-year journey Larry Silverstein has been on since he first envisioned the project in 1984.
Mr. Silverstein, president of Silverstein Properties of Manhattan, is developing the $225 million building -- the first of two towers planned for his River Place development on the full block between 11th and 12th Avenues -- in anticipation of the renewal that he expects to wash over the stretch of 42nd Street west of Eighth Avenue. Mr. Silverstein always anticipated that the redevelopment of Times Square, now awash with millions of square feet of new and proposed office space, would ignite the need for housing nearby. 
 "The site's proximity to the river and to the planned office space three blocks east propelled this development," Mr. Silverstein said. "Little did I know it would take until 1999 to get started." In the intervening years, the developer waited out a rezoning of the site from industrial use, an unsuccessful lawsuit concerning the change, the recession and the political debate over proposals to use the site for expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
The waiting ended last July when the developer, using financing from a consortium of lenders led by the Bank of New York as well as his own equity, started building the first tower, 1 River Place. Because the developer is receiving a 20-year tax abatement from the city under its 421a tax abatement program, 20 percent of the units will be for tenants with maximum annual incomes of $25,545 to $47,770, depending on family size.
The building, where occupancy will start in July, is the first rental project for Mr. Silverstein. Though his company is best known as a commercial developer, it has also either built or converted at least 3,000 co-op or condominium units. The company's office buildings include 7 World Trade Center, with two million square feet of space, and 140 Broadway, with 1.2 million square feet
Mr. Silverstein is stocking 1 River Place with smaller apartments: studio, one- and two-bedroom units with 360 to 1,202 square feet. Because Costas Kondylis, the Manhattan architect, designed the building with multiple angles and ribbon windows, the units have unusual layouts and clear city and river views.
Mr. Silverstein said he also stressed amenities, including valet parking for 200 cars, 40,000 square feet of retail space, a cafe and high-tech wiring. There will also be a 34,000-square-foot fitness center, including a gym, an Olympic-size pool, two outdoor tennis courts, a slightly-smaller-than-regulation indoor basketball court, a 2,500-square-foot special events room and three sun decks.
Monthly rents for the market-rate units will start at $1,650 for studios, $2,100 for one-bedroom units and $3,300 for two bedrooms, said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a rental brokerage firm in Manhattan and the project's leasing agent. Monthly rents for the moderate-income units will be $639 to $822.
While 1 River Place is the largest residential project in the four-block West 42nd Street area -- now a hodgepodge of buildings, including warehouses and parking lots -- it will not be the last. At least four more apartment towers are planned, helping to restart the area's revival.
The proposed projects include a 40-story apartment building with 260 rentals over six theaters at 42nd Street and Dyer Avenue, between Ninth and 10th Avenues, that the Brodsky Organization in partnership with Quinlan & Field Inc., both of Manhattan, expects to start next month. Twenty percent of the units will be for tenants with limited incomes. The project also calls for the development of a new 499-seat Shubert theater and five new or rebuilt smaller theaters.
In 10 months to a year, the Durst Organization together with the Brodsky Organization also plans to build a rental tower, with 200 to 250 mixed-income units, at the northeast corner of Ninth Avenue and 42nd Street. And the second tower at River Place "will probably be residential," Mr. Silverstein, said, adding that construction could start as soon as 2001.
The new buildings will join the New Gotham, a 374-unit mixed-income rental that led the way for the current residential surge when it opened two years ago between 10th and 11th Avenues and 42nd and 43rd Streets. The building was fully leased in seven months, according to the Gotham Organization of Manhattan, the developer.
The far west 40's is still on the edge as a residential area, said Cathe LeBlanc, managing director of the rental division at the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan brokerage firm. "And beyond 10th Avenue, which is farther away from the necessary residential services tenants require, such as food stores and restaurants," she added, "new construction must offer units that are priced to draw people there and have amenities within to service them."
Mr. Silverstein is upbeat about the project's prospects. "There is more than enough demand given the influx of professionals to take all the planned apartments," he said, "and we will get our share."

HEADLINE: Denver's Newspapers, Long at War, Now Plan to Publish Jointly

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
After losing $123 million since 1990 in an unsuccessful effort to win the country's fiercest newspaper war, the owners of The Rocky Mountain News in Denver announced yesterday that they intended to combine their business operations with those of The Denver Post, effectively ceding victory to The Post's owner, William Dean Singleton.
The agreement ending the war would leave the Denver area with two newspapers that would compete journalistically but split their profits equally. To gain its 50 percent share, the E. W. Scripps Company, the owner of The News, is paying $60 million to Mr. Singleton's MediaNews Group, the owner of The Post. 
 The proposed joint operating agreement is subject to Justice Department approval, under the terms of a 30-year-old law that allows newspapers to skirt antitrust provisions to maintain two editorial voices in a community. If approved, the Denver arrangement would be the first new joint operating agreement in the country in 11 years.
Kenneth W. Lowe, president and chief operating officer of Scripps, said at a news conference yesterday that the losses, averaging more than $12 million a year, were "not a situation Scripps could sustain." Scripps is a public company with broad interests in newspapers, broadcast television stations and cable television channels like the Food Network. MediaNews is privately held.
The two newspapers together employ more than 3,600 people, with 1,785 at The News and 1,870 at The Post. In a news release , Scripps said, "It is currently anticipated that any need to eliminate positions will be done primarily through attrition."
The announcement, made after the close of the New York Stock Exchange, brought gloom to the newsroom of The News, an upscale tabloid. In recent years, the newspaper has expanded its business coverage and competed fiercely on breaking news like the killing of JonBenet Ramsey, last year's killings at Columbine High School and the sale of a local sports arena. "People are upset," one reporter said.
Each newspaper won a Pulitzer Prize for Columbine coverage last year. The Post won in the breaking news category, The News for breaking news photography.
The aggressive editorial competition was matched, or exceeded, by an economic competition that led both newspapers to lower their subscription prices to as little as a penny, cutting circulation revenues by as much as two-thirds.
The low prices, which began almost three years ago, helped pump up the two newspapers' circulations. The latest daily figures -- 446,465 for The News and 413,720 for The Post -- put both in the ranks of the country's top 25 daily newspapers.
But The News could not translate its circulation gains, including a 25 percent increase in the most recent report from the Audit Bureau of Circulations, into profits, Mr. Lowe said yesterday. He said the paper had enjoyed only "a modest increase in advertising." Scripps also, he said, has "not been able to turn circulation gains into operating profits."
William R. Burleigh, Scripps' chief executive, was to travel today to Washington to give the Justice Department a statement declaring The News "in probable danger of financial failure," Mr. Lowe said.
Both The News and The Post would continue their current daily publication schedules. On Saturday, The News's editorial staff would produce a broadsheet newspaper under both nameplates. The Post's newsroom would produce the Sunday newspaper, the best-read newspaper of the week. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Clinton Asks Congress to Raise the Limit on Visas for Skilled Workers

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Racing to keep up with a booming economy, President Clinton today proposed an increase of more than 85 percent in the number of skilled foreign workers who could be admitted to the United States to fill job openings in high-technology industries.
Mr. Clinton asked Congress to provide 200,000 visas for such workers in each of the next three years. The existing law, adopted in 1998, limits the number of such visas to 107,500 in 2001. After that, under existing law, the ceiling will fall back to 65,000 a year, the level in effect before Congressional action in 1998. 
 In January 1998, the Clinton administration said it did not support an increase in the number of visas. But the president, under pressure from Congress and the computer industry, agreed to support a modest increase six months later. Since then, technology companies say, the demand for computer programmers, engineers and other skilled workers has outstripped the supply and exceeded official expectations.
Many in Congress favor an even bigger increase than the one Mr. Clinton proposed today. Congress therefore appears likely to approve a substantial increase in the number of visas, known as H-1B visas, for high-technology workers.
Robert Cohen, senior vice president of the Information Technology Association of America, an industry group, welcomed the president's proposal.
"It's very encouraging that the White House sees the need to raise the cap," Mr. Cohen said. "The administration understands better now than in 1998 that information technology gives an incredible push to the overall economy. But the number of visas proposed by the administration is probably not adequate. We would be pleased to see the cap eliminated, so the marketplace could decide how many people are needed to get the job done."
Nations in Europe and Asia are competing for the same pool of high-technology workers. And Senator Spencer Abraham, Republican of Michigan, said some American companies would "move their operations overseas, taking American jobs with them," if they could not get the workers they needed here.
India provides by far the largest number of skilled foreign workers under the H-1B visa program. Its citizens received 47 percent of such visas issued in the last year. The next largest share went to China, with 9 percent.
Gene Sperling, the president's economic policy adviser, set forth Mr. Clinton's proposal in a letter to Congress.
The best way to increase the supply of skilled workers is to improve the education and training of United States citizens and other people already in the country, Mr. Sperling said.
"However," he said, "at times, U.S. businesses need additional access to the international labor market to maintain and enhance our global competitiveness, particularly in high-growth new technology industries and particularly in tight labor markets."
Mr. Sperling said the previous increase in the number of H-1B visas had proved inadequate because "our economy has grown beyond anyone's most optimistic predictions."
Representative Lamar Smith, the Texas Republican who heads the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, was skeptical, saying, "There is still no objective, credible study that documents a shortage of American high-tech workers."
Michael W. Gildea, a policy analyst in the professional employee division of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said: "We would have preferred no increase in the number of visas. We see no credible evidence of widespread shortages of information technology workers."
Mr. Sperling said technology companies appeared to have difficulty finding workers with the necessary skills. But he added, "The lack of clear data suggests that it's best to offer a temporary solution, and to make that solution contingent on an increase in spending for the education and training of American workers."
Mr. Clinton proposed a sharp increase in the fees charged to employers who use the foreign worker program. He said the fee for an H-1B visa, now $500, should be raised to $2,000 for most employers, with a visa fee of $3,000 for companies that depend heavily on skilled foreign workers.
The president said he would use the fees to help pay for the training of American workers, especially those who are underrepresented in the information technology industry, like women, blacks and Hispanics.

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Computer Model on Auto Pollution Is Flawed, Study Says

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency's computer model for predicting how much air pollution comes from cars and trucks underestimates emissions and may overestimate the benefits of some pollution-control strategies, the National Academy of Sciences said in a report today.
The report did not say how far off the model is, but it said the model "substantially" underestimates emissions of unburned fuel from cars and nitrogen oxides from trucks, both major ingredients of smog. And the model may overestimate the value of dashboard lights to warn of pollution control problems and of the value of ethanol and gasoline additives intended to reduce emissions, the study said. 
 "The decisions that rely on the results of this model are of tremendous importance to human health, the environment and the economy," the report said in explaining the value of accurate computer predictions.
One member of the committee that wrote the report, Dr. Laurence S. Caretto, dean of the College of Engineering and Computer Science at California State University at Northridge, said the investigators questioned whether the Environmental Protection Agency was "looking at the right things" in creating a model. A more accurate model would indicate which pollution-control strategies to pursue, he said.
The agency developed the program, the Mobile Source Emissions Factor Model, known as Mobile, in 1978 and has revised it intermittently since then. The study said it was "the central tool used by environmental and transportation agencies to estimate on-road mobile-emissions and to assess national, state and local air-quality programs for controlling such emissions."
A spokesman for the agency, David Cohen, said the study was "constructive, fair and balanced," and made good recommendations. Agency officials noted that they were sometimes accused of setting emissions rules that were too stringent, but that the study seemed to say they might be too lax.
The committee said the environmental agency was in the dark on some crucial issues, like the reaction of drivers to what is colloquially known as the "idiot light," the federally required warning light on the dashboard that illuminates when a car's computer senses a problem.
"The committee is unaware of any studies conducted to assess the motorist response to illuminated malfunction indicator lights, although this response rate is one of the most important factors for determining the effectiveness of on-board diagnostic systems in reducing emissions," the report said.
The agency, the report said, also needs to know more about "high-emitting vehicles" -- cars and trucks with smoking tailpipes -- that are believed to be the source of a large portion of pollution.
Pollution regulators should also pay more attention to off-road sources of emissions, the report said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ford Acknowledges Risks Of Sport Utility Vehicles
Ford Motor, which depends on sport utility vehicles for much of its profits, acknowledged that they cause serious safety and environmental problems. Ford said that the vehicles contributed more than cars to global warming, emitted more smog-causing pollution and endangered other motorists.
Ford said that it would keep building them because they are so profitable but would seek technological solutions and look for alternatives to the big vehicles. William C. Ford Jr., the company's chairman, depicted the company's statements as a combination of altruism and long-term business planning. Page A1. 

Increase in Foreign Workers Urged
Racing to keep up with a booming economy, President Clinton proposed an increase of more than 85 percent in the number of skilled foreign workers who could be admitted to the United States to fill job openings in the high-technology industries. A16.
 
Merrill Lynch Joins the Perks Parade
Merrill Lynch has joined the rush of Wall Street firms offering new perks and risk-free investment opportunities to attract young investment bankers and prevent others from defecting to Internet companies. Merrill is building a new fitness center for employees and providing a concierge service. The firm also hopes to lock in investment bankers by giving them chances to invest in new-economy companies that are still private. C2.
 
Denver Papers in Joint Agreement
The Denver Rocky Mountain News announced that it intended to combine its business operations with those of The Denver Post. The agreement, which would end the nation's fiercest newspaper war, would leave the Denver area with two newspapers that would compete journalistically but split their profits. A21.
 
Stocks Climb, With Nasdaq Up 3.4%
Stocks climbed after a report of a slowdown in retail sales calmed investors who have been selling stocks amid fears about rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 178.19 points, or 1.7 percent, to 10,545.97. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 114.85 points, or 3.4 percent, to 3,499.58, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 24.76 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,407.81. C8.
 
Profit Rises 21% at Dell Computer
Dell Computer posted a 21 percent increase in first-quarter profit, beating Wall Street expectations, as it benefited from a richer mix of products, with particular strength in sales of servers and storage devices for Internet use. Before Dell reported its results, its shares closed down 25 cents, to $44.6875. After hours, Dell rose as high as $47.625. C6.
 
In Spain, Olive-Fueled Electricity
In Spain, olives are being transmuted into a fuel. For the last three years, farmers around one olive-growing hamlet have delivered the residue of olive oil production to a specially designed power station, where it is burned to produce electricity, thus reducing Spain's reliance on imported oil. C4.
 
Retail Sales Dropped 0.2% in April
Sales at the nation's retailers fell 0.2 percent in April, the first time in a year and a half, as consumers took a breather after three months in which they spent at the fastest rate in 17 years, government figures showed. C5.
 
Y.& R. Chief Expected to Depart
Young & Rubicam's president and chief executive, Thomas D. Bell Jr., will most likely step down from the advertising agency after it is acquired by WPP Group, executives close to the negotiations said. Both companies were working to complete the deal. C20.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Parallel Universe

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
When the Industrial Revolution came along it shaped the contours of several U.S. elections. Although our current election comes at the dawn of the information and biotech revolutions, you'd never quite know it from the presidential campaign, which has been almost a parallel universe, operating on its own news and historical logic. It has been characterized either by the arcane -- the Confederate flag and Bob Jones -- or by the evergreens -- Social Security, campaign finance reform, abortion and gun control. There is a general sense that not much is at stake in this election, and that we have entered an era of good feelings and tiny differences.
This is an illusion. My gut tells me that by 2008 we will look back at the Clinton years as a fool's paradise -- the quiet interlude after the cold war and before all the forces unleashed by e-commerce, the biotech revolution, the information revolution and global integration reached their critical mass and ushered in a period of radically new political choices and issues in U.S. and global politics. 
 Look at the headlines on the eve of this 2000 election: The "love bug" virus, launched by a student in the Philippines, wipes out in a few hours millions of dollars' worth of files on 10 million computers all over the world.
The next day we read that the Internet is giving way to the Evernet, meaning that anything with electricity is having chips embedded in it -- from pagers to toasters to cars -- and connected to networks. The new Mercedes 500 has more computing power in it than the 747-200. Not only will this mean that you will always be able to surf the Web everywhere, but it is also going to mean that the Web will be able to surf you, and know where you are, and what you are consuming, everywhere all the time. And the faster and more diffused networks become, the more vulnerable we all are, not to Big Brother but to the Little Brothers -- the Web site, the video store, the hacker, the credit card company that can amass and sell your personal data with little government restraint. This is going to raise huge privacy issues.
And if, as The Times reported Wednesday, "Freenet" technology really comes about it will be possible to acquire or exchange any kind of digitized music, book, video, software or data over the Internet, without paying any royalty to any publisher, filmmaker or anyone. It could mean the end of copyright.
The next day we read that we are soon going to have a single, global 24-hour stock market. Regulated by whom? And the next day we find that the 10-year project to decode the human genome, the operating manual for how human beings are constructed, is about to be completed, giving us the ability not only to cure disease in a new way but also to design offspring and change human nature.
"The biotech revolution raises big moral issues that scream out for international governance and a common agreement on rules," notes Francis Fukuyama, author of "The End of History." We don't want to just leave this to the market and have people designing babies in the Cayman Islands, he adds, but there is no global means to regulate this yet.
Indeed, what all these issues have in common is that we will all be affected by these radical changes, and they can really only be regulated through global institutions, but none exist today. We are all increasingly connected, but nobody's quite in charge. And when everyone is more tightly connected, but not everyone is more tightly governed, small units can wreak large havoc -- the love bug. Which is why this new era is going to actually demand more global governance, not less. But how and in what form?
These issues have not quite ripened into hard political choices yet, so one can't fault the candidates for not discussing them frontally. But as society is reshaped by these forces, and the future becomes the present, this era of small differences will burst right open.
Maybe we could have three debates this season. One would be called "Mudslinging," during which both candidates could unleash any lie, exaggeration or personal attack against the other. The next could be called "Golden Oldies," which would focus on the still relevant evergreens, from Social Security to abortion. And lastly, we could have the "Tomorrowland" debate, in which each candidate would have to present his thoughts on the new issues that will actually be shaping his presidency before it's over.
