HEADLINE: Putting 'That Great Street' Back Into State Street

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHAROFF 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
AFTER 20 years of on-again off-again urban-renewal efforts, State Street, which was for generations Chicago's premier retail area, appears ready to reclaim its heritage.
Last month, the JMB Realty Corporation unveiled plans for a new $251 million mixed-use project on a square block across from the landmark Marshall Field's department store. The project will include a five-story retail mall anchored by a Lord & Taylor department store, a 34-story tower containing condominiums and a Marriott Suites Hotel. 
 The project, which is to break ground by the end of the year and is expected to be finished in stages starting in 2002, is the climax of what has already been an extraordinary year on the street.
Directly across Randolph Street from JMB Realty's project, a new theater and dormitory complex for the School of the Art Institute is nearing completion. It includes a 17-story tower as well as a renovated former office building that will have 34,000 square feet of retail space.
Several blocks to the south, Sears, Roebuck & Company, which has been absent from State Street for 17 years, is preparing to open a large new store on the first five floors of a recently renovated office building.
In addition, a number of national chains and local retailers, ranging from Kinko's and Radio Shack to Potbelly Sandwich Works and Nuts on Clark, a candy and nut shop, have recently signed leases in other buildings on the street.
"If you look at State in four years," said Tyrone Tabing, an assistant planning commissioner and the point man for the redevelopment of the street, "it will be a dramatically different street than it is today. And it's dramatically different now than it was four years ago."
That may be an understatement. In the early 90's, State Street "was being kept alive on a ventilator," said Bruce Kaplan, the president of the Northern Realty Group Ltd., a large real estate company in the Loop. "It was in horrendous condition," he added.
After a century-long run as the most prominent retail district in Chicago, if not the Midwest, State Street went into a decline in the 1970's and 80's. That decline was brought on by the rise of suburban shopping and the simultaneous development of nearby North Michigan Avenue as the new retailer to the carriage trade.
Contributing significantly to State Street's decline was the urban-renewal project in 1979 that closed the street to vehicles and turned it into an enormous -- and usually deserted -- pedestrian mall.
By the early 80's, State Street, which had boasted seven major department stores a decade earlier, was down to two: Marshall Field's and Carson Pirie Scott. What little specialty retailing that remained was increasingly of the fast-food and adult-bookstore variety.
There matters stood until the early 90's, when two things happened. The first was a housing boom, which resulted in some 12,000 new apartments in and around the Loop. The second was the city's willingness to jump-start the redevelopment process on State Street. It approved $44 million in incentive grants to 10 developers, and in 1996, a $25 million streetscape improvement project that reopened State Street to auto traffic, spruced it up with numerous planters and added lampposts and subway entrances with a turn-of-the-century look.
The results have been striking. Statistics complied by the Northern Realty Group show that annual rents for retail space on State Street have doubled in the last five years, to $52 a square foot, while the vacancy rate is just under 3 percent.
THE street currently has 2.5 million square feet of retail space; 1.6 million of that is accounted for by Marshall Field's and Carson Pirie Scott. In addition, another 750,000 square feet is currently under construction or on the drawing boards.
"Retail is driving the street, and it's driving it harder every week," said J. Paul Beitler, the chairman of Douglas Elliman-Beitler, the developer of the Sears project. Mr. Beitler is also the developer, along with the Prime Group, of Dearborn Center, a new 1.8 million-square-foot, 37-story office building under way at the corner of State and Adams Streets, which will have 100,000 square feet of retail space.
"The Loop is becoming a 24/7 living environment, and people need somewhere to shop," Mr. Beitler said. "State has become a community center. The whole emphasis is on providing the kinds of goods and services that you find in the suburbs."
The Sears project is often mentioned by developers and real estate brokers as an example of what State Street will be like in the future. Sears opened its first store on State Street in 1932, at the corner of State and Van Buren Streets. The building still exists, but it is now occupied by Robert Morris College, a business school. The new Sears store, which is scheduled to open next spring, is four blocks farther north, at the corner of State and Madison Streets and diagonally across State Street from Carson Pirie Scott.
"I think State Street customers tend to be a little more mainstream and mass America than those on Michigan Avenue," said Milton Mooney, the senior vice president for Sears stores in the north-central region. "We're going to merchandise the space in a way that will play to the strengths of that market."
The store, which is costing about $30 million, will have 250,000 square feet of space, about twice as much as an average new Sears store, Mr. Mooney said.
The just-announced Lord & Taylor project is also being described as one that will harmonize with the newly residential character of the Loop. The project brings to a close a troubled chapter in the street's redevelopment. JMB has owned the site for over a decade, and it has been vacant -- except for a Commonwealth Edison substation and an ice-skating rink in the winter months -- for nearly that long.
Neil Bluhm, the chairman of JMB, said that the collapse of the real estate market in the early 90's led to the cancellation of an office project planned for the site. Several other projects also came and went. "Then the city decided it wanted more retail to energize State, so our project changed to reflect that," Mr. Bluhm said.
The new project, which is being designed by Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, the New York architectural firm, has a distinctly modern look, a departure on a street where most of the buildings date from the 1920's and earlier.
The new building nearing completion as part of the School of the Art Institute project across Randolph Street is an echo of the architect Daniel Burnham's historic Reliance Building, now called the Hotel Burnham, a block south at the corner of State and Washington.
The Art Institute's architect, Larry Booth of Booth Hansen & Associates in Chicago, said he very much had turn-of-the-century Chicago architecture in mind when he designed the project. "I feel like Louis Sullivan and Daniel Burnham and John Root are old pals of mine," Mr. Booth said, "and this was my chance to join the party."
The project, which is costing about $55 million, will have 34,000 square feet of retail space, 300 dormitory rooms, 2 movie theaters for the Art Institute's Film Center and a legitimate theater that has been leased to the Noble Fool comedy troupe.
The retail anchor for the project will be Borders Books, which will open a 30,000-square-foot store on three levels next fall.
"We always wanted to be on State, based on what's been going on there for the last few years," said Alex Lelli, the vice president for development of the Borders Group Inc. in Ann Arbor, Mich. "There's a lot of activity both during the day and at night and on the weekends. It's a very attractive street."

HEADLINE: Addressing the County's No. 1 Need;
Trying to Create Affordable Housing in a Place That Few Can Afford

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
ON a recent sultry afternoon, fortified only with box lunches and their own passion, a dozen government officials and an equal number of housing advocates boarded a bus at the County Center here and made a great loop around New York's wealthiest county, visiting affordable housing projects from Peekskill to Mamaroneck.
They were guests of the county executive, Andrew J. Spano, who has called the lack of affordable housing Westchester's No. 1 problem, for reasons both practical and philosophical. It weakens the fabric of communities, he said, by forcing out young adults who were raised there, retirees who can't afford to stay and blue-collar stalwarts who staff the volunteer fire departments and ambulance corps. 
 Were that not bad enough, Mr. Spano said, the difficulty of finding affordable housing in all but a few communities, like Yonkers and New Rochelle, is contributing to choking traffic on arteries like the Tappan Zee Bridge, a conduit for those who work here but must live where it is less expensive, say in Rockland or Orange Counties. It discourages economic development. And it fosters certain values that thrive in this petri dish of privilege.
"When we talk about improving the quality of life for all our residents, we must attack the lack of affordable housing," Mr. Spano declared in his State of the County address. "Every study -- whether the subject is transportation, economic development, planning or senior services -- refers to it as the county's most crucial problem."
But the county has no power, except for the bully pulpit, when it comes to land use decisions by its 43 municipalities. And so Mr. Spano, a Democrat, has begun a $250,000 public relations campaign to help overcome resistance from residents and elected leaders.
"We've got to show that the political numbers are greater for than against," said Mr. Spano, whose initiatives include using county money to buy land for such developments, giving legal and technical assistance to municipalities and developers, and tying the distribution of discretionary funds to a community's record in building affordable housing.
Each municipality, under authority granted by the state, drafts its own zoning regulations; approves, rejects or stalls projects as it sees fit. And with a few exceptions, most of Westchester's towns and villages vigorously resist the idea of opening the gates of paradise to those who can not afford to enter without subsidy.
The problem with that attitude is that virtually nobody can afford to live here anymore, including the people who already do, since the median house price is $365,000 and rising.
A case in point is Ron Bianchi, the mayor and supervisor of Harrison. "A lot of us, including myself, couldn't buy the houses we're living in now," Mr. Bianchi said. "My three sons, none of them can afford to live here."
The irony of Mr. Bianchi's lament may be lost on all but county insiders. His community, it turns out, is the most recalcitrant in Westchester when it comes to building affordable housing, refusing even to endorse a nonbinding county resolution that sets goals for each municipality. Harrison, a contiguous town and village, was urged to build 307 units in the last decade. It built none. It plans none. It wants none, Mr. Bianchi said.
There are few places in the United States where the gap is greater between the cost of housing and the wages of all but the fabulously rich. "In years gone by, the basic premise of housing policy was, If you could work you could afford a place to live," said Nicolas P. Retsinas, director of the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University, who recently viewed the situation here firsthand during a speaking engagement. "Now, that connection is broken."
The numbers are eye popping, proof that Westchester has pulled the welcome mat out from under people who would be solidly middle class virtually anywhere else, but for a few exceptions like Silicon Valley in California and Fairfax County in Virginia.
To be eligible for affordable housing, according to government regulations, an individual or family must earn less than 80 percent of the local median income. In Westchester, the median income for a family of four is $83,100, which means that a family earning $66,480 would qualify for help.
Again using a government formula, which says housing should cost 30 percent of gross income, that hypothetical family of four should spend no more that $1,600 a month, either in rent or mortgage payments, the ceiling for housing that meets the "affordable" criteria. To find market-rate housing at that cost in most parts of Westchester is impossible.
County planners say that without equity from a previous real estate investment, an income of $110,000 would be required to buy a typical home. And apartments have all but disappeared. About 40,000 were lost to condominium conversions in the 1980's. Only 10,000 rental units remain, or 16 percent of the housing stock countywide, so landlords can charge premium prices.
It is this set of economic conditions, worsening every day, that drives the need to build affordable housing, whether in clusters of new townhouses, in derelict buildings rehabilitated for that purpose, above stores and offices or in accessory apartments in private homes.
To that end, the county created the Housing Opportunity Commission a decade ago and, with assistance from the Rutgers University Center for Urban Policy Research, set goals for the county as a whole and allocations for each municipality. Westchester is the only county in New York State, outside the five boroughs, to do so.
But, the results have been disheartening, to put it mildly.
The countywide goal was 5,000 units in the decade just ended. Fewer than half that many were built. Of the 43 municipalities, 19 failed even to respond with a vague statement of good intentions. Two of those, Yonkers and Cortlandt, are under court order to produce low-income housing. Two others, Harrison and Port Chester, passed resolutions of opposition to the county goals. The cooperation of the remaining towns and villages has been uneven. New goals will be set after the 2000 census, with the county then playing a desperate game of catch-up.
The county's campaign, including glossy informational brochures, is intended to educate the public about who it is that needs this housing, to disabuse a wary citizenry that they are being asked to welcome welfare mothers or minimum-wage workers. But explaining that the target buyer or renter is a local teacher or firefighter, the grown children or aging parents of residents is only a partial solution.
Resistance is driven by other concerns, the recurring themes in all Nimby disputes. Preserving open land. Preventing clusters of bland town houses in neighborhoods of beautiful old homes. Holding down school enrollment and thus taxes. Sustaining property values. Controlling local traffic. Not interfering with one person's views or another's fondness for the woods nearby.
"People are oriented to their own comforts and their own bottom line," said John R. Nolon, director of the Land Use Center at the Pace University School of Law. "Our appetites, desires and whims drive this problem, absent over-riding state authority."
And there is no over-riding state authority in New York that forces municipalities to create a full range of housing opportunities.
A series of court cases, beginning with Berenson v. New Castle, which was decided by the State Court of Appeals in 1975, asserts that "regional considerations must be reflected in local zoning."
But despite its condemnation of exclusionary zoning, neither Berenson nor several cases that followed include any enforcement mechanism. Thus municipalities flout the courts at will, as North Salem has done for seven years by ignoring a court order regarding the illegal upzoning of 63 acres from multifamily dwellings to two-acre parcels, which effectively eliminates the possibility of building affordable units there.
New Jersey, by contrast, has mandated the construction of affordable housing though court cases known collectively as the Mount Laurel rulings. The New Jersey court adopted a statewide allocation plan. The court also retained jurisdiction over any cases brought by developers against recalcitrant municipalities, appointed special masters to ensure follow through and set timetables for compliance, none of which was done by the New York courts.
"It's the difference between 'ought to' versus 'must,' " said George M. Raymond, chairman of the Westchester Housing Opportunity Commission, who cut his teeth in this field as special master in 14 New Jersey communities.
Connecticut tackled the problem legislatively by passing the Affordable Housing Appeals Act in 1988. Any community that does not already have 10 percent of its housing in the affordable range is subject to the law. In these communities, if a developer proposes a project with 20 percent of its units affordable and is turned down because of restrictive zoning, that denial is deemed illegal unless the municipality can show a clear public purpose. That reverses the burden of proof from the usual scenario, where a developer seeking a zoning variance comes to the planning board hat in hand and is usually rejected.
"Where the political will is there, it can happen," Mr. Raymond said.
Certain Westchester communities have shown that political will. The town of Greenburgh, alone in the county, has enacted a requirement that any development in districts zoned for multifamily dwellings must include one affordable unit for every nine priced at market rate.
Such inclusionary projects, as they are known, are favored by many advocates because they integrate subsidized and market-rate units, with no apparent distinction. By legislating inclusionary housing, Greenburgh is encouraging private building without dependence on government subsidies, which are highly competitive, difficult to apply for and thus beyond the expertise of all but a few developers who specialize in affordable housing.
The town of New Castle, which includes the wealthy hamlets of Chappaqua and Millwood, has also shown leadership. The town was supportive of a project, developed by Wilder Balter Partners of Elmsford, with 52 two-family town houses, each with an owner-occupied portion and a rental flat below. And New Castle has a request for proposals out on another site, which it intends to rezone for multifamily dwellings.
This is a reversal of the more common upzoning, which makes lots larger and larger and thus limits them to the very rich. Somers, for instance, has upzoned 15 square miles to parcels of two to three acres, over the objections of the County Planning Board. "They have created a gated community without gates," said Raymond Seidelman, a professor of political science at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers.
New Castle also inspired a county program of financial and technical aid to people in large houses who are willing to add an affordable accessory apartment.
The town administrator, Jerry Faiella, said his goal is to create "cradle to grave housing options," and thus "generational stability," while enabling town employees and volunteers to live side by side with the people they serve.
He said that this attitude is not always popular and that his planning board meetings, like those across the county, draw strident opponents. "I've heard every reason not to do it," he said. "The board's got to make a decision whether they want it to happen or not."
That attitude is not shared by Mr. Bianchi, mayor and supervisor of Harrison, the county's poster child for noncompliance with its housing goals. Mr. Bianchi says his constituents are against providing housing for people who can't afford it on their own, since longtime residents "had to pay their fair share."
When reminded that housing prices have risen exponentially and that current residents could not afford their houses today, Mr. Bianchi tacked in another direction. Residents of Harrison, he said, "don't trust the government" and fear that units set aside today for families earning $60,000 could wind up occupied by the poor.
Mr. Bianchi said he does not share their skepticism. "But I have great respect for the wishes of people who live in this town," he said. "I'm not going to go out and do something that they feel short-changes them."
Developers of affordable housing shun communities that do not welcome them, since the task is hard enough, and the profit margins too low, to permit time-consuming and costly political battles or litigation. To make a project viable requires concessions from the local government, like density bonuses for including affordable units, along with a jigsaw puzzle of Federal, state and county subsidies.
Jonathan Rose, scion of the Rose family real estate dynasty in New York City, is widely considered the guru of affordable housing here. Other developers say that no one is more expert in layering the available sources of financing, a task so time consuming and complex that few attempt it.
Mr. Rose argues that the obstacles to building affordable housing here are surmountable, were the development community not so profit driven. But most developers are less sanguine.
They say that Westchester is in a class by itself in terms of resisting development of any kind, not merely affordable housing. "It's hard to get anything built here -- a shopping center, a garden apartment, a million dollar house -- because of sensitivity about density," said Robert H. Wilder Jr. of Wilder Balter Partners, which calls itself the state's largest developer of affordable housing.
Mr. Wilder and his partner, William G. Balter, proudly display renderings of their projects elsewhere -- Goshen, Middletown, Ballston Spa, Babylon, to name a few. In the last 10 years, they say, they have built more than 1,000 affordable units outside Westchester and just 92 in the county.
"If we could do all our work within 20 minutes of our office, don't you think we would?" Mr. Wilder asked. "The opportunities don't present themselves. It's so much harder here. Sure, it's hard every place: hard but doable."

HEADLINE: Dining Where the Garden Is Decor and Cuisine

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG 

 BODY:
FOR the better part of a decade, critics have extolled the food and ambience at The Ryland Inn in Whitehouse. Craig Shelton, the inn's chef, extolls something else: the glories of its garden. "The garden is the restaurant," he said. "It dictates the approach to cuisine."
This holistic philosophy, linking kitchen, garden, cuisine and ambience, is not new. American chefs, led by Alice Waters of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., have championed the concept since the 1970's. But in New Jersey, economic factors make it less practical to surround a restaurant with lush gardens, even if they produce raw materials for the menu. Jack Boehlert, owner of the Stockton Inn in Stockton, summarized the problem neatly; "Most people who think about the costs of doing business are not going to use one-third of the seating area to make a garden." 
 At the Stockton Inn, shady conditions and rocky soil limit large-scale production of edibles, but homegrown mints appear in sauces and desserts, and flowers are tossed into salads and used as garnishes. The garden is planted with shade-tolerant annuals, perennials and shrubs. Standing amid the rocky outcroppings and waterfalls that surround the terraced outdoor eating area, it defines the restaurant.
At the Ryland Inn, the main garden consists of two fenced acres that produce vegetables, herbs, fruits and ornamental and edible flowers. Another unfenced acre is home to mulberry and elderberry bushes. The head gardener, Chip Shepherd, uses the "French intensive gardening" system, growing plants close together in raised beds full of organically enriched soil to produce larger yields in relatively small spaces.
A walk through Mr. Shepherd's beds is a lesson in the art of composing a kitchen garden. Bare earth is rarely visible. Magenta bee balm, the herb best known as the flavoring in Earl Grey tea, leaps out of one bed, as bees hover over its blossoms. The purple blooms of thyme sprawl along the ground. Red-leafed lettuces face upward, their heads resembling many-petaled flowers. A row of basil plants with green and purple varieties planted alternately runs alongside a bushy row of orange-flowered nasturtiums, creating a combination that would be equally at home on a plate or in a vase.
Mr. Shepherd is convinced that raising fresh, organic produce makes economic, philosophical and gustatory sense. "It's cheaper to grow your own organic produce," he said. (To be certified as organic in New Jersey means, among other things, that fruits and vegetables must be grown in soil that has not been treated with pesticides or herbicides for at least three years.)
Mr. Shepherd, who may be the only organic gardener with previous professional experience in the hazardous waste disposal industry, has supervised the garden for three years. Since the Ryland Inn does not yet have a commercial-size greenhouse, Mr. Shepherd starts the inn's seedlings -- all from heirloom seed varieties -- at his home a short distance away. If all goes according to plan, Mr. Shepherd hopes the majority of the seeds he sows in coming seasons will come from the plants grown in the garden. The germination rate of these collected seeds is comparable to that of commercially obtained seeds, making them an economical alternative.
EVERY spring at Mia Sorella, Abbas Aboelata, the father of the chef and owner, Sam Aboelata, plants seeds and starter plants of basil, sage, rosemary, thyme and Italian parsley in the beds that run like ribbons around the restaurant's sunny outdoor patio. By midsummer, the garden is also producing the tomatoes, peppers, scallions, French beans and arugula used in the younger Mr. Aboelata's Italian cooking. This year, according to the chef, walls will be constructed to raise the beds, enabling diners to be close enough to smell and touch the fragrant herbs.
Because of the "cut and come again" nature of the herbs in the garden, Mr. Aboelata is able to supply the restaurant all summer. If there is a surplus of basil, it is dried or frozen for winter use, or made into classic pesto sauce.
Then there are the flowers. Abbas Aboelata plants them in any space not occupied by vegetables and herbs. Some stay outside to beautify the patio; others are cut for table arrangements inside the restaurant. Homegrown flowers, like homegrown produce, make both aesthetic and economic sense in a business where profit margins can be thinner than French crepes.
The connection between restaurant and garden is as tangible at the Stockton Inn as the stone that was quarried on the spot to construct the restaurant's original building. The space beside the structure, created when the stone was removed, is now home to the three-tiered outdoor dining area and garden. Water cascades down the stone walls, and an array of plants fills the raised beds. In the spring, Virginia bluebells share space with boldly colored ranunculus and pansies. Later on, ostrich ferns and other varieties wave over double impatiens. Azaleas and rhododendrons bloom on the steep hillside behind the dining area, and a pair of lace-leaf maples mark the boundary between tiers of the patio. A pair of hibiscus standards, presented to Mr. Boehlert by a customer, claim a sunny spot flanking a walkway.
Mr. Boehlert began his gardening career at the age of 12, and his career at the Stockton Inn as a waiter six years ago. Since that time he has become chief gardener as well as owner. When he bought the property in 1998, the garden beds were engulfed in English ivy, and the hillside was covered with scrubby vegetation. Gradually he and his crew of part-time helpers weeded out the unwanted greenery and began putting in other plants. In the future Mr. Boehlert hopes to install fragrant lilac and viburnum bushes in the outdoor dining area. For the present he will plant hanging baskets with trailing nasturtium. By summer the flowers will be doing double duty in the kitchen and garden.
Mr. Boehlert is an avocational painter whose renderings of cyclamens and water lilies hang in one of the indoor dining rooms. He approaches the garden as both horticulturist and artist, bringing the same sense of composition and color to his outdoor and indoor canvases.
The fruits of Mr. Boehlert's labors are on display from Mother's Day until the end of the growing season. "Some people will only come during the summertime," he said.
The gardens at the Ryland Inn are open to both the general public and the restaurant's patrons. Garden tours are available as Mr. Shepherd's time permits, and unaccompanied strolling is encouraged. "People come here to walk in the garden all the time," said Mr. Shelton, who described the gardens as an important link between the Inn and the surrounding community.
MR. SHELTON and Mr. Shepherd look ahead to the day when the Ryland Inn will extend its horticultural outreach and provide seedlings of organically grown flowers and vegetables to the public. "Ryland should be part of the community," said the chef. Eventually, he and Mr. Shepherd envision cooking and gardening apprenticeship programs at the Inn. "We want to invite people to participate on an individual level," he added.
Though there is no space to expand Mia Sorella's garden, Mr. Aboelata has his own plans. He wants to build a pergola over part of the terrace. The structure will then be covered with grapevines, providing shade for diners as well as leaves that will make their way into special dishes.
All three restaurateurs view their establishments as part of a larger community. "There is such history here," said Mr. Boehlert of his 300-year-old-inn and its 50-year-old gardens and waterfalls. "My job is to keep it all together."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY;
What Market Windfall?

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
To many Americans, the stock market boom has been like a solitary breeze on a torrid summer night: just when they turn to enjoy the coolness, it seems to go away.
Two-thirds of Americans who responded to a survey about their retirement plans said they had not gained substantially from the decadelong bull market. 
 Six hundred people over the age of 25 took part in the poll, which was commissioned by the Keyport Life Insurance Company in Boston. Of the respondents, 278 were working and 322 were retired.
Of the current workers, only 10 percent said their stock market gains would allow them to retire early; 3 percent of the retired respondents said such gains had let them retire early.
Keyport, which conducted a similar survey in 1995, found contradictory attitudes and expectations about retirement needs and lifestyles. Three-fourths of the current workers said their standard of living in retirement would be the same or higher than it was now, but just over half could not estimate how much money they would need to retire in the lifestyle they wanted. That was up from 43 percent in 1995.
Among the current workers who listed an amount, the median was $400,000, but 26 percent said they would need less than $100,000.
"This lack of financial realism is very disturbing," said Philip K. Polkinghorn, president of Keyport. "Financial planners and other experts that take inflation, life span and other factors into account when setting retirement savings goals would find that $100,000 is only a fraction of what an individual needs as a retirement nest egg."
He said $400,000 was more realistic.
The survey found that half of current workers expected to be working for pay in retirement; 56 percent of those said they would need the money. By contrast, 22 percent of the retirees said they were working part-time now, up from 13 percent in 1995.
Only 23 percent of current workers expect Social Security to be a major source of retirement income, down from 35 percent in 1995. Most expect the majority of retirement income to come from 401(k)'s, individual retirement accounts and Keogh plans. MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: CITY LORE;
Brooklyn on 10,000 Calories a Day

BYLINE: By TARA BAHRAMPOUR 

 BODY:
The bagel. The knish. The pepperoni slice. To couple the words "Brooklyn" and "food" is to evoke these legendary immigrant-inspired snacks that over the last century have filled the bellies of locals and injected pizazz into palates of Americans from Memphis to Malibu.
But lest anyone think Brooklyn's gastronomic glories are limited to these classics, the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce last year created Brooklyn's Kitchen, a program intended to help the borough's food manufacturers develop and increase sales of Brooklyn fare around the country. 
 Why Brooklyn? It has more food manufacturers than any other borough, with food making up 12 percent of its economic development, said Shawn Starbuck, assistant director of the pilot program, which serves 32 small and midsize clients. The borough's diversity also makes it ideal.
"The different ethnic pockets that make up Brooklyn all have their own food component," Ms. Starbuck said. "There's the Italian sections, the Middle East sections, the Russians in Brighton Beach. The whole food scene in Brooklyn is changing as people develop products they've made at home and try to sell them in this market."
To make her point, Ms. Starbuck (who is no relation to the coffee chain, although she noted that Starbucks' founder was a Brooklyn boy), dropped in on some of her favorite spots the other day.
DAMASCUS BAKERIES, DUMBO -- For anyone who has ever pondered the mysteries of the pita, Edward Mafoud has the answers. Towering over six feet, white hairnet peeking out under a yellow construction hat, Mr. Mafoud, grandson of America's first pita manufacturer, led visitors into his hot, bread-scented warehouse on Gold Street.
Puffy, sandwich-sized pitas glided by on conveyor belts as Mr. Mafoud described the mating habits of yeasts ("typically an asexual reproduction") and stretched dough over his hand to demonstrate the window test ("If I can see my fingernails through that piece of dough, I've done my job").
When Mr. Mafoud's Syrian-born grandfather, Hassan Halaby, started Damascus Bakeries in an Atlantic Avenue storefront in 1930, five employees made the pitas by hand. Today, 60 employees work around the clock, producing 11,000 pitas per hour in 11 different flavors, including cinnamon-raisin and pesto. The company also makes flatbread for wraps, which Mr. Mafoud praises as a fat-free alternative to tortillas.
But the real mystery lies inside the pita.
"I know what you want to ask: how does it get its pocket?" Mr. Mafoud said, nodding wisely. "A lot of people think, 'Well, why don't you put two pieces of dough one on top of the other?' Well, that's not how it's done." Rather, he explained: "We cook the pita bread for 50 seconds at 900 degrees Fahrenheit. As it gets hot, thousands if not millions of air bubbles form. They become excited and move further and further apart. Finally we get one continuous bubble, or pocket."
STEVE'S KEY LIME PIES, RED HOOK -- "I'm the key lime guy," admitted Steve Tarpin, standing in shorts and an apron in a small doorway on Columbia Street. It would be hard to deny, given the hulking 1953 Ford panel delivery truck out front that's painted a creamy pale green and reads "Steve's Authentic Key Lime Pies." But now that Mr. Tarpin has moved his five-year-old business out of his Boerum Hill studio apartment and "gone legit," with two employees and an 800-square-foot storefront he shares with a wedding cake baker, he can afford to boast.
Mr. Tarpin's interest in key limes goes far beyond just squeezing them. "This is the true lime," he said, plucking a pinball-sized yellow-skinned fruit from a box. "It originated in south Asia, the Arabs brought it through the spice trade and passed it over to the Spanish. The Spanish and Portuguese brought them to the New World."
Shaking his head reproachfully, Mr. Tarpin displayed a bottle of preservative-laced juice concentrate that he said most key lime pie manufacturers rely on. To counter such travesties, Mr. Tarpin has created a Web site, www.keylime.com, that outlines the fruit's provenance and explains how to grow your own key lime tree.
Asked the secret of the perfect pie, Mr. Tarpin, who moved here from Florida, began to explain: "Any self-respecting Miami native should know how to make a decent key lime pie. It's a basic recipe----" He stopped short. "I shouldn't tell you that," he said and, tongue-in-cheek, continued, "It's a long family secret which we don't divulge." He did divulge the five simple ingredients: egg yolks, sweetened condensed milk and key limes for the filling; graham crackers and butter for the crust.
Catering mostly to local restaurants and hotels, the company produces up to 120 large pies and 500 individual ones a day. Starting this month, the upscale grocery Citarella will be carrying his pies, which Mr. Tarpin hopes will afford him and his truck a little peace. "So people won't actually have to chase me down the street to get a pie, which has been happening," he explained.
INTERNATIONAL GOURMET DELIGHTS, BAY RIDGE -- Don't try to figure out how many generations Anwar Najjar's family has been in the pastry business. Back in the 11th century, when Crusaders and caravan merchants roamed the Near East, the Najjars were making the baklava that travelers carried to neighboring states and into the Arabian desert.
Transporting their delicacies to Brooklyn was perhaps the next logical step.
"My mom and dad came here in 1972," Mr. Najjar said as his sister and mother uncovered platters of Turkish delight, pistachios in filo dough, and shredded dough with walnuts in their wholesale bakery on Bay Ridge Avenue. Speaking of the Lebanese civil conflict, he said, "In 1976 when the war broke out, they went back and got us in Tripoli." Thus did the business embark on its second millennium, combining ancient Lebanese techniques with an American-style melting-pot marketing philosophy.
"We're halal and we're kosher," Mr. Najjar explained. "We're also in Jewish communities; we're also in Israeli markets." They're also in South America, Asia and Canada, as well as in United States chain stores and Middle Eastern markets.
Butter is a major component in the pastries, but so are more esoteric ingredients. Mastic gum, the sap of a special Grecian tree, gives the sugar-coated loukoum its chewy consistency; rose water provides an aromatic counterbalance to the nuts in the Turkish Delight.
Badrieh Najjar, Mr. Najjar's mother, said local customers include transplants from traditional baklava-belt states like Pakistan, India, Greece, Iran and Yugoslavia. But in this era of rapid transit, even non-baklava countries are tuning in.
"One time some Chinese person brought our product back to China and they wrote about it in their newspaper," she said, adding that the article specifically mentioned the bird's nest, a shredded dough specialty of the house. "They loved the shape of it, they loved the taste of it, and they loved the name."
 
"DAMASCUS SMOKED SALMON PITA CLUB SANDWICH"
 
 From Damascus Bakeries
6 oz. cream cheese
1 teaspoon tarragon
1 teaspoon chives
6 Damascus onion pitas
1 lb. sliced smoked salmon
1 sliced red onion
1 sliced cucumber
3 hard-boiled eggs
3 sliced tomatoes
3 oz. watercress capers to garnish
Mix cream cheese with tarragon and chives. Spread on pita. Add salmon, onion, cucumber, hard-boiled eggs, tomatoes. Garnish with capers and watercress. Serves six.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2938 words

HEADLINE: The Sound and the Fury

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
HAVE you heard the noise?
Madelyn Wils has. A longtime resident of TriBeCa, where three- and four-star restaurants make their home, she listens every evening as motorists honk their horns at double- and triple-parked limousines and their well-dressed passengers, who bark into cell phones as they arrive and depart. 
 "It's like the movie 'Network,' where the characters yell, 'I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take it any more,' " said Ms. Wils, a freelance television producer, complaining about yet another restaurant that recently applied for permission to open on Duane Street, where she lives. "That's what my neighbors and I are saying now."
Marcia Lemmon, chairwoman of the Ludlow Street Block Association, has also heard the noise. She lives on the Lower East Side, where the freewheeling drug traffic of a decade ago has been replaced by residential gentrification and an explosion in cacophonous bars and "scene" restaurants. On Orchard Street alone she has counted seven places that serve liquor.
"People have said to me that they look back on the time of the drugs as the halcyon days of the neighborhood," Ms. Lemmon said, "especially compared to now, with the noise, taxis and yelling in the street."
For Max Strauss, who runs an aluminum recycling business and lives in an apartment facing West 67th Street, just off Central Park West, the din is "just off the scale." He blames Makor, a Jewish cultural center that opened on the block last fall and runs evening programs aimed at young singles.
"You can feel the music vibrating through the walls," said Mr. Strauss, who added that he and his wife are so frustrated they plan to knock through the walls of another apartment they own in the back of their building and move their bedroom there, away from the commotion.
"We're lucky that we can do that," he said. "Otherwise, we'd have to move."
Noise has always been a part of Manhattan life. But in recent years, people have moved to areas where few, if any, used to live. Spurred by a red-hot economy, they are also demanding, and getting, entertainment in those neighborhoods, as well as in communities that have traditionally been residential.
As a result, the disturbances drawing public ire are not just the jackhammers, car alarms and fire sirens that have long assaulted urban eardrums. Today, nearly everywhere around town, people are also complaining about restaurants, movie theaters, clubs, bars and other gathering places. Many of those complaining were raised outside the city in quieter places and are unwilling to accept the growing din.
Attend a meeting of virtually any community group, and you will hear the same story: despite a stricter city noise code, the racket is growing.
Increasing numbers of residents say they want offending establishments exiled to the fringes of the city or kicked out of Manhattan altogether.
In some cases, they are succeeding. In 1997, Manhattan State Supreme Court Justice Sheila Abdus-Salaam overturned a liquor license that had been approved for a bar at 72 Grand Street in SoHo, ruling that the detriment to the community far outweighed any gain to it. In 1998, the State Liquor Authority rejected a license application from a bar at 76 Wooster Street, also in SoHo. It was one of the few times the agency had refused to grant a license for the sake of neighborhood tranquillity.
In February, Justice Franklin R. Weissberg of State Supreme Court in Manhattan rejected an application for a license for a proposed nightclub at 372 Broadway, south of Canal Street, on the ground that the club was likely to disrupt the community. The club would have occupied an old four-story building next to a residential high-rise surrounded by stores selling fabric, futons and discount jeans. At night, when the stores are closed, the area is silent save for a few cars and trucks heading down Broadway.
"I don't know if it's a change in people's sensibilities or if the noise is actually louder," said Charles G. Sturcken, chief of staff of the city Department of Environmental Protection, which fields so-called quality of life complaints on a 24-hour phone line. In the last year or two, he said, far more people seem to be complaining about noise from social events and gathering places than ever before.
Judy Duffy, the assistant manager for Community Board 1, said of the din from restaurants, clubs and bars, "It is the most increased kind of complaint we've seen in the last few years."
Her district includes much of Lower Manhattan, where, she said, such noise is "more and more the key issue." Even normal conversation on the street occasionally provokes the wrath of residents.
"We just flat out have more people living here and more people coming here," Ms. Duffy said. "And people make noise."
 
Now, the Once-Sleepless City Dreams of Peace and Quiet
To New Yorkers, it used to be a matter of civic pride that this was the city that never slept. Manhattan, especially, was a mix, a hodgepodge of homes, stores, theaters, restaurants and bars. And that was fine with New Yorkers, who wanted to be able to buy a quart of milk in their neighborhoods, or go out for a drink, a meal or a show.
But that was when the populace had a greater "tradition of tolerance for noise" than it does today, said Philip Kasinitz, a professor of sociology at Hunter College and the City University Graduate Center, who specializes in urban affairs.
With elevated trains screeching past and windows open on summer nights, "there were different norms of noise," he said.
Times changed. In the 1950's and 60's, great waves of newly affluent or at least middle-class young families packed up and headed for the quiet of the suburbs. Then times changed again. Many grown children of the suburbs returned to Manhattan and many of them are raising their families here, preferring the verve and excitement of the city to what they perceived as the boredom and sterility of the suburbs.
Yet despite their enthusiasm for urban life, these returnees and other new Manhattanites have acquired "certain expectations of behavior that are really quite suburban," Professor Kasinitz said.
They feel entitled to conditions similar to those that prevailed in the places they were raised. "Like peace and quiet," he said.
But there are other reasons for the new militancy against party noise. A major one is the influx of New Yorkers moving into marginally residential or newly gentrified areas like TriBeCa, the Lower East Side, far west Chelsea and the East Village, where elevated noise levels might be expected. The city's prosperity also results in more noise, largely because of the peculiarities of the city's zoning regulations, in which commercial districts are overlaid on Manhattan's residential neighborhoods.
As a result, many of the worst offenses occur in places where New Yorkers have always lived, like the Upper East Side or the block on West 67th Street where Max Strauss and his neighbors suffer.
As Joseph B. Rose, director of the Department of City Planning, points out, Manhattan is a small place, and the commercial heart of the city. If the city is to thrive, he said, both residential and commercial uses must coexist on one relatively tiny island. In Manhattan, unlike the suburbs, there is hardly any residential-only zoning, and even historically residential areas are studded with restaurants, clubs and bars. In boom times, coexistence between the two worlds is increasingly precarious.
"The goal of land use regulation is to achieve and maintain a balance, and noise per se is not a general land use issue," Mr. Rose said. "We are not going to do away with the commercial overlay on residential areas in Manhattan."
 
Problems of Prosperity In the East Village
One neighborhood where the problem has become particularly intense in recent years is the East Village.
From Second Avenue to the East River, the area is zoned as a general residence district, with restrictions on building size, height and uses. On the avenues, however, and some side streets, zoning allows commercial uses, which can include everything from antiques stores to supermarkets to shoe repair shops to bars.
Once an impoverished haven for drug dealers, the East Village was increasingly gentrified in the last decade. It also became host to several New York University dormitories.
Lisa Ramaci, a member of Community Board 3, said the presence of students led to the opening of dozens of bars and clubs, many of which displaced delis, dry cleaners, shoe repair shops and other businesses that could not pay higher rents.
"You now have wolf packs of 20-somethings roaming residential side streets at 3 or 4 o'clock in the morning, screaming, kicking over garbage cans and fighting," Ms. Ramaci said.
"There are also plenty with fake ID's," she said. "It's like Disneyland East."
Ms. Ramaci cited the Cock, a bar at 188 Avenue A at East 12th Street, as an example.
The Cock was cited seven times between spring 1997 and summer 1999 for violations like selling alcohol to minors and after-hours operations. During that period, it was fined $20,000.
Davis Tong, the building's owner, declined to comment on the present status of the Cock, and the club's owner, Allan Mannarelli, could not be reached.
In December, the liquor authority suspended the bar's license, citing multiple violations, and shut it down for 30 days. But the bar has since reopened. The music is so loud, Ms. Ramaci said, "you have to plug your ears as you go by."
Not even the prospect of college finals could deter midweek revelers from visiting Avenue A on a recent weeknight. Well after midnight, the street was filled with knots of people in various stages of tipsiness, laughing and talking loudly.
At the Cock and other bars, like the Raven near 13th Street, loud, percussive music drifted out the door.
 
If You Can't Throw Them Out, Zone Them Out
One way to improve the situation is to redefine the kinds of businesses that can operate in a certain place. Mr. Rose said the City Planning Department would recommend some modifications along those lines later this spring as part of a major overhaul of the city's 1961 Zoning Resolution.
The City Council has the power to enact zoning changes. But the Council usually acts only in tandem with the planning department. As a result, one proposal to modify uses allowed in specific neighborhoods, made two years ago, has been languishing in committee with little chance of passage.
In October 1997, the Council did pass a law drastically increasing the penalties for multiple violations of the noise code. Establishments that repeatedly "cause or permit" music louder than 45 decibels to be heard in neighboring residences can be fined up to $24,000; the maximum fine had been $8,000. (For purposes of comparison, normal conversation is 60 decibels, while the level for the audience of a rock concert can be 115 decibels or more.)
But there is no agreement on whether the new law has been effective.
"We can't see any correlation between the change in fines and the number of summonses or complaints one way or the other," said John Scanlon, chief of patrol for the Police Department. He and Mr. Sturcken of the Department of Environmental Protection both said that the number of calls to their agencies' complaint lines went way up when the change in the law was first made public, but had since fallen off.
"Most people don't bother to call up to complain about noise," said Ms. Duffy of Community Board 1. Instead, people tend to complain at community meetings.
Even A. Gifford Miller, the councilman from the Upper East Side of Manhattan who sponsored the bill, is qualified in his assessment of the harsher penalties.
"It deals only with repeat offenders," he said, "and there are lots of cases of people who are not being repeatedly cited."
"We've still got a long way to go," he added.
Community groups agree. Frustrated at their inability to remove offending businesses and social halls from their neighborhoods through zoning, they have turned to the courts and other government agencies, with varying degrees of success.
Most turn first to the State Liquor Authority. By law, all bars and restaurants serving alcohol must be licensed by the authority. Community boards review the appropriateness of each prospective license, and forward their findings to the authority. Although their recommendations are only advisory, most boards take their role seriously, as do their constituents.
"In some ways, people are treating us as if we were the zoning agency," said Ms. Duffy of Community Board 1.
Some boards act as if they were. Even though licensed establishments in Manhattan may stay open until 4 a.m., Community Board 4 in Chelsea recently recommended to the liquor agency that a planned restaurant to be called Chelsea Place be granted a license only on the condition that it close at 2 a.m., and that its owners meet monthly with board members to deal with any problems.
The owners agreed to some of the conditions, including the 2 a.m. closing. They promised that Chelsea Place would remain a restaurant and not become a bar or a club, as has happened with other establishments in the neighborhood.
"I call it morphing," said Maria Garcia, a member of the community board. She fears that the restaurant may try to amend its license if it can show some kind of hardship.
"The liquor authority is there to keep places in business," she said. "If that happens, they're never going to close down a place like this."
Her misgivings are shared by members of many Manhattan community boards. As a result, most concentrate their efforts on stopping new bars from opening altogether.
Their recommendations center on the so-called 500-foot law passed by the State Legislature in 1993. That law forbids any new drinking establishment if there are already three others within a 500-foot radius. The law permits exemptions, however, if the authority finds that they are in the public interest.
Public interest can mean many things, like increases in jobs and tax revenues. Over the years, many bars and restaurants that fall within the purview of the 500-foot law have received licenses on that basis, despite opposition from some residents.
 
Fighting Back, And Sometimes Winning
But residents have been fighting back, and sometimes they have won. One recent victory involved a building at 372 Broadway, on the border of TriBeCa and Chinatown. Last year the liquor agency turned down a proposal by the Bowery Room Corporation, which had previously run a club in Greenwich Village, to open a nightclub there.
Community board members, the East TriBeCa Community Association, a local group, and Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed banded together to oppose the granting of a liquor license. They contended that the area had become increasingly residential during the last few years, and that the proposed club, which would have had more than 10,000 square feet on three floors, accommodating 800 patrons, was simply too much for the neighborhood. The liquor agency agreed, and its decision was upheld in State Supreme Court.
"I think there's been a real turnaround with the State Liquor Authority," said Barry Mallin, the lawyer who represented local groups in the case. In other words, licenses are no longer approved without question.
In other neighborhoods, like the East Village, the authority has allowed dozens of bars to open, many on the same block. The authority's willingness to defer to community concern is of no help when there is no liquor license, as in the case of Makor, the Jewish social center on West 67th Street, where residents complained of loud music and noisy young people on the street.
Because of the growing protest, there is concern on the part of many of the city's clubs and restaurants. One person who is especially worried is Robert Bookman, the lawyer for the New York Nightlife Association, a trade group representing about 80 cabaret, bar and restaurant owners.
He acknowledges that there are bars and clubs at which patrons are unruly. But he asserts that many neighbors have "unrealistic expectations" about the amount of noise that is appropriate in the city.
He also contends that the police often cite clubs and bars as offenders when their customers should be blamed. "If a patron after a hockey game gets into a fight in the street," he wrote in a recent issue of his association's newsletter, "Madison Square Garden is not issued a summons."
Mostly, though, Mr. Bookman says, outdated zoning is at the heart of the problem.
"Nightclubs always explored new areas of the city, opened new neighborhoods," he said. "Now these neighborhoods are increasingly residential, and there is no place where there isn't some sort of opposition."
"You can have a place on the West Side Highway, and then people will move in next door," he said. As a result, "professional entrepreneurs are looking to other cities" like Aspen, Los Angeles or Miami, all of which he called more business-friendly.
Such an exodus would undoubtedly delight opponents of noisy bars and restaurants, like Ms. Ramaci of Community Board 3, who said she would welcome the return of "the shoe repair shops, dry cleaners and pet food stores that the clubs have driven from the neighborhood," not to mention "a good night's sleep."
But it would bode ill for New York's nightlife industry, which entertains 24 million patrons annually, Mr. Bookman said.
"If the trend continues, it will change the city," he said. "And not for the better."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
National Debt? The Sum Depends on The Candidate

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"IT'S TIME for "Fiscal Jeopardy."
The first answer is: About $3.5 trillion, and falling rapidly. 
 The correct question is: What is the national debt?
The next answer: About $5.6 trillion and rising rapidly.
The question: What is the national debt?
Confused? Well, there are going to be many confusing claims and counterclaims emanating from the presidential campaign trail in the next few months about who will do more to put the federal government's finances in order. And they start with very different definitions of the debt.
Vice President Al Gore puts his emphasis on the national debt held by the public, the $3.5 trillion that the government has borrowed by selling Treasury securities to individual investors, banks, pension funds and foreign governments.
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas is taking the view that the government's obligations include not just the public debt, but also the special bonds it is issuing to the Social Security system in ever-growing amounts, representing promises to pay retirement benefits in decades ahead. By that accounting, the current $5.6 trillion in total debt will grow inexorably for years to come.
The differences are coming into play as the candidates hurtle into a high-intensity debate about how to shore up Social Security in time for the aging of the baby boomers.
Mr. Gore has made paying off the entire public debt by 2013 the centerpiece of his economic agenda. He wants to use excess Social Security revenue -- more than $2 trillion over the next decade -- to do it.
Mr. Gore would then channel the interest savings from debt reduction to Social Security, in effect committing trillions of dollars of general tax revenue to keep the system afloat. In that way, he would extend the system's solvency from 2037 to around 2050 without cutting benefits, raising payroll taxes or altering the way Social Security works.
In addition to helping deal with Social Security in a relatively painless way, Mr. Gore's plan would free up trillions of dollars for other kinds of investment, helping to put downward pressure on interest rates and create new economic opportunities for companies and individuals.
Mr. Bush's approach is different. This week he plans to set out a goal of adding private investment accounts to Social Security, a major change that would require hundreds of billions, if not trillions, of dollars over the next decade. The only place to find that money is the Social Security surplus.
To the extent that the surplus is used to finance private accounts, it would not be available to reduce the public debt, a goal in which Mr. Gore sees both economic logic and considerable political appeal.
But Mr. Bush's team argues that reducing the public debt is not the only way to improve the government's financial condition. Because the private investment accounts would replace part of the government's obligation to pay Social Security benefits in the long run, his approach would in effect reduce the debt, broadly defined.
"You'd be improving the government's balance sheet in an even more efficient way," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, the former Federal Reserve governor who is Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser.
The scale of any reduction in total debt under Mr. Bush's approach would depend on the amount of money committed to the private accounts, a decision that Mr. Bush says should be made through bipartisan negotiations after he is elected.
Under Mr. Gore's approach, the public debt would sink steadily, but all the while the Treasury's obligation to the Social Security trust fund would be rising even faster, from $855 billion today to $4.2 trillion in 2013. So even if the public debt is retired on Mr. Gore's schedule, the total debt would rise, from $5.6 trillion today to $6.8 trillion in 2013.
The two plans are pretty much a wash when it comes to improving national savings. "Whether you're taking $100 billion and buying down debt or adding it to a pool of private funds available for investment doesn't make a great deal of difference," said Robert D. Reischauer, president of the Urban Institute and a former director of the Congressional Budget Office.
Mr. Gore's approach is conservative in the sense that it is based on debt reduction, but it affirms Democratic orthodoxy by retaining Social Security as a guaranteed benefit, even if tax revenue must pay for it.
Mr. Bush bucks mainstream economic thinking to a degree when he plays down the importance of wiping out the public debt. But at heart, his plan is about transferring some control of retirement finances from the government to individuals -- a most basic conservative value.
We'll be back with the final round of "Fiscal Jeopardy" in November, when the voters will decide.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE;
Profits and Diversity Jostle At a Gentrification Forum

BYLINE: By TARA BAHRAMPOUR 

 BODY:
Some trembled with emotion as they recounted horror stories about apartment-snatching real estate brokers. Others voiced support for small-property owners who could now afford to send their children to college, thanks to soaring local rents.
They were among nearly 200 Park Slope residents who packed a forum entitled "The Gentrification of Park Slope" Thursday night at Public School 321 on Seventh Avenue to discuss the pros and cons of the neighborhood's increasing prosperity. The panel included a community leader, an urban sociologist, a real estate agent and a property owner. 
 The issue, panelists said, revolves around balancing free market forces with the economic and ethnic heterogeneity that many residents say first attracted them to the area.
"Can we find ways to honor the values of our neighborhood -- diversity, affordability and long-term residents -- even when they conflict with many of our interests?" asked Brad Lander, executive director of the Fifth Avenue Committee. "Do we want the person paying $600 or $700 a month to be able to continue to live where their families have lived for years, even when the market forces raise that apartment to $1,500 to $1,800?"
Mr. Lander said his committee has recommended a voluntary "displacement-free zone" for blocks where lower-income families are in danger of being evicted in favor of tenants who can pay twice or three times as much rent.
But Roger Melzer, a panelist who is a property owner and a board member of a neighborhood revitalization group, countered by saying, "I'm happy to be enjoying the benefits of what's happening in the real estate market, and I'm not ashamed of that."
Sharon Zukin, a professor of sociology at Brooklyn College and the City University of New York, said market forces could only be resisted through political action. Marc Gerstein, president of Warren Lewis Realty, suggested that the way to preserve diversity in high-priced areas is to improve education and give everyone the opportunity to earn high incomes.
Some audience members said real estate brokers were to blame for escalating housing prices. Sheree Lane angrily described how, after she had signed a contract to buy a co-op she had been renting and then applied for board approval, a real-estate broker on the board persuaded the seller to hold out for more money. "Co-ops should not operate as real estate cartels," she said.
Carl Giangrande, a property owner, said he hoped the high real estate values would spread gentrification into surrounding areas.
"I look forward to the day we'll have this discussion in East New York," he said.
 TARA BAHRAMPOUR

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS with WILBUR L. ROSS Jr.;
In Accounting, Separating Church and State

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
THE stock market has turned ugly, cutting off potential cash for Internet companies, many of which can measure their life expectancies in months. And accounting concerns, so often ignored when stocks are rising, are again becoming an issue in corporate America.
In a speech last Wednesday, Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, threw a harsh spotlight on the often close relationships between accounting firms and the companies they audit. Mr. Levitt warned that accounting firms doubling as consultants might be tempted to go easy on audits to keep clients happy and the consulting business flowing. 
 It seems like a good time to talk to Wilbur L. Ross Jr., who has made a very successful career of buying stakes in seriously troubled companies. At 62, an age when many people are considering retirement, Mr. Ross has not lost his appetite for the game. Two months ago, he made waves when he announced that he would leave Rothschild Inc., his home for 24 years, to form his own investment firm, W. L. Ross & Company.
Mr. Ross took some time last week to offer his thoughts on accounting, Internet stocks and the broader market. Following are excerpts from the conversation. ALEX BERENSON
 
Q. Is there a structural conflict when accounting firms offer consulting services?
 
A. That is a bit of an issue. I think there's a question -- I think it's dangerous when a person tries to wear more hats than he has heads, because it makes for complicated relationships. What I think gets more complex is if somebody is a partner in a firm and therefore is benefiting from both the accounting profits and the consulting profits.
At the actual working level, it's accomplishable, but I think it makes more sense to have some kind of separation between the two firms.
 
Q. What do you think has led to the increased number of restatements of corporate earnings over the last few years?
 
A. I frankly think it's the whole concept of the stock market driving business decisions in this country. I think there are an awful lot of companies that are hugely obsessed with the progression of quarterly earnings. There's such intense pressure on the earnings results that companies are tempted to find ways to regularize their earnings and meet forecasts. Too many companies have reacted by using very aggressive concepts of reported earnings, and that has led to a lot of pressure on the accountants.
 
Q. For investors, what is the No. 1 red flag? Some analysts say it is companies with positive reported earnings but negative cash flow.
 
A. You can invent earnings. It's really hard to invent cash flow. And when a company goes bankrupt, it's not usually because they run out of earnings. It's because they run out of cash.
 
Q. A lot of young companies are now bleeding cash. Are they likely to go bankrupt?
 
A. People forget that when the automobile industry started, there were something like 100 manufacturers of cars. Now there are only three. And it wasn't because the car wasn't a revolutionary product, because it was. And it wasn't because the market didn't become a huge market, because it did.
I think it's very unfortunate that investors have moved into the position of venture capitalists, financing early-stage companies. It's very hard for the private individual investor just looking at the prospectus, and not having a business plan, and not doing any due diligence, and maybe not even reading it, to make an informed decision.
For the companies, I think there will be three different outcomes. I think some will just go by the boards; they will run out of cash and go bankrupt. A few already have, and I think more to come. I think there will be another pattern that will get venture money, even though that's the reverse of the current pattern, getting venture money after you go public, and maybe strategic partner financing. And I think the third category will get normal financing, from banks or the public markets. But I think the public markets are largely closed for most companies.

Q. What about the overall economy?
 
A. I don't think it's Armageddon, but I do believe the probabilities are that our economy is headed to a slower period. I do think there have been a lot of individual excesses in the marketplace, and those will have to be corrected. It shouldn't be that any brand-new person with a few hours in a training course can make a fortune trading stocks.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY;
The Economy Is New, But Not the Standards

BYLINE: By PATRICK J. LYONS 

 BODY:
Wall Street is fond of saying that dot-coms are a breed apart, that none of the old-economy financial and valuation standards necessarily apply. Does the same go for how these new corporations are managed and governed at the top?
Hardly, according to a new survey of institutional investors to be released this week. Two-thirds of respondents said they expected Internet-company boards to be well stocked with members who are independent of management and are competent to oversee important areas of the company's business, just as those on boards of old-economy companies are. 
 "Forward-thinking dot-com companies should closely review their corporate governance practices" in light of the findings, said John T. W. Hawkins of Russell Reynolds Associates, the executive search firm that sponsored the survey, the fifth in an annual series. "The leading companies are starting to migrate away from the small, venture capital dominated board model to larger, more diverse boards."
Money managers surveyed by Wirthlin Worldwide early this year thought new-economy compensation practices needed another look as well. A big majority of the 409 respondents, drawn from the United States and six European countries, favored pricing the stock options granted to officers and directors at a premium, so that recipients benefit only if the stock performs well. And they opposed repricing option grants in a down market without a shareholder vote.
The investors had some expectations for old-economy boards, too. More than two-thirds said every company's board should have a formal Internet issues committee, and nearly as many said every board should include at least one technology expert. And their money is where their mouth is: A majority said they steered away from investing in companies with unsatisfactory governance practices. PATRICK J. LYONS
