HEADLINE: Heard the One About Hip Newark?

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS CENTURY 

 BODY:
ON a recent Thursday evening, at the grand opening of Maize restaurant, a crowd of men in five-button suits and young women wearing Prada and DKNY mingled over passed hors d'oeuvres of tuna tartare, sipping glasses of Gray Goose vodka. As a jazz singer in a spaghetti-strap dress sang "La Vie en Rose," flashbulbs captured the smiles of young artists and musicians, next to the beaming mayor, two former governors and the ageless baseball icon Yogi Berra.
It may have looked like the opening of the latest bistro on Park Avenue South or Spring Street, but what made the gathering notable was that it wasn't in Manhattan at all; it was in downtown Newark, a city not much known for chichi restaurants and the clientele to match. 
 "There's this incredible energy of young artists and writers and musicians coming here, drawn to the realness of the city," said Verushka Spirito, a young woman with a Sinead O'Connor haircut, who stood at the bar with friends.
The opening of Maize, at 50 Park Place, inside the historic Robert Treat Hotel, was certainly a big event by Newark standards; it is easily the most fashionable restaurant the city has seen in years, with a sleek, airy dining room, cigar lounge and tearoom, and an executive chef, Pat Kotsonis, whose resume includes Le Bernardin and Bouley.
It's another indication that a city long moribund, an easy target of late-night monologuists ("First prize is one week in Newark; second prize is two weeks in Newark") is reawakening. Besides an economic resurgence and ambitious real estate developments, Newark is seeing a much less publicized flowering of artists, writers and musicians -- honest-to-goodness bohemians. Hard to believe, but it may be transforming itself into a cool city.
Last Saturday night, Queen Latifah -- the rapper, actress, talk show host and Newark native -- gave a record-release party for her Flavor Unit Entertainment stable of hip-hop artists at Groove, a local nightclub. She is negotiating to develop the Griffith Building on Broad Street into luxury apartments, a restaurant and a nightclub. Shaquille O'Neal, the National Basketball Association's most valuable player, sneaks back to his native Newark from Los Angeles for soul food at Je's Restaurant on Halsey Street, and he is also looking to invest in the city, Mayor Sharpe James said.
Rumors have swirled that Robert De Niro is taking over a waterfront restaurant, though Mr. De Niro's partner in the TriBeCa Grill in Manhattan, Drew Nieporent, said he was unaware of any such plans. Well then, maybe James Gandolfini should think of buying into a riverfront bistro; after all, his Tony Soprano -- inarguably the coolest character on television today -- came by his childhood neuroses in Newark.
It is not the Jersey chic of "The Sopranos," however, that is luring artistically inclined young people to inner Newark. Nor is it the recent building boom, which includes a new baseball park where the minor-league Newark Bears play and a downtown arena that will be home to the New Jersey Nets and the Devils by 2004.
Instead, young transplants cite the reasonable rents and 15-minute trip to Manhattan by New Jersey Transit train; the vibrant mix of Portuguese, Spanish and Brazilian restaurants and bars in the Ironbound section; and a grass-roots fine arts and music scene, which draws even New Yorkers on a reverse night-time commute.
"We've got a lot of friends that come out from Brooklyn and Manhattan for Sounds of the City," Elisabeth Ssenjovu, a programmer of events at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, said of the free outdoor series she oversees. It begins June 1 and features spoken word, rap, reggae, Latin jazz, Dominican and Haitian music. "It's Sounds of the City, not sounds of the suburbs," she added.
Lawrence P. Goldman, the president of the three-year-old performing arts center, which normally books top national artists like the Mark Morris Dance Group, pointed out that the home-grown outdoor series has played an interesting role in the city's social life. "There's a huge young middle-class now in Newark -- white, African-American and Hispanic -- for which there had previously been no civic gathering place," he said. "Basically, what Newark really needed was a good singles scene. That's what Sounds of the City provides, and it doesn't require police or security guards. All it requires is young people willing to meet each other and have a good time."
Naturally, there are skeptics. Many Manhattanites, familiar with the stigma of crime and urban decay that has long hung over this, New Jersey's largest city and still one of its poorest, refuse to believe there's a new Newark. "Get out of here," said Chris Hulbert, a publicist, who has represented trendy New York clubs like Hush and Ohm. "There's no way Newark is cool."
But to spend an afternoon and evening with Ms. Ssenjovu and some of her friends is to get an unmistakable taste of the East Village on the Passaic River. There is a thriving literary movement, ranging from the online Newark Review to a spoken-word series -- whose host is Ras Baraka, a son of Amiri Baraka, the former LeRoi Jones -- at the Lama Lounge on Linden Street.
There's the smoky, couch-filled Euphoria Cafe, in the shadow of the Prudential Insurance Company's global headquarters, at Broad and Academy Streets, which draws a dreadlocked collegiate crowd (and even some suits from Prudential) to poetry slams.
In many ways, Ms. Ssenjovu, 24, tall, lean and wildly energetic, seems to embody the hip side of Newark. "I grew up in the Jersey suburbs, in Union County," she said. "My family's originally from the Ironbound. They're Italians who moved out to the suburbs, and I guess I've come full circle now." She lives with her husband, Patrick, a Ugandan-born actor and performer, in a renovated chocolate factory in the Ironbound, which got its name from the rail lines that encircle it.
Stephanie Voulgaris, the owner of Maize, who was born and raised in Kalamata, Greece, says she has waited years for the city's long-trumpeted renaissance to finally take hold. "I got excited about three years ago in all the activities upcoming in Newark, and I decided that's where I wanted to invest in and to stay," she said. When the arts center opened, "there was no doubt in my mind that it was no longer just a dream -- it was a reality," she continued, adding: "I'd say that the difference I've seen in three years is breathtaking. There are streets where nobody ever wanted to be around 6 p.m., and now people freely walk around at 10 or 11 o'clock."
A generation ago, Harper's magazine called Newark, which never fully recovered from the rioting of the 1960's, the "worst city in America." Its vast tracts of housing projects inspired the nickname Brick City. Nowadays, violent crime is down more than 50 percent from 1995, and real estate values in the immigrant-heavy Ironbound have risen 30 to 40 percent since 1997.
As they toured the streets of the working-class Ironbound, Ms. Ssenjovue and her posse of friends, including Fernando Baptista, born in Portugal, and Khabirah Myers, a native of Newark, jokingly acknowledged that they have the look of a walking Benetton ad.
"I don't know if it's just my generation, or my group of friends, but everybody seems to be in an interracial relationship," Ms. Ssenjovu said. "My husband and I feel very comfortable here, he being African, me being white. I've traveled a lot, but this is the first place I feel is home. I lived in Berlin, I lived in London. I certainly don't feel at home in the suburbs, but it's weird, I really feel at home in Newark."
Lori Barcliff, a young woman who also works at the performing arts center, said, "My family came to Newark in the 30's; my grandparents lived in the West Ward, near South Orange Avenue." After attending college in California and living in Florida, she returned to New Jersey to live in the Ironbound. "I like the cafe culture that's on Ferry Street," she added. "You go to the grocery store, the bakery, the Portuguese fish market, and you can basically do all your shopping on Ferry Street and not have to get in the car."
Asked about recent high-profile investment in the city, including the 11-acre sports arena site that also calls for bars, shops and restaurants, Ms. Ssenjovu said with mock horror: "Just please don't say we're the new Hoboken! That's my biggest fear in the world." She sees Hoboken as a case of gentrification run amok.
"Newark's still got an urban flavor that I don't think will be changed by that," she said. "It's still really edgy."
Ms. Spirito agreed. "You don't want people moving in and all these yuppie bars erupting and suddenly you're losing the Brazilian flavor and the Portuguese flavor," she said. "You'll lose the Haitian community and the Cuban community. That's what makes Newark, and we have to make sure it stays."
For years, Newark has been known as a hip-hop and rhythm and blues hotbed, spawning such artists as Redman, Canibus, Faith Evans, Rah Digga and Lauryn Hill, whose remembrances of her childhood there are captured in her song "Every Ghetto, Every City." ("Every ghetto, every city and suburban place I've been/ Make me recall my days in the New Jerusalem.")
At his desk in the Beaux-Arts City Hall, which has served as the backdrop for Hollywood films like "Presumed Innocent," Mayor James said, "Many of these up-and-coming rap artists have gained strength through struggle, have stepped over a crack vial, stepped over a hypodermic needle, and onto the stage of life."
The city's greatest living cultural figure, however, is a Newark expatriate. From his debut novel, "Goodbye, Columbus," in 1959 to his latest, "The Human Stain," Philip Roth, a product of Newark's Weequahic section, has "turned his bleak part of Jersey and its people into a kind of Jewish Yoknapatawpha County," Robert Stone wrote in a review of another novel, referring to Faulkner's fictional setting.
Mr. Roth's Newark is spectral; the lower- and middle-class Jewish milieu has largely vanished, and his references to contemporary Newark can be biting. "My father was one of those Prince Street guys who loved that city all his life," recounts Swede Levov, the tragic hero of "American Pastoral." "What happened to Newark broke his heart. It's the worst city in the world." He adds: "Used to be the city where they manufactured everything. Now it's the car-theft capital of the world."
Those fictional reminiscences, circa 1995, are now out of date. For one thing, Newark no longer leads the nation in car theft. And many of the 19th-century factories that housed the city's leather, garment and toy manufacturers are seeing a rebirth. On Tuesday, as the temperature topped 90 degrees, Ben Polsky paced around his fourth-floor loft in a factory building on New Jersey Railroad Avenue, wearing shorts and flip-flops.
Mr. Polsky, 34, is a painter, and he shares a 3,500-square-foot loft with his wife, Holli Schworno, 35, also an artist. "The scene here is very organic," he said. "The artists who have come to Newark are a lot less interested in meeting a bunch of other artists down at a cafe; they're interested in having enough space to work and still have some semblance of a family life."
Originally from Miami, Mr. Polsky moved to Newark eight years ago from New York's Lower East Side. He and Ms. Schworno came before the economic boom, when it was still possible to rent 3,000 square feet for $600 a month. And while rents have risen substantially since then, huge studios in the Ironbound still cost a fraction of those in New York City.
In Manhattan, "what they call artists' lofts all look like multimillion-dollar Ikea ads," he said. His loft, across the street from the elevated railroad tracks separating the downtown from the Ironbound, is undeniably authentic: stiflingly hot, paint-splattered, strewn with art-making debris. He smiled and sopped the sweat from his forehead as a New Jersey Transit train whirred past his window at eye level. "We call that our toy train."
Mr. Polsky still hears the skepticism from his Brooklyn and Manhattan friends about Newark's newfound hipness. "We get that all the time," he said, "and quite frankly I hope it continues."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
In Bonds, Worrywarts or the Wise?

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
STOCK investors are optimists by nature, believing that rising share prices can help them achieve their hopes and dreams. The boys and girls in bondland, by contrast, are professional worriers, looking for clouds long before they appear on the horizon.
So it was quite in character last week that the corporate bond market struggled mightily while the major stock indexes held their ground. Still, the gulf between the two markets is remarkably wide. 
 Most people on Wall Street expect the Federal Reserve to raise the federal funds rate by a half-percentage point on Tuesday. Stock investors seem to think the Fed will cool the economy but not stop it cold.
But the bond market acts as if grave economic danger lies ahead. Yields on low-grade corporate bonds are six percentage points above 10-year Treasury yields, a spread also seen in 1998, when Russia defaulted on its debt. Remarkably, high-yield bonds of United States companies recently yielded more than emerging-market debt.
The signals from low-grade bonds of small companies are even worse than in 1998. Martin S. Fridson, chief high-yield strategist at Merrill Lynch, said the yields on small issues now average 3.5 percentage points more than those of large issues. During the Russian crisis, this spread peaked at around 2.5 percentage points.
One of the bond market's biggest problems is that Wall Street dealers are so loath to commit capital that investors are finding it harder to get out of trades. "Dealer liquidity is dramatically reduced in both the high-yield and high-grade markets," said Gary Goodenough, portfolio manager at Loomis Sayles in New York. "This creates more volatility, larger swings and more of a discontinuous market."
Companies are having difficulty raising money. Thomson Securities Data says issuance of corporate bonds is down 20.6 percent this year, versus 1999. Last week, not one high-yield bond issue came to market, a first for this year.
Clearly, bond investors see much greater risk in the market today. One concern is that even in a torrid economy, the default rate is rising -- to 5.6 percent on high-yield bonds, according to Moody's, up from around 3 percent recently. It will rise to 7.7 percent by April 2001, Moody's predicts.
Bond issues from untested companies have made investing in corporate debt much trickier. When investors buy a bond, they try to predict what they will get back if it defaults. In the past, most could count on the return of at least some fraction of their original investment. But the Iridium L.L.C. bankruptcy, in which bondholders will be lucky to get anything, changed expectations.
Another problem is that the securities typically used by investors to hedge corporate bond or mortgage holdings -- Treasury bonds -- no longer work. As the Treasury buys back debt, a stampede of buyers for remaining issues has thrown prices out of sync with the overall market. Hedging a bond position is so hard that many buyers have run away.
"The fixed-income market is rightly assigning a higher risk premium to companies now," said Stan Jonas, managing director at Fimat U.S.A., a broker-dealer in New York. He expects the Fed to raise rates on Tuesday, but unlike many economists, he thinks this increase might be the last. The higher rates, he reckons, will set off financial turmoil -- perhaps a high-profile failure -- forcing the Fed to back off from further rate increases. "When the Fed begins to put on the brakes, somebody goes through the windshield," he said. "We just don't know who it is."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
The Line Forms Here For Northern Exposure

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
CANADA has been called a nation that hews wood and draws water, even though it is home to some of the world's most successful high-technology companies. And after years in the financial wilderness, its economy and its stock market are on the prowl again.
With little fanfare, the Toronto Stock Exchange 300 composite stock index has done much better so far this year than major market indexes elsewhere. 
 The TSE 300 was up 9.5 percent through Friday, compared with a decline of 3.3 percent in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Last year, the TSE 300 outperformed the S.& P. 500, rising 31.7 percent in Canadian dollar terms.
Still, the numbers may be deceiving. Nortel Networks, the big telecommunications company, represents nearly 26 percent of the TSE 300's market value. Last year, the stock rose more than 400 percent. Through Friday, it was up more than 6 percent.
"When your top stock is viewed that favorably, that is very positive," said David Picton, a portfolio manager with Synergy Asset Management in Toronto.
There are other positives besides Nortel.
Price increases for oil and natural gas, as well as for other raw materials, are lifting Canadian natural-resource companies. And the prospect of further consolidation in the financial services industry has put a floor under bank stocks, despite rising interest rates in the United States.
Perhaps most important, the Canadian economy is starting to hum.
In a commentary on Wednesday, David Rosenberg, chief economist and strategist for Merrill Lynch Canada, wrote that "today's economy is arguably the strongest it's been since the mid-1960's."
Mr. Rosenberg said that if consensus forecasts proved correct, the Canadian economy should grow by more than 4 percent this year, adjusted for inflation, and an additional 3.5 percent in 2001.
Benign inflation is another plus. Prices are rising at an annual rate of around 1.5 percent, well below most of the important inflation measures in the United States. And exports are surging.
All of this suggests that the Canadian dollar, which has been in the doldrums, should be rising in value against other currencies, particularly the American dollar. That has not happened yet -- a major positive for American investors, analysts said.
"The currency is cheap and stable," said Robert J. Haber, chief investment officer for Fidelity Canada Ltd., a unit of Fidelity Investments.
Is it too late for investors to buy in? Leila Heckman, managing director of global asset allocation for Salomon Smith Barney, said that eight or nine months ago, Canada "was one of our dream markets."
"The market has moved up a bit," Ms. Heckman said, "but it is still our second choice among developed-country markets behind France."
While many Canadian companies, like Nortel and Celestica, which makes products for Lucent Technologies and Nokia, are listed on both Canadian and American exchanges, most are not. Of the 300 stocks that make up the Toronto index, Ms. Heckman said, only 10 percent are traded in New York.
Mort Cohen, an expatriate Canadian who is chairman of Clarion Partners in Cleveland, which manages about $150 million in hedge and venture funds, said that about 25 percent of his firm's portfolio was invested in Canadian energy stocks.
Mr. Cohen said he owned Anderson Exploration, Canadian Occidental and Talisman Energy, and two drillers -- Precision Drilling and the Ensign Resource Service Group.
Mr. Picton at Synergy Asset Management also owns Anderson Exploration, as well as Alberta Energy and Canadian Natural Resources. Despite Nortel's lofty valuation, he said he likes it for long-term investors. And he said that while he was not very excited about Canadian financial stocks, particularly the banks, he was a big fan of Toronto Dominion Bank.
"Our banks are ripe for consolidation," he said. "That will carry them for the next 6 to 12 months. But beyond that, they are shrinking relative to international competition."
Toronto Dominion is another story. "Toronto Dominion has a big holding in TD Waterhouse," he said, referring to the the New York-based online brokerage firm, one of the top five. "I think TD Waterhouse has the capability of becoming an Internet bank."
THE downside risk to further increases in Canadian stock prices is the 800-pound gorilla next door.
"If the Federal Reserve tightens monetary policy too much and the U.S. economy rolls over, Canada will feel that recession," said Dan Chornous, chief strategist at RBC Dominion Securities in Toronto.
"But if there is a soft landing in the U.S.," "corporate earnings in Canada will prove to be sustainable," he continued. "At that juncture, the Canadian market will be really well-placed."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Why G.M. Is Getting A Cold Shoulder

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
THE car business is booming these days -- in Europe, Mexico and Brazil as well as in the United States -- and the shares of General Motors have climbed nearly 17 percent so far this year. Of course, G.M. has major technology exposure in the form of its Hughes Electronics business. (While G.M. owns all of Hughes's assets, G.M.'s class H shares are designed to track the unit's earnings independently.)
Even with G.M.'s run-up, however, its stock trades at less than nine times projected earnings, scarcely one-third the average multiple accorded the Dow industrials. 
 Yet analysts have recently soured on G.M., still the world's biggest company by revenue. In the last two weeks, many of them have cut their ratings on the stock.
One of them, John A. Casesa, a managing director at Merrill Lynch, took time on Thursday to explain his change of heart about G.M. and why its archrival, Ford Motor, seems relatively attractive. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. We know that investors usually look ahead, not in rear-view mirrors. But sales are still setting records, with G.M.'s new pickup trucks a huge hit. What's not to like?
 
A. Autos are early-cycle stocks. They tend to outperform dramatically as the economy recovers and underperform later. We're very deep into this current cycle. Since 1991, 130 million vehicles have been sold in the U.S. Essentially, every household has replaced at least one vehicle. It's a risky time to invest.
 
Q. But everybody seemed to love the stock until the last few weeks. What's changed?
 
A. It has been terrific because the company's done some brilliant financial engineering. It is monetizing a big chunk of its very valuable stake in Hughes Electronics, essentially using high-priced Hughes stock to buy back low-priced G.M. common.
The reason we lowered our opinion is that this transaction, which was announced in February, comes to an end May 19. Then the outlook goes back to automotive fundamentals, which is a very peaky market and, in G.M.'s case, means a continuing struggle to stabilize its market share.
 
Q. But aren't the new Silverado and Sierra pickups quite competitive?
 
A. There's a big shift in emphasis in the company's plans, away from passenger cars and toward light trucks. But it's largely catch-up. The new products are better than the old ones, but they still have to contend with the declining competitiveness of these older products.
 
Q. G.M.'s market capitalization of about $53 billion is only one-eighth that of Cisco. Could somebody like Rupert Murdoch really take it over, as some people have suggested?
 
A. There's a great deal of interest in Hughes, in particular its DirecTV business. The rumored buyers are News Corporation and even Disney. Even after the current deal, G.M. will still own more than $10 billion of the Hughes tracking stock, or 15 percent.
Investors are eager to know whether someone will come along and pay a big premium for Hughes and spin off the automotive business. But it's not that easy to do. Since G.M. owns 100 percent of Hughes's equity, it would require a very friendly deal with G.M.; it would have to get done on their terms. And there are very practical political, labor and regulatory issues.
 
Q. But G.M.'s history has been to sell off noncore businesses, as with Delphi last year.
 
A. That's right. In fact, it's not a matter of if G.M. will divest the rest of Hughes, it's a matter of when. They want to get the maximum price, and capital gains are a consideration. Divestiture is not around the corner.
 
Q. What are you advising clients to do about the offer expiring on May 19 to swap each share of their G.M. stock for 1.065 shares of Hughes?
 
A. We're advising that people tender. It's a very attractive way to get some Hughes and lower your exposure to the auto business. But the deal is limited so you won't be able to exchange all your shares, only 14 percent of them if every G.M. share was tendered.
 
Q. At the same time, you're recommending putting money into Ford. Why?
 
A. Just as G.M. is completing this value-enhancing transaction, Ford is about to do the same thing on a smaller scale.
Ford, which has billions in excess capital, will give shareholders a big cash dividend sometime before the end of July and then spin off to them its parts business called Visteon.
 
Q. Is Ford better as a car company than G.M.?
 
A. I think so. Its margins are higher, and it has acquired Jaguar, Volvo and now is adding Land Rover. . . . This takes the product line more upscale, and luxury cars are far more profitable than mass-market cars. And Ford has laid out a credible plan to improve its European business, which has been a mess.

HEADLINE: The World: AIDS in South Africa;
A President Misapprehends a Killer

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

 BODY:
THE tone and substance of the letter was so peculiar that some officials in Washington thought it was a hoax. In a five-page letter to President Clinton last month, South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, argued that his country had to chart its own course in dealing with AIDS, including consulting those who challenged prevailing views on the causes and treatments of the disease.
A "campaign of intellectual intimidation and terrorism" akin to "medieval book-burning" was keeping such voices from being heard, Mr. Mbeki wrote. 
 The letter was no hoax, and it touched off an uproar, in part because South Africa's democratic politics and advanced industry make it the natural leader in the fight against a disease that has devastated Africa. This status was acknowledged in the nation's selection to sponsor this year's international AIDS conference. Yet here was Nelson Mandela's anointed successor questioning many years of scientific research. Never mind that Mr. Mandela hardly mentioned the disease during his presidency.
In the weeks since, many South Africans have engaged in a kind of psychoanalysis of the 57-year-old president they elected last year. Why did this cultured man, educated as an economist at Sussex University in England, take such a position? What does he gain from it?
Mr. Mbeki is the only African leader to have questioned the consensus theory on AIDS. He has, moreover, an embattled history with the disease, having first become embroiled in the scientific debate three years ago, when Mr. Mandela's cabinet backed research into Virodene, a supposed cure developed locally that turned out to be carcinogenic.
Attacked by scientists, the health minister in Mr. Mandela's government, which Mr. Mbeki was virtually running, refused to back down, and it later turned out that stock in the company set up to make Virodene had been given to the ruling African National Congress.
Virodene was discredited long before Mr. Mbeki began publicly questioning the causes of AIDS, so there seems little reason to believe that led to his present position. But it helped create the ill-will that exists between the scientific establishment and the A.N.C.
Last year, Mr. Mbeki stunned experts by questioning the safety of the standard anti-AIDS drug AZT, which the government has declined to distribute to pregnant women despite studies indicating that it could greatly reduce the transmission of the virus to newborns.
Still, AIDS activists are shocked by Mr. Mbeki's refusal to accept the standard scientific model of the disease. Political analysts, meanwhile, say they can see little political gain for him or for his party (which took 66 percent of the vote in the 1999 elections) in his stance.
Most see it as a personal decision from a man who, since his teens, has lived largely in exile, petitioning world leaders to help fight apartheid. They say that Mr. Mbeki's desire to reject Western thinking -- and condescension -- is strong, and his speeches have repeatedly called for an African renaissance.
"He is very keen on doing things in an African way and not just accepting the gospel from the West," said Raymond Louw, editor of the weekly newsletter Southern Africa Report. "You hear this all the time."
Wishful thinking about a cheap cure may also have played a part, some say, since South Africa isn't nearly rich enough to afford $15,000 AIDS cocktails, (or even $3,000 ones, if drug companies cut prices, as they indicated they might last week) for the 13 percent of the population that is infected.
Others believe that Mr. Mbeki simply couldn't help himself. He has repeatedly displayed a stubborn inclination to master technical issues in his own way, and in a highly personal speech recently he told of Internet searches with dictionaries at his side as he looked for information that might help him formulate his country's AIDS policies.
Whether his current approach -- convening a "What Causes AIDS?" panel divided between orthodox AIDS researchers and those who believe it is caused by malnutrition and parasites -- will help or hurt his country is an open question. Heading the panel of 33 experts is William Makgoba, who runs South Africa's equivalent of the National Institute of Health. Mr. Makgoba strongly supports the standard model of AIDS, but said that bringing the dissidents "into the tent" will be a good thing.
MR. MAKGOBA believes Mr. Mbeki to be a "very intellectual person" who is trying to inform himself on a disease that is ravaging his country. He wishes, however, that Mr. Mbeki had informed himself in private, fearing that he will be classified "as one of those African leaders who doesn't care about science or technology."
Tom Lodge, a professor of political science at the University of Witwatersrand, says that Mr. Mbeki shows the personality traits of what he calls "an interferer, not a delegater." It is a trait that has come up in other arenas as well, he says.
At the moment, Professor Lodge points out, Mr. Mbeki is shuttling back and forth to Zimbabwe, trying to ease the tensions over the violence that has broken out as supporters of President Robert Mugabe have seized white-owned farms. But Professor Lodge says Mr. Mbeki should let his foreign minister do the traveling. "He is running up to Harare every two minutes like an office boy," Professor Lodge said. "The AIDS issue is the same. Maybe he will learn the lesson that a head of state does not busy himself with details."

HEADLINE: Chernobyl Revisited

 BODY:
Fourteen years after the worst accident in the history of nuclear power, Ukraine seems determined to shut down the lone active reactor remaining at Chernobyl by the end of the year. The long overdue decision will close a reactor that has experienced an unsettling variety of minor failures and end power generation at a complex that once contained four nuclear plants. But in other ways the Chernobyl accident still haunts the people and lands of the former Soviet Union. The steel and concrete shell encasing the radioactive ruins of the destroyed reactor is leaking and must be replaced.
Reactors with similar designs to those at Chernobyl -- and considerable safety problems -- still operate in Russia and Lithuania. Several countries in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union depend on other types of Soviet-built reactors that also fall short of Western safety standards. These are expensive problems, requiring money that former Soviet bloc nations do not have. The West has provided millions in financial assistance, but it will have to contribute more to improve nuclear safety and close dangerous reactors. 
 The sarcophagus that houses the No. 4 reactor at Chernobyl, the one that exploded in April 1986, is unstable and cracked. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is trying to raise $768 million to reseal the tomb temporarily and to build a new one. So far, the United States and European nations have given only about half that amount. When donor nations meet in Berlin this summer, they must pledge to pay the balance.
A second need is to continue to care for those affected by the Chernobyl disaster. The greatest problem is thyroid cancer in people who were children at the time of the accident. Most of the 2,000 victims so far live in Belarus and are being treated with help from the World Health Organization.
In 1992, the Group of Seven industrialized nations recommended the closure of 25 Soviet-designed reactors, including all Chernobyl-style power plants. These reactors -- there are 14 today -- are considered the most dangerous. Though they have been upgraded to fix the flaws that contributed to the Chernobyl disaster, they remain unsafe. The 43 other Soviet-design reactors in use are considered somewhat safer, but all need more backup systems and other protective measures. The poverty of former Soviet nations adds to the risk. At Chernobyl, for example, maintenance is slighted and employees have often had to wait months for their paychecks.
The desire to join the European Union has encouraged Lithuania, Slovakia and Bulgaria to try to meet European safety standards by scheduling early closing of their most dangerous reactors. It is no small sacrifice for a poor nation to shut down a source of cheap energy. Lithuania, for example, is planning to close one of its two reactors, which together provide 75 percent of the country's power.
The industrialized nations have been talking about helping Ukraine to close Chernobyl for years. Their aid will take the form of loans to complete two new nuclear reactors -- a bad idea, as the reactors will not meet Western safety standards. The safer, if costlier, choice would be to build a coal plant and improve the energy efficiency of existing factories. Few catastrophes have less respect for borders than a nuclear meltdown. Unsafe reactors are an international problem, and decommissioning requires international cooperation.

HEADLINE: DATABANK: MAY 8-12;
Wall Street Remains on a Fed Alert

BYLINE: By VIVIAN MARINO 

 BODY:
A dash of positive economic news and strong quarterly earnings helped pull some stocks out of the dumps, but most investors remain fixated on the Federal Reserve. 
 We had a nice rally at the end of the week, but the volume has been very light, said Barry Berman, head trader for Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee. The market is really on a Fed watch.
 Fed policy makers are expected to raise short-term interest rates by as much as half a percentage point when they meet on Tuesday. The central bank is concerned that the economy is growing too rapidly and that inflation will heat up.
 But economic data released last week gave some indication that the economy is slowing. The government reported that wholesale prices showed a 0.3 percent decline in April, reversing two months of increases, and that retail sales slowed in the same month.
 Blue-chip stocks posted gains, and many companies reported solid earnings, including Dell Computer.
 The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week at 10,609.37, up 31.51 points. The Nasdaq composite index settled at 3,529.06, down 287.76
 VIVIAN MARINO

HEADLINE: MY FIRST JOB;
Your $40 Pledge, Her $3 Tote Bag Work That Matched The Moment

BYLINE: By JEREMY RIFKIN; Written with Barnaby J. Feder; Jeremy Rifkin, 55, a technology gadfly and consultant who heads the Foundation on Economic Trends in Washington, has just published "The Age of Access: The New Culture of Hypercapitalism Where All of Life Is A Paid-for Experience" (Jeremy P. Tarcher/Putnam).

 BODY:
I WORKED during high school for my father, who had a small business on the South Side of Chicago manufacturing plastic bags. He wanted me to take it over, which was supposedly why I went to the University of Pennsylvania to study at the Wharton School, but I had no intention of going back. It was 1963, and I became involved in civil rights and then the antiwar movement.
 After graduate work at Tufts University's Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, I got my first real job in summer 1968, as a Vista volunteer. Most of the work involved helping people deal with the welfare system. I lived with Ernestine Royster, a welfare rights activist in Queens, and her eight children, then moved to an East Harlem apartment. It was firebombed, and my car was destroyed. My roommate and I never found out who did it. Vista moved us to Yonkers, and I was assigned to work in White Plains for the rest of my year. 
 I had grown up in a working class neighborhood with poor people. But I learned in Vista that you cannot really know what overwhelming poverty is like until you have lived with the people suffering it. I also learned that grass-roots organizing has its limits, although it took more time to appreciate them. You can get attention in the streets, and that's a prerequisite for change, but it's not enough. You also have to have real policy ideas and a national thrust.
 I think a lot of life is determined by the historical moment you are caught in. If I were seven years older, I might well have ended up running the family business.

HEADLINE: Marchers And Their Imprints

BYLINE: By John B. Judis; John B. Judis is a senior editor of The New Republic and the author of "The Paradox of American Democracy."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On this Mother's Day, thousands of mothers will march on Washington to demand tough new gun control legislation, but it is unlikely that the Million Mom March will prove effective in getting Congress to act. Americans have been marching on Washington to demand change ever since the populist Jacob Coxey led his ragtag army of the unemployed from Ohio to Washington during the depression of the 1890's. Some of these marches have had lasting and visible effect, but others have been quickly forgotten.
The most successful marches have made straightforward, but far-reaching, demands that the president or Congress could conceivably meet. Participants in the August 1963 civil rights march demanded that Congress pass the civil rights bill that had already been introduced; the antiwar marchers in October 1967 demanded that the Johnson administration get out of Vietnam. 
 The effective marches have also attracted not just unexpectedly large numbers, but usually the participation of important and powerful public figures. Walter Reuther, the head of the United Auto Workers, had a prominent role in the 1963 march, along with Martin Luther King Jr. and the N.A.A.C.P.'s Roy Wilkins. The 1967 antiwar demonstration featured leading literary lights, including Robert Lowell, Allen Ginsberg and Norman Mailer, who celebrated the march in "The Armies of the Night."
Perhaps most important, marches that have won the most serious attention have embodied, implicitly or explicitly, the threat of nonviolent civic disruption and national embarrassment. They carried an intimation of chaos, if not in the demonstration itself, then from what could occur afterward. This sort of threat was obvious in the 1932 Bonus March of World War I veterans, which helped discredit President Herbert Hoover, and in the 1967 and 1969 antiwar marches.
This last characteristic has held true for the most successful civil rights demonstrations. The massive 1963 march was entirely peaceful, though its leaders included three proponents of civil disobedience: King, James Farmer of the Congress of Racial Equality and John Lewis of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee. The march didn't just make a moral appeal; it sent a warning that the more obstreperous parts of the movement would not accept defeat.
One of the most successful marches on Washington never happened at all. In 1941, as the country began preparing for war, A. Phillip Randolph, the chairman of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, began to organize a huge march on Washington to demand that President Franklin Roosevelt issue an executive order banning discrimination in defense industries and the armed forces. Roosevelt, fearful that the demonstration would weaken support among blacks for the coming war effort, capitulated and signed the executive order five days before the march was to occur.
The less successful demonstrations of recent years have all fallen short in at least one crucial respect. Civil rights marches in 1983 and 1993 attracted as many people as the 1963 march, but they lacked either a clear and achievable demand or the threat of disruption. They functioned largely as uplifting social events, as have Earth Day demonstrations, which have become little more than concerts on the Mall. The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Solidarity Day in 1981, which attracted 260,000 demonstrators, and the 300,000-strong abortion rights march in 1989 were forgettable because it was not clear what was being demanded or what exactly would happen if the demands were not met.
Today's Million Mom March promises to be a stirring event. It has certainly inspired political discussion and reflection, and it may contribute to making gun control a more salient issue in the fall elections. The leaders are calling for handgun registration and licensing -- a reasonably dramatic demand -- but they are not even insisting that the president sign on. And the only threat is far off: the marchers' opposition at the polls in November. (Won't most of them be voting for pro-gun control candidates anyway?)
Moreover, there is no hint of disorder. The marchers are not contemplating picketing gun stores, clogging the aisles at gun shows or sitting in at the offices of recalcitrant politicians -- activities that would raise the costs of not taking the moms seriously.
These tactics may not be necessary for getting controls on guns. It might make more sense to create a national organization of mothers who can walk precincts and run ads against politicians who oppose gun control. That's the way much of politics is conducted today, and there is nothing wrong with it. But if that is what the proponents of gun control want to do, then the Million Mom March, no matter how wonderful an occasion, is only a small, and perhaps not even needed, step.
Organizations rarely grow out of marches, as Bayard Rustin, the organizer of the 1963 civil rights march learned when he tried to sustain the coalition.
If the moms marching today are serious about winning the battle over gun control, they will have to show the allies of the National Rifle Association that if they continue to block legislation, they may have to face opposition more daunting than Sunday marchers or precinct walkers.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: The Nation: The Children's Hour;
Hugging and Kissing Your Way Into the White House

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AT first glance, it was hard to say whether the scene looked more like a television chat show or a "Saturday Night Live" parody. There on a Washington stage last month sat Gov. George W. Bush, his wife, Laura, and two prominent Republican officeholders, both women, all in a semicircle and awaiting their first guest.
On cue, out walked an adorable second grader with a giant white bow in her hair, along with one of her teachers. As the women beamed, Mr. Bush asked 7-year-old Elena Douglass, "How is it here in the nation's capital? Are you having a good time?" 
 "Yes, sir, very," she whispered into her hand-held microphone.
"Me too," confided Mr. Bush, who was using her to showcase his interest in literacy and foreign language instruction.
Call it the infantilization of politics. Ever since President Clinton won re-election four years ago with child-centered issues like school uniforms, literacy and teenage smoking, candidates have increasingly behaved as if they are auditioning for the role of Santa Claus, and not running for public office.
Yes, politicians have always kissed babies. And yes, even in 1988, both George Bush, the father, and Michael Dukakis were vying to be the education president. But it was Mr. Clinton who built a whole campaign around children, displaying his empathy for working parents by watching children make model airplanes, or dropping into a school that requires uniforms, or reading along with towheaded tykes.
Bob Dole, his Republican opponent, once complained, "You give President Clinton five minutes on television, he'll mention children 15 times."
This time around there are no complaints. Everybody's doing it. Just try to count how many times over the last year that Mr. Bush has read "The Very Hungry Caterpillar" to kindergartners to demonstrate his commitment to literacy. He said it was his favorite book from childhood -- no matter that it wasn't published until 1969, a year after he graduated from Yale.
Or how about Al Gore in New Hampshire, where he not only knelt to read "Tikvah Means Hope" to 6-year-old Nikkita Gottling, but bought her the book and autographed it?
These days, Mr. Gore can regularly be found in schools, eating in the cafeteria or sitting at a student's desk. This habit may even have raised the level of debate. At one high school, students were discussing the Plessy v. Ferguson case of 1896, in which the United States Supreme Court upheld the concept of separate but equal facilities for blacks and whites.
Voters have put education and the decline of civic and cultural values at the top of their list of concerns. The boomers have made raising children an obsession, while more and more women voters are trying to balance motherhood and work.
"If you will check out your Jeep Cherokee, you will see the vanity mirror is on both sides," said Alex Castellanos, a Republican political consultant. "It's now on the driver's side and the soccer mom has her hand on the steering wheel. The soccer mom is 70 percent of consumer spending. Two out of three new college entrants are women. The economic power has shifted and she's still the key swing voter in suburban America."
What better way to play gender politics than by having a child on your lap? It telegraphs warmth, empathy and understanding. "Everyone who is running for office has to bend over backward to show that they know what it's like to be a typical American family," said Rachel Gorlin, a Democratic media consultant.
Anyone who wanted a demonstration of the emotional power of an encounter with a child had only to watch Mr. Clinton hug a boy on crutches at the funeral for Cardinal John O'Conner, leaving the other dignitaries looking stiff and remote by comparison. Still, a few lonely voices in both parties deplore the dumbing down of political dialogue.
"It atrophies the muscle of political debate," says Jeff Faux, a liberal Democrat at the Economic Institute, a Washington policy research center, who argues that it all started with Ronald Reagan's success with political imagery.
William Kristol, the editor of The Weekly Standard, blames Mr. Clinton. "The kid card is used as a trump and it trumps all debate," he said. "You say this is good for our kids and that's the end of it, instead of here are the arguments for and against the measure."
Then again, Bill Bradley and John McCain, the primary candidates who ran on "authenticity" and "substance," lost.
In fact, politicians are using people as props more than ever. They hold small panel discussions with people who agree with them, to highlight some policy proposal. The elderly are paraded for discussion of Social Security. Nurses stand around listening to talk of health care.
Most Republicans say they are delighted they have a nominee with some of Mr. Clinton's political skills and an ability to soften their party's image. "Unfortunately, politics is about symbols and I don't even think you can overdo it," said David Horowitz, whose pamphlet "The Art of Political War" has been circulating among House Republicans.
Several recent polls have shown Mr. Bush in the lead, and making a strong showing among married women, a swing group that Mr. Clinton won in 1996. So don't be surprised to see Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore surrounded by children, reading away like school librarians, right up to November.

HEADLINE: A Plague in New Orleans, With Jaws of Steel

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
It is the height of the social season here. Every year around Mother's Day, emboldened by humidity as dense as wet laundry, tens of thousands of couples, romantically lit by gaslights, descend upon the historic French Quarter to mate.
It is Formosan termite swarm season, a time of year when termite wing cases flutter in the breeze and homeowners wonder if they have stumbled into a 1950's horror film. Formosan subterranean termites with an insatiable taste for irreplaceable historic structures have been devastating the French Quarter, drawn to its moist, porous bricks and centuries-old wood, ravaging ancient live oak trees. The Quarter is ground zero in the federal government's $15 million effort to thwart the Formosan, the most destructive species of termite in the world, capable of building colonies of up to 10 million writhing white bugs, which devour an average of 1,000 pounds of wood a year. Native termite colonies, one-tenth the size, eat a meager 7 pounds per year. 
 An exotic species probably imported in the 1940's in infested planks aboard military cargo ships, the Formosan termite has spread through 11 states, creating an estimated $1 billion a year in damage, $300 million of it in greater New Orleans. Eighty percent of the city's historic structures have been affected, and almost every house, experts say.
The Formosans have found their Galatoire's in this languid semitropical climate where sometimes it can be difficult to distinguish the air from the water.
Bugs are eating their way through landmarks along the Gulf Coast, from barracks at the Citadel in Charleston, S.C., to cast-iron fronted stores in Galveston's Strand Historic District. And they are heading north, having been confirmed in North Carolina.
Much of their movement can be traced to humankind: infested railroad ties sold for raised planting beds and other landscaping, said Brian Forschler, an associate professor at the University of Georgia.
In New Orleans, termite baits round out historic decor, lying in wait behind Victorian velvet settees, beneath Persian rugs. In swarm season, which lasts through June and is triggered by 80-degree temperatures with 85 percent humidity, flying Formosans, called alates, leave their nests by the tens of thousands to build new colonies, blinding motorists in bewinged blizzards.
"You can't have people over," said Roland Behan, who lives in the Lower Pontalba apartments, built in 1851, overlooking Jackson Square. "You don't want them to step in the wrong spot and go through the floor."
Jimmy and Marie Cahn, longtime residents of an 1840's Creole cottage, remember all too well the dinner party they threw last year that was interrupted by clouds of termites streaming out of the kitchen walls, swarming toward the fanlights and dropping into the chicken cacciatore. They have not made it since. "It kind of kills the mood," Mr. Cahn said.
In a city below sea level with a long history of flood and pestilence -- yellow fever epidemics killed thousands -- termite damage is both physical and psychological, playing into its citizens' predilection for dark humor and fatalism.
"In New Orleans we're addicted to apocryphal stories," said Patrick Dunne, a well-known antiques dealer. He tells of a client who complained that her 18th-century Venetian mirror was hanging crookedly, only to discover its wooden backing riddled with termites.
With powerful mandibles and droplet-shaped heads, Formosan subterranean termites are more intrusive foragers than their native counterparts, tunneling through plaster, creosote, plastic, asphalt, electrical high-voltage wire, utility poles, even espresso makers, to find food and water. A queen can live for 30 years and lay up to 1,000 eggs a day.
Dr. Gregg Henderson, an associate professor of entomology at Louisiana State University Agricultural Center in Baton Rouge, calls the swarm "the eighth wonder of the world." He is working with the United States Department of Agriculture and the New Orleans Mosquito and Termite Control Board on Operation Full Stop, a national termite eradication program which includes treating 15 blocks in the 100-block French Quarter.
Dr. Dennis Ring, his colleague at the Center, added, "This termite flies. We can reduce numbers. Eradicating them is just not going to happen."
New Orleans architecture is custom-made for termites: flat-roofed wooden structures with shared walls and porous stucco, designed with a cooling wicking action to absorb moisture in days before air-conditioning. Joists supporting floors and ceilings sit in pockets in the ancient brick, providing "a Ho Chi Minh trail between bricks and mortar and their food source," said Marc Cooper, director of the Vieux Carre Commission, the city preservation agency that oversees the French Quarter.
One house in Lake Charles, La., has a colony estimated at 70 million Formosan termites.
Around this time of year, lights are dimmed at dusk and the talk revolves around baiting and trapping, giving the "city that care forgot" the impression of a gigantic Rod & Gun club. In the testing area around Jackson Square, tourists pass sticky traps and step unawares on shiny silver discs implanted in the sidewalk, indicating underground baits. Baiting, which costs about $1,500 a year a house, is the newest and most promising treatment thus far. In contrast to traditional pesticides, which create a poison barrier around a building, baits contain wood laced with a low-toxicity pesticide that prevents the termites from shedding their exoskeleton during molting, essentially strangling them in their own skin. They carry the toxin -- the termite equivalent of an Obituary Cocktail, a legendary local drink -- back to the nest, infecting their cohorts.
The termites hid successfully for 25 years, reaching a critical mass a decade ago. "They're cryptic insects," said Ed Bordes, the administrator of the city's Mosquito and Termite Control Board. Three years after a colony is formed, the population starts "square-rooting" and continues to do so each year, said Ed Martin, an entomologist and president of Terminix New Orleans, a pest-control franchise. The infestation has grown bigger since 1987, when chlordane, an effective termiticide, was banned by the Environmental Protection Agency as a probable human carcinogen.
Because of central heating, entomologists say that Formosan termites may have the potential to survive in more northerly climates.
Baiting is having promising results in some of the city's most treasured landmarks, which just a few years ago were infested. They include the majestic Cabildo, built in 1795-1799, where the Louisiana Purchase was signed, (now part of the Louisiana State Museum) the Presbytere, 1795-1847, originally built as the rectory for St. Louis Cathedral, and Perseverance Hall (1820), a longstanding cultural center for the African-American community. "We're going after the enemy instead of letting him come to us," said Mr. Martin.
Preliminary research in treated areas of the French Quarter indicates that scientists have turned a corner in their battle. At a recent public update for residents of the quarter, entomologists bearing charts and red pointers explained ways to invite termites into your home. These included air-conditioning leaks and polystyrene slab insulation, which likened to a "great big termite Po Boy."
Some homeowners with termites volunteer as trappers during swarm season, when the insects are dramatically visible. They use fluorescent lights to draw them to buckets with metal traps.
"There are nights when they all seem to get together and say, 'Let's rumble,' " Mrs. Cahn said. "It's atrocious. You can hear the low hum of wings beating."
The economics of Formosan termite infestation are of greatest concern to residents here. Termite inspections are mandatory before the purchase of a property, but they are of limited effectiveness. When inspecting a house, pest-control operators are not responsible for pulling up floor boards or checking inaccessible crawl spaces.
Despite regular termite inspections, Janet and Scott Howard and their children one day discovered a terrible infestation in their 1920's Federal house in the city's historic Garden District, its renovated dining room inspired by the Pompeiian Room at the Met, she said. Termites had turned their joists, in her words, "into straw." They say it will cost around $400,000 to repair the damage. Of that, $150,000 is reimbursable through her pest-control company, which they are suing for misdiagnosing the problem and for improper repairs.
There is no federal disaster relief for homeowners. Deloise Rainey, 63, a deli clerk nearing retirement, lives about 10 miles from the French Quarter. One day she saw dust on the kitchen counter. A year later, it was the walls. "When I pushed the wall they were peeking out at me," she said. Then she discovered mud tunnels in the sheetrock. Over the past five years, she has spent about $5,000 on repairs and another $1,000 on pest control, she said. "I'm spending all my money on termites," she said.
Last month, Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, introduced a bill proposing tax relief for homeowners. It would change the definition of casualty loss to include Formosan termites. It would also provide low-interest loans for treatment. "It's not a sudden disaster," Ms. Landrieu said, "but it is certain."
The Formosans have reached the San Diego area.
And in Hawaii, residents have been battling the termites for well over a century. The famed Iolani Palace in Honolulu, built in 1845, was so decimated that it had to be totally rebuilt in 1879. Builders are now required to use chemically treated wood for framing. But in Louisiania, builders object that it would add $3,000 to the price of each house.
Many Hawaiian builders are also turning to steel and concrete construction, a more expensive solution.
Building techniques are evolving even in historic structures. In New Orleans, the old clock in the tower of St. Patrick's church was recently replaced with a fiberglass version, its beams with steel, its wooden floors with lightweight concrete.
In their never-ending search for what one scientist called the termite's "Achilles' heel," researchers are focusing on behavior and detection, hoping to find termites within walls by homing in on the sound the emit. They are also studying vetiver, a fragrant grass cultivated for centuries by the Creoles that contains nootkatone, a natural repellent.
Still, community-wide action, such as the one in the French Quarter, seem to hold the most promise. "It's an effort that has to cut across property boundaries," said Professor Forschler, of the University of Georgia.
In the Quarter, Mother's Day finds residents in a philosophical mood. "God may have said 'subdue the earth,' observed Kenneth Hedrick, rector of the landmark St. Louis Cathedral in Jackson Square, which is still battling termites. "But some things can't be subdued."

HEADLINE: TEACHERS OFFERED A TAX EXEMPTION

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 13

 BODY:
In a striking gesture of support for public education, Gov. Gray Davis today proposed to exempt California public school teachers from the state's personal income tax, in what state officials said they believed was the first such peacetime exemption for any occupation in American history.
State officials said the proposal, part of the governor's revised budget package to be announced on Monday, would amount to an income tax cut of $1,350 for the average experienced California teacher, who earns about $50,000 a year. 
 The state has about 283,000 credentialed public school teachers, and the estimated annual cost of the program, which is subject to legislative approval, would initially be $545 million out of a total statewide budget of about $90 billion.
At the same time, the governor proposed to spend another $500 million a year to reward teachers whose schools show improvements in student performance.
Under this plan, teachers whose schools show an improvement rate of 20 percent or more based on the state's new academic performance index, which ranks schools according to standardized tests, would receive one-time bonuses of $5,000 each, while others would receive lesser amounts based on their schools' performances.
That amounts to a form of merit pay that rewards collective achievement by an entire school, as opposed to individual teachers, which education unions generally oppose.
"You know I value all work, whether you're a janitor, middle manager or a C.E.O., and I take a back seat to no one in my respect for people who put themselves in harm's way, such as firefighters, policemen, paramedics," Mr. Davis said in a conference call with reporters, when asked why he was singling out one profession.
"But I really believe we have to make a simple declarative statement that above all else, teaching matters," he said. "This is the single most important profession to us in the Year 2000 and that's the statement I'm making."
In New York, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature recently agreed to create a program that would cover the cost of college tuition, up to $3,400 annually for four years, for students who agree to teach in schools with severe teacher shortages. The plan would also help the state's 11,500 uncertified teachers cover the costs of college courses to become fully licensed teachers.
California has often been a trend-setter in tax policy, and Mr. Davis, who took office two years ago vowing to make education his "first, second and third" priority, has sometimes been mentioned as a potential Democratic vice-presidential contender.
But as a fiscal conservative, cautious to a fault, he has also faced growing criticism for not moving swiftly enough in a booming economy to redress the severe educational problems in a state that once led the nation in per-pupil spending and investments in education but that since the tax revolt of Proposition 13 in 1978 has seen itself slip toward the bottom in numerous national rankings.
Mr. Davis, the first Democrat to lead the state in 16 years, had faced pressure from fellow Democrats in Sacramento and especially sharp attacks from the state's largest teachers' union, which had threatened to sponsor a statewide ballot initiative this fall that would have required California to return its per-pupil spending, which has lagged in the bottom third of states in recent years, to the national average over the next five years. Mr. Davis has opposed that measure as requiring a costly tax increase.
This week, the union agreed to drop the measure after the governor proposed an additional $1.8 billion in discretionary spending for education, intended to compensate for the lean years of the early 1990's, when teachers were forced to do without cost-of-living increases in wages to help close looming budget deficits.
This year, with a projected budget surplus of $11 billion to $13 billion, the challenge has been how to spend the unexpected money.
Senior Davis aides said the idea of the tax exemption, which would apply to fully credentialed teachers from kindergarten through 12th grade, arose at a brainstorming session in a staff retreat last week.
"He's made a huge statement about the importance of teaching," said one senior adviser, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "What are the Republicans going to say? They and the teachers are going to be hard pressed to oppose this."
In fact, legislative Republicans have said they believe there is room in the budget to spend perhaps an additional $3 billion on education, and while they may well be wary of anything that looks like special treatment for the teachers' unions, it seems likely that they would have trouble objecting to the symbolism of Mr. Davis's gesture, which was held in extraordinary secrecy by the governor's staff over the last week so as to make a maximum public splash.
The State Senate Republican leader, Jim Brulte of Rancho Cucamonga, said his members favored tax relief but believed it should be "for all taxpayers in California, not just for one group." Mr. Brulte said he wanted to review the proposal before commenting further, but added, "It'll make my kid brother happy: he's a teacher."
Barbara Kerr, the vice president of the California Teachers Association, the state's largest teachers' union, expressed pleasure at Mr. Davis's proposal.
"It's an incredible package," Ms. Kerr said. "It's a positive step, and I think it's going to help the kids of California. It shows teachers are valued, and it's awfully creative."
Davis aides said their research had shown various past tax exemptions for certain employee groups, but only in wartime.
Under the Davis plan, public school teachers would be permitted to deduct 100 percent of their teaching income on state personal income tax returns. The estimated tax relief for a beginning teacher would be $500 a year, rising to $1,350 for experienced teachers.
The tax break for teachers is just one element of Mr. Davis's proposals for doling out the budget surplus. Other plans include a $150 rebate for every income-tax payer to the state, and $300 for couples who file joint returns, at a total cost of $1.76 billion. Other measures include cutting state parks fees in half.
Like other governors, Mr. Davis has offered a series of financial incentives to recruit and retain qualified public school teachers.
This year, he proposed offering candidates who agree to teach in low-performing schools $10,000 loans for buying a home, $30,000 bonuses for attaining advanced certification and $11,000 to repay college loans.
But Mr. Davis has generally resisted formally committing the state to returning its per-pupil spending, which is calculated by complex and sometimes disputed means involving a mix of state and federal money, to the national average. He contends that his latest proposals will take California's spending, which is estimated at $6,045 this year, very close to the national average by the time that average is next recalculated.
Yet Davis aides acknowledged, for example, that there are bound to be disagreements about whether to count the teacher tax exemption toward the per-pupil spending figures, since it is an indirect expenditure of state funds.
In his State of the State speech in January, Mr. Davis acknowledged that California must spend more to return its schools to the post-sputnik era achievements of former Gov. Edmund G. Brown.
"But even more important, we must spend wisely," Mr. Davis said then. "We cannot win this battle simply by throwing money at it. We must not let taxpayer dollars be wasted on bureaucracy, but, instead, we must invest them directly into the classroom: for students and for teachers."

HEADLINE: Dr. J. Edward Carothers, 92, Methodist Leader

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
The Rev. Dr. J. Edward Carothers, a retired minister and former chief executive of national ministries for the United Methodist Church, died on May 1 at his retirement home in Doylestown, Pa., near Philadelphia. He was 92.
Dr. Carothers, who took a keen interest in theology's relationship to economics, science and technology, published seven books, among them "Keepers of the Poor," published by the church in 1966, and "To Love or to Perish: Technological Crisis and the Churches" (Friendship, 1972), of which he was co-editor with Margaret Mead, Roger L. Shinn and Daniel D. McCracken. 
 He held positions with the National Council of Churches from 1952 to 1964. He was the drafting editor of documents that the council issued on labor policy, among them one in 1965 that called for the repeal of statutes outlawing union shops.
Dr. Carothers was chief executive of his denomination's national missions from 1964 to 1972, when he retired to teach, write and serve as an industrial consultant on family welfare.
For 12 years, until last September, he wrote monthly reviews of books on Christian theology, in a bulletin distributed by the church's board of global ministries.
John Edward Carothers was born in Las Animas, Colo., about 60 miles east of Pueblo, and graduated in 1930 from Asbury College in Wilmore, Ky., before earning his master's and his doctorate in theology at the Iliff School of Theology in Denver. He was ordained a minister in 1932 and served congregations in Colorado, Vermont and New York.
Later, as chief executive of the church's national missions, he established the Methodist Urban Service Training program to prepare clergy for the ministry in a changing urban climate. In 1970, he was named executive director of a task force on the future of humanity and the role of the churches.
Dr. Carothers is survived by his wife of 70 years, Leta Hicks Carothers; two daughters, Bettie Lee Thomas of Portland, Me., and Joan Marsan Murphine of Laguna Beach, Calif.; seven grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren.
