HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
In A.L. West, a .500 Record May Prove Elusive

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
It's beginning to smell a lot like 1994. That would be the aroma coming from the American League West.
When the 1994 season ended prematurely, courtesy of a labor dispute between the players and the owners, no A.L. West team had a winning record. None had even a .500 record. The Texas Rangers were in first place, and their record (52-62) was far from .500. 
 Check the division's developments in the early weeks of the season, heading into yesterday's games:
The Rangers (16-19) had their best winning percentage after they won the first two games of the season. The last time they had a .500 record was at 5-5.
When the Oakland Athletics (19-17) sneaked one victory over .500 at 18-17 on Thursday night, it was the first time since they had a 2-1 record that they had climbed above .500.
The best the Anaheim Angels (18-19) had done was get two victories above .500. They were one under .500 before yesterday's game.
Since the Seattle Mariners (17-16) had a 12-7 record, they had won 5 games and lost 9.
The teams, however, aren't ready to play down to their past. "I don't think it's going to reach that," Pat Gillick, the Mariners' general manager, said.
Doug Melvin, the Rangers' general manager, said, "I think somebody will be at .500 to win the division."
Each team has had its problems. The Mariners put together what promised to be the best starting pitching rotation in their history, but the leaders of that rotation, Jamie Moyer and Freddy Garcia, are on the disabled list, having started a combined seven games. The Mariners think Moyer, recovering from a strain behind his left shoulder, can return before June 1. Garcia, who inexplicably fractured a leg, isn't expected back until the latter part of June.
"I hate to say it," Gillick said, "but it will come down to who can stay injury-free. There have been a lot of injuries in this division already. If you lose a significant contributor, it puts a crimp in everything."
The Angels began the season with Tim Belcher, one of their veteran starting pitchers, on the disabled list. He has since been joined by two other starters, Ken Hill and Jason Dickson, as well as shortstop Gary DiSarcina, who had hit .395 in 12 games.
Rusty Greer and Gabe Kapler, two-thirds of the Texas outfield, are on the disabled list, as is Frank Catalanotto, a .500-hitting platooned second baseman. The Rangers also learned last week that Justin Thompson, the primary pitcher they received in the Juan Gonzalez trade, needs rotator-cuff surgery and won't pitch at all this season.
Oakland's offensive catalyst, second baseman Randy Velarde, only recently came off the disabled list, where he had been since the start of the season. Kevin Appier, one of their veteran starting pitchers, came off the list yesterday, while John Jaha, one of their productive hitters, remains on it.
But the Athletics have no shortage of productive hitters. The division, in fact, boasts an offensive orientation.
The Rangers lead the league in hitting, while the Athletics lead in runs scored despite having one of the lowest batting averages and the most strikeouts, and they are second in home runs.
The Athletics' Jason Giambi entered the weekend No. 1 in the league in home runs (15) and runs batted in (42) and second in slugging percentage (.735), Darin Erstad of Anaheim had the highest batting average (.388), the highest home average (.461) and the most hits (59), Alex Rodriguez of Seattle was first in runs scored (36), on-base percentage (.483), road batting average (.435) and walks (29), David Segui of Texas was second in batting average (.378) and Ivan Rodriguez of Texas was second in total bases (92).
Pitching, then, must be a problem.
Melvin readily acknowledged that the Rangers' relief corps has undermined the team's efforts to attain a winning record. John Wetteland squandered a couple of ninth-inning leads over Cleveland and the Yankees, and Jeff Zimmerman, who last year was virtually unhittable, gave up game-losing home runs to Clay Bellinger of the Yankees and Greg Vaughn of Tampa Bay.
Just as damaging, some of the relievers' earned run averages look as if they were attacked by a severe siege of inflation: Mike Munoz 13.50, Matt Perisho 10.50, Tim Crabtree 9.18. The Angels have some of those, too: Mark Petkovsek 8.84 and Shigetoshi Hasegawa 6.98.
"Our starting pitching, for the most part, has been good," Bill Stoneman, the Angels' general manager, said. "Our relief pitching started off poorly, but it looks like it's coming along."
Stoneman said he believed the Angels were better than a .500 team. "We haven't been able to separate ourselves from the .500 mark," he added, "but I see ourselves doing it."
With the departure of Ken Griffey Jr., the Mariners are not the same offensively explosive team they have been in the past. "We don't bludgeon anybody," Gillick said. "Our offense is sporadic. Our game is get a well-pitched game and good defense and hope we score enough runs."
Gillick said he didn't think there was any real difference between his division and the Central. Melvin offered a similar view, noting that the West was "a good division from the standpoint of being competitive."
"Beyond the Yankees," he added, "everybody has problems. If you take away what the Yankees have done, I'm not sure there are any other great teams. That's the way it is in our league right now. It looks like there's parity."
With parity comes mediocrity. Mediocrity breeds .500 teams, or worse.
 
A Rare Pair of 1-0 Shutouts
If, as some baseball people believe, the ball has been altered to allow batters to hit more home runs, which balls must Steve Trachsel have used in his last two starts for Tampa Bay? An 18-game loser last year who did not win two successive starts until September, Trachsel has pitched in two consecutive 1-0 shutouts.
He did not complete the second one, against the Yankees and Orlando Hernandez on Thursday night, but his seven-inning, three-hit performance was impressive nonetheless, especially following his complete-game three-hit shutout against Boston last Saturday in a matchup with Pedro Martinez.
The only 1999 performance that came close to Trachsel's achievement was a pair of 1-0 complete-game shutouts Jose Jimenez pitched for St. Louis against Arizona, whose pitcher in both games was one Randy Johnson. Just to make the feat more spectacular, Jimenez pitched a no-hitter in the first shutout and allowed only two hits in the second. The only problem was Jimenez made a start between those 1-0 shutouts, losing to Houston, 11-3.
According to research by Elias Sports Bureau, the last pitcher to win two consecutive starts by 1-0 scores was Zane Smith of Pittsburgh in 1992. Smith pitched a complete-game five-hitter against St. Louis, then permitted five hits in eight and a third innings against Houston. Stan Belinda got the last two outs.
 Home runs may be up from last season, but so are 1-0 games. Eight such games have been played this season compared with seven in the corresponding period last year. The Devil Rays have won three of them. The Red Sox, the Angels and the Dodgers have each lost two.
 
Left-Handers Can't Hit Johnson
In Randy Johnson's first seven starts for Arizona this season, the relatively few left-handed batters who faced him did not fare well. But then left-handers seldom do. Rafael Palmeiro, for example, made no pretense about not wanting to play when Johnson pitched against his team. Palmeiro has batted against the left-hander 21 times and has only one hit to show for his futile efforts.
This season Todd Helton of Colorado and Mark Grace of the Chicago Cubs had the only two left-handed hits against Johnson in left-handers' 25 times at bat. Then last Wednesday night Johnson pitched against Los Angeles, and the Dodgers put only one left-handed hitter in their lineup. That hitter, Shawn Green, who had not had a hit in five American League at-bats against Johnson, stroked three singles in four tries.
 "You just don't see a left-hander stay in there against Randy the way Green did," said Sandy Johnson, the Diamondbacks' assistant general manager.
 
Hernandez Homer Ratio Up
Hideki Irabu was not the most popular pitcher who ever played for the Yankees. One element of his game that aroused criticism was his penchant for giving up home runs. Last season he allowed an average of one home run for 6.5 innings. The popular Orlando Hernandez, meanwhile, permitted one in nine innings.
Pitching for Montreal this season, Irabu has basically maintained his 1999 pace, giving up one home run every 7 innings (5 in 35 1/3 innings). But look who's giving up more? Hernandez has thrown 11 home run pitches in 56 2/3 innings, or one every 5 innings. He is tied for second in the American League for most home runs allowed, one behind Mike Mussina of Baltimore.
 
Kim's Glove Full of Strikeouts
Byung Hyun Kim, a Diamondbacks relief pitcher from Kwayngsan-ku Songjung-dong, South Korea, committed a no-no in a game against the Dodgers last week. As a bunt by Alex Cora rolled past him, Kim flung his glove at the ball to try to stop it.
Fortunately for Kim, his aim was not good and the glove missed the ball. Had he made contact, Cora would have wound up at third base with one out in the 10th inning of a tied score. The rules award three bases to a batter if a fielder throws his glove at a ball and hits it.
"Ah yes, three bases, no more," Kim said the next day when he was asked about the play.
The 21-year-old right-hander might not have known about the glove-throwing rule, but ask him about strikeouts and he could already write his own book. In six appearances from April 27 through last Wednesday, Kim pitched a total of six innings and struck out batters for 17 of the 18 outs.
His only miss? A tapper back to the mound by Todd Hundley of Los Angeles in the fifth off those six games. Kim pitched to two San Diego batters Friday night and both grounded out.
Throwing a fastball in the low 90's and an assortment of sliders, Kim dazzled batters for Philadelphia, Milwaukee, San Diego and Los Angeles. He gave up four hits, and the lone run he allowed cost the Diamondbacks the first of those games, but his string of strikeouts represents one of the most impressive performances of the season. In 13 games over all, he has struck out 28 in 16 2/3 innings and has a 1.62 earned run average.
What happened after the glove-tossing display? He had struck out Adrian Beltre before the bunt, and afterward he struck out Dave Hansen and Todd Hollandsworth.

HEADLINE: Bush Versus Gore Means an All-Baby-Boom Race

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
After decades of caricature as the most self-indulgent and permissive generation in American history, baby boomers -- including Al Gore and George W. Bush -- are realizing it is time to get with the program.
Despite their differences in political orientation, the two parties' presidential candidates, both of whom were born into the vanguard of the boomer generation, are delivering the same message on the campaign trail: "responsibility." It is a message that goes to the personal and the political and speaks, the candidates hope, to a generation once famous for its idealism and its determination to do the right thing. 
 Moreover, the campaigns have sensed a new wrinkle, so to speak, in the ever-scrutinized lives of the boomers that has emerged as they have aged -- the oldest boomers are now in the unusual position of contemplating their own retirements even as their parents are living longer and requiring more care. At the same time, some, like Mr. Gore, whose mother is 87 and whose mother-in-law lives with him and his wife, are even becoming grandparents.
This nexus of life-defining events for the biggest cohort in American history (the 76 million people born between 1946 and 1964) has infused the presidential campaign with a new urgency, especially regarding Social Security and health care. Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore have devoted much time on the campaign trail to Social Security and both plan to deliver major addresses on the topic on Monday.
"It's a response to what's happening in society," said John Rother, director of legislation and public policy for AARP, one of the biggest and most effective lobbying groups in the country. "It's driven by demographics, the economy and technology. There's a growing awareness, particularly of people who are Bush's and Gore's age, that their parent's generation is becoming frail, we don't have support systems that are in very good shape, and the anxiety about your own retirement is on the top of people's minds."
Al Gore was born March 31, 1948, making him 52. George W. Bush was born July 6, 1946, making him 53. And while they had different coming-of-age experiences during the 1960's and 1970's -- Mr. Gore was closer to the counterculture than was Mr. Bush, but still by no means a radical -- both are invoking their generational roots as themes in their campaigns and are developing "responsibility" as rationales for their candidacies.
This campaign marks one of the few times that candidates from both parties have been so close in age. For the first two baby boomers are running for president, representing a definitive break with the World War II era. Given the unprecedented prosperity, these factors give the nation a chance to reset its compass and restructure its priorities.
Here was Governor Bush in a recent interview with "The News Hour" on PBS:
"I'm a strong candidate because I come from the baby boomer generation, recognizing that we've got to usher in an era of responsible behavior, which starts with behaving responsibly in the office."
Here was Vice President Gore at a fund-raiser Thursdayin Los Angeles, explaining the strong economy:
"We got rid of the politics of illusion and said to the American people: 'We have got to make the real hard choices. We have to accept responsibility for our own future.' That's why it was so tough to pass the changes that have helped to unleash all this potential. Tough, tough, tough."
Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster, says the invocation of responsibility is a harkening to fundamental values.
"The notion that people ought to be responsible for their actions is one of the top-most widely shared values in this country," he said. "So it's no surprise that politicians talk in that idiom."
But there is also a strong degree of self-interest in their appeals, particularly when it comes to issues like Social Security and Medicare. Politicians used to focus issues like Social Security and Medicare solely on the over-65 crowd. But now, Mr. Mellman noted, "people are worried about taking care of their parents, and the leading edge of the baby boom are worried about their own retirement and some are worried about both at the same time, which is a newer phenomenon."
A political focus group of mostly middle-aged people conducted earlier this month in Bala Cynwyd, a suburb of Philadelphia, by Peter Hart, a Democratic pollster, found unanimity on one subject -- despite the prosperous economy, people are anxious about health care and Social Security.
"As baby boomers get older, people start to feel it as well as think it," Frank Ratel, 60, an accountant, said during the focus group.
Mr. Rother of AARP said: "The assumption among many people is that it's only seniors who care about Medicare and Social Security, but nothing could be further from the truth. Our polling shows it is boomers who are the most interested in prescription drug coverage because you're thinking about your mom and at the same time wondering about your own future. When you're in your 50's, you don't know what kind of shape you're going to be in. This is a greater concern of people in their 50's than it is for people 65 and older."
The crunch for baby boomers is becoming increasingly obvious. Almost 50 percent of the people who filed for bankruptcy in 1999 were baby boomers. Some academics, like Elizabeth Warren, a bankruptcy expert at Harvard Law School, argue that, contrary to the popular image of affluent boomers spending their way to consumer heaven, this is "the most vulnerable generation" because of the confluence of potential failures that they face, from the loss of a job to catastrophic illness to the effects of divorce and the need to care for aging parents.
The likelihood of bankruptcy increases with age, as those facing retirement face mounting costs, particularly for prescription drugs and long-term care. Both Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush are offering proposals to help people meet these needs.
The Social Security system has a surplus now, but the government predicts that the trust fund will begin paying out more than it takes in by 2015 as the baby boom generation retires. Without a major fix, the system could go broke by 2037.
But for both candidates, the notion of "responsibility" goes beyond strengthening Social Security, which they would do by different means.
Mr. Bush emphasizes personal responsibility as a direct counterweight to what he perceives as the irresponsibility of President Clinton (the first baby boomer president). The goal of his candidacy, Mr. Bush says, is to restore honor and dignity to the White House.
And the signal inherent in his message is an appeal to family values, long seen as Republican turf.
Mr. Bush has emphasized the theme since he began his campaign last June, saying "My first goal is to usher in the responsibility era -- an era that stands in stark contrast to the last few decades, where our culture has said: If it feels good, do it, and if you've got a problem, blame someone else."
Mr. Bush has also used his emphasis on compassion to temper any impression that responsibility means harshness or sacrifice.
For Mr. Gore, responsibility is a multipurpose concept, and he tends to use it both subliminally and overtly. He too is trying to distance himself from the actions of President Clinton. But he also wants to present himself as the logical successor to Mr. Clinton as the steward of the nation's current prosperity, and so he offers himself as the responsible heir apparent.
This, of course, necessitates presenting Mr. Bush as the "irresponsible" alternative, a neat way, learned from President Clinton, of transforming a policy matter into a values judgment. Repeatedly, Mr. Gore casts Mr. Bush's proposals as "reckless," a quality Mr. Gore conjures up with his relentless referencing to Mr. Bush's "risky tax scheme." The contrast between the responsible Mr. Gore and the irresponsible Mr. Bush has fast become the organizing principle of the Gore campaign.
Like Mr. Bush, Mr. Gore is using the idea of responsibility to reinforce one of the basic tenets of his party. While Mr. Bush's reference summons family values, Mr. Gore's highlights the Democrats' traditional advantage on preserving entitlement programs. The "risky tax scheme" that he invokes is a direct threat to two tenets of Democratic orthodoxy -- Social Security and Medicare -- that baby boomers are now either depending on to help their parents or expecting to receive themselves.
"It references the basic policy dilemma of his presidency," said Elaine Kamark, Mr. Gore's chief domestic policy adviser. "The challenge has gone from how to manage the insolvency of these programs to who can keep control of the surplus. The money guys on Wall Street understand this very well. They want confidence. You get it by running a straight, sound fiscal policy."
Because Mr. Gore had children relatively early for his generation, he is now a grandparent. "His life cycle is slightly ahead of his generation, so he can see ahead to the centrality of some of these issues," Ms. Kamark said. Still, Mr. Gore is more a creature of the popular image of the baby boom than is Mr. Bush.
Mr. Bush exudes a more retro 1950's youth, one of hijinks and drinking and frat parties, remarkably detached from the Vietnam War or any kind of rebellion or existential angst. As he told an interviewer for GQ: "I don't remember any kind of heaviness ruining my time at Yale."
The vice president seems much more a product of his time. He invariably dangles his boomer credentials before his audiences, mentioning the touchstones of his generation -- the assassinations, the civil rights movement, Vietnam, Watergate, his "disillusionment with politics," though never rebellion, and his admission that he smoked marijuana.

HEADLINE: U.S. LABOR LEADERS PUSH HARD TO KILL CHINA TRADE BILL

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
The American labor movement is mounting its biggest lobbying campaign ever on trade matters in seeking to defeat the Clinton administration's drive to normalize commerce with China. Unions are holding dozens of meetings on Capitol Hill, putting intense pressure on individual legislators back in their districts, staging rallies and writing huge numbers of letters across the nation.
With the House scheduled to vote on the China trade bill the week after next, organized labor is struggling to counter the intense lobbying of the administration and business groups, with some labor leaders believing that their efforts will succeed in defeating the measure. 
 The members of a single union -- the Steelworkers -- have written more than 200,000 letters urging House members to oppose the bill, which would grant China permanent normal trade relations and pave its way into the World Trade Organization.
Acknowledging that the House vote is too close to call, John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, has cleared much of his schedule to hold one-on-one meetings with House members as well as sessions with moderate Republicans, the Congressional Black Caucus and the New York Congressional delegation.
"We're telling them that our members take this issue very seriously," Mr. Sweeney said. "We tell them that there is absolutely no good reason for them to support permanent normalized trade relations with China. There is no information showing that China is improving its human rights situation or workers rights situation."
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has dispatched full-time coordinators to 32 Congressional districts that are represented by undecided House members. These coordinators are organizing demonstrations and candlelight vigils, arranging meetings with lawmakers and taking cell phones to factories so union members can inundate House offices with phone calls.
Labor's lobbying is often done in conjunction with religious leaders, environmentalists and exiled Chinese dissidents. On April 12, thousands of union members crowded the halls of Congress to lobby.
Last Thursday night, 60 union members demonstrated at a Wal-Mart in Tewksbury, Mass, which stocks many items made in China, to pressure Representative Martin T. Meehan, a Democrat, to vote against the bill. This Monday, union members plan to set up a tent outside the Alabama district office of Representative Robert E. Cramer, a Democrat, to urge him around the clock to oppose the bill.
Labor leaders oppose the bill because it does not protect worker rights and because of China's poor human rights record.
Many acknowledge that defeating the bill remains an uphill battle. President Clinton and Congressional leaders, they say, will make any deals necessary to obtain the 218 votes needed in the House.
"It's still neck and neck," said Peggy Taylor, lobbyist for the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, which represents 13 million union members. "We're not only holding our own, we're challenging them very strongly. We can win this vote."
Administration officials and Congressional leaders say the bill will pass easily in the Senate.
"Right now neither side has 218 votes," said Commerce Secretary William Daley, who is coordinating administration efforts to win passage. "Labor's been very active. The fact of the matter is we've seen a whole host of House members struggling with this issue. One of the main reasons they've struggled is their friends in organized labor feel so strongly about it." Mr. Daley said the House would pass the bill.
Administration officials and business executives assert that the bill will help the American economy and workers by increasing exports to China. In the bill, Congress would approve the administration's agreement with China calling on it to lower tariffs and many trade barriers.
"This is a very good deal," said William Morley, trade lobbyist for the United States Chamber of Commerce. "What can be wrong about accepting a deal that will slash tariffs on American exports?"
Union leaders assert that the deal will not bring about increased exports but an exodus of American factories to China using low-wage Chinese labor to produce for the American market.
Much of the union members' opposition stems from a widespread conviction that the North American Free Trade Agreement encouraged an exodus of American industry -- and jobs -- to Mexico.
In 1993, labor fought that agreement in vain. Union leaders say the campaign against the China trade bill is bigger, involving more members and a wider swath of unions.
In one unusual move, hundreds of members of the United Steelworkers of America at a Rubbermaid factory in Wooster, Ohio, upset that much of the plant's operations were being transferred to Mexico, recently wrote on the back of a bathmat and sent it to Representative Ralph Regula, an Ohio Republican.
"Dear Ralph Regula," they wrote, "We are losing 180 plus jobs to Mexico. These products will no longer be made in the U.S.A. Since Nafta, the biggest export has been our jobs. Don't make the same mistake. Vote No on P.N.T.R. for China."
George Becker, president of the Steelworkers, said: "This deal is for multinationals, not for workers. It's for multinational companies to build plants in China and bring products back to the United States. It's the same as the Mexican trade deal."
Representative Bob Clement, a Tennessee Democrat, acknowledged that labor's lobbying helped sway him to oppose the bill. Noting that he was upset by China's religious repression, he said he believed that the current annual trade review of China helps to pressure it on human rights.
But John J. LaFalce, a Buffalo Democrat, who has met with many labor leaders, said he was leaning toward supporting the bill. He said he favored inserting labor rights into trade accords, but he said that because most of America's trading partners refuse to accept such provisions that should not block all future labor agreements.
Mr. Sweeney insisted that in his meetings with members of Congress he never threatens retribution against people who vote for the China bill. Acknowledging that the bill might make it harder for Democrats to regain control of the House, he said union members would certainly weigh each lawmaker's stance on China in deciding whom to endorse.

HEADLINE: Lending Crackdown Said to Fall Short

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
When government regulators announced recently that they were protecting homeowners by cracking down on an abusive nationwide lending company, Margaret C. Roundtree hoped that they would intervene to save her home in Jamaica, Queens, from foreclosure.
"I did expect to get some help," said Mrs. Roundtree, 68, a hospital technician. "But nothing has been done." Now she faces the loss of the house, where she has lived since 1972. 
 Three federal agencies settled their joint lawsuit against her lender, Delta Financial Corporation of Woodbury, N.Y., on March 30. They portrayed their decision as an industrywide warning to the booming but loosely regulated market in high-cost loans. But advocates for victims like Mrs. Roundtree say the officials let Delta off the hook. The critics also say the settlement did nothelp the thousands of suffering borrowers, many of whom have been forced into foreclosure or bankruptcy.
And consumer groups are also attacking Delta's earlier settlement with two New York State regulatory agencies. While the state did extract some restitution for victims, critics say it is only a token amount of Delta's $1 billion-a-year operation. Only a few of the victims will be aided, and nothing will go to those who must lose their homes.
Delta operates in 26 states, and in New York grew to become the largest subprime lender, a type that makes high-cost loans to people with poor credit ratings. But critics called Delta a predatory lender that focused on minority neighborhoods. Its victims, often elderly women, were targets of high-pressure pitches for loans with exorbitant fees and interest. Reacting to the complaints, regulators accused the company of violating lending and civil rights laws. But the settlements have frustrated Delta's critics.
"Delta admits no wrongdoing and agrees to comply with the law -- which it's supposed to do anyway -- while many victims are stuck with horrendous loans for years to come, and people who already lost their homes and their life's savings are completely left out," said Sarah Ludwig, director of the Neighborhood Economic Development Advocacy Project, a nonprofit group in Manhattan.
Federal and state officials defend their decisions, saying they imposed heavy sanctions and stopped the abuses now, avoiding years of litigation and possibly keeping thousands more from being victimized. The restitution is the most ever won in the nation's banking industry, the regulators say. Delta also agreed to restrictions beyond statutory requirements and is subject to civil and criminal penalties for new violations.
"This is not just a slap on the wrist," said David Medine, an associate director at the Federal Trade Commission, one of the agencies involved in the settlement of the federal lawsuit.
Another agency, the Justice Department, said, "This suit sends a clear message that the United States won't tolerate discrimination or illegal lending practices." The Department of Housing and Urban Development declined to reply to the critics. But earlier, Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo praised the deal, saying, "Lenders and mortgage brokers are put on notice by this settlement agreement that HUD and the federal government are prepared to fight for borrowers who are being victimized."
The first official to go after Delta was the state attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer. At first, he tried to place Delta in receivership, but eventually his office settled. His civil rights chief, Andrew Celli, said: "We started with one goal, to change the way the largest subprime lender in the state does business, and we met that goal. We made a conscious choice to reform this industry."
Mr. Spitzer's deputy, Mark Peters, added, "Delta is now bound by a 265-page code of conduct, requiring a whole bunch of things the law doesn't require."
Mr. Spitzer pushed for $6 million in restitution, which the State Banking Department raised to $7.25 million, plus 525,000 shares of Delta stock it valued at nearly $5 million. "The governor instructed us to obtain the maximum amount of restitution to the victims," said the acting banking superintendent, Elizabeth McCaul. "We took the most from the company we possibly could.
Under that settlement, 600 Delta borrowers were recently offered reductions of $50 to $400 in their monthly payments, or 5 percent to 40 percent, Ms. McCaul said. In addition, foreclosures were halted for 75 homeowners, who will also be offered reductions.
Delta issued this statement: "While Delta does not believe it has done anything wrong, it has acceded to these agreements in the best interests of our shareholders, customers and the communities we serve."
But the restitution pales in comparison to the victims' losses and Delta's billions of dollars in loans, critics say. The reduced-payment benefits end when borrowers die, sell their homes, refinance or are foreclosed upon. And the value of the Delta stock has shrunk below $1 million. "It's funny money, all flash and no cash," said Patricia Sturdevant, director of the National Association of Consumer Advocates, a nonprofit group. "This case sets a dangerous precedent for going soft on lenders who are cheating people out of house and home. The message is that crime pays." Since the federal agencies won no restitution, she said, there is no aid for victims outside New York.
Because the settlements were court-approved, there is no apparent way to challenge them. Despite their long efforts against predatory lending, consumer groups say they were not consulted. The federal agencies filed their lawsuits against Delta, and that same day announced their settlements with the company.
Most disturbing, the critics say, is a state requirement that victims who accept restitution must promise not to seek any other legal redress. They cannot sue Delta, and if they eventually face foreclosure, they will not be allowed to raise a defense in court that their loans were improper.
"That's terrible," said Lee Squitieri, a Manhattan lawyer who is organizing a class-action suit for Delta borrowers. He is seeking to release them from bad loans, get compensation for excessive charges and impose punitive damages.
Nearly all the restitution offers that the critics have heard about are for $50 a month. "It's not nearly enough," said Nancy Slahetka, a lawyer who fights foreclosures for South Brooklyn Legal Services. Those offers are paltry, she said, and there are too few of them. "There are thousands of victims, not hundreds."
Mrs. Roundtree said she fell behind on her bills when she was out of work because of two car accidents and her resulting hip surgery. Her lawyer, Jeffrey Rosenberg, said she was talked into a loan of $92,000, "far more than she needed," to pay her debts, plus $20,800 for home improvements, with cash supposedly left over for her. The interest rate was 12.15 percent.
Mrs. Roundtree said she reluctantly signed blank papers when salespeople threatened that "they were going to take my house away." Soon after, she said, she tried to invoke her right to cancel but was ignored. She never got the final papers, she said, and most of the promised renovations were never done.
Although technically Delta did not originate the loan, the company was involved at the outset and took over the loan at the closing, the lawyer said. Inevitably, the payments fell into arrears, and now Delta is demanding $137,000 or the house.

HEADLINE: C.E.O. ROUND TABLE;
On the Continent, on the Cusp

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
THE newly won star status of the European entrepreneur, and the crushing burden of Big Government. The lure of the nimble American economic model, and the strengths of European multiculturalism. The unifying force of the euro, and lingering obstacles to a truly single European market.
Those were some of the puzzle pieces on the table one evening early this month when the chief executives of six fast-growing companies gathered at the Hotel de Crillon here to talk with Money & Business about the challenges facing European business. 
 Rather than the larger-than-life characters who run Europe's imperial blue chips, these executives represent a relatively new type on the Continent's business scene: the upstart. And while none are household names in the United States, all have been especially successful at something for which European business is not particularly noted: creating jobs. They are members of a Brussels-based organization called GrowthPlus that promotes pro-business policies across national borders.
The panelists were Leendert Bikker of the Bikker Communication Group, a Dutch public relations firm; Sylvain Forestier of D Interactive, a French marketing consultant; Christian Hunt of the EMDS Group, a Belgian executive headhunting firm; Martin A. Schoeller of IFCO Systems, a German shipping specialist; Nico Willaert of Lernout & Hauspie, a Belgian speech technology company; and Simon Worth of QAS Systems, a British software concern.
The executives were joined in the two-hour discussion by Edmund L. Andrews, Alan Cowell, Jim Schachter, Andrew Ross Sorkin and John Tagliabue of The Times.
Much of the conversation focused on a Europe in transition -- a place where a young, Internet-nurtured generation is artfully sidestepping political boundaries and cultural barriers to doing business, and where a multitude of tongues and national points of view both foster flexibility and impede change.
The conversation was conducted in English, a second language for five of the chief executives. Following are excerpts, edited for space and clarity.
 
Q. We Americans often see Europe as being a place not exactly friendly to business, with a rigid labor market and difficulties in financing companies. Our newspapers are constantly reporting about how difficult it is to do business in a European context. And yet at the same time, we've been constantly reporting about how Europe is changing, how one market after another is being deregulated, whether it's telecommunications, airlines, banking, postal services. My question: Is Europe gradually coming around to your kind of company?
 
MARTIN SCHOELLER -- I think the view of the entrepreneur in Europe, especially the last one or two years, has changed tremendously. Entrepreneurs are role models, are stars, are heroes. You don't have to defend yourself anymore, excuse yourself for being an entrepreneur.
We think, too, that the European environment is better than it ever was, with low interest, low inflation, growth picking up -- and while the growth is picking up, the inflation isn't picking up. So I think we have a very, very positive outlook here, and we can grow stronger.
 
Q. What about the entrepreneurial environment in France?
 
SYLVAIN FORESTIER -- I agree that there has been a lot of change. In the entrepreneurial environment, it's much easier to get money. The key issue for France is to change the state. Right now, the French state is way behind the private sector. Education is very much backward. And one of the things which could really prevent us from keeping on growing is the lack of people, because we don't have enough people, especially in the high-tech sectors.
 
Q. What has inspired the new appreciation for entrepreneurship here in Europe?
 
SCHOELLER -- I think the Internet and the new markets -- the Nasdaq new markets -- changed the whole perception. First, the Internet makes it apparently easier to realize innovations and to get business models running. Second, it has taught the capital market that things might cost some money. It's not only the big corporations who can now afford start-up losses; the market is trading the future.
I want to add, too, the issue of recruiting people. Everybody says how scarce talent is and how we lack in education on technology, on technical jobs and so forth. But on the positive side, I see that the growing companies get the good people. Before, ABB and Siemens took all the good talent from the market, and then McKinsey and Boston Consulting took the good talent.
And now we are in the pole position, and they want to come to us. They want to come to strongly growing companies where they can get stock options that are not already at Mount Everest peak prices, that are still at a small price that can grow to big mountains. There is really a big change, and this is in the last 12 to 24 months. G.E. people are happy to come to us; Boston Consulting people come to us.
 
Q. Is that your experience, too, Christian, given the kind of business you're in?
 
CHRISTIAN HUNT -- Yes, in the last two years, we've seen clearly a shift, in career preferences, from big traditional corporations, consulting firms, investment banks, etc. People are not honestly looking at the P/E's on the Nasdaq and the high-growth companies. And they are very, very much attracted. You see not one or two people leaving Boston Consulting and McKinsey and the others; you see tens and tens of them leaving.
And obviously, there's a cultural shift. It's a big trend, If you look at Europe, the attraction for big, stable companies was very, very, very strong in the last 10, 20, 30 years, maybe. And now --
 
SCHOELLER -- That's old economy.
 
HUNT -- Yeah, that's old economy. And more and more, probably, people have realized that they have to take charge of their own future in a way. And the result is more attraction for high-growth companies, for stock option models and more people starting their own business.
On the shortage of talent: There is clearly a shortage in Europe -- not just in Europe, but in particular in Europe -- in I.T. information technology and in global management capacity. As economies go global, all companies need people who can run global companies. And there are just not enough people. There's not enough people at the senior level; there's not enough people at all.
 
SIMON WORTH -- I see that a little bit differently in the U.K. The first thing is that the social acceptability of starting a business in the U.K. started before the Internet.
Probably 10, 15 years ago, suddenly, two things happened together. The American experience became more available through the media: satellite telly, quicker transmission of photos and numbers; you get American business pages and numbers in the London press. And in the case of the U.K., taxes and school fees came down. It sounds ridiculous, but if you're a middle-aged guy stuck in a serious job with one of these big companies, and you were paying 60 or 70 percent income tax, and you have two or three kids in private school, then you were stuck.
The other thing that went on in my generation -- I'm coming up 40 -- was that suddenly, in the final year of university, employers were not there saying they'd employ you for life. They were saying 5 or 10 years. And I think this is a two-way street, and both employees and employers have realized that you have to manage your own career. And all of a sudden the options for starting up in business on your own become easier and socially acceptable.
I was employed by a corporation, and we were given instructions: You do not talk to people who've had a go on their own, because they were deemed as trouble. And that's done a U-turn. People of my generation think nothing of having had one or two gos and still be roaring along.
 
LEENDERT BIKKER -- In Holland, becoming an entrepreneur is not an option when you leave high school or university. And that's because, in comparison to the small size of our economy, we have a lot of big internationals, like Unilever, like Royal Dutch, like Akzo Nobel, like Philips. That was Option One, to go to those big global companies.
It was only 12 years ago when I left university, and all the students had to go to one of the teachers to discuss their future. "Becoming an entrepreneur is a dead-end option," they told you. "Don't do it."
 
Q. So your teachers basically steered you to one of the big globals.
 
BIKKER -- Yeah, yeah. And the new generation -- I have a son who became 16 last month, and he said, "Dad, everything is fine, but my first option is having my own company."
And I said, "What kind of company? And why?"
"Doesn't matter what."
It's not taught at school, but the whole group of kids that age -- that's it. And they all talk about dot-coms.
 
SCHOELLER -- What kind of father does he have?
 
BIKKER -- No, no, it's not only his father. It's the new generation, because they're connected to all over the world. He spends his holidays all over the world. It's all over the Web.
 
SCHOELLER -- And you can get rich quick now. This is totally exaggerated, but it shows to many people who were very risk-averse and looking for safety that, wow, this could be just incredible and outmaneuver everything you would do in a whole lifetime's work.
 
Entrepreneurial Origins
 
Q. Were any of your fathers businessmen, or were they all working in large organizations?
 
BIKKER -- hiding his face in his hands Civil servant.
 
NICO WILLAERT -- Small entrepreneur.
 
Q. So entrepreneurialism is not all brand new.
 
WILLAERT -- No, it's not all brand new. I'm happy to hear all these positive comments of my colleagues here. But just to put a couple of things in perspective -- and maybe I'm in the best place to do that, since we were the very first Belgian company quoted on Nasdaq, on Dec. 1, 1995: I had gone through the experience of going to the limits of what European bankers and Belgian bankers were prepared to give us. And even shortly before we went to Nasdaq, one of the bankers asked me if I could send him a sample of an algorithm.
Now, in those days --
 
SCHOELLER -- Even today --
 
WILLAERT -- Yeah, even today, I think, you have to explain to a lot of people what an algorithm is. And software in general was something that made a lot of eyebrows start moving when you talked to bankers, because you didn't have buildings. Yes, you had computers, but what were they worth, after all? I mean, what were your assets?
 
SCHOELLER -- Your assets go home in the night and eat and have sex.
 
WILLAERT -- So it is, first of all, very recent. Secondly, what happened afterward in the European context -- the euro and so on -- helped the feeling that technology was going to play a very important role in our society. I think some of the examples that were set on Nasdaq, and the growth of Nasdaq in general, helped.
Then, of course, we were not in such a bad position, particularly not our company. When you talk about languages, well, where do engineers talk three or four languages? Surely not in the States. I think Holland and Belgium and so on were very well placed -- and Scandinavia -- to engage in global international business.
So we had a couple of assets when the Internet started showing that you could do other types of business than the classical ones.
And I still wonder: Europe may be in a good position to help young entrepreneurs in their first phase, because there is this general feeling that these things are good. But I think there may be limits of $20 million, $30 million. Then, from there on, I think it still becomes relatively difficult to get proper financing.
 
BIKKER -- The market in the U.S. is much more mature.
 
WILLAERT -- It's much more mature. The capital market in the U.S.A., let's not forget, has always had this concept of conceptual I.P.O.'s. When you talk in Europe about the conceptual I.P.O., I think you still have a lot of explaining to do.
 
Q. Have any of you had to get financing from the States?
 
SCHOELLER -- We are also on Nasdaq, yes, and we have funding from U.S. banks. That means 100-page contracts and covenants, higher cost of money, but faster and more supportive decisions.
 
BIKKER -- Yes, but our banks are not run by entrepreneurs, but by policy makers.
 
Weathering the Storms
 
Q. Do any of you have any fears or worries about what happens if and when the first real bear market arrives?
 
FORESTIER -- I'm not very much worried about the possibility that we'd be slowed down by lack of funding, because there is a lot of money coming over; I'm talking about the venture capitalists. And as for the stock market, if you want to raise money, even with French stock you can raise a tremendous amount of money, more than $200 million. And if you really need more money, you can still choose an American bank as a second funding source, or you have other solutions.
My first concern is that really there could be a slowdown in growth because of the lack of skilled people. And that's why in France we're fighting so much for stock options -- because we are in a fiscal environment which is not easy at all and which, of course, prevents us from keeping French talent from emigrating to the U.K. or the States. And, of course, it's not very easy to make U.S. engineers migrate to France, even with our wine and food.
 
Q. We talked about the change in the acceptance of entrepreneurs in Germany and Britain. What's the situation like in France?
 
FORESTIER -- Well, I think it has improved a little bit, but I would definitely not say that there are stars. People are wary of us. French people don't like people to get rich. So they would like Microsoft, but not with the wealth of Bill Gates -- and without Bill Gates, if possible.
 
SCHOELLER -- Don't you think the jealousy factor has come down a little bit? That was very dominating in the 70's and 80's. I somehow feel it changing, at least in Germany.
 
FORESTIER -- What I would say is that young people, especially in the university, in school, have changed a little bit. But if you are talking to anyone on the street -- especially when you are talking to civil servants, one-third of the work force in France -- they don't like at all this sort of wealth going around in the economy.
 
WILLAERT -- What worries me most in the whole concept of the new economy is how very important perception is for the value of a company. If things go down on Nasdaq, Easdaq follows, and you have quite a domino effect throughout the world. These are things that do not emanate from an individual company and that you do not have control of.
But the fact is when people like Motorola, Intel or Microsoft issue profit warnings, that is enough for a lot of investors to run out of the technology sector.
You can say all right, whether our company has a market cap of $7 billion or only $5 billion, you won't eat one steak less or more as an entrepreneur. But, mind you, at a certain moment when you're using your shares as a currency to acquire other companies, these things become important. So if you're not careful, you're overtaken by elements that are totally out of your control.
 
WORTH -- It works the other way. You could be acquired equally if your share value is low. That makes you more receptive to an acquisition.
 
WILLAERT -- Absolutely, absolutely.
 
Navigating a New Era
 
Q. Is this a new era, then, an environment that European executives have to deal with and are ready to deal with?
 
WILLAERT -- I think we're enjoying it right now, because it is a new challenge, it's a new game, and we're not playing too badly. What I just wonder is whether we're all aware of the consequences, ultimately, of that type of game.
 
Q. Is Europe having a harder time throwing away fundamentals?
 
FORESTIER -- There was a joke going around France recently during the drop in the market. The Nasdaq closed down and, of course, the following morning, the French stock market was down. Then one day, the Nasdaq was high, and the following morning the French stock market was down. And so someone wrote: Well, who knew? We don't need the Americans to go down.
Seriously, the problem in France is that we started much later than the U.S. economy on the model and the growth. And so if the U.S. economy is slowing down, it could really slow us down before we really arrive at something good.
 
SCHOELLER -- There's no reason that the economy slows down.
 
FORESTIER -- I hope not.
 
SCHOELLER -- Because new technology enables growth without heating up inflation and enables more and more services to be exchanged. And there is no limit to exchanging services. It doesn't cost material, it doesn't cost energy, it doesn't waste anything. And our Internet world allows us to grow in services without limit, without a top.
That's why I don't see growth going down at all. We only have an issue of how long shall the Europeans move slower, and how efficiently will the European government, with one currency, promote competition.
 
A Sustainable Boom?
 
Q. People say the American economy has moved into a phase of sustained growth, whereas in Europe the danger is that it's simply another cyclical upswing. Do you agree?
 
 
BIKKER -- No doubt about it that we follow the U.S. market, because there is not a U.S. market and a European market and an Asian market anymore. There is a global market. I guess Holland and Germany are the No. 2 and 3 investors in the U.S.
 
Q.What about labor mobility?
 
BIKKER -- Labor mobility is much lower in Europe, because of the culture and the language. That's not an economic difference; that's a generational difference.
 
Q. Christian, do you find that this is the case?
 
HUNT -- People are ready to move, for sure. And as we move more into a service economy, physical mobility becomes less of a requirement, actually. You need people to be able to work in global companies and speak languages -- speak English in particular. More and more people are able to do that. Now you can work on the network from Alaska, servicing a company based in India. I mean, all the software development companies use offices in India and all over the world to be able to work on a 24-hour basis.
And I guess that's an area where Europe actually has an advantage, because we are more used to different languages.
 
Q. But there are obstacles, too.
 
WORTH -- There are all sorts of impediments. We've got different tax regimes in different nations. We've got different legal structures. When we wanted to set up in Holland and Germany, we doubled our legal bill to write contractual agreements, to employ staff, to license customers. And then you go to another nation; you do it again.
 
SCHOELLER -- The banks. Banks cannot control assets in other countries.
 
WORTH -- So you have another bank account. In America, a state is part of the same nation. So you achieve economies of scale. And I think that's quite significant. We're not quite on this boom yet in Europe.
 
SCHOELLER -- But still, we're on a track to --
 
WORTH -- I agree. We are moving forward. But there are still very entrenched problems in Europe. Americans can sell to 250 million consumers. Don't kid yourself. We can't sell to 300 million consumers in Europe as readily as you can in the States. We incur much more cost and many more impediments, and I think many of those things will take longer to change.
 
HUNT -- Yes, but if you look at it from a global point of view, we are in a much better position to sell to Europeans because we understand European culture.
 
WORTH -- Certainly.
 
HUNT -- The Americans probably have more difficulty in doing that. And certainly if we can leverage on that capacity, we can do that also on a global basis. So to the various cultural environments, the various tax environments, the new generation of entrepreneurs says: Nobody operates in an ideal environment. That's the environment we have to deal with, and we find solutions around that.
Sometimes it means the underground economy. Sometimes it means other solutions. And altogether, we are developing skills that will be, I think, very, very useful for the global economy.
 
The Impact of the Euro
 
Q. What difference has the euro made? And is it creating pressure for change?
 
HUNT -- It is. The main impact, seen from my own perspective, is it's another element showing that European economics is becoming actually one element in the global economy, that it is becoming one single economy. And, sure, it means stability. It means it's a lot easier to do business between France and Germany and Belgium and the Netherlands, etc., and there's no risk factor in exchange risk.
 
Q. Mr. Willaert, has it made a big difference for your company?
 
WILLAERT -- Let me put it this way: The euro has been launched in a very euphoric way. And I think it gave us, as Europeans, a good feeling that we were now ready to face international competition.
But I don't really see, at this moment, very much progress in really having a unified market. I still feel that countries individually take advantage, and that there is a tremendous difference in doing business in France than in Holland, Belgium, Germany and the U.K. Having said that, all the business community felt strongly in support of the euro because, in our inter-European transactions, it helps a great deal.
A lot of the future of the European Community will have to do with the social aspects and the harmonizing of the social aspects -- because, let's face it, if you have things made in Portugal, they're bound to be a lot cheaper than in Holland. If you have things made in Greece, they're bound to be a lot cheaper.
Whether it really has an impact on European business with the rest of the world? I'm not too sure. I get the feeling we're sheltering ourselves within a little bit of Fortress Europe.
 
SCHOELLER -- The question is: Can we afford forever this free world trade theory, or shall we switch to what has already been discussed in Seattle -- a fair trade theory, where free trade can happen when a country applies certain minimum salaries and certain minimum ecological standards? That's the question.

WILLAERT -- This is what affects political decision-making. We have politicians who will go against mobility, because they are afraid that the new economy will take jobs from local people. But that is not necessarily the case.
 
Q. So what is the solution?
 
WILLAERT -- My feeling is that we do not have political statesmanship anymore. And that is the major problem that we have. We still have European nations where every politician is getting a profile for himself and is capable of falling back on his national political playing field. We are not harmonizing the situation within Europe.
 
BIKKER -- The policy makers are focused on very rigid systems to solve all the problems with one system for everything.
 
SCHOELLER -- And the market is assaulted by demands for flexibility.
 
Q. Is the overall trend heading in the direction of liberalization, the direction supportive of entrepreneurs, regardless of what political party is in power in the country?
 
SCHOELLER -- I think that everybody would agree that politicians have less and less leverage, and instead of being there like the king and deciding what has to happen, they have to run after the resources to make their country efficient and look attractive, just like companies have to be attractive. It's like running a club. They have to say: "I ask a membership fee, it's less than the other guy and we still have good services here." And this triggers a sense of competition that was never there before.
And the other thing is that entrepreneurs don't feel the government too much, because we have the freedom of capital. The poor victim is the employee. And the employees should stand up and should ask governments to make a more entrepreneur-friendly country, to get more entrepreneurs in and make jobs.
 
BIKKER -- Twenty years ago, we had a left-wing -- very left-wing -- minister of economic affairs in the Dutch market. And that was the reason one of the leading guys of Royal Dutch, a member of the board, left Shell after 20 years of serving Shell all over the world, to become a member of Parliament -- just to oppose these left-wing politics. Now, 20 years later, the one is the president of the European Central Bank, the other is a European Union commissioner for fiscal affairs, and they tell exactly the same story.
 
HUNT -- Maybe the weakness or the strength of the dollar is an illustration of everything we're talking about here. If the euro goes further down, it's going to become alarming, and hopefully everybody's going to wake up and say, "O.K., now we really have to do something about this." And it becomes easier to say that to the French unions, etc. And I guess it represents the pressure of the financial markets here, international financial markets, who are saying we've got to do something. Because the European economy is not doing that badly. And the euro should be stronger.
 
Rewards for Risk-Takers
 
Q. I am struck by the incredible popularity, in companies going public these days, of stock options and other kinds of incentive programs -- and of the possibility of getting very rich very quickly. That implies, with it, a whole different attitude on the part of employees toward loyalty, staying with a company, notions of relative egalitarian pay and so forth. Do these things change business culture for you?
 
BIKKER -- Of course, it has an impact on corporate culture and ways of working. It's new, and we want it old. In Western Europe, it used to be that your whole life was guaranteed and organized. So this feels like quite the opposite. And we will end up in the middle, I guess.
 
SCHOELLER -- I think it's helpful -- because it puts tremendous additional pressure on performing and benchmarking and transparency and professionalism that wasn't there before, when we were a private company. And if we look at the stock markets that have grown by 15 percent while the economy grows by 3 percent, one can deduce from it that you can get in the left lane and start heading faster. It's caused much more work and much more stress, but it points in the right direction.
 
BIKKER -- And much more fun.
 
WORTH -- I don't know about you chaps, but I'm firmly in favor of share options. We're still privately owned, and we have 14 percent of the equity amongst 176 staff out of 230-odd. And it brings people to pay attention to what we do; it makes them be constructive, be critical of their colleagues. They don't waste raw materials or energy.
But the other thing that I find quite amusing and interesting is that it obliges people to learn about the business of business, where before they didn't. You know, what is a joint stock company? What is this private or public limited liability? What's the difference between a shareholder and an officer and a member?
 
BIKKER -- And this helps.
 
WORTH -- I think it's very progressive for everyone.
 
BIKKER -- This also helps in creating breakaways -- new start-ups.
 
WORTH -- Well, one of the humorous bits is you then have trained executives who know how to do all those things. But that's part of the game, isn't it? What goes around comes around.
 
BIKKER -- I guess one of the biggest compliments you can have as an entrepreneur is the number of breakaways.
 
WORTH -- Exactly.
 
BIKKER -- That's the way the Dutch play soccer.
 
A Continent in Transition
 
Q. Would you like to make any concluding points that might be useful for American readers to know about European business?

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
The Fed, in a Supporting Role for the Euro

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE European Central Bank has not been the best friend of the beleaguered euro over its 16 1/2-month life. The confusing signals that bank officials have sent about the euro, the unified currency of 11 European nations, have clearly contributed to its 21 percent decline against the dollar.
And while hints of European Central Bank intervention to support the euro helped it rally last week, to 91.96 cents as of Friday, it remains near its record low of 89.48 cents, reached on May 3. Several American currency analysts still expect the euro to fall as low as 85 cents. 
 So where can Europeans turn for help? Try the United States Federal Reserve, whose policy makers on Tuesday are expected to raise their short-term interest rate target for the sixth time since last June. The only debate is whether the rate increase will be a quarter of a percentage point, like the previous five, or a half-point, in response to recent signs of inflationary pressure.
How could Fed action help Europe?
There are several possible scripts, some of which have the euro continuing to fall -- and the dollar continuing to rise -- in the near term. But longer term, if it finally becomes clear that the Fed is not only determined to slow the American economy but that it is also accomplishing that goal, then the dollar will lose its lift against the euro. And that is important for American investors who have bet on European stocks. The euro's plunge this year has turned almost all of Europe's stock market gains to minuses for American investors.
One possibility is probably best for the euro: a half-point increase in interest rates by the Fed. That would help cement the view that the Fed will not stop raising rates until the annual pace of economic growth slows in the United States from the 5 percent pace of the last four quarters to something closer to 3 or 3.5 percent.
The Fed could underline that message with a statement that "the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future." In fact, those words were included with the announcement of the quarter-point increase in March. Repeating it would signal that there are more rate increases to come.
Adding to the market tension on Tuesday will be the government report on the Consumer Price Index for April. It was the unexpected March jump of 0.4 percent in the core index, which excludes food and energy, that raised the specter of a more aggressive Fed. Another high number would increase inflation fears, making investors even more leery of future rate increases.
Karen E. Parker, director of currency research at Chase Securities, said a high consumer price number and a half-point rate increase would suggest that the United States economy was headed for a hard landing -- and equities would take a hit. Further stock market declines could help break the confidence of European investors in the American market, meaning they would sell American stocks and convert their dollars back to euros.
In the longer term, the slowing of growth in the United States, in comparison with Europe, is what will weaken the dollar and strengthen the euro. "More convincing than ever is the notion that the United States economy is going to slow," said James McCormick, currency strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities. "If the Fed goes half a percentage point and comes up with a strong statement, that is telling you that the growth is going to slow."
That does not mean the euro will turn on a dime. Mr. McCormick expects the euro to fall to 86 cents, because direct European investment in the United States is strong, and there are no sure signs yet that the American economy is slowing. The 0.2 percent downturn in retail sales in April, the first decline since August 1998, buoyed some equity investors. But one month's numbers do not a trend make.
Still, an American investor who believes that the euro can turn in the months ahead would do well to buy European stocks now -- they are cheaper when the dollar is stronger -- and then get the benefit when the euro rallies, making European stocks more valuable in dollar terms.
WILLAERT -- What is important to realize is that Europe is going through a transition period. I think that's the key word there. And transition means a balancing act. And we are not doing too badly on that balancing act. But I would hope for a bit more statesmanship on the European level to improve on the longer-term vision of what we are doing.
And I think if we can take a lot of the good aspects from the U.S. economy -- take some of the good points there and mix it and blend it with where we are traditionally strong: a good basis of social security, a good concept of health care, good schooling. If we can blend that to a good mixture, I think Europe has a fantastic future.
 
FORESTIER -- I think that Americans should realize that Europe is different from America, that the idea's not for Europe to do exactly the same as America, only a few years after. Europe will succeed by inventing a new way of doing business, especially business in the new economy. And I'm really confident about what we are going to invent, provided all the world surrounding us remains stable, because we are really dependent on government.
What worries me more is the pace of it. I mean, within 10 years we definitely have invented something new and something profound, but how fast is it going to move? And is the surrounding world going to wait for us to make our move?
 
BIKKER -- We are absolutely on the right track, and I'm very positive about our future. Let's focus on the very good things that many countries in Europe have organized pretty well. Probably Scandinavia and, I think, the Dutch are the best in education and health care. I've got a lot of kids and I don't pay any kind of hospital care or education costs --
 
SCHOELLER -- But if you would pay, our system becomes more efficient.
 
BIKKER -- That's one of my big problems with Europe: We have by far too many fines, and subsidies for all kinds of initiatives. If we can bring them back down to zero, in agriculture and also other industries, that will speed up prosperity.
 
HUNT -- Just like everybody else, I'm quite optimistic on the future of Europe. First of all, because it's never the endgame, it's an ongoing game forever -- at least that's what we hope. And I think that the biggest challenge for everybody today is globalization, and I believe that Europe is quite well placed from that point of view.
 
SCHOELLER -- I would say from the American perspective, if you look to Europe, the trends are very positive -- the political trends and liberalization, an easing environment for business. We have the trends of innovation. We have the trends that if capital markets catch up, the stock exchanges catch up, the Internet catches up. It's like an undervalued stock.
And I think the fact that we have the multicultural challenge -- that one McDonald's burger cannot be sold all over the world the same way because of the cultural differences -- makes us more fit.
And we have to be able to grow, so even if governments put many hurdles before us, we are still growing. Sometimes American investors think it's better to keep their money in America, but they have much more potential to unlock if they put it into Europe.
 
Q. When's the secondary offering? Sign me up. Simon?
 
WORTH -- We are changing. We are deregulating and becoming more liberal in the business environment, and I suspect for Americans, that balancing act is what they'll see.
 
Q. Thank you all very much.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 4; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 448 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
The Way We Live Now

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
IT may take a village to raise a child, but a family still ought to be able to afford one. It now costs about $160,140 to raise a middle-class child through age 17, according to the Department of Agriculture's annual report, "Expenditures on Children by Families." That's up from $25,229 in 1960 and $69,333 in 1980, seemingly a huge increase. But that 1960 figure, adjusted for inflation, would equal $141, 998 today, so in fact, the cost of brining up baby has risen only about 13 percent since 1960.
Housing has always been the biggest single expense, these days making up about a third of the cost of rearing a child, just as it did 40 years ago. But many other expenditures have changed since then. 
 In 1960, for example, child care was a tiny subcategory lumped into overall housing costs. In the 1970's, however, as mothers of young children poured into the work force, child care expenditures shot up. By the 1980's, child care and education were given their own category, which now comprises an average 10 percent of expenses for preteens. Education costs -- school supplies, books and tuition -- have risen, too. They now accounts for 8 percent of family spending on teenagers, up from only 2 percent in 1960. A large proportion of that increase is likely due to spending on private school, according to Mark Lino, the Agriculture Department economist responsible for the report.
Health care costs, 4 percent of the total in 1960, are now at 7 percent, having risen sharply in the last 10 years. Food and clothing, by contrast, haven't fallen as a percentage of the whole.
Single-parent families spend about as much on each oftheir children as much as two-parent families, by using a greater share of their income for their children. And across all income strata, families with a single child lavish about a third more on that child than families with three or more children spend on each of theirs. The rich spend about half again as much on food, clothes and health care than the poor, and more than twice as much on housing, childcare and education.
Costs are highest in in Western cities, lowest in rural areas and Midwestern cities. And as every parent finds out, older children cost more than younger ones: child care costs go down, but not enough to make up for all the extra food, clothes, and video games.
The middle-income baby born last year, incidentally, will have cost $236,680 by the year 2016, the Department of Agriculture estimates. But don't worry, that's not adjusted for inflation. Keep in mind, however, that even after college bills are paid, almost half of all parents in their fifties are still supporting their over-21 children.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: May 21, 2000, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the average cost of raising children born in 1999 referred incorrectly to the amount, $230,680, that would be spent per child by the year 2016. The figure was indeed adjusted for inflation -- at 4.3 percent a year.
