HEADLINE: Some A.I.G. Shareholders to Press for More Independent Board

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
When the American International Group, one of the world's biggest insurance companies, holds its annual meeting in New York on Wednesday, it will be confronted by several shareholder proposals challenging the dominance of Maurice R. Greenberg, its chief executive.
None of the challenges is likely to prevail. Advocates rarely succeed in storming the corporate gates, and Mr. Greenberg, at 75, has for more than 30 years led what analysts say is consistently America's most profitable insurer. 
 But experts in corporate governance say the shareholder demands that A.I.G. create a more independent board underscore the gap between A.I.G.'s management structure and prevailing practices at most American corporations. They say the structure has also allowed Mr. Greenberg to designate his 45-year-old son Evan as his successor, even though the family does not control the company.
Of American International's 18 board members, 10 are company executives, including Mr. Greenberg and his son, A.I.G.'s president. Two others are consultants to the company, leaving only six truly independent directors. In contrast, more than 90 percent of American corporations have boards with a majority of independent directors.
"You can't question their success and their profitability," said John Nash, founder of the National Association of Corporate Directors, a nonprofit group in Washington that sets standards for corporate governance. "But let's say the company starts to go downhill. Who's going to fire Mr. Greenberg?"
In its proxy statement for the meeting, A.I.G. denies that the board is run autocratically. "Your board of directors stresses the complete participation of all members in the Board decision-making process," it says. A spokesman for A.I.G. said the company would have nothing to add to that.
Barber B. Conable Jr., a former Congressman and past president of the World Bank who is one of the six independent board members, noted that shareholder groups have pressed for similar changes in A.I.G. governance in the past. One group last year got the support of 24 percent of the shareholders.
"They make a pitiful performance," Mr. Conable said. "What are these people yelling about? A.I.G. has gone from a very small company in 1969 to a corporate giant that is three jumps ahead of everybody else in the insurance business. We have some strong people among the outside people, people who are not easily rolled over."
Some experts and advocates have taken Mr. Greenberg's selection of his son as his successor as a strong sign of the senior Mr. Greenberg's hold on the company. The elder Mr. Greenberg says he has no plans to retire.
For years, Mr. Greenberg, who along with other executives controls more than 20 percent of A.I.G.'s voting stock, has run the company as if it were his own. And many analysts say that has been all to the good.
"This is not some guy who is milking the company," said Alice Schroeder, an analyst for PaineWebber who has just completed a nearly 300-page study of A.I.G. after five months of research. "He gives the company 100 percent of his time and energy. His goal is to make A.I.G. the best company on earth, and he's very shareholder-oriented."
Still, governance experts say, A.I.G. is out of step with corporate practice. "Board independence is critical," said Nell Minow, an expert on corporate governance who has co-authored three books on the subject and is editor of the Corporate Library, a Web site that publishes corporate governance information (www.thecorporatelibrary.com).
"The single most important task for a board is C.E.O. succession," she said, "and that task cannot be accomplished right unless the board is independent in both practice and appearance."
People who have dealt with the younger Mr. Greenberg, who did not graduate from college, say he works hard and seems devoted to the company. But they say it is difficult to compare him with his father, who is regarded with awe throughout the industry.
"The son has yet to be proven," said Charles Elson, a specialist in corporate governance at the Stetson University law school. "That's not to say the son won't be good. But you'd feel a lot more comfortable if a non-management dominated group had approved the succession."
One group raising a challenge is the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), which wants A.I.G. to establish a committee of independent board members to select future board members.
"Decision making at A.I.G. is a very closed process dominated by one individual, and we do not think that is healthy in the long term," said William Samplatsky-Jarman, who is in charge of corporate responsibility at the Presbyterian Church.
In her report on A.I.G., Ms. Schroeder depicts a robust company poised for further growth. Its compound annual return since going public in 1969 has been about 20 percent, Ms. Schroeder said, compared with just over 9 percent for the S.& P. 500-stock index.
At about $115 a share, the company is trading at more than five times book value, or about twice the level of most other insurers. And its market capitalization of about $178 billion is nearly twice as great as the next closest insurer, the German company Allianz, at about $91 billion.
A.I.G., with assets of $268 billion, is the nation's leading commercial insurer, with growing businesses in life insurance and auto coverage. With operations in 130 countries, it is by far the most global of American insurers. A.I.G. also runs a big aircraft leasing business that provides planes to the major airlines and operates pension and asset management businesses.
Ms. Schroeder, who previously distinguished herself with detailed studies of Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett, said A.I.G.'s single greatest competitive advantage is the solid grounding it has in so many countries. "In many markets," she said in her report, which is being sold for $500 a copy to people who are not clients of PaineWebber, "A.I.G. may well be the only foreign insurer that can successfully go head to head with local companies and take share profitably."
Mr. Greenberg, who serves as chairman of the Asia Society in New York, travels heavily, often to China and other parts of Asia, where his close ties to political leaders have given him opportunities to begin selling insurance while competitors were waiting for official approval.
Ms. Schroeder, who upgraded her rating of A.I.G. shares from "attractive" to "buy" with the issuance of the report, said three things could cause A.I.G. to stumble as an investment -- a global downturn, big regulatory or political changes in the countries where it operates or "a management succession that is poorly timed or executed."
In her analysis, Ms. Schroeder focused on the process of transferring power from Mr. Greenberg to his son rather than on the questions raised by activist shareholders and governance experts about whether there was sufficiently wide participation in the choice of a new chief executive.
"As the company's business becomes more developed in certain critical countries such as China and India, the risk in the transition should be mitigated," she said.
"Mr. Greenberg has gotten licenses in those countries based partly on personal relations developed over many years. Once he's got developed businesses going in those countries, some of the risk of losing those relationships goes away. We believe he is also working to graft some of those relationships onto his successor."
Some of the challengers plan to demonstrate outside A.I.G.'s headquarters in lower Manhattan on Wednesday dressed in revolutionary-era costumes, accompanied by fife and drum.
"Corporate independence is our theme, playing off some of the themes in the original Declaration of Independence," said Scott Klinger, co-director of Responsible Wealth, a nonprofit organization in Boston whose members say they are among the wealthiest 5 percent of Americans.
Mr. Klinger's group is asking that A.I.G. begin nominating 50 percent more candidates for board seats than the seats available, something no company in America now does. "We filed this resolution," Mr. Klinger said, "to provoke discussion and debate about the way directors are elected. We picked A.I.G. because it is one of the few remaining large companies that do not have an independent board."

'Friends' Stars Accept Deal That Will Keep Show on Air
Under pressure to take a deal worth more than $40 million a year each, or face cancellation of their series, the stars of the NBC comedy "Friends" agreed to a deal that will bring the show back for two more seasons.
The six stars of the show -- Lisa Kudrow, Courteney Cox, Jennifer Aniston, David Schwimmer, Matthew Perry and Matt LeBlanc -- accepted $750,000 an episode for the next two seasons as well as a higher percentage of future profits in the show. Page C8. 

Microsoft Cites AT&T in Defense
As the Microsoft antitrust case hurtles toward its conclusion, both sides are drawing on the experiences of the AT&T breakup to support their legal and political arguments, though in some cases the references are inaccurate or incomplete. And a few of the predictions made by Microsoft and its chairman, William H. Gates, mirror arguments AT&T made 20 years ago -- predictions that never came to pass. C4.
 
United Against Outside Interference
If Microsoft worries the government, then what about the giant that will be created by the merger of America Online and Time Warner? The Justice Department's antitrust chief, Joel Klein, sees little comparison, although he has no jurisdiction in the case. But there is one similarity: all the companies are on the same side in wanting to fend off government intervention. New Economy. C4.
 
Intel Spinoff for Custom-Ordering
Intel plans to announce today that it will spin off a tiny Internet company, Developonline.com, that it hopes will help consumers and business customers custom-order technology products. C10.
 
Catalog Retailers Shine on Web
Now that investors have turned their attention to profitability, old-line catalog companies that have built extensive Web operations are stepping into more favorable light. Companies like Lands' End and Hanover Direct are already generating profits from their e-commerce sites. And, thanks to the Web, the prospects for their catalog businesses are improving. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C16.
 
Berkshire Hathaway Profit Up 49%
Berkshire Hathaway posted a 49 percent increase in first-quarter profit, but its major insurance operations incurred underwriting losses, and the company predicted more of the same this year. C6.
 
Miners Creating Online Marketplace
Fourteen of the world's largest mining and metals companies said that they were creating a single procurement marketplace on the Internet, which could cut the industry's $200 billion-a-year supply bill. C6.
 
A Turkish Cartoonist Far From Home
From the New York suburb of Scarsdale, Salih Memecan, the political cartoonist for Sabah, one of Turkey's largest newspapers, sends forth a stream of daily cartoons that use deft humor to skewer the politicians and politics of his native country seven time zones away. Mr. Memecan moved 18 months ago. Rather than leaving him stranded and out of touch with Turkish affairs, as friends in Istanbul had feared, he said the distance has given him better insight into the economic and political transformations sweeping Turkey. C20.

The publishers at the annual meeting of the Newspaper Association of America in New York expressed confidence despite some disturbing trends. Media. C21.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Stars, Mobsters and Blue Bloods Welcome

BYLINE: By MIKE WALLACE; Mike Wallace is the author, with Edwin G. Burrows, of "Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898."

 BODY:

STORK CLUB
America's Most Famous Nightspot and the Lost World of Cafe Society
By Ralph Blumenthal
Illustrated. 296 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $25.95.
 From the 1920's to the 1960's the Stork Club was a glittering fixture of New York night life. During its Depression heyday, Sherman Billingsley's club became a playground for celebrities from society, screen, radio and the rackets, and for the well-heeled who flocked to drink and dance in their aura. If not indisputably America's most famous nightspot, it was certainly in the front ranks of Cafe Society, whose effervescent goings-on (as reported in daily columns, glossy magazines and sophisticated Hollywood comedies) furnished material for the fantasy life of millions in that bleak era.
In "Stork Club" Ralph Blumenthal has deftly recaptured its evanescent glamour. He evokes its convivial din: 'the rattling of ice in cocktail shakers, the pop of Champagne corks and the sudden blare of rhumba music" and its "air violet with pleasurably exhaled smoke," a haze punctuated by "the flare of flicked lighters" and "roving photographers firing blinding barrages from silvery Speed Graphics." 
 Mr. Blumenthal, who reports on the arts for The New York Times, has dug up notes Billingsley made for a never-written autobiography; interviewed the proprietor's family, friends and former employees; and ransacked appropriate archives. His accumulated data give heft to what is in effect a twin biography, of the club and its owner-manager.
There are times when Mr. Blumenthal seems in thrall to his sources, and the lengthy lists of celebrity attendees and ceaseless flow of family anecdotes and business arcana tell us more than we care or need to know. But his good-humored style keeps the story moving. His tight focus on Billingsley and his club does, however, emphasize description over analysis and circumscribe his investigation of "The Lost World of Cafe Society."
"Cafe Society" was a new kind of elite Manhattan socializing in which formerly reclusive upper-crust men and women began partying in public alongside entertainment celebrities, with the collective merriment sped to mass audiences by various media. Mr. Blumenthal dates the phenomenon's emergence to the early 1920's, when Billingsley arrived on the New York scene, and its passing to the 1960's, when he died. Arguably, however, there has been a series of Cafe Societies, beginning in the 1890's, when venturesome blue bloods and Broadway stars began stepping out to spectacular restaurants and naughty cabarets, their doings trumpeted by a hungry press.
Prohibition wiped away this first generation of clubs and cabarets, and turned the entertainment business over to gangsters and bootleggers, providing Billingsley with his entrance cue. A man with impeccable criminal credentials, Mr. Blumenthal makes clear, this youthful Oklahoman had traveled around dry states, watering parched inhabitants with whiskey, until he landed in Leavenworth prison. When Prohibition went national, Billingsley moved to New York, failed to make it in the violent big leagues of bootlegging and settled for running one of the innumerable new gangster-backed speak-easies.
The 1929 crash, in turn, swept away many of these second-wave nightspots, but the Stork Club hung on, partly thanks to mob connections but mainly because in 1930 the columnist Walter Winchell plugged it, in print and on radio, as "New York's New Yorkiest place." Better yet, Winchell moved in as resident scribe and tout, guaranteeing a steady flow of customers and allowing Billingsley to catch the third wave in 1933, when repeal sent respectable nightlife surging.
Mr. Blumenthal makes clear the grubby backstage reality behind the swanky front, notably Billingsley's provision of free food and drink to the columnists who served as shills, and to the well-born (or merely well-dressed) youths who served as bait. Blacks were distinctly unwelcome.
Brilliantly successful through its wartime peak, the Stork began to lurch and wobble in the 1950's, before crashing to earth in the 1960's. Mr. Blumenthal suggests the problem was "a growing distaste for the self-indulgence of a spoiled class." True enough, as far as it goes, but the passing of the club, and the top-hatted, high-heeled version of Cafe Society itself, seems insufficiently situated in the context of the times. What Mr. Blumenthal does demonstrate is how much of Billingsley's fall was of his own making.
In the case of television, a general threat to all nightspots, Billingsley was at his most active, trying to ride the electronic wave lest he drown in it. He signed with CBS to do an interview program live from the Stork, but proved an awkward on-screen presence. The big beneficiaries of television were new clubs like the Blue Angel, whose daring comics or breakaway singers often wound up on the Ed Sullivan or Jack Paar shows. But Billingsley wasn't into novel entertainment forms.
As Billingsley's cultural caution cost him, so did fallout from his racial, political, and economic stances. Mr. Blumenthal presents these as separate issues, but they might more advantageously be seen as linked conservatisms. The Stork's (and other nightspots') restrictive racial policies came under indirect assault when in 1938 a club in Greenwich Village, provocatively named Cafe Society, began courting black patrons as well as performers. Then in 1950, after an incident at the Stork involving Josephine Baker, the desegregation struggle came directly to Billingsley's doorstep, with N.A.A.C.P. pickets bearing signs reading "Famous Nite Spot Just a White Spot."
The Stork's standing was not improved when Billingsley and the previously New Dealish Winchell made the club a haven for the Cold War right. J. Edgar Hoover had long been a Stork habitue (and to an amazing degree a fix-it man for his buddy Billingsley). Now the club played host to Joseph McCarthy and Roy Cohn (who struck up their chumship there) and got Billingsley involved in damaging wars with liberal media. Billingsley also fought a ferocious and losing battle against unionization -- with Cohn as his pugnacious lawyer -- a fight that cost him clients and cash, including his children's trust funds.
Finally, with office buildings swallowing up the surrounding brownstones, Billingsley sold the Stork to CBS, who had it torn down and the site on East 53rd Street turned into a vest-pocket park. Billingsley died in 1966, a year after his club's demise. When the latest incarnation of Cafe Society took to the dance floor at Studio 54, he would not be around to join the party.

LENGTH: 1193 words

HEADLINE: E-COMMERCE REPORT;
Catalog companies show the upstarts that they know a thing or two about Internet retailing.

BYLINE: By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
IN this season of comeuppance for Internet-only retailers, catalog companies that also sell on the Web may finally be getting their due.
Even as the stock prices of so-called "pure play" electronic retailers spiked last Christmas season, the e-tailers acknowledged that they would still need to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on marketing and warehouses to make their businesses viable -- investments the catalog companies had made long ago. 
 Internet merchants also acknowledged their need for direct marketing expertise -- an admission that might have seemed downright flattering to catalog companies, if they were not too busy trying to keep the dot-coms from luring away their best executives.
But now that investors have turned their attention to profitability, the old-line catalog companies that have built the most extensive Web operations are stepping into more favorable light. Companies like Lands' End, Hanover Direct and BMG Direct are already generating profits from their e-commerce sites. And, thanks to the Web, the prospects for their catalog businesses are improving.
"Their numbers are staggering," said Barbara Wykoff, an analyst with the investment firm Buckingham Research. "It's frightening how fast they're growing."
Lands' End, for example, generated 3 percent of sales from its Web site (www.landsend.com) in 1998, Ms. Wykoff said. But last quarter, that number was 12 percent. BMG Direct, a Bertelsmann unit that sells CD's, generated 10 percent of its sales from the Web last year, and could reach 15 percent this year.
Ms. Wykoff said that companies with a catalog pedigree -- including J. C. Penney, Lands' End and L.L. Bean -- not only have some of the most visited e-commerce sites on the Web, but they have proved to be the best at converting browsers to buyers. Those three companies each have conversion rates of 13 to 16 percent online, according to Nielsen/ NetRatings, an Internet research firm, compared with an average of about 1.8 percent among all Web retailers.
But perhaps the most important statistic separating catalog companies from their Web-only competitors is customer acquisition cost. According to a recent survey by the Boston Consulting Group on behalf of the industry association Shop.org, catalog retailers spent $11 on average for each new customer last year. In comparison, e-tailers spent $82 per customer.
The reason for such a disparity, of course, is that e-tailers are still burning through tens of millions of dollars in advertising to attract customers to their sites.
Catalog companies, meanwhile, have a built-in marketing vehicle that can sit around a consumer's house for weeks before it reaches the trash. And to make sure customers remember the Internet sites, catalog companies often print their Web addresses on every page.
Catalog companies also report that instead of the Web cannibalizing their catalog sales, it is creating new customers.
Hanover Direct, which owns several catalog operations, including Gump's, International Male and the Company Store, said that 50 percent of its online customers last year had not previously purchased goods from their catalogs.
"We've found that taking a print catalog and using targeted marketing principles is the most efficient way to create online customers," said Rakesh K. Kaul, Hanover's chief executive. "It's no contest," he said, when compared with "e-tailers who go out and buy ads on the Super Bowl."
The Web has also helped build the overall profit the company can squeeze out of each customer over repeat visits, he said. Rather than send an existing customer a new catalog each month, Mr. Kaul said, the company complements the catalog mailings with e-mail messages, thereby reducing marketing costs. "So the Web now becomes a very efficient way to maintain customer contact," he said.
Catalog businesses benefit from the Web in other ways as well.
George McMillan, chief executive of BMG Direct, said the company could use the Web to test and create new catalog ideas that might not otherwise be viable.
"If you can't identify a market of 400,000 to 500,000 users, you can't justify the product development costs and research necessary to test it," Mr. McMillan said.
"With the Web, you don't have any paper or printing costs associated with testing an idea," he continued. "You can try more things without getting burned, and maybe find niches of the market that are smaller, but still make sense economically."
Mr. McMillan declined to say if BMG would roll out new catalogs aimed at BMG customers as a result of this testing. But he said the company was "experimenting with some things" among BMG's 10 million customers -- 2.8 million of whom are online. "There are a lot of segments in 10 million people," he said.
Happy as they are with their core businesses, catalog companies recognize that it is far more economical to close a sale over the Web than over the phone, so they are pushing to convert more of their customers to the Web with every passing month. According to Ms. Wykoff of Buckingham Research, catalog companies "won't save a significant amount of money" on overall customer costs "until the Internet gets to 20 percent of their business."
There are exceptions. The Bear Creek Corporation, which owns Harry and David, a food catalog and Web site (www.harryanddavid.com), generates about 9 percent of its sales on the Internet, and saves about $4.60 for each order placed through the Web, according to Nancy Tait, the company's executive vice president. Given the orders the company handled on the Web last year, that amounts to about $1.1 million saved.
But as Lands' End found out last year, companies cannot rely too much on the Web to deliver profits. Lands' End mailed about 9 percent fewer catalogs last holiday season, analysts said -- a move that might help explain its 17 percent dip in holiday sales and a substantial decline in its stock price.
"There's an inextricable link between the catalog and the site," said Bill Bass, vice president of e-commerce for Lands' End. "Our traffic always spikes when the catalogs arrive."
But that will not stop the company from an Internet-only approach in other countries. This summer, Mr. Bass said, Lands' End will roll out sites in several European countries where the company does not mail catalogs. As for marketing in those countries, he said, "online, word-of-mouth means a lot."
For catalog companies, one of the most satisfying aspects of the recent slide in e-tailing stocks is that their own employees are now less inclined to jump ship when a dot-com recruiter calls. "That's been a real drain on our industry," said Ms. Tait of Bear Creek. "I'm hoping those days are over."
They may be. Mr. Kaul of Hanover said that dot-coms were now more interested in forming partnerships with catalog companies than luring away their employees.
"We've seen a number of Internet companies approach us recently saying, 'Gee, why don't you create a catalog for us and help us understand how this works?' " he said. "So I wouldn't be surprised if you see more and more combinations in the catalog and Internet world."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1496 words

HEADLINE: 'Super-Editor' Spot May Be Created At Post-Merger AOL-Time Warner

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Last Thursday night, Norman Pearlstine, the editor in chief of Time Inc., boogied to the sounds of Barenaked Ladies, the Canadian pop group, at a party at San Francisco's Pacific Bell Stadium.
The occasion was an invitation-only party for a 1,000 guests to introduce Time Inc.'s E-Company Now, an offshoot of Fortune magazine that will focus on the Internet economy. 
 The party was supposed to mark the first time that executives from Time Warner and America Online celebrated the birth of a Time Inc. magazine together. And the gala took place far from Time Warner's New York headquarters, in a city more closely linked with the new-media culture that America Online so embodies. Gerald M. Levin, chairman of Time Warner, and Don Logan, chief executive of Time Inc., joined Mr. Pearlstine. Stephen M. Case, chairman of America Online, was supposed to attend, but could not get away from the East Coast. He sent remarks along by videotape.
Which raises the inevitable question: can the current executives of Time Warner and America Online all boogie to the same corporate tune?
That question was addressed, at least for the moment, last week, when the two companies released an organization chart with a mother lode of corporate turf under the name of Robert W. Pittman, an America Online executive and the designated co-chief operating officer of the new company, to whom Mr. Logan and his magazine division, pushed farther down the food chain, will now report.
And within the last six weeks, Mr. Pearlstine has seemingly answered questions about his own immediate future. A year ago, it was widely believed inside Time Inc. that he would leave the job of editor in chief at the end of 2000, a belief that led to an internal guessing game about whether John Huey, managing editor of Fortune, or Walter Isaacson, managing editor of Time magazine, was more likely to take his job.
But the 57-year-old Mr. Pearlstine has renegotiated his contract and in an interview last week said he would stay at the company for at least another three years.
Still, the corporate tinkering may be far from over. Two senior Time Inc. executives said last week that an editorial job might be created above Mr. Pearlstine's, a sort of AOL Time Warner uber-editor who would oversee -- and try to create synergies between -- the journalistic activities at Time Warner and America Online. In this scenario, one person would supervise the journalistic work of CNN, Time Inc. and America Online.
The notion of an editor in chief for the integrated company would please both Mr. Case and Mr. Levin, who have discussed the notion, the executives said. Both men are determined to show an integrated company to Wall Street -- and Time Warner has never been perceived as particularly well integrated by the business community. And Mr. Levin, the Time Inc. executives said, has not been excessively pleased with the level of synergy within his own company, particularly between Time Inc. and CNN.
Peter Costiglio, a spokesman for Time Inc., said no plans had been made for the editorial czar position. But with Mr. Pittman now overseeing subscription and advertising sales not only at Time Inc. but for other Time Warner and AOL divisions as well, some believe it might make sense to have an executive with the same breadth of editorial responsibility reporting to him. If the position is created, it will not be happen before the end of the year.
Or, as another Time Inc. executive, put it: "Until the merger is done, you never know how things will play out."
America Online has long argued that the separation of editorial church and commercial state does not jibe with the new-media concept that success comes from the integration of commerce and content.
But does it make sense to alter a magazine division that is thriving so mightily? Time Inc. -- a division that includes both magazines and book publishing -- took in $4.6 billion in revenue in 1999, according to the company's annual report, up from $4.4 billion in 1998. The magazines the division publishes range from the outrageous puffery of In Style and Teen People to the authoritative business coverage of Fortune magazine. (Only 6 percent of the division's revenue was attributable to book publishing, according to industry estimates.)
Mr. Pearlstine, at a conference sponsored by the Industry Standard and New York magazines two weeks ago, said he was less worried about interference from America Online on the editorial front than about the internal distribution of corporate resources. How does one convince Wall Street, he asked, that investing in a new magazine is better than say, expanding a cable system?
Of course, there are more pressing concerns for Mr. Pearlstine. As Time Warner is absorbed into America Online, there is a question within the company about whether Time Inc. magazines will receive special treatment from America Online and whether America Online might even get preferential treatment in the pages of Time magazines -- which have so far in fact gone out of their way to cover Time Warner and America Online with a brusque and sometimes biting fairness. (Time magazine clearly portrayed Time Warner as the loser in the company's public relations battle with the Walt Disney Company over the Time Warner cable blackout of ABC two weeks ago.)
And there is some minor turbulence within the magazine division: Real Simple, the new magazine for women from Time Inc.'s immensely successful People division, has met with disappointment both on the newsstand and within the company. Last week, Henry Muller, Time Inc.'s editorial director for seven years, gave up that position to become an editor at large. At the same time, Isolde Motley -- the former managing editor of Life, which was closed last month -- was named corporate editor. But no replacement was named for the editorial director position Mr. Muller left behind.
In an interview last week, Mr. Pearlstine addressed the issue of editorial independence -- which has been assured to him from all angles, he said -- and whether or not Time Inc. magazines would receive preferential treatment on America Online.
"From a distance, you might say, 'Why do this merger if you don't do that?' " Mr. Pearlstine asked. "But I think it winds up being more an issue of right of first refusal. If it makes sense, you obviously want to cooperate. But if you try to force everything through those filters, you will probably get in trouble."
The situation, Mr. Pearlstine said, is not unlike that in which Time Inc. found itself when Time magazine sought a television network as a partner in producing a special based on Time magazine's Person of the Century issue.
"We went to CNN first and they said, 'We don't have a lot of money to put into this, and we don't have 50 years of archives because we haven't been around that long, and we don't have that many customers for this kind of appointment viewing,' " he said. "Meanwhile, CBS was there saying, 'We have fifty years of archives, and lots of eyeballs and money to put into it.' So we wound up doing the deal with CBS."
All the instincts within the company, Mr. Pearlstine said, "will be to -- the old Wall Street cliche -- 'unlock shareholder value' by finding more synergy in the deal." But he added that "Gerry, and certainly Case, at least to date, have been saying that where it makes sense, we will do deals, but where it does not, we will not."
Mr. Pearlstine insisted there were no substantial problems at Real Simple -- although one senior staff member said the new magazine might better be described as "real complicated."
"It has some work to do, and it is a hard concept to execute," he said. He added that because of the swift success of Teen People and In Style, both of which also originated in the People division, the introduction of Real Simple faced higher expectations from the outset than most magazines. The first issue was also released at the same time as the first issue of Hearst Magazine's "O: The Oprah Magazine," which Mr. Pearlstine described as "first rate."
In the meantime, the larger corporate structure has yet to affect Mr. Pearlstine, or his relationship with Mr. Logan. It is known throughout Time Inc. management that Mr. Logan and Mr. Pittman get along well. They share the ideas about using each other's companies to get more subscriptions and about using the two companies together as a formidable advertising platform -- and they share similar Southern backgrounds.
"I'm from Mississippi, and he's from Alabama," Mr. Logan said. "So we both know the difference between hush puppies and barbecue."
As for filling the uber-editor job, candidates mentioned include Mr. Pearlstine, Mr. Isaacson and, to a lesser, degree, Mr. Huey.
Mr. Logan would not comment on whether the new position will be created. As for any other changes, he said: "You will see some movement within the management teams. But it too early to say what."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
His Civil Rights Challenge: Equal Access to Technology

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SITTING in his eighth-floor office as he prepared to deliver the commencement address at Howard University, William E. Kennard found himself torn.
Mr. Kennard, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said he was simultaneously rejoicing and disappointed about the way things had changed for blacks since 1965, when President Lyndon B. Johnson used the commencement at Howard, a historically black school here, to deliver a landmark address on civil rights. What bothered Mr. Kennard most was the growing economic divisions among blacks themselves -- and the failure of the most well-off in times of prosperity to take care of those who remain behind. 
 "There's cause for lots of celebration. African-Americans have made tremendous progress in 35 years," he said. "But it's also sobering to think that by all objective indicators of success we are still disproportionately represented. And I get particularly frustrated because I think successful African-Americans focus too much time and attention on achieving more success and wealth at the upper ranks. Nothing diminishes our success more than to realize as a people we're still behind."
"Sure, we've made progress and some of the policies Johnson announced in that speech are responsible for that," he added. "But at the same time, we have a long way to go."
The F.C.C. may seem an odd pulpit from which to be preaching social justice and racial equality, as Mr. Kennard, the agency's first African-American chairman, has been doing since he took the job nearly three years ago. It is a place, he said, where he and others typically spend their time "refereeing fights between the rich and the very wealthy."
But then again, in the current technological and political climate, the F.C.C. is not such an unusual forum from which to advance change.
At the vortex of a telecommunications revolution and a whirlwind of corporate deal-making that faces regulatory review, Mr. Kennard said he was ideally positioned to advance interests that some civil rights leaders say have caused a deep digital divide between the haves and have-nots, a gap that has been ignored by Congress and only belatedly recognized by the White House. With his agency buffeted daily by the competing interests of some of the nation's most powerful industries, Mr. Kennard views his mission as providing a voice to those who cannot hire a K Street lobbyist.
"I believe one of the main civil rights challenges of this new millennium is the challenge of ensuring equal access to technology," he said. "W. E. B. Du Bois said, 'The problem of the 20th century is the problem of the color line.' At the dawn of this century, our challenge is preventing the color line from determining who is online."
As such, Mr. Kennard has championed an unusually liberal agenda in a town controlled by a moderate White House and a Republican Congress. He has made political enemies by fighting for more money for a program to provide the Internet to schools and libraries, paid for through a tax on telephone bills. He has incurred widespread opposition from the nation's largest broadcasters for promoting a plan to approve hundreds of new low-power FM radio stations for churches, schools and community groups. And he has alienated telephone companies by blocking them from expanding into lucrative new markets while pressing them to provide service in less profitable underserved areas, including Indian reservations.
"If you look across the nation, 94 percent of homes in America have telephones," he said. "When you look at people living on tribal lands, the average drops below 50 percent. And in some areas, such as the Navajo nation, telephone service is down at 20 percent. We're not talking about Internet access, we're talking about basic phone service. In an era of wireless technology and satellite technology, that shouldn't exist."
Mr. Kennard's views are a byproduct of his upbringing. "My parents had a sense that the way to raise children is by teaching them about the benefits they had enjoyed, and the importance of helping the disadvantaged," he said.
He described his parents, a successful architect and a teacher of bilingual education, as "first-generation middle class." One of his grandfathers was a Pullman porter and school janitor; the other was a chauffeur who later owned a restaurant.
Mr. Kennard was 7 years old at the time of the Johnson speech at Howard, living in an integrated community in Los Angeles. His parents worked for the farm labor movement and against the Vietnam War. Before he left for college, he and his family helped run an orphanage in Mexico.
After attending Stanford University, he briefly worked for an NBC television affiliate in California before entering Yale Law School. There he met his future wife, Deborah D. Kennedy, who recently left her job as a corporate lawyer at the Exxon Mobil Corporation and is now raising the couple's infant son, Robert, named after Mr. Kennard's father.
Mr. Kennard's oldest sister took over their father's architectural firm after he died a few years ago. Another sister runs the Los Angeles Airport Authority and, like Mr. Kennard, is a lawyer.
AT the F.C.C., which he joined as general counsel in 1993, Mr. Kennard has occasionally been both amused and frustrated by the way some companies have reacted to his agenda. Some have retained black lobbyists and lawyers in a transparent attempt to curry favor. Others opposed to his regulatory regime have run to Congress and enlisted the support of Democratic and Republican lawmakers to rein in the agency.
He said his greatest frustration was the inability of members of Congress even to consider the commission's policy recommendations.
"I'm frustrated that oftentimes the debate focuses on winners and losers in terms of who will make money and lose money and not what I think is most important, which is how will something benefit the public," he said. "And I'm frustrated that members of Congress often don't want to engage with me on policy but have made up their minds, often after hearing from big interests who are constituents.
"When I got here I thought, maybe naively, that we could really grapple and engage on issues of policy. Some do, but most don't."

LENGTH: 1740 words

HEADLINE: Hints of New Inflation May Draw Sharp Fed Reaction

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Judging that rapid advances in technology were making businesses and workers more productive in ways that tempered inflation, the Federal Reserve has given the economy more or less free rein over the last five years to find its own limits.
It may have finally found them. 
 After a long spell in which the Fed's patience was rewarded with an almost perfect combination of strong growth, declining unemployment and stable prices, there are tentative but worrisome signs that inflation is emerging from hibernation.
With that in mind, when the Fed meets on Tuesday to consider whether to raise interest rates, it may feel compelled to adopt a more aggressive inflation-fighting stance than it has employed in years.
Although Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has provided no clear signal that he has made up his mind, analysts and investors expect the central bank to raise its benchmark interest rate by a half-percentage point at the meeting, abandoning a steady path of smaller rate increases favored of late by Mr. Greenspan.
Should the Fed opt to go with a half-point rate increase, it would be the first time the Fed has made such a big tightening move since February 1995. Such a move would bring the federal funds target rate to 6.5 percent, its highest level since January 1991, and would be felt by homebuyers looking for mortgages, by anyone financing a car loan or carrying a credit card balance and by companies deciding whether to build a new factory or invest in new equipment.
Inflation is still more a threat than a reality, and some economists think the Fed is again proving too willing to sacrifice jobs and prosperity in a fight against a phantom enemy. But there is growing evidence of upward pressure on wages and prices.
Wage growth seems to be accelerating -- good for workers in the short run but a development that could lead employers to push through price increases to maintain profit margins. The employment cost index, which tracks both wages and benefits, surged in the first quarter.
Broad price measures like the Consumer Price Index are starting to edge up, even after the jump in oil prices is factored out.
Other indicators, like the Producer Price Index for April, which was released on Friday, provided no firm evidence that inflation has taken root. And if the economy were slowing or running at a more moderate pace, the Fed might be less concerned.
But despite a string of five quarter-point rate increases by the Fed in less than a year, the economy continues to barrel along, suggesting that inflationary pressures are more likely to intensify than to abate.
"The free lunch we enjoyed in terms of inflation," said Diane Swonk, chief economist at Bank One and president of the National Association for Business Economics, "is clearly over."
The Fed's experiment with giving the economy more running room dates back to the last prolonged episode of prolonged monetary policy tightening, in 1994. Back then, the conventional wisdom among economists held that inflation was all but inevitable if the pace of growth exceeded 2 percent to 2.5 percent a year or if unemployment fell much below 6 percent.
But even as he was raising rates aggressively during that period to choke off budding inflation pressures, Mr. Greenspan began to notice two things: that inflation was not as strong as might have been anticipated, and that the growth rate of productivity, or output per hour, seemed to be increasing faster than was being captured in the official statistics.
In March 1994, according to recently released transcripts of one of the Fed's closed-door policy meetings, Mr. Greenspan asked a provocative question of his colleagues around the 28-foot-long conference table in the central bank's ornate board room.
"Is it automatically the case," Mr. Greenspan asked the members of the Federal Open Market Committee, "that when the economy is tightening up that inflation takes hold?"
Mr. Greenspan did not venture a firm answer. But he cited the possibility that "we are getting extraordinary productivity increases that are keeping unit labor costs down." At that point, almost no one else was detecting any improvements in productivity growth, which appeared to be stuck at a lackluster rate of 1 percent, dooming the economy to a tepid performance.
Out of such musing on Mr. Greenspan's part grew considerable research by the Fed's staff into productivity -- and a growing conviction on the Fed chairman's part that the economy might be capable of higher rates of noninflationary growth than the traditional models suggested.
The result has been monetary policy that has helped nurture the longest expansion on record, the lowest unemployment in a generation, a resurgence in real wage growth, a flood of business investment that has allowed the United States to reclaim its position of economic pre-eminence and the rise of a stock market that until the last few months seemed rocket powered.
To some extent, the economy's performance was helped by factors that clearly were not going to last forever, including several years of extremely low oil prices, the downward pressure on compensation costs from the advent of managed health care and the way in which falling import prices helped drive inflation down after the global financial crisis a few years ago.
Moreover, Mr. Greenspan and the Fed never quite bought the notion of a "new" economy that was immune from the forces that ignited inflation in the past. And indeed, should the central bank raise rates by a half-percentage point on Tuesday, it would be making the point that America's vaunted technology-driven, globally oriented economy is still subject to the same forces behind the old, discredited speed limits, even if not to those specific limits themselves.
"There is a tendency to go too far and talk as if we're in a world where there are no limits and where we don't need to think in terms of the old concepts at all," said George L. Perry, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, the research organization. "We're in a position where there's not much doubt about what we have to do -- we have to tighten monetary policy to slow the economy."
It is unclear precisely what the economy's new boundaries are and whether they are any more permanent than the old ones. Economists now talk about sustainable growth rates not of 2 percent to 2.5 percent a year, but of as much as 4.5 percent a year.
Where economists once pinpointed the "natural" rate of unemployment -- the level at which inflation begins to accelerate -- at about 6 percent, they are now debating figures like 4.5 percent and even lower.
But whatever the new speed limits, it is all but certain that the economy is breaking them today.
The economy grew at a 7.3 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter of last year and at a 5.4 percent pace in the first quarter of this year. Unemployment in April dropped to 3.9 percent, the lowest rate since January 1970.
"We don't know exactly what the limits are, but the current rate of growth and the current rate of unemployment go beyond the economy's capacity," said Mark Zandi, an economist at RFA Dismal Sciences, a consulting firm. "What's going on now is just too much."
Too much, economists fear, to keep a lid on inflation.
In March, consumer prices jumped 0.7 percent, pushing the consumer price index 3.7 percent above where it was a year earlier. That compares with an inflation rate of 2.7 percent in December and January. And even excluding volatile food and energy costs, prices rose 0.4 percent in March, pushing the "core" inflation rate to 2.4 percent, up from 1.9 percent in January.
Meanwhile, compensation per worker rose at a 4.2 percent annual rate in the first quarter, up from 3.8 percent the previous quarter. Unit labor costs rose by 1.8 percent after falling during the previous six months.
While not overly alarming yet, such signs suggest that more troubling news on inflation is yet to come unless the overheated economy slows down.
Still, for the Fed, trying to slow the economy to a more manageable 3 percent or 4 percent annual growth rate gives Mr. Greenspan a lot more room for error than if he had to slow growth to the old speed limit of 2 percent. That is a critical difference given that most expansions turn into recessions only when the Fed tightens the interest rate screw too much or too quickly to squelch inflation.
The degree to which the Fed becomes more aggressive in attacking inflation this week and for the rest of the year depends on a host of factors. The stock market, which Mr. Greenspan had identified as the source of much of the excess demand in the economy, remains volatile, and a sustained move up or down would no doubt heavily influence Fed policy.
The degree to which inflation actually materializes will clearly play a role. There could be further clues in the Consumer Price Index for April, which is to be released on Tuesday morning just before the start of the Fed meeting.
There are other factors that are harder to pin down, including the fact that it is an election year. The Fed has not shied away from raising rates during presidential campaigns -- it did so through much of 1992 -- but it might prefer to get any big rate increases out of the way well before the race heats up in the fall.
But the central question is whether the imbalances in the economy -- particularly the potential for the economy to run short of workers, setting off a spiral in wages and prices -- are substantial enough to overpower the benefits the economy has derived from the rebound in productivity.
Since he first started raising the issue in the mid-1990's, Mr. Greenspan has become increasingly convinced that widespread technological advances have ignited a resurgence in productivity growth, allowing employers to pay more to workers without facing a choice between higher prices or diminished profit margins. Last month he told a conference at the White House that productivity growth -- which in the last few years has been running at about 3.5 percent -- may still be accelerating.
But Mr. Greenspan, ever cautious, also made clear that even the magic elixir of improving productivity has its limits.
"Should the pool of available workers continue to shrink, there is a point at which this safety valve for excess demand will eventually close," Mr. Greenspan said, "even in the face of accelerating productivity."

HEADLINE: Keizo Obuchi, Premier Who Brought Stability as Japan's Economy Faltered, Dies at 62

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 14

 BODY:
Keizo Obuchi, a bland, self-effacing politician who as Japan's prime minister brought some stability to the country's faltering economy and fractious politics, died this afternoon in Tokyo.
He was 62 and had been relieved of his duties as prime minister after suffering a stroke in early April. 
 Mr. Obuchi died here in Juntendo University Hospital, where he had been hospitalized in a coma since last month, the prime minister's office said. Doctors said he died from complications of the stroke.
News reports earlier in the day said that Mr. Obuchi's blood pressure had dropped to a near-critical level and that he was becoming unresponsive to medication to stimulate circulation.
Because many Japanese considered him to be pedestrian and lacking in charisma, Mr. Obuchi was the least popular choice for prime minister when he was selected in 1998 by the Liberal Democratic Party, which has governed Japan for most of the period since World War II.
Although he had served as foreign minister and chief cabinet secretary, Mr. Obuchi was considered too cautious to pursue the far-reaching reforms needed to resolve Japan's worst financial crisis in decades. The country's banking system was collapsing, unemployment was rising and the public pension fund was running dry. Critics predicted that Mr. Obuchi would not last more than a few months.
But his quiet, unassertive manner belied his political skillfulness and daring, and he quickly reversed longtime policy and pushed a huge spending package and a number of other economic measures through Parliament that temporarily halted Japan's economic slide, though at a heavy cost to taxpayers.
Although the results of Mr. Obuchi's policies were mixed, the economy showed some signs of improvement and his popularity soared, reaching a 51 percent approval rating last summer.
But support for his government waned considerably in the months before his stroke following his decision to forge an alliance with opposition parties and a string of corruption scandals.
Thomas S. Foley, the United States ambassador to Japan, said that Mr. Obuchi's record in office refuted critics who had dismissed him as a lightweight and that Mr. Obuchi would rank high among postwar Japanese prime ministers.
"When he became prime minister I was shocked that he was received with such low expectations and publicly dismissive comments by people who suggested he would be a short term or transitional prime minister," Mr. Foley said. "He confounded everyone's estimate."
John F. Neuffer, a noted analyst of Japanese politics, had described Mr. Obuchi as having "all the pizazz of a cold pizza," -- a characterization that haunted him throughout his tenure. But Mr. Neuffer maintained that his statement had been widely misunderstood.
"Cold pizza was a comment on his leadership style, but in Japan you don't have to be an especially tantalizing political leader to get things done, and Obuchi proved that," Mr. Neuffer said. "In many ways he was the right man for the job and far more clever than the mainstream media gave him credit for being."
Mr. Obuchi became prime minister after a frenzied race within the Liberal Democratic Party to replace his predecessor, Ryutaro Hashimoto, who had been forced to resign after an upset in the upper house elections in 1998. Critics said Mr. Hashimoto's tenure was marked by an insufficient effort to turn around a failing economy.
Mr. Obuchi, Japan's 23rd prime minister since World War II, was by all accounts a shrewd tactician, skilled in the back-room negotiations and consensus-building that are the hallmark of Japanese politics.
But former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone once referred to Mr. Obuchi as "a vacuum prime minister," contending that he had no valuable policies or principles of his own but simply absorbed the ideas of the talented ministers and advisers that he kept around him.
"Emptiness helps me avoid confrontation with others," Mr. Obuchi said in an interview last year. "It also allows me to absorb whatever available ideas seem good. I am affable to everyone."
Mr. Obuchi turned his low-key style into a genuine asset, and the Japanese people were enamored with his humility and the stability he imposed on politics.
"He restored people's confidence in leadership," said Yukio Okamoto, a political consultant. "He did not appear to be smart, and he deliberately tried not to convey an air of intelligence. He pretended to be a commoner and this was his unique way of disarming people of their criticism of politicians."
While Mr. Obuchi gained legislative approval for a $400 billion pump-priming stimulus plan and a bank recapitalization program that were popular with the public, some of his critics feared that his pork barrel politics would undercut these efforts. Tough reforms on health care, corporate taxation and other areas have been stalled or weakened while the national debt is ballooning.
Mr. Obuchi honed his political skills by sparring with some of Japan's heavyweights. Early in his career, he competed for votes in the same district as two former prime ministers, Mr. Nakasone and Takeo Fukuda, under a multiseat constituency system that was recently abandoned.
Reflecting on those years, Mr. Obuchi often described himself as "a noodle shop sandwiched between two skyscrapers" -- the rival prime ministers. But it was in this grass-roots environment that Mr. Obuchi mastered the art of the Japanese political deal, especially in cultivating personal relationships.
When he became prime minister, Mr. Obuchi never abandoned the tactics that served him well at the local level. For example, he was said to make as many as 50 "courtesy" telephone calls a day, often to people he did not even know. This practice proved effective in establishing Mr. Obuchi as a man of the people.
While traveling in the United States last year, Shinichi Kitaoka, a history professor at Tokyo University, returned to his room to find a message from the prime minister on his answering machine. "I had no connections with him, but he just called to say hello and to thank me for writing and doing research on him," Mr. Kitaoka said. "Yes, it was calculated but it certainly made me feel like he cared."
Perhaps Mr. Obuchi's most notable political coup came last August when he assembled the largest governing coalition that Japan had seen in decades and began pushing through Parliament a variety of measures long stalled in the political gridlock of past administrations. The measures included the adoption of the Japanese flag and imperial anthem as official national symbols and laws to crack down on terrorist groups like Aum Shinrikyo.
Keizo Obuchi was born on June 25, 1937, into a middle-class family in the town of Nakanojo in the mountainous Gumma Prefecture. His father, Kohei, managed a silk mill and was elected to Parliament. Mr. Obuchi's older brother is the mayor of Nakanojo.
A graduate of the prestigious Waseda University in Tokyo, Mr. Obuchi vowed to pursue a political career after the death of his father. He was elected to the lower house in 1963 at age 26, the youngest Japanese ever to win a seat in Parliament. He was elected to that seat, previously held by his father, for 38 years.
He held a number of ministry and cabinet positions before being named chief cabinet secretary for his political mentor, former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, in 1987 and minister of foreign affairs in 1997.
Mr. Obuchi is survived by his wife, Chizuko; two daughters, Akiko and Yuko; and a son, Takeshi, all of Tokyo.
At the height of Mr. Obuchi's popularity last year, Beat Takeshi, a popular comedian, picked up on Mr. Obuchi's own references and said that instead of cold pizza, Mr. Obuchi was more like the low-cost noodles that are sold at public beach houses in summer. The noodles are generally regarded as bland but after a long day of swimming and frolicking at the beach, many Japanese find that they taste pretty good.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
For 22 Years, Rickey Has Bedeviled Both Pitchers and Managers

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
Only a week earlier Kirby Puckett had become baseball's first $3 million-a-year player with a three-year, $9 million contract with Minnesota and now Oakland was about to announce a new contract for Rickey Henderson that would pay him $3 million a year over four years.
But Henderson was not happy. In November 1989, he wanted to be the highest-paid player, bar none, and he had groused to his agent, Richmond Bry, that he had failed to get him there. They were on their way into a news conference at Oakland Coliseum when an electrician, working in the area, spotted the Athletics star. 
 "Hey, Rickey," the workman shouted, "it better be $4 million a year."
Turning to Bry, Henderson said, "See, I told you."
With Henderson, it has always been about money. That attitude has made him no different from most players, most people; it's just that Henderson has often reacted more severely to perceived economic slights than most.
It was his unhappiness with his $2 million salary this year that plunged him into a preseason funk that undermined his performance and fueled his premature departure from the Mets.
Had Henderson had a .315 batting average and a .423 on-base percentage, the figures he attained last season, the Mets would not have released him in his 22nd year in the major leagues. Had the Mets been winning three out of every five games, they would have given Henderson more time to get back to the leadoff hitter who caused consternation every time he reached base.
The problem was that he was providing virtually no production (.219 batting average) but creating much consternation for Mets management. His teammates had no problem with Henderson, at 41 years old a senior player always willing to help younger players. But it has always been thus with Rickey.
Long before the 2000 salary fallout fell into Bobby Valentine's lap, Tony La Russa, with Oakland, and Lou Piniella, with the Yankees, endured the Rickey brand of aggravation.
The second spring after Henderson signed that $3 million-a-year contract, he boycotted the early days of spring training. In the interim 15 months, dozens of players had signed more lucrative contracts and Henderson wasn't happy.
"I still don't like the contract," he said. "I never liked the contract from the day I signed it."
La Russa acknowledged that the Athletics knew Henderson, by his absence, was making a statement. "We can appreciate it," the manager said on the day Henderson was officially late for spring training. "But once he makes his statement, he has to be here for the team. At some point, get in camp."
In an attempt to lure Henderson to camp, the manager and the players good-humoredly established a "Rickey Appreciation Fund," stuffing a 10-inch-high jar several times over with dollar bills.
"We're just trying to make the point," La Russa said, " 'You're worth more than $3 million. We know it; we want you.' "
Henderson had won the American League Most Valuable Player award the year before, the first year of the contract. But in 1991, the year of his boycott, his production plunged, and he was suspected of not playing hard because he was unhappy with his contract.
It was a scenario that would be repeated this year.
"People mix my business with my job," Henderson said at that time. "It's two different things." He blamed his below-average season on an injured body, not a disgruntled state of mind.
"I get hurt, and the press says you're dogging it," he said. "Like I'm supposed to be a robot. If I get hurt and I play, they say, 'Why do you play?' But if I don't play, they don't believe me. They say, 'Why aren't you playing?' How can I win? I can't win."
Henderson did not win in 1987, when he was out with a hamstring injury. Neither did the Yankees, who had been in contention, after George Steinbrenner delivered one of the most destructive acts in his ownership of the team.
Piniella had become impatient waiting for Henderson to return and made some comments privately to other club officials.
But Piniella himself became embroiled in a dispute with Steinbrenner. The owner retaliated by disclosing Piniella's comments, saying that the manager had called the general manager about Henderson and said: "He's a dog. I want him out of here. Trade him."
Henderson has moved around in his career. He has played for the Athletics four different times and the Yankees, Toronto, San Diego, Anaheim and the Mets once each. Based on his performances with the Padres and the Angels in 1996 and '97 and with the Athletics in '98, he appeared to be closing in on the end of a brilliant career.
But the Mets, seeking a left fielder and a leadoff hitter, signed him for the 1999 season and added an option for this year. He was a pleasant surprise for them last season, helping fire them into the playoffs. His performance in the series against Arizona was also exceptional.
But the year ended sourly, when he was accused of playing cards in the clubhouse with Bobby Bonilla in the final innings of the final game with Atlanta. The mood didn't improve in the ensuing months as he complained about the $2 million salary that vested automatically when he reached his 500th plate appearance last season.
The Mets will formally place him on unconditional-release waivers today. He will clear waivers Wednesday, then pursue a job with another team, perhaps Detroit or Seattle.
"A change of atmosphere always gives a person new life," Henderson once said. "I'm looking to play even better than I have this year."
Rickey has almost always responded positively to change. He will surprise no one if he does it again in the coming weeks.

HEADLINE: Los Alamos Residents View Their Ravaged Homes as Wildfire Spreads

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., May 14

 BODY:
As David Lewis explained, you have to hit bottom before you can bounce back.
And this morning, when Mr. Lewis had his first opportunity to look out of a bus window and observe the blackened ruins that were his house in Los Alamos, he said he found himself plunging to an emotional nadir after the fire that has swept through the deeply scarred, austerely beautiful canyons here. 
 "I've started all over before, but I've always carried those boxes that have those mementos that are really heavy duty," said Mr. Lewis, who works as a systems specialist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, which conducts nuclear weapons research. "I don't have that this time. There was nothing."
The fire that has destroyed more than 42,000 acres continued to expand today, driven by a resurgence of the winds. But today also marked the symbolic beginning of the area's emotional recovery.
The New Mexico National Guard organized bus tours for residents whose homes had been destroyed, which left every 20 minutes starting at about 8:30 a.m. from an armory outside town.
The people who joined these emotional journeys were told they could not leave the buses or collect any belongings; the purpose was just to end one process, clinging to false hopes, and begin another, rebuilding.
The scene at the armory under a scorching sun was solemn, melancholy and resigned, with only faint sparks of the kind of restorative energy that will be needed to rebuild the city of Los Alamos, 30 miles to the north.
The authorities, however, announced one particularly satisfying piece of news: the roughly 7,000 residents of White Rock, a suburb of Los Alamos that suffered no actual fire damage, were permitted to return to their homes. They said the roads to White Rock were crowded, but people were moving in an orderly manner.
The roughly 11,000 residents of Los Alamos may have to wait until the end of the week to return home.
That was little solace to the more than 300 people who had accepted the offer to take the sobering bus trip back to their neighborhoods in Los Alamos. These were people who had already been told their homes had been reduced to cinders and twisted scraps of steel and plastic.
The roughly four-hour trips began quietly. Each bright yellow school bus took 20 to 35 residents, along with two grief counselors and several National Guard troops.
As they boarded, many residents were handed little brown teddy bears and a bag containing work gloves donated by an insurance company.
"I just kept thinking: none of those things we had can be replaced," Lou Pierotti, a retired store owner who had lived in Los Alamos for 49 years, said after he got off his bus. "People were kind of emotional, but it was quiet, very quiet. All you could see was the outlines of where our house had been."
Mr. Pierotti said he had lived on Arizona Street, where all the houses had been destroyed. As he stood by his car in the armory's parking lot, absorbing what he had experienced this morning, he said his most painful feelings were for the small, sentimental losses, like his softball trophies.
"You just realize you can never, never get those things back," he said.
Kim Lalley, a spokeswoman for the New Mexico National Guard, said that in spite of the warnings that no one would be allowed to get out of the buses in Los Alamos, several people had demanded a closer look at what was left of their homes.
"They were upset, and they wanted to inspect their property," Ms. Lalley said. "We can't force them to stay on the buses. So we let them off and then informed the state police they were there."
Robin Peterson, who works for Los Alamos County, said people on the buses mostly watched, took photos and stared in silence. There were a few tears, she said.
Mr. Lewis said he had decided to take the trip because, "I just wanted the closure.
"But you still don't know what it's like until you really see it," he said.
Robert Olson, who also lost his home, said: "I'm numb. I'm confused."
Firefighters said today that they did not expect the fire, which had been set on May 4 by the National Park Service in what was supposed to be a controlled burn, to return to heavily populated areas. But swifter winds were causing the flames to leap across some canyons.
The more than 1,100 firefighters were focusing their efforts in three zones, mostly to the north and northeast, as the fire threatened archaeological sites on the Santa Clara Pueblo, an Indian reservation, and the Baca Ranch, 95,000 acres of meadows and fir-covered mountains that is home to about 7,000 elk.
A spokesman for the United States Forest Service, Jim Paxon, said that if the high winds continued, firefighters might be pulled back and the fire allowed to run its course.
Many of the people getting off the buses here today expressed appreciation for the efforts being made by firefighters and relief officials.
"You truly can't believe how generous people have been," Ms. Peterson said. "You see it everywhere. It just feels great. They had computers at one of the relief centers and my 16-year-old daughter was able to get online and find her friends. It just made us feel really good."
She said there had long been some resentment in the region of the people who lived in Los Alamos because, with their jobs at the nuclear weapons laboratory, they were generally wealthier and better educated.
"You saw none of that, not even a little," she said.
But there was also a steady undercurrent of anger at the park service for starting the blaze.
"When all is said and done, I had to ask myself this morning, 'Why was I on that bus?' " Mr. Lewis said. "Darn right, I'm mad."
