LENGTH: 1421 words

HEADLINE: State Agencies Make Pataki the Star of $20 Million in Ads

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 14

 BODY:
Over the last several months, Gov. George E. Pataki has become one of the most visible pitchmen of the airwaves, starring in no fewer than five television advertising campaigns paid for by state agencies under his control, for causes from children's health care to energy conservation, at a total cost to taxpayers of about $20 million.
Put another way, the state is spending as much money from the public treasury to put Mr. Pataki's face before the public as the total spent in his 1998 re-election campaign. 
 The spots advertise Mr. Pataki at least as much as their ostensible subjects, prompting the charge by government reform groups and Democrats that they are nothing more than a veiled political campaign at government expense. "To use public funds to do what are essentially P.R. spots for the governor is ridiculous," said Rachel Leon, executive director of the New York State chapter of Common Cause. "It doesn't pass the smell test. If it looks like politics, it's politics."
Michael McKeon, Mr. Pataki's communications director, said of such criticism, "The world is, unfortunately, full of cynics who would rather play politics than applaud accomplishments."
The governor, a Republican, is not the first politician to use his power to advertise himself with public money, nor the first to be criticized for it. In fact, the immediate response from several administration officials was that the same thing has been done by the governor's predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and by Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut.
But Mr. Pataki's current exposure is extraordinary, and it far exceeds the others' efforts. In addition to ads for children's health care, energy conservation and the environment, which are all new this year, the governor is starring in perennial campaigns promoting tourism and the state's economic recovery. And while some governments, like New York City's and Connecticut's, prohibit politicians from appearing in advertising at public expense when an election is approaching, New York State's has no such restrictions.
Politicians in both parties say -- Republicans with a hint of admiration, Democrats with exasperation -- that the commercials are an extension of an administration that has turned governing into a perpetual campaign.
Although Mr. Pataki has said he has no interest in running for the United States Senate this year, state Republican leaders are talking about Mr. Pataki as a possible replacement candidate if Mayor Giuliani decides to drop out. Mr. Pataki has said he might run for a third term in 2002, when his Democratic opponent could be the state's comptroller, H. Carl McCall.
But Mr. Pataki has been battered by his leading role in state Republicans' ultimately unsuccessful efforts to keep John McCain off the presidential primary ballot. And he has also been harshly attacked, both through paid ads and on op-ed pages, by Change New York, a conservative group of onetime Pataki supporters who now call him a big-spending liberal. At the same time, the governor's poll numbers have slipped. His approval rating remains above 50 percent in most published surveys, but a year ago it was more than 60 percent.
"Is it about helping the governor?" a Republican political consultant asked rhetorically about the ad campaigns. "Well, duh."
Judith Hope, chairwoman of the state Democratic Party, said, "We are seeing a remarkable attempt at the rehabilitation of George Pataki at taxpayers' expense."
The promotions all showcase Mr. Pataki in the kind of warm-and-fuzzy ways that are too leisurely for the frantic pace of a real campaign. They deal with issues that let him appeal across party lines to centrists and liberals and that rank high with women, who tend to prefer Democrats to Republicans. The ads have been most prevalent during morning and daytime television, when most viewers are women. The best example is also the biggest of the current campaigns, one intended to encourage parents to enroll their children in Child Health Plus, a state-subsidized health insurance program for low-income parents. The State Department of Health spent $8 million on the ads.
In the television ad, Mr. Pataki, wearing a baby-blue V-neck sweater, speaks into the camera, sitting in a bright room amid happy children of all races. Next to him sits the state health commissioner, Dr. Antonia C. Novello, who happens to be one of the few women, and the only Hispanic, among the administration's top officials. The ads have been broadcast in every part of the state since October, including a Spanish-language version in some markets, and will continue through late June.
"These ads are clearly to promote him, and they're another example of how he's not acting like a person who's getting out of public life at the end of his term," said Jeffrey M. Stonecash, a professor of political science at Syracuse University who conducts polls for Democratic and Republican politicians. He added that it was as if Mr. Pataki was "worried about the liberal base getting mobilized in ways that it didn't in '94 and '98."
The ads represent a certain contradiction. During the 1994 gubernatorial campaign, William D. Powers, the state Republican Party chairman, attacked Mr. Cuomo for planning a government-financed ad campaign featuring himself, an effort that ultimately fell through. "If Mario Cuomo wants to develop an ad campaign for his re-election bid, he ought to pay for it himself," Mr. Powers said then.
This is just one instance of Mr. Pataki's doing much the same thing that he or his surrogates criticized his predecessor for doing: Mr. Cuomo's proposed buyout of the Long Island Lighting Company, his frequent use of state aircraft and his paid speaking engagements.
Mr. McKeon contended that "people know and trust the governor," making him the logical spokesman for each of the ads' causes. "The governor has made no secret of the fact that he's going to do everything he can to promote the changes he's made in New York's economic climate," he said. "It's not enough to do it; you need to tell the world about the changes. No one has better credibility on environmental issues than Governor Pataki. He is the perfect spokesman for encouraging energy conservation."
John Signor, spokesman for the Department of Health, said that enrollment in Child Health Plus had climbed rapidly since the campaign began. When asked why the governor should appear in them rather than, for instance, a pop culture figure who would be more familiar and appealing to young parents, he said, "Well, the ads are working."
The state's Empire State Development Corporation is spending $5.5 million from early April through late May on a collection of ads -- $4 million on television, $1.5 million on radio and print media -- that showcase the governor promoting tourism in New York. The ads are running both in New York markets and in a few other Eastern cities. The development agency sponsors a springtime tourism campaign every year, in ads that have often centered on the governor, but the budget this year is up sharply, from $3.7 million last year.
The same agency paid for a $4 million television and radio campaign in March and April, celebrating the state's economic recovery and promoting the state as a fine place for businesses. Again, the ads ran in New York and other states, and they featured the governor.
A television ad campaign still under way has Mr. Pataki promoting the Energy Star program, which encourages people to buy energy-efficient appliances. The primary sponsor is the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority.
Tom Collins, spokesman for the agency, said he was not sure how much the agency was spending or how long the ads would run. But state officials said the energy agency was spending several times as much as the Long Island Power Authority, which contributed $500,000 to the effort in March.
In February, the Long Island Power Authority spent $175,000 on radio and television ads starring the governor, to let people know of its commitments to clean sources of energy, like wind power.
"The governor probably is the best pitchman for the state of New York," said Nelson Warfield, a Republican political consultant who is on good terms with Mr. Pataki. "If it benefits him politically, it doesn't mean it comes at the detriment of the state. This is one of those happy political happenstances of everybody benefiting."

HEADLINE: Free Trade: Why Labor Is Wary

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, May 9) argues that a good way to reduce the unions' resistance to free trade is by having the government empower them and enable them to thrive in the new, open economy. This can be done, he believes, by reducing management's capacity to permanently replace striking workers and by increasing penalties on employers who interfere with their workers' right to unionize. 
 Why does labor law reform have to be linked to free trade? Even without the threat of expanding trade, workers would deserve broadly defined and strongly enforced rights to join unions and engage in collective bargaining.
 
GARY CHAISON
Worcester, Mass., May 9, 2000
 
The writer is a professor of industrial relations at Clark University.

HEADLINE: Free Trade: Why Labor Is Wary

 BODY:

To the Editor:
James P. Hoffa, the teamsters' president, says (Op-Ed, May 11) hundreds of thousands of jobs have been lost since passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement and uses this example to argue against permanent normal trade status for China. The flaw in his argument is that the unemployment rate in this country is the lowest it has been in decades. It is impossible for hundreds of thousands of jobs to have been lost if more people have jobs now than in the past. 
 What has, in fact, occurred is that low-paying manufacturing jobs have been moved to foreign countries, while the United States has created a surplus of higher paying, higher skilled jobs. The net effect is not that Americans have lost jobs but that Americans have changed jobs to their economic advantage.
 
FLORA WAPLES
Chicago, May 11, 2000

HEADLINE: The Economy Rises, And Crime Falls

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Serious Crimes Fall for 8th Consecutive Year" (news article, May 8):
Attributing crime reduction to "get tough" policing and mandatory sentencing policies, minor gun control legislation and baby boomers aging past their crime-prone years ignores one very important determinant of crime in the United States: improvements in economic opportunity. 
 Crime rates are very much a function of labor market opportunities, especially for minorities and low-wage workers. The tight labor market that has prevailed since the mid-1990's is an important reason for the steep fall in crime. Punitive factors have contributed, but so has the increase in low-wage earnings and employment.
Creating good, paying jobs is one of the best deterrents to crime that money can buy.
 
ELLEN HOUSTON
Washington, May 10, 2000
 
The writer is a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: The Economy Rises, And Crime Falls

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A striking and generally unexamined factor in the rise of crime from the mid-1960's to the mid-70's and in its current decline (news article, May 8) is the Vietnam War.
The war was the determinant factor in American life precisely during these 10 years, when so many of the past generation's problems took off: from the rise in crime to the epidemic divorce rate, from the drug culture to the decline of America's cities. Not only does the periodization (as historians would call it) of these issues parallel our involvement in Vietnam, but such broad negative effects are also just what one would expect in a country that, for a decade, waged an unjust and divisive war that bred nihilism and moral breakdown. 
 The decline in crime is one sign, among several social indicators, that we are now emerging from that great trauma.
 
JOHNSCHRECKER
Waltham, Mass., May 10, 2000
 
The writer is a professor of history at Brandeis University.

HEADLINE: Casinos Put Money in Race In New Jersey

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
State Senator William L. Gormley, a leading contender for the Republican nomination for United states Senate from New Jersey, slipped away from the campaign trail one day in early March for an unpublicized visit to Las Vegas. He was not treated like a typical tourist.
 
 There to greet Mr. Gormley at Le Cirque restaurant in the Bellagio Hotel, Steve Wynn's sumptuous new fun house, was the gambling magnate himself. Mr. Wynn had gathered casino executives for a fund-raiser that drew about $40,000 in donations for Mr. Gormley, who in recent years has championed an effort by New Jersey to spend more than $200 million to subsidize the opening of a Wynn casino in Atlantic City.
 Later in the month, another casino impresario, Donald J. Trump, held a similar event for Mr. Gormley at Trump Tower in Manhattan. The proceeds: $55,000.
 Mr. Gormley has amassed far more money than this three Republican opponents, in large part by attracting support from casinos and others tied to the gambling industry - donors over whom he wields considerable authority as Atlantic City's state senator and chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, which handles most casino legislation.
 Under New Jersey law, Mr. Gormley and other state officials are usually barred from accepting donations from casino executives and employees. The law is intended to prevent corruption, or at a minimum the appearance of a conflict of interest, when state officials render decisions that affect millions of dollars in Altantic City casino profits.
 But the law applies to state and local elections in New Jersey, not to federal ones. And Mr. Gormley has declined to abide by it voluntarily in the Senate race to succeed Frank R. Launtenberg, a Democrat who is retiring.
 In a Republican race between little-known candidates relying on advertising to break through to voters, Mr. Gormley's casino ties and stockpile of contributions, now about $1.9 million after expenditures, could prove a critical asset in the final days before the June 6 primary.
 When it comes to gambling in New Jersey, it would be difficult to overstate the influence of Mr. Gormley. He spearheaded measures that allowed companies to expand their casino holdings, permitted casinos to stay open around the clock and let gamblers use credit cards to pay for chips. He wrote a plan to channel a state tax on casino revenues back into subsidies for new casino properties.
 Mr. Gormley said the donations from the casino industry were legal and did not affect how he carried out his job in Trenton.
 "I don't think that it's an issue," he said in an interview. "I have represented my district well, and I have represented the state with integrity. This is an industry that is a vital part of the state and has a right on the federal level to participate."
 But his casino ties could turn into a major issue if he becomes the Republican nominee. Pamela Garfield, a spokeswoman for group that seeks tighter campaign finance laws, criticized Mr. Gormley, saying he was following the letter, not the spirit, of the law.
 Ms. Garfield said Mr. Gormley's decision to raise casino money underscored flaws in the system. "As candidates are feeling more and more pressure to raise money, they are going to be forced to press their ethical boundaries," she sad. "His acceptance of casino money is a symptom of a broader problem."
 Mr. Gormley is not the only candidate in the priary to reap money from people with an interest in official action. One rival, United States Representative Robert D. Franks of Union County, has been a favorite of political action committees based in Washington. Another, James W. Treffinger, the Essex County executive, has raised money from county employees and from law firms and others with county contracts.
 Still, Mr. Gormley's connection to the casinos has provided him with an edge. He has taken in more than $200,000 from casino executives and their spouses, out of $2.1 million in total contributions. He has raised about $68,000 from Nevada alone, nearly as much as he has raised from New York State, the records show.
 Park Place Entertainment, Mirage Resorts, Boyd Gaming, Mandalay Resort Group, Showboat, Trump Taj Mahal, Trump Plaza, Trump Marina, Resorts, Treasure Island, Harrah's, Goldn Nugget, Bally's Park Place, Caesars, Tropicana, Sands, Atlantic City Hilton - executives from most of the major casinos in Atlantic City and in Las Vegas and their corporate parents have given, mindful that even if Mr. Gormley loses, he will remain a state senator. (He is up for re-election for his state term in 2001). He has even received contributions from executives in the Mississippi riverboat gambling industry.
 In interviews, the casino executives asserted that they were not looking for something in return from Mr. Gormley, though they acknowledged that it was not a good idea to offend him.
 "I would say he is somebody with a great deal of power in Atlantic City, a great deal of respect in Atlantic City," said Mr Trump, who has feuded with Mr. Gormley in the past over the state's effort to court Mr. Wynn. "And certainly it is a lot easier if he is on your side."
 Alan Feldman, a spokesman for Mr. Wynn, whose company, Mirage Resorts, is being bought by MGM Grand, said Mr. Gormley "has shown leadership that stands out from the pack."
 Mr. Trump said he opposed the ban on casino donations to state candidates in New Jersey, adding that no such rule existed in Nevada. He contended that the New Jersey ban infringed on the industry's right to take part in the political process. That view was echoed to some extent by Mr. Gormley himself, who said he would support weakening the ban, though he would not push to change it because he did ot think that a majority of lawmakers would approve such a move.
 In defending the donations, Mr. Gormley said they formed a relatively small percentage of his total treasury. But he acknowledged that he had also received hundreds of thousands of dollars more from donors who were tied to the industry and cared about his decisions, including lawyers and real estate developers, but would not be barred from giving under the state law because they were not casino employees.
 For instance, Mr. Gormley attracts money from people whose firms and companies have contracts with the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, a state agency that collects taxes from casinos and spends the revenues on projects in Atlantic City and elsewhere in the state. In Trenton, Mr. Gormley is considered to possess virtual veto power over the development authority's activities.
 Lawyers at Connell, Foley, a law firm that received $1.3 million in fees from the authority last year, donated about $28,000 to the Gormley campaign. Lawyers at another firm that has worked for the authority, St. John & Wayne, gave $20,000, while lawyers at a third firm with authority contracts, Riker, Danzig, Scherer, Hyland & Perretti, gave roughly $20,000.
 Executives at Frederic R. Harris, an engineering company that is helping to construct a $330 million tunnel intended to help Mr. Wynn build a new property in the marina area, contributed $17,000.
 Asked about those donations, Mr. Gormley said: "What I have tried to do over the years is to create an environment of economic growth. People who have participated in that in one form or another think that I have done a pretty good job. Even my critics would say that."
 To parry questions about casino money, Mr. Gormley's aides have sought to draw attention to fund-raising by Representative Franks and by Mr. Treffinger, the Essex County executive, both of whom have not collected as much money as Mr.Gormley has but have raised significant amounts from people with business before their offices. (A fourth candidate, Murray Sabrin, a college professor, has raised $300,000).
 Mr. Franks has collected 25 percent of the $1.35 million he has raised from political action committees, particularly those interested in legislation before two committees he serves on, the Budget Committee ad the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee. He has received money from PAC's representing the American Pilots Association, the American Road and Transportation Builders Association, the American Short Line and Regional Railroad Association and the United Transportation Union.
 Charlie Smith, an adviser to Mr. Franks, dismissed suggestions that those contributions were related to Mr. Franks's votes in Congress.
 "Political action committee contributions," Mr. Smith said, "are nothing more than the aggregated contributions of an industry or group of people who wish to compete in the political process, alongside special interests such as the casinos."
 Mr. Treffinger, who took office as the county executive in 1995, has raised more than $100,000 from people who work for the county and another $100,000 from lawyers at firms with contracts with county agencies, out of his total of $1.1 million. He is not accepting PAC money.
 Matthew J. Kirnan, Mr. Treffinger's treasurer, said the campaign had not focused fund-raising appeals on county workers.
 "With respect to Essex County employees, most of them are residents of Essex County and rally respect the fact that Jim has changed things," Mr. Kirnan said.
 Of the law firms, the biggest contributor was DeCotiis, Fitzpatrick, Gluck, Hayden & Cole, whose partners have close ties to both major political parties. Its lawyers donated $55,000 to the Treffinger campaign. Another significant benefactor was McCarter & English, whose lawyers gave about $10,000.
 Decotiis, Fitzpatrick represents the Essex County Improvement Authority, which paid the firm $514,000 last year, officials aid. McCarter & English handles the authority's bond work, receiving $380,000 last year.
 Mr. Kirnan said, "Both firms were doing work for the county long before Jim got here, and they will be doing work afterward."
 Eric D. Wisler, a partner at Decotiis, Fitzpatrick, said his firm was retained by county agencies because of its skills, not its donations.
 "I'm not naive to say that if you don't contribute and support your firends in their endeavors, that others won't step in behind you and try to take your place," Mr. Wisler said. "But certainly Jim has never exhibited to me the kind of vindictiveness that people associate with politicians - that if you don't contribute to politicians, you're gone."

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Science Desk 

LENGTH: 2101 words

HEADLINE: Seas and Soils Emerge as Keys to Climate

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
Over the last 150 years, the burning of coal, oil and natural gas has released some 270 billion tons of carbon into the air in the form of heat-trapping carbon dioxide. If all that had stayed in the atmosphere, much of the substantial global warming predicted for a century from now might have already taken place.
Luckily, more than half the carbon dioxide emitted by fossil-fuel burning is absorbed from the air by the oceans, by plants (which use it in converting sunlight to chemical energy) and by soils. Fewer than half the emissions, scientists believe, remain airborne to warm the earth. 
 All of this is part of one of nature's grand and endlessly complicated global recycling networks. In it, carbon is constantly exchanged among the air, the terrestrial biosphere, the oceans and the solid rock of the earth at varying rates on time scales ranging from hours to millions of years.
Now, as the economic and political difficulty of reducing carbon dioxide emissions at the source becomes ever more obvious, a broad-based move is under way to manipulate the carbon cycle so that it will remove more of the heat-trapping gases from the air. It is an ambitious idea, but on closer inspection one surrounded by questions, potential risks and obstacles.
In one approach, researchers are investigating ways to remove carbon chemically from industrial and automotive emissions before they are released to the atmosphere, then to sequester it at some other way station in the natural carbon cycle -- by injecting the removed carbon back into underground reservoirs or into the ocean, for instance.
The United States Department of Energy has expanded research into carbon-removal technologies at eight of its national laboratories. But this option, the department said in a recent study, is "truly radical" and most experts believe it is some distance from providing a practical alternative.
More promising in the near term, many scientists believe, are prospects for increasing the absorption of atmospheric carbon dioxide by what is called the terrestrial biosphere: that is, the whole complex of living things on land, mainly plants and various tiny inhabitants and detritus of the soil.
Every time a plant sprouts and grows to maturity, it absorbs carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, breaks it down chemically and uses carbon as construction material for roots, stem, branches, flowers and leaves. When the plant dies, some of the carbon goes back into the atmosphere, but some is also released into the soil as the dead plant decays. Decomposing animals, including people, further add to the carbon reservoir in the soil. Globally, soil contains about five times as much carbon as vegetation.
The expansion of these carbon reservoirs, or "sinks," in vegetation and soil has been sanctioned as one way industrialized countries might meet their obligations under the 1997 Kyoto Protocol, which is aimed at reducing emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping greenhouse gases.
Lately, intense argument has developed over the degree to which countries like the United States, which may have great potential for expanding its carbon sinks, ought to be allowed to meet their emissions reduction targets under the protocol by means like planting trees, improving forest management and conserving soils rather than reducing carbon dioxide emissions from cars, factories and power generating stations.
Delegates from more than 100 countries are to grapple with the issue when they meet in November in The Hague for what is widely seen as a make-or-break effort to make the Kyoto Protocol operational.
The rules governing carbon sinks are among the many sets of yet-to-be adopted regulations necessary to put the protocol into effect, and only a few countries have ratified the agreement pending action on them. The United States, where the protocol has encountered strong opposition in Congress on several grounds, is one of those holding back.
In preparation for the critical November meeting, scientists of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, created by the United Nations more than a decade ago to advise the world's governments, issued a report on the carbon issue at a meeting last week in Montreal. The analysis suggested that expansion of terrestrial carbon sinks in the industrialized countries could potentially more than enable them to meet their entire combined emissions reduction quota under the protocol.
But experts associated with the report questioned how much of that potential could be achieved, given the difficulty of actually expanding the world's carbon sinks in practice.
"Judging the technical potential is easy," said Dr. Robert T. Watson, chairman of the intergovernmental panel, who is also the chief atmospheric scientist and environmental adviser of the World Bank. "The real question is, what is the likelihood of realizing that technical potential?"
Under the Kyoto Protocol, the rich industrial countries as a group are obligated to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions 5 percent below 1990 levels by about 2010. The reductions are widely seen as a first step in eventually stabilizing atmospheric concentrations. If emissions are not reduced, prominent scientists say, the average global temperature will rise by about 3.5 degrees Fahrenheit by the year 2100. (By comparison, the world is now 5 to 9 degrees warmer than in the depths of the last ice age 18,000 to 20,000 years ago.)
This much warming, the experts say, would bring rising seas, more severe droughts, rainstorms, heat waves and floods, along with broad shifts in climatic and agricultural zones that would benefit some regions but seriously harm others.
Environmentalists and some parties to the Kyoto Protocol, especially the European Union, strenuously object to allowing any country to meet all or most of its emissions reduction goal by expanding carbon sinks.
"Sucking carbon out of the atmosphere is not the same as preventing it permanently from leaving the exhaust pipe or power plant," said Jennifer Morgan, director of the World Wildlife Fund's climate change campaign.
Environmentalists argue that since forests can always be cut down as well as planted, and soils can always be plowed up as well as conserved, the terrestrial biosphere is not nearly as secure a carbon reservoir as the underground reservoirs where coal, oil and gas are contained. So, they say, why remove them from that secure spot in the first place?
They also fear that reliance on sinks to meet the Kyoto targets could delay the adoption of measures to reduce fossil fuel use and replace it with other energy technologies.
In any event, scientists say, carbon sinks will eventually probably reach a saturation point, at which they will be unable to absorb any more carbon dioxide. The dominant view therefore remains that if the world is serious about reducing and stabilizing the atmospheric concentrations, emissions must be cut at the source by burning fossil fuels more efficiently, switching from relatively high-carbon fuels like coal to lower-carbon natural gas, and replacing fossil fuels altogether by alternatives like hydrogen fuel cells.
Given the slow progress in that direction, though, proponents of the carbon sink idea argue that it could be a valuable interim measure.
In many ways, however, human activity has been shrinking carbon sinks rather than expanding them. Deforestation and farming have obliterated great stretches of forest and grassland that once absorbed carbon dioxide. Farming has also chopped up soils in ways that cause them to give off carbon dioxide rather than to sequester it.
In fact, said the scientific report issued in Montreal, human use of the terrestrial biosphere, including the burning of wood, has released some 135 billion tons of carbon into the air since 1850 -- about half as much as has been emitted by fossil fuel burning.
The net result of all this is that overall atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide are about 30 percent higher now than at the start of the industrial revolution.
A de facto counterattack has been under way for some time in the Northern Hemisphere, where the replanting of forests on deforested lands has made headway in recent decades. One provision of the Kyoto Protocol allows for industrialized countries to gain credit toward their reduction targets for tree planting since 1990 -- but also to incur debits for any deforestation since then. To reap meaningful credit, a country would have to show a net gain.
The protocol also allows countries to gain credit for reductions through a variety of other ways of expanding terrestrial carbon stocks should the parties to the agreement so decide. These include, for instance, expanding carbon stores in soil through no-till agriculture, in which no plowing takes place and seeds are sown in the carbon-rich detritus of the previous year's harvest.
Other possibilities include conversion of cropland into grassland, fertilization of pastureland and forest management practices designed to increase carbon stocks -- for example, lengthening the period between harvests of a forest's timber, or promoting faster tree growth and thicker stands of trees, plantation-style.
Estimates suggest that these kinds of measures might allow some countries to achieve large cuts in net carbon dioxide emissions. The potential of such measures in the United States, Canada and Russia is great, according to a recent calculation made for the World Wildlife Fund by Kevin Gurney, an atmospheric researcher at Colorado State University who studies the carbon cycle.
Mr. Gurney estimated, for example, that without planting any trees, the measures would potentially enable the United States to remove about 150 million tons of carbon a year from the atmosphere. This exceeds its Kyoto emissions reduction target by tens of millions of tons. "They're pretty big," Mr. Gurney said of the estimates.
The Montreal report estimated that in theory, measures other than tree-planting by the industrialized countries could remove nearly 290 million more tons of carbon a year from the atmosphere by about 2010 than are removed by such measures now. By comparison, the Kyoto Protocol would require the rich countries to cut emissions by about 200 million tons a year below 1990 levels by about 2010.
The report also raised caveats about how much of this estimated potential might be achieved. Even with "an ambitious policy agenda," it said, the estimates were "likely to be on the high side."
Far smaller gains could be achieved by the rich countries by planting trees and slowing deforestation, the report concluded. It said that a 20 percent increase in forest planting would probably offset no more than 3 million tons of carbon emissions a year, while slowing deforestation by 20 percent could offset about 18 million tons.
Even if the potential for carbon sequestration can be realized to a substantial degree, many headaches still present themselves. For instance, forest growth is spurred -- and terrestrial carbon stocks are increased -- by a warming climate, and by rising levels of carbon dioxide and of atmospheric nitrogen deposited on forests as a result of industrial emissions.
In assessing a country's carbon stocks for purposes of assigning credit, how can these effects of human activity be separated from the growth in carbon stocks brought about by tree-planting efforts alone? It is almost impossible to make such a separation, Dr. Watson said.
Another difficulty for some kinds of carbon sequestration efforts is that of monitoring and accounting for carbon stocks. Although there are well-established means of measuring the increase of carbon in a stand of growing trees, other sinks may present problems. One way to get around the difficulty in the case of agricultural soils might be to set up a business-as-usual control plot, in which conventional farming methods are used, against which to measure the change in carbon stocks as a result of no-till farming.
Then there are ecological concerns. For instance, managers of carbon-sequestration projects might be tempted to replace naturally functioning forests with tree plantations, which in biological terms are comparatively poor and sterile, with little of the biological richness and variety of the wild woods. Likewise, managers might be tempted to cut down mature forests so as to plant new, faster-growing ones that sequester carbon at a higher rate.
It is on questions of detail like these that the success or failure of the Kyoto Protocol may ultimately hinge.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: A United Nations convention on climate change in Kyoto in 1997 led to an agreement to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases. (Associated Press)(pg. F4); (Angel Franco/The New York Times); (Linda Kahlbaugh for The New York Times); (Fred Bernstein for The New York Times); (Hannah Fairfield and Al Granberg/The New York Times); (Will and Deni McIntyre/Photo Researchers)(pg. F4)
 
Chart: "Manipulating the Carbon Cycle"
Scientists believe that more than half the carbon dioxide put into the atmosphere by the burning of fossil fuels is absorbed by the earth's oceans, plants and soils. The rest of the carbon dioxide remains in the atmosphere, trapping the sun's radiation and warming the earth. Researchers are now exploring ways to reduce atmospheric carbon dioxide further by expanding plant and soil carbon reservoirs, or sinks, on land.
 
THE GLOBAL CARBON CYCLE
Carbon atoms -- many in the form of carbon dioxide, organic compounds, fossil fuels or carbonate rocks -- cycle through the earth among air, water and land.
 
Ocean
 
MARINE PLANTS, ANIMALS
Carbonate shells fall to the ocean floor when an animal dies.
 
Respiration and Decomposition
A carbon atom, on average, will remain in the ocean for 350 years as aquatic life uses it in photosynthesis and respiration.
 
Land and the Living Earth
The average residence time for carbon on land is 35 years, but atoms can be buried for millions of years, becoming fossil fuels if subjected to high temperatures and pressures
 
Atmosphere
On average, an atom stays in the air only five years before it gets cycled.
 
Carbon taken up by plants may return to the air through decomposition and other processes, or it may be buried.
 
Combustion
For 10,000 years, the amount of carbon in the atmosphere was stable. But since the advent of industry in 1850, levels have been rising.
 
The Route to a Cleaner, Perhaps Cooler, Earth: Pulling Carbon Out of the Atmosphere . . .
Scientists on the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change suggest that increasing plant and soil sinks in industrialized countries may help those countries meet quotas for emissions reduction.
 
SOME RESEARCHERS PROPOSE TO:
Plant forests and lengthen the period between timber harvests to extract carbon from the atmosphere.
Convert cropland into grassland because plowed land releases carbon dioxide rather than absorbs it.
Use no-till agriculture, in which seeds are sown in the unplowed soil of the previous harvest.
 
... Or Not Putting It There at All?
Some environmentalists question this strategy, arguing that added carbon sinks are a less reliable approach and that they have limits in their capacity to store carbon.
 
SOME ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS WOULD RATHER ENCOURAGE:
Using nonfossil fuel energy sources like solar power and hydrogen fuel cells.
Switching from high-carbon coal to lower-carbon natural gas.
Finding greater efficiency in burning fossil fuels.
(Sources: Biology of Plants, by Peter H. Raven, Ray F. Evert and Susan E. Eichhorn; William H. Schlesinger, Duke University)(pg. F1)

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
A Human Pez Dispenser Of Jokes and One-Liners

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Bruce Vilanch, who has written scripts for dozens of award shows and variety shows and supplied patter for celebrities, has become known as something of a Hollywood laugh-dispenser, a 24-hour grocery of wisecracks, show biz in-jokes and snippy bons mots. "Got any lines?" is the question Mr. Vilanch, in his new one-man show, "Bruce Vilanch: Almost Famous," says he is perennially asked. Interestingly, he's not referring to cocaine.
If you are wondering about what makes these credentials worthy of an evening of theater -- Mr. Vilanch has written for the Osmonds, among others, and even the Oscars aren't exactly known for consistent drollery -- it's a good question. For the show, which is running through June 10 at the Westbeth Theater Center, is not so much a theatrical presentation as a party at which the funniest kid in the class is expected to be the center of attention. 
 "I have no act," Mr. Vilanch says early on, an invitation to criticism that won't be accommodated here. The idea is that the audience is eager to hear him reminisce in a chatty, off-the-cuff fashion about the backstage antics of Bette Midler, Cher and the like, and that's a bit of an assumption. To judge from his enthusiastic reception at a recent performance, there is an audience for the kind of inside scoop he can provide, a niche market in diva flapdoodle. But the world in which Mr. Vilanch travels isn't all that -- what's the word? Significant? And anyone who brags about writing the script for the Miss Black Teenage Utah pageant is at least a bit self-trivializing.
Mr. Vilanch, a paunchy, hirsute fellow who has the look and demeanor of a weird, antisocial child that Santa Claus's parents kept hidden in the attic, enters in a sequined T-shirt designed to suggest an evening gown, bare-shouldered and in bad taste. "Hi, I'm Linda Tripp," he says, then sings a campy song about gay men who work in the wardrobe and wig departments. He is accompanied by an onstage pianist, Dick Gallagher, who is otherwise deployed throughout to no substantial effect.
Mr. Vilanch's show is organized along vaguely autobiographical lines. Against a backdrop of pastel-colored T-shirts pinned to the wall, many of them in children's sizes -- "Michael Jackson's laundry," he explains -- he speaks about growing up as an ungainly boy in Paterson, N.J.; doing some modeling (for Lane Bryant) and acting; and his early career as a journalist in Chicago, where he met Ms. Midler 30 years ago while writing about her nightclub show.
From then on, apparently, his life followed one long, upwardly mobile path from variety show to awards show to movie bit to movie subject (the recent documentary about him is called "Get Bruce!") to the apparent pinnacle, as head writer and frequent guest on the game show "Hollywood Squares."
Mr. Vilanch does have some amusing stories to tell, most of them vulgar. There's one about Tallulah Bankhead and flatulence that would be priceless if he learned how to tell it more economically for the stage and not as though he were holding court at a drunken dinner party. But his best lines (unprintable here) are those he recounts as delivered by others, namely Sophie Tucker and Paul Lynde, the latter of whom he describes as having been dull when sober, incredibly charming and funny on one drink "and on two drinks, Josef Mengele."
Jewish and openly gay -- "Now you have to get up and say, 'I'm Spartacus,' " he says, with some appropriate scorn, about the social pressure to declare one's sexual credentials -- he delivers some otherwise standard-issue material about gay pride and Jewish stereotypes in Hollywood. Much of the second act depends on questions from the audience.
Over all, the evening yields insight only into the blandness of Hollywood-style entertainment. This is the kind of storytelling that relies far too much on the presumption of a man who is quite used to being told, "Oh, you're so funny," by people who have a stake in its being so.
 
BRUCE VILANCH
Almost Famous
A one-man show. Directed by Scott Wittman. Associate producer, Craig Austin; musical director, Dick Gallagher; sets by James Schuette; lighting by Josh Monroe; sound design and operation, Gregory Kostroff; stage manager, Larry Baker. Presented by Westbeth Theater Center, Arnold Engelman, producing director; Joan Hyler, associate producer. At Westbeth Theater Center, 151 Bank Street, West Village.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Visionary of the Opera Inspires a Turnaround

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
When Paul Kellogg became the artistic and general director of the New York City Opera in 1996, the company was carrying a $5 million debt, had lost its sense of artistic direction and was coping emotionally with the death from AIDS of its previous director, the conductor Christopher Keene. Revitalizing the City Opera was going to be a formidable challenge. And the greatest impediment to doing so, in fundamental ways, was the New York State Theater itself, the City Opera's home since 1965, which is shared with the New York City Ballet. Rehearsal space and administrative offices had always been woefully inadequate there.
The immediate problem Mr. Kellogg confronted was the poor acoustics of the 2,700-seat auditorium. Two earlier attempts to correct the problem with minor architectural adjustments had not appreciably improved the sound in the house. In exasperation, Mr. Kellogg, with the support of the City Ballet, finally approved the installation of an electronic sound enhancement system before the opening of the season last fall, surely the most controversial decision of his tenure. Natural sound has been a hallmark of the classical music heritage, and there are few places left in the world, other than opera houses and concerts halls, where audiences can experience music without the sound being processed electronically. 
 But Mr. Kellogg maintains that the sound system has been an enormous success over all. Without exception, he asserts, the company's music staff, orchestra players and singers support its use. And the vast majority of City Opera audiences either strongly approve, he says, basing his observations on feedback and mail he has received, or at least are not bothered by it.
During a recent interview, Mr. Kellogg vigorously defended his decision to resort to an electronic solution for the house's poor acoustics. Yet he also indicated for the first time that the system was an "interim solution" for a problem that he hopes will be solved architecturally by a major renovation of the house. Discussions are under way about renovations of the entire Lincoln Center complex. A major redesign of the State Theater auditorium to improve the acoustics is on the table, though the project could easily be derailed by the sheer expense involved, which could exceed $30 million for the State Theater alone. Moreover, the auditorium is a historic and justly acclaimedspace for dance. The City Ballet, which actually prefers to minimize sound from the stage, has more interest in preserving it as is.
If the renovation plan does not come to pass, Mr. Kellogg stated unequivocally, the company will find "another solution." He refused to specify what that might entail, but the only apparent solution would be to relocate the company to a site outside Lincoln Center. That idea was raised unofficially by Mr. Kellogg's exasperated predecessors. Such a move would be Mr. Kellogg's boldest stroke by far, challenging the idea of the urban arts complex.
What Mr. Kellogg mostly wanted to talk about during the interview was good news about the company's current finances and artistic strength. The City Opera is thriving, and he has compiled the facts and figures to back his case. Debt has been erased, and the company now boasts a $12 million endowment. Fund-raising is up 50 percent since 1996. The operating budget has increased some $5 million over the same period, to $31 million for the 1999-2000 season, which ended three weeks ago. In the last year attendance has increased by 10 percent: this season the company sold an average of 83 percent of the house.
How did this happen? Soon after arriving, Mr. Kellogg announced a three-year revitalization plan with specific goals. Because the Metropolitan Opera was right across the plaza at Lincoln Center, it was essential, he felt, that City Opera distinguish itself by performing repertory the Met was not known for, especially Baroque operas and 20th-century American works. Even when the City Opera presents the staples -- "Carmen," "Tosca" and such -- it should do so, he believed, in innovative modern productions that contrasted with the Met's grand traditionalism in the standard repertory. If the City Opera could not afford to hire renowned vocalists for, say, "Madama Butterfly," then it should present casts of fresh-voiced, younger singers who looked like the characters they were portraying and were strong actors.
Yet every aspect of Mr. Kellogg's vision for the company was contingent on making the house more acoustically vibrant. If attractive singers with young voices were going to flourish there, the sound in the auditorium had to become more alive. If Baroque operas were going to be presented effectively, and if audiences new to opera were going to be attracted to it, then the house had to be made to feel more intimate.
"For so long, so many people complained about the acoustics of the State Theater, its unfriendliness to young voices, the dryness and unevenness of the sound in the house," Mr. Kellogg said. The press complained continually, he added. The company had to find an interim solution.
Of course, until recently, the idea that the sound system might become a permanent feature of even a renovated State Theater was very much alive. When the system was installed, Mr. Kellogg asked wary critics and audiences for a grace period. He promised to present a demonstration for critics and patrons to hear just how subtly, in his opinion, the system works. Excerpts from operas would be performed with the system switched off and on. That demonstration has never occurred, he conceded, citing the expense involved.
Last fall he also said that once the system was installed and fine-tuned, the controls and levels would be set and never tampered with. It was important, he felt, that the State Theater have a distinctive house sound.
But even at the Met, with its quite good acoustics, the house sound varies from production to production, mostly depending on the size and placement of sets. Wouldn't it be impossible for technicians at the State Theater to resist fiddling with the controls from night to night? If the capability exists, it is human nature to utilize it.
Sure enough, not only has daily tinkering become commonplace, Mr. Kellogg conceded, but on some nights the system has been turned off completely, he said, though no announcements were made to the press and public. This put audiences, but especially critics who are expected to offer informed evaluations, in an impossible situation. Can we trust what we are hearing?
That singers and musicians apparently support the sound system is not really surprising. Why shouldn't they take advantage of electronic assistance in an acoustically unfriendly house? That audiences have largely embraced it is also to be expected. Amplification has become pervasive, and the younger audiences the company is attracting, having grown up with electronic sound, are unlikely even to notice.
"The fact is, no matter what, people are going to complain about the sound in this house," Mr. Kellogg said. "This system is a way of solving the problem on an interim basis. The audience is not reacting, for the most part, on a matter of principle. Nor am I." Critics can "wring their hands as much as they like," he added. "It works for me."
Defenders, even among critics, argue that there is a difference between real amplification, typical today in Broadway theaters where singers wear body microphones, and systems that enhance the acoustical properties of a hall itself. But whatever labels are coined to describe the equipment, voices are still being picked up by microphones, carried through wires and disseminated through dozens, even hundreds, of tiny speakers that cover the walls.
And just as on Broadway, the use of sound systems in opera and concert music will eventually affect the way singers sing, musicians play, audiences hear and composers write. Mr. Kellogg maintains that the State Theater system "allows voices to be heard as they really are," and that it "does not make a small voice large or an ugly voice pretty."
I am not convinced, nor are some other critics, and at least a vocal minority of audience members. Because of the enhancement system, certain sounds -- a soprano's sustained, full-voiced high notes, for example -- are almost always piercingly present. Some sounds get oddly emphasized. During a recent performance of Virgil Thomson's "Mother of Us All," the opera sounded at times like a concerto for snare drum.
Of course, we have this adventurous and increasingly essential company to thank for finally bringing us the first production ever by a major New York opera house of Thomson's great American opera, as well as many other important works, like Rameau's "Platee" in the imaginative production by Mark Morris (which sold 95 percent of the house in six performances). Next season come other rarities and treats, like Prokofiev's "Love of Three Oranges" and Handel's "Rinaldo" with the splendid countertenor David Daniels in the title role.
Mr. Kellogg readily agreed that there was "no substitute for a house whose good acoustics are architectural." He hopes this can be achieved at the State Theater. It falls to critics, then, to point out the shortcomings of the current system.
Last week the company presented "Showcasing American Composers 2000," an invaluable contribution to the city's cultural life and the future of American opera. Over a period of two weeks, excerpts of roughly 25 minutes each from 12 American operas, either works-in-progress or existing operas that have yet to be produced, were performed in open readings with a full orchestra and strong vocal soloists at the Great Hall of Cooper Union.
This is the second consecutive year that these free performances were presented. The rehearsal schedule was tight but sufficient to give the composers, interested singers and operagoers and, most important, potential producers a good sense of the various works. That Mr. Kellogg and his company secured funds for this important project demonstrates how fully they are committed to the future of American opera. The Met has done nothing remotely as helpful to the cause.
That the City Opera's showcase was taking place off-site, downtown, not far from the home of the most famous organization to bolt Lincoln Center, Joseph Papp's Public Theater, seemed significant. What other bold ventures could the newly energized City Opera undertake if it could just scrap that sound system and fix up its house, or, maybe even get out of Lincoln Center and start afresh?

HEADLINE: Production Surged in April, And the Fed Was Watching

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities grew 0.9 percent in April, the fastest pace in nearly one and a half years, as businesses scrambled to meet demand, the Federal Reserve said today.
Analysts said the report underlined the economy's momentum and made it nearly certain that the central bank would raise interest rates by half a percentage point when its policy makers meet on Tuesday. 
 The Fed wants to slow the pace of growth in the economy to avert a possible surge in wages and prices, especially with the unemployment rate at a 30-year low.
The rise in industrial output in April was the strongest since a 1.8 percent pickup in August 1998. The Fed also said output grew by 0.7 percent in March, faster than the 0.3 percent it reported a month ago.
As a result, businesses ran at 82.1 percent of their maximum capacity last month, the highest rate since 82.4 percent in May 1998. The factory use rate in March was 81.7 percent, implying that the industrial sector was picking up speed at the start of the second quarter instead of slowing.
"This is bound to further bolster the Fed's perception that it must become more aggressive about reining in demand," said David Orr, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
Mr. Orr said that excess global manufacturing capacity that developed in late 1997 when Asia entered an economic crisis had now largely disappeared as overseas economies recovered and worldwide demand picked up.
While April's heightened factory operating rate remained well below the 85 percent level that is generally taken as a signal of potential production bottlenecks, it implied that businesses were beginning to strain to meet robust consumer demand.
The report said that virtually every manufacturing industry posted gains in production last month as output climbed 0.8 percent after a 0.9 percent rise in March. The rate of new-car and truck assemblies was pushed up to 13.3 million a year during April from 13 million in March.
At utility companies, production of gas and electricity rebounded 2.8 percent last month after falling 1.8 percent in March, while mining companies raised their production by 0.4 percent in April after a 1 percent gain in March.

HEADLINE: Panel Fears Security at Labs Hurts Foreign Hiring

BYLINE: By JAMES GLANZ 

 BODY:
A panel of scientists and engineers who advise the president and Congress issued a statement yesterday expressing concern that heightened security measures at federal laboratories appeared to be damaging their ability to hire and retain foreign-born and minority scientists.
If the laboratories could not attract those scientists, who make up a large portion of the technical talent in the United States, the labs' abilities to perform tasks as diverse as ensuring the safety of the nuclear stockpile and cleaning up toxic wastes could be threatened, said the panel, the National Science Board. 
 Energy Secretary Bill Richardson immediately disputed the board's contention that the security measures are behind the laboratories' hiring difficulties, pointing instead to "an atmosphere of fear" generated by Congress.
The Energy Department, which runs the labs, "is doing its best to strike the proper balance between protecting that which legitimately requires protection while encouraging the openness that science requires," Mr. Richardson said.
Security requirements have been tightened at federal labs since Wen Ho Lee, a former nuclear scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory, was arrested and charged with mishandling nuclear secrets more than a year ago. Rules involving close scrutiny of scientists' contact with foreign nationals, polygraph tests and limitations on scientific collaborations have been imposed.
Some of the measures have been criticized as needlessly intrusive and unfairly burdensome to Asian and Asian-American scientists at the laboratories and are said to create a hostile and discriminatory workplace.
The issue is a serious one, since, for example, more than a quarter of doctorates in technical fields awarded in the United States each year are given to Asians or Asian-Americans.
The statement from the National Science Board, which also governs the National Science Foundation, said the security concerns at the labs have led to a "growing difficulty" in attracting foreign-born and minority scientists "because of perceptions based on nationality, ethnicity, or other characteristics."
Dr. Eamon Kelly, president emeritus of Tulane University and chairman of the science board, said: "There's an accumulation of evidence that the current environment is becoming a detriment to the hiring of foreign-born and minority American scientists. This can have an impact on the integrity of the scientific process, which would be detrimental both to our national security and our economic growth."
He said that while the board was mindful of suspicion surrounding Asian scientists at federal laboratories, its concerns went further, covering all foreign-born scientists.
Congress has also placed a moratorium on visits to the labs by scientists from numerous countries, except when special waivers are granted by Mr. Richardson. An Energy Department official said the routine paperwork generated by the security rules was "overlaid with this sense of suspicion" only because of the intrusion of needless restrictions imposed by Congress.
Mr. Richardson said the security requirements by themselves did not discourage international collaborations or intimidate lab scientists. Rather, he said, "It is Congress, by creating an atmosphere of fear, that has caused concerns among the foreign-born scientists."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Crop Genetics On the Line In Brazil;
A Rule on Seeds May Have Global Impact

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA with SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO

 BODY:
He was dazzled by the vast fields of soybeans in Brazil, and the efficiency of the farms in Argentina frankly frightened him. But nothing that Harold H. Dyer, an Iowa farmer, saw on his working vacation in South America last year surprised him more than finding out that his competitors freely used genetically modified soybeans in ways that would have landed him in a heap of trouble.
He knew that most farmers in Argentina planted modified soybean seeds, but he did not know that they saved seeds from one year to plant the next, a practice that is legal in Argentina but not in North America. The Argentinians told him they never pay a technology fee for the seeds, which cost American farmers an extra $6.50 a bag. 
 And in Brazil, where such seeds are still outlawed, Mr. Dyer was convinced -- though no one came right out and said so -- that the seeds were being smuggled in. The Brazilian government insists that no genetically altered soybeans are grown there, but Mr. Dyer said he saw soybean fields that were as free of weeds as the parts of his own 2,500-acre farm in Iowa and Missouri where he sows the superseeds.
"They have to live by their rules, of which there aren't any, and we have to live by ours, which are numerous," said Mr. Dyer, 75, who also runs several grain elevators in Iowa and Missouri. "It's not fair, and I would like for it to be changed, but that's the way it is."
Brazil is in the process of deciding whether to make the new technology legal. And there is a growing sense that what happens in Brazil -- the world's No. 2 soybean producer, after the United States -- could tip the balance on genetically altered crops around the world.
Should Brazil officially reject biotechnology's lure, it would be a big setback for American companies that have already been hurt financially by fierce resistance in Europe from consumers and large companies that refuse to buy modified produce. But if Brazil's huge agricultural sector joins the biotech fold, experts say, it may someday be difficult for consumers anywhere to find any food free of genetically modified material.
That is because the United States, Brazil and Argentina, the No. 3 producer, together grow 80 percent of the world's 157 million metric tons of soybeans, an extraordinarily versatile crop that is pressed into oil, processed into food, and added to countless foods.
"Once Brazil starts harvesting transgenic soybeans, there will be no turning back," said Joao Carlos Carvalho, president of Agropecuaria Basso, a Brazilian company licensed to sell the seeds if they are approved.
The situation in Brazil also shows how difficult it is to control this new technology in the absence of any global regulatory mechanism. The Brazilian government approved the use of modified seeds developed by Monsanto in 1998, but a consumer group challenged the approval in federal court in Brazil. Delmiro Silva, a spokesman for Monsanto in Brazil, expects a ruling sometime this year.
Technically, it is still illegal to plant high-technology seeds in Brazil. This is such a sensitive issue that the minister of agriculture, Marcus Vinicius Pratini de Moraes, would respond only to a written question. "The commercial planting of genetically modified soybeans in Brazil is not permitted," he wrote. Frequent government testing, he added, confirmed that the harvest is free of genetically modified organisms.
Still, many agricultural experts, Brazilian and American alike, suspect that modified seeds are being smuggled in from Argentina. Dwain L. Ford, chairman for international affairs at the American Soybean Association, estimates that up to 30 percent of Brazil's soy crop could already be genetically modified. South American farmers are thus using the new technology without paying for it or necessarily understanding how to control it.
"There are no strict controls on highways or in warehouses, so no one really knows how many seeds have been smuggled in," said David Brew, a partner at Brasoja Corretora de Cereais, a grain trading company in Porto Alegre, Brazil. "Now the concern is that the smuggling has resulted in the trafficking of second-generation seeds as well."
While suspicious consumers stopped such farming in its tracks in Europe, the rush to biotech on this side of the Atlantic appears to be picking up steam. The big biotech companies, led by Monsanto, have made the Western hemisphere a vast proving ground for farmer acceptance of the seeds, government regulation of the crops and the limits to which intellectual property rights can be claimed.
The companies' progress has been formidable. In 1996, altered crops were planted on little more than four million acres worldwide. Today, altered soy, corn, cotton, canola and other crops are grown on nearly 100 million acres, 99 percent of it in just three countries: the United States, Argentina and Canada.
Although American consumers generally have been less upset than Europeans by the new crops, the Clinton administration plans to tighten regulations on the development and marketing of genetically modified plants and foods.
The reason farmers in many countries, even a few in Spain, France and Portugal, embrace the new technology despite consumer fears is simple: lower costs. With declining prices and an oversupply of soy, farmers look for every advantage.
By altering the seeds, Monsanto enables plants to withstand the widely used weed killer Roundup, which Monsanto also manufactures. Farmers who use Roundup Ready seed save on chemicals and labor because they can apply a single herbicide without harming the soy plants.
A study by Auburn University found that farmers who use the seeds can cut costs 4 percent, reduce the need for pesticides, and save time as well. For someone like Mr. Dyer, this is incentive enough to switch entirely this year.
But he will have to live by several conditions imposed by Monsanto, at least in North America. Farmers must pay a fee for each bag of seed. They must agree not to save seed for the following year, a practice farmers have used for years. And they must agree that if they ever stop using the seed, Monsanto investigators -- farmers call them gene police -- can walk their fields to take plant samples.
Monsanto has fought hard to define its intellectual property rights broadly, and to defend them vigorously. Thousands of calls have come into its informers' hotline about farmers planting saved seed. Monsanto has brought charges against "a fraction of a fraction" of the roughly 250,000 farmers who have ever used Roundup Ready seed, a spokesman said, declining to be more specific. Nearly all quietly pay their fines.
But in Saskatchewan, Monsanto is bringing a farmer to court for illegally growing genetically altered canola. The farmer, Percy Schmeiser, acknowledges that Monsanto investigators found altered plants on his land, but he insists he did not plant them. They were grown, he said, from seed that had blown off passing grain trucks or drifted in on the wind.
"I never had anything to do with Monsanto," Mr. Schmeiser said. "They were simply trying to see how far they could exercise property rights over farmers -- even those who hadn't planted their seed."
When he refused to pay the fines, Mr. Schmeiser was taken to court by Monsanto. The case, scheduled to be heard before summer, is widely seen as a test of Monsanto's intellectual property rights.
"If I lose my case," Mr. Schmeiser said, "every farmer in North America will become a serf." Monsanto declined to discuss the case.
In South America, Monsanto has been far less vigilant. In 1995, its application for a patent on Roundup Ready seed in Argentina was rejected. It appealed, but went ahead with plans to introduce the seed. Without a patent, Monsanto had no legal right to charge a fee or inspect farms to see if unauthorized seed was being planted.
With no patent, a black market flourished, forcing Monsanto to lower prices to less than half what it charges American farmers.
Today, as much as 90 percent of Argentina's soy crop may be genetically altered, the highest percentage in the world.
Monsanto's decision to enter this market without patent protection puzzled many people, including its fiercest critics.
Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends -- which is suing Monsanto in federal court for for what the group contends are antitrust violations -- said Monsanto has long argued that it cannot make money unless it controls intellectual property rights. But its decision to sell the seeds in Argentina anyway, he said, shows "they don't have to do that."
Monsanto says it will eventually have adequate patent protection in Brazil. Executives insist that despite the experience in Argentina, patent protection remains essential.
"But we have to deal with realities as well," said Robert L. Harness, director of international government affairs at Monsanto. "The consideration entering Argentina was that we wanted to obtain patent protection. We also wanted to provide our new technology to this market. We wish the situation were different, but it's not."
In Brazil, police have raided fields in the states of Rio Grande do Sul and Mato Grosso do Sul, where officials have said they intend to declare their states free of modified seeds.
The attraction is clear. European customers have reportedly already started asking for Brazilian soybeans because modified seeds are illegal there.
But segregating vast quantities of a commodity produced at thousands of farms would be daunting even in the United States. The ability of a developing country like Brazil to pull off such a task is questioned, even by Brazilians.
"Is someone going to sift through each truck of soybeans that arrives at port for export?" said Mr. Carvalho, president of Agropecuaria Basso.
Linda Thrane, a spokeswoman for Cargill, the large American commodities company, said the company "certainly wouldn't represent soybean shipments from Brazil as being 100 percent nongenetically enhanced."
Opinion about the future is deeply divided in South America, as elsewhere. While some see salvation in keeping the seeds out, many farmers are eager to enjoy an edge in a tight global market.
"How can we compete against the Americans and the Argentinians if they're allowed access to this technology and we're not?" said Armando Carlos Roos, a soybean farmer in Rio Grande do Sul. "Everyone knows transgenic soybeans have been smuggled in from Argentina," he said, and the pressure to use the new technology, legally or not, is intense. "I will go broke if I don't get to use transgenic beans. It's as simple as that."
