HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Complete And Utter Nonsense

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN; Gail Collins is on vacation.

 BODY:
During a visit to Shanghai last year my Times colleague Seth Faison and I interviewed the top managers of one of China's largest food companies, which had been partially privatized. While Seth interviewed the Chinese executives in Chinese, I leafed through the company's annual report. On the first page there were four pictures: the chairman, the vice chairman, the general manager and "the Communist Party representative" to the company. At one point I interrupted Seth's interview, pointed to the picture of the Communist Party rep and asked our Chinese hosts: "Say, what does this guy do?" They waved at the picture with disdain, as if to say: "He doesn't do anything. Just ignore him."
That encounter always stuck in my mind because it illustrated one of the political implications of the rise of the private, free-market economy in China. When managers and workers, students and intellectuals are no longer totally dependent on the state or the Communist Party for jobs, they are much more likely to speak their own mind and act on their own interests. That is a fact worth remembering as the U.S. Congress now debates whether to grant China permanent normal trade relations with America. 
 To be sure, the claims by some Clintonites or business types that trade will lead inexorably to democracy in China are exaggerated and too deterministic. But even more ridiculous is the claim by John Sweeney, head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., that "there is no information showing that China is improving its human rights situation or workers rights situation," and thus no reason to support permanent normalized trade ties with China.
As any regular visitor to China can see (unfortunately the U.S. unions have been discouraging members of Congress from visiting China and seeing for themselves), there is ample evidence that the strengthening of private enterprises and free markets in China, and the surge in Internet usage there, is creating the space and private incomes for more Chinese to live independent of the government and thereby expand their personal freedoms. And the more Chinese can live without the state, the more the democrats among them can afford to speak their minds and the more other Chinese can afford to listen.
Read Elisabeth Rosenthal's May 8 front-page piece from Beijing in this newspaper. It details the messy reality of today's China, where the leadership, terrified about the political fallout from China's joining the World Trade Organization, is cracking down -- and will continue to do so -- at the same time that Chinese liberals are becoming more self-confident and willing to challenge the state.
"In the China of today," writes Ms. Rosenthal, a Times Beijing reporter, "threats from the central authorities have diminished influence. Bookstores are still filled with provocative books. And people fired from government institutes can now often find a way to make a living in the expanding private sector. . . . Even as Chinese intellectuals bemoan the current climate, they feel more inconvenienced than terrified by the government's wrath. 'The methods are pretty much the same as in Deng Xiaoping's and even Mao's time,' a professor said. 'What's different is that nobody pays attention anymore. . . . Intellectuals don't feel that much pressure.' "
Ms. Rosenthal also notes that several recent devastating critiques of China's rulers, and disclosures about corruption in the Communist Party, have been circulated first on the Internet in China, and the Chinese leadership has been powerless to stop it. The China trade pact Congress is currently debating greatly enhances the ability of U.S. companies to invest in Internet development in China.
The truth is the A.F.L.-C.I.O. couldn't care less about political change in China. That is just a cover for their head-in-the-sand protectionism. China could become a democratic paradise tomorrow and Mr. Sweeney and his union would still oppose this trade bill, because they see it (wrongly) as just a vehicle to move U.S. manufacturing jobs to China.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is free to argue that this bill will hurt U.S. workers. Republican hard-liners are free to argue that China's entry into the W.T.O. will make it a more formidable geopolitical rival to the U.S. But for either of them to say that this bill will hurt the cause of democratization in China, or that it won't help create more islands from which Chinese democrats can operate and more tools by which they can communicate, is to speak utter nonsense, and, one hopes, a majority of Congress will see it as such.

HEADLINE: Rodman Rockefeller, 68, Dies; Active in Latin Trade Efforts

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Rodman C. Rockefeller, the eldest son of Nelson A. Rockefeller, who was active in efforts that led to the North American Free Trade Agreement and in forging closer ties between the United States and Latin America, died on Sunday night at his home on the East Side of Manhattan. He was 68 and also had a home in the Pocantico Hills section of Tarrytown, N.Y.
The cause was cancer, said Fraser P. Seitel, a spokesman for the Rockefeller family. 
 Mr. Rockefeller was the longtime chairman of Pocantico Associates, a private venture capital and real estate investment concern. He was also long active in Rockefeller family affairs.
Nelson Rockefeller was President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs during World War II, and Rodman's first journey to Mexico was as a teenager with his father in 1946, when President Miguel Aleman was inaugurated. Nelson Rockefeller went on to become governor of New York and vice president of the United States.
From the late 1960's into the 1990's, Rodman strove to spur trade with Mexico and other countries in Latin America and worked for the liberalization of foreign investment there.
During that period, he became a high executive of the International Basic Economy Corporation and co-chairman of the Mexico-United States Business Committee, an organization focusing on economic and political issues of interest to both nations' business communities. The passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement in the mid-1990's has been called the culmination of his and the committee's efforts.
Mr. Rockefeller was president from 1968 to 1972 and chief executive from 1972 to 1980 of International Basic Economy, a commercial genetics and agribusiness concern based in New York. Its activities, all in Latin America, included developing corn production there and building thousands of low-cost homes in three places in Mexico.
He was also chairman of IBEC Inc. a successor concern, from 1980 to 1985, and of Arbor Acres Farm, based in Glastonbury, Conn., a seller of genetic material for poultry stock, for some years.
In a 1988 interview, he said, "Our chickens are the grandparents of the ones you eat."
He was on the board of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund for nine years. For many years, he was a trustee of Rockefeller Financial Services, which in effect manages the family's office, its investment company and its foundations.
He was the head of the finance committee of Rockefeller Financial Services for years and was a longtime trustee of Rockefeller Financial's holding company, Rockefeller & Company.
He was also a trustee of the Institute of International Education, a nonprofit organization that works for international student exchanges and manages many such programs.
He was recently active in the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation, of which he was a trustee. Its programs include the restoration of Jefferson's estate, Monticello, in which Mr. Rockefeller was particularly interested.
The honors he received included a high Mexican decoration, the Order of the Aztec Eagle.
He was also a trustee of the Museum of Modern Art, the Americas Society and the New York Blood Center.
A native New Yorker, Rodman Clark Rockefeller was the son of Nelson Rockefeller and his first wife, the former Mary Todhunter Clark. He recalled years later that he and his siblings "called my father Dad, and later on we called him Chief," adding that "he was very enthusiastic, exciting, outgoing, very much of a family leader."
Rodman graduated from Deerfield Academy in Deerfield, Mass., and received a bachelor's degree in international economics in 1954 from Dartmouth College, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He received a master's degree in 1957 from Columbia's Graduate School of Business Administration. He was in the Army from 1954 to 1956.
As a young man, he recalled years later, it never occurred to him not to work despite the family's fortune. "It would have been boring just to go to the country club," he said.
He married Barbara Ann Olsen, a graduate of Wellesley College, in 1953. They were divorced in 1979.
He is survived by his wife, the former Alexandra von Metzler, known as Sascha, an interior designer and graduate of the Parsons School of Design, whom he married in 1980. He is also survived by four children from his first marriage: a daughter, Meile Louise Rockefeller of Manhattan; three sons, Peter, Stuart and Michael, all of Manhattan; and five grandchildren.
A private burial and a memorial service are to be held on June 1.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1833 words

HEADLINE: Who Lives Here? Who's Asking?;
In a Black Community, Official Mistrust Hinders Census

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
When Millicent Gillespie pulled the 38-page Census 2000 form out of her mailbox, on 171st Street in Jamaica, Queens, she tossed it in the trash.
First of all, the questionnaire, which arrived in March, was too long -- like a book, she said -- and the questions struck her as too personal and, in a few instances, simply ridiculous. 
 But there was more to Mrs. Gillespie's reluctance to fill out the form and mail it back: she has no faith in the government. And when she explained her reasoning, Mrs. Gillespie, a special education teacher at a nearby school, repeated the views of many of her neighbors in Census Tract 414, a quarter-mile slice of southeastern Queens.
The middle-class neighborhood of 3,800 people, 89 percent of them black, borders affluent St. Albans but is not far from dirt-poor pockets of Jamaica, with some of the borough's fanciest and most downtrodden blocks just around the corner.
A lot has changed in Tract 414 since the 1990 census. Renovated duplexes and newly constructed homes and churches are visible now on almost every block, on the same streets that at the end of the 1980's were lined with burned-out buildings or abandoned homes and swarming with drug dealers.
Another big change in the neighborhood was participation in the census, which plunged in Tract 414 to 33 percent of households mailing in their forms this year from 46 percent in 1990, according to a New York Times analysis of 2000 census data collected so far. Low responses to the 2000 census in tracts like 414 helped drag down the citywide response in black neighborhoods to under 40 percent, the analysis showed, a decline of five percentage points over 1990, which is a sharp drop in the census-taking world.
The low response rate in black neighborhoods appeared to be well below this year's response among other races, both nationally and in New York City and State. Only one other city, Baltimore, saw such a notable decline in the response among black residents, according to census officials, who were mulling over preliminary census data last week and said they could not yet give an explanation for the decline in Baltimore.
Census officials say they were puzzled by results from New York City's black population, which were calculated by analyzing the initial response rates from largely black neighborhoods. Late last month they reported significantly higher responses this year from largely black cities like Detroit and Oakland, Calif., and, on average, no decline among blacks elsewhere in New York State or across the country. An unusually high response among minority members, particularly Hispanics, helped lift the national response rate to about 66 percent, exceeding the bureau's expectations after dramatic declines that began with the 1980 count, officials said.
"It'll be studied for the next 10 years," Steve Jost, the United States Census Bureau's associate director for communications, said of the low black response rate in New York City. "It's way too early to try and diagnose."
But inside Tract 414, there was little mystery about the low response there. Resident after resident, from pastors to postal workers, described a deep sense of mistrust and suspicion of the government, even among those employed in the public sector.
The mistrust of the government drew no distinction between local, state and federal agencies, though residents say their suspicions have worsened in recent years because of several high-profile police brutality cases in New York City.
"There's a combination of mistrust and the feeling that we're not going to get counted anyway," said the Rev. Samuel L. Zimmerman Jr., associate pastor of St. Paul Baptist Church of Jamaica on 171st Street, who has rented an apartment near the church since 1992.
For many neighborhood residents, who are concerned about giving information to government agencies, all levels of government are "clumped in the same basket," Mr. Zimmerman said, and the most visible arm of the government to the people of Tract 414, once a high-crime area, is the Police Department.
"The fact that the Census Bureau has said that this information is confidential probably carries less credibility when they see other institutions that don't necessarily honor that," Mr. Zimmerman said during an interview in his one-room church, a converted house that has served as a church for 23 years. "For example, the Police Department is to protect and serve, but there is some prominent evidence that it would seem to be otherwise."
Mr. Zimmerman, who said he mailed in his census form immediately because he believes the neighborhood needs federal aid that is doled out based on population figures, read announcements from the Census Bureau during church services every Sunday in April, as did other neighborhood clerics, urging residents to fill out and return the forms. But Mr. Zimmerman said the response from his 45-member congregation was, at best, lukewarm, and, more often, dismissive.
But the reluctance to send in questionnaires has not stopped many residents of the neighborhood from taking advantage of job opportunities with the Census Bureau, and several said they had applied for jobs doing door-to-door surveying. The jobs, which require passing an exam, pay $18.50 per hour in New York City.
Census workers, living both inside and outside the neighborhood, said they were encountering much resistance in Tract 414.
"They don't believe that the census is being taken for the good of the community," said Joyce Sweeting, a census taker working in Tract 414 and a resident of another neighborhood of Jamaica, who began knocking on doors on April 26. "I'm having trouble. They believe it's just a sly way for the government to get into their business."
A census taker eventually persuaded Mrs. Gillespie to fill out a two-page questionnaire -- the long form she had received in the mail was sent to one-sixth of the nation's households -- but it was a hard sell.
Mrs. Gillespie, 59, and several of her neighbors said their unwillingness to respond stemmed from the feeling that the people of the neighborhood had lifted themselves to middle-class status. (The median income in Tract 414 has risen gradually since 1990 to $45,000.) And the residents had turned around the area from a place that was literally tumbling down after the crack epidemic of the 1980's. When they needed help, they said, the government gave them none. So it is now difficult to see the point of getting counted to receive government assistance, they said.
"Slowly, this place is coming along," said Mrs. Gillespie, who moved to 171st Street with her husband, James, a supervisor with the city's Department of Transportation, 11 years ago from a nearby section of Jamaica. "But my thing is that in 11 years in other neighborhoods, it would have all been done by now. In better neighborhoods. If you want to put it bluntly, in white neighborhoods."
Mrs. Gillespie said that her block, 171st Street, between 107th and 108th Avenues, was "torn up with potholes," when she moved there, and that the street remained so bad that no one could drive down it for another five years. She said that she and her neighbors got no action after making dozens of calls to city officials and politicians.
Finally, Mrs. Gillespie said, a friend of hers who also worked for the Transportation Department called someone she knew in the Giuliani administration, and the street was paved within a few weeks.
"We spent years just to get a decent street to park our cars and have people on the street," Mrs. Gillespie said. "Most of the people here have put down their own sidewalks. They didn't put down a sidewalk for us. We have what the people put down, but we don't have one from the city."
Mr. Zimmerman and others, noting the strong response to Census 2000 in places like Detroit, where Mayor Dennis Archer began an all-hands effort to get that city's population of 970,000 over the 1 million mark, said another cause of the low black response in New York may be a lack of effort on the city's part to get the word out to the black community.
Comparing the census to voting, which has historically drawn low turnout from black constituents, Randolph Scott-McLaughlin, director of the Social Justice Center at Pace University's law school, said, "We haven't got the habit yet, and it works against our own interest.
"There is a cycle of distrust at work here, but also maybe you have to help people out," said Professor Scott-McLaughlin, a resident of Jamaica Estates, north of Tract 414. "It seems like other cities did something about it, and now we're going to say there's an undercount again. Surprise, surprise, that's like saying there's gambling at Rick's," he said, referring to the scene of most of the action in the movie "Casablanca."
City officials said that while they had not seen a racial breakdown of the census response, they had talked to elected officials and others from neighborhoods with historically low response rates and concluded that not much had changed since 1990. The overall 2000 census response rate for the city, 53 percent, was equal to the 1990 response.
"We went out with a full-press" effort, said Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington, who oversaw what he described as a two-year effort costing the city several million dollars to persuade New Yorkers to respond to the census. This included, he said, an advertising campaign that put 8,000 posters on subways, buses and garbage trucks and notices in residents' utility bills.
"But you know we are faced with a problem, and this is from California to New York," Mr. Washington said. "Why is it that within the African-American community people are suspect of these forms? There's a systemic problem, and I don't know what the answer may be."
Some residents of Tract 414, like James Terrell, 35, who now owns the house he grew up in on 171st Street, a few doors from Mrs. Gillespie, gave another reason for suspicions about the forms.
Mr. Terrell said that he and several of his neighbors were afraid that giving too much information to the government, like a Social Security number or details about their jobs, would somehow jeopardize their newfound economic security, some of it pieced together with earnings from second and third jobs that are off the books.
"In a lot of poor neighborhoods, people don't have anything to lose," said Mr. Terrell, who works at a nearby auto shop and also installs car stereos on the side. "But here, I figure you have more to lose. I think that a lot of black people don't trust the American government. They feel that if I tell them all about myself, then all I'm doing is digging a bigger hole for myself. Maybe some people feel like they're getting away with something, let's just say. And this is the first time they've really had money to get out of a jam, you know."
As he was leaving for work, Mr. Terrell added, "People finally have something now, and they don't want to lose it."

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE;
Nike's Power Game

BYLINE: By Sarah Edith Jacobson; Sarah Jacobson, a senior at the University of Oregon, is active in United Students Against Sweatshops.

DATELINE: EUGENE, Ore.

 BODY:
When Phil Knight, the chief executive of Nike, withdrew a promised $30 million donation to the University of Oregon last month, his announcement had the tone of an angry parent. He chastised the university for joining the Worker Rights Consortium, a group that monitors conditions in factories that make clothing with college logos. He accused the university of "inserting itself into the new global economy where I make my living" and doing so "on the wrong side, fumbling a teachable moment."
Mr. Knight, an Oregon graduate, was angry that the university had joined this consortium rather than the Fair Labor Association, a group that includes as members the same industries that have profited from sweatshop conditions in their production plants. The Worker Rights Consortium is based on the premise that work conditions will not be changed by codes and monitors that come from industry, but by involvement of workers, through collective bargaining with management. 
 In joining the consortium, the University of Oregon pledged to use its influence to improve conditions at factories producing clothes with the university logo. Mr. Knight, accusing his alma mater of shredding its "bonds of trust" with him, seemed offended that it had not asked his permission.
The university's decision was not made lightly. In March, a referendum sponsored by the student government yielded a three-fourths majority vote in support of membership. A committee accountable to the the university president, David B. Frohnmayer, and made up of students, faculty, administrators and alumni, voted unanimously the same month in favor of joining. Then the University Senate, composed of faculty and students, passed a resolution calling for membership. It was only after all these steps that President Frohnmayer signed the university into membership.
Mr. Knight's punitive reaction really questions the autonomy of the university itself. If the voice of one alumnus held more weight than a year of university-wide deliberation, what role would there be for shared governance on campus? If donations from corporate America depended on toeing a corporate line, the university would be better off without the money.
The goal of students across the country who are organizing around sweatshop issues is to create widespread change in an industry where insufficient wages and mandatory overtime are common. In many third world and American apparel factories, there have been reports of intimidation of workers who try to speak out. And because it is easy for these factories to cut and run, vanishing across national borders and abandoning workers, many people are hesitant to organize unions or demand a living wage.
The Worker Rights Consortium and the student anti-sweatshop campaign challenge companies like Nike not only to let the public know the conditions in apparel factories, but to begin long-term change.
Will the debate about sweatshop conditions move beyond the specifics of monitoring and toward establishing the right to organize? Phil Knight's withdrawal of money from the University of Oregon sends the signal that his company is resisting a move in that direction.

HEADLINE: Good Propaganda, Bad Economics

BYLINE: By Jaime Sneider; Jaime Sneider is editorial page editor of The Columbia Daily Spectator.

 BODY:
College students continue to propagate the myth that Nike and other apparel companies contract out to foreign "sweatshops" where overworked and underpaid workers toil in unhealthful conditions. They are especially outraged by the recent decision by Phil Knight of Nike to withdraw a promised $30 million donation to the University of Oregon in protest of the school's decision to join the Worker Rights Consortium, a labor rights group.
Rather than condemn Mr. Knight, students should commend him. 
 The Worker Rights Consortium, which was established last fall by students, unions and human rights groups, accuses Nike of failing to pay its workers a "living wage," ignoring safety concerns, and forcing employees to work overtime. But, comparatively speaking, conditions at third world factories where Nike goods are made are remarkably benevolent. For example, a number of the plants have air conditioning in countries where it is a rarity. Some factories also have clinics that can be used by employees' families, who otherwise would have little if any medical care. Several others even have schools where workers' children can learn everything from reading and writing to biology and physics.
A typical worker in a Nike factory in Vietnam makes about $564 a year, which may not seem like much, but is more than twice the country's average annual income. The employee turnover rate in Nike's factories in Indonesia is consistently below 2 percent, low even by American standards. Such loyalty suggests that workers do not have better prospects.
Many statistics cited by student activists are misleading and originate with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has endorsed the Worker Rights Consortium. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has a direct economic interest: the regulations advocated by the consortium would increase American companies' foreign manufacturing costs, thus encouraging them to abandon their operations abroad and manufacture products domestically instead -- employing union labor.
Phil Knight has agreed to an open monitoring of Nike factories through the Fair Labor Association, a group composed of consumer groups, corporations and universities that has been endorsed by the White House. Nike has said that many students have genuine concerns about working conditions abroad, and that the company recognizes that there is always room for improvement.
But, according to a Nike spokeswoman, "the way to get true reform is to have all the players at the table." The Worker Rights Consortium, on the other hand, has not prescribed clear goals or monitoring procedures, and does not yet have legal status as a nonprofit organization. It has been reluctant to include companies like Nike in the dialogue, claiming that corporate participation of any kind threatens workers' rights.
While many students uncritically believe the Worker Rights Consortium, they ignore the fact that Phil Knight and Nike have championed the well-being of workers internationally. By trying to punish Nike, these students threaten to impoverish the workers they claim to protect.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 534 words

HEADLINE: Closing the Achievement Gap

 BODY:
Over the last five years, the New York State Board of Regents has enacted a series of public school reforms that have placed the state in the lead of the national movement for standards and accountability. At the same time, however, local educators and politicians who claim to want reform have sometimes reacted with skepticism and resistance when confronted with the discomfort that comes with change. Defenders of the status quo whipped up a fuss, for example, when the Regents raised graduation standards across the state, demanded a tougher curriculum and began to issue "report cards" that exposed as mediocre schools that many citizens thought were excellent.
A similar backlash has emerged since the Regents announced that they will soon begin reporting student performance by income and race, to focus attention on the achievement gap that often exists between rich and poor and between white and minority students within the same school. Critics say that holding districts accountable for closing the achievement gap is onerous and unfair, some of them suggesting that nothing can be done. But national studies indicate that the gap can indeed be closed and that disaggregating data by race and income is a crucial first step in the process. 
 Pessimism about closing the performance gap is widespread, but it is not supported by the facts. The most recent study of national achievement data by the Education Trust, a Washington foundation devoted to school reform, shows that while black and Latino students continue to trail white students on reading scores, schools that serve those students made great strides in recent decades. Between the mid-70's and mid-90's, the gap in achievement between African-American and white students, as measured by a federally sponsored test called the National Assessment of Educational Progress, narrowed by about half. The progress stopped in the late 1980's, when poverty became more concentrated and educators began to focus on remedial studies instead of much-needed high-level instruction.
Several states now report performance by race, most notably Texas. It began its effort in the 1980's with the Perot Commission, whose work culminated a decade later in a novel accountability system that rates the public schools by how well their minority students perform. Simply put, a school cannot receive the highest state rating unless 90 percent of its students -- including 90 percent of minority students -- perform at the highest levels on all state assessments. Texans looked at the data and recognized that the schools were jeopardizing the state's future by writing off minorities -- who make up more than half the public school enrollment. Since the reform effort, more minority students than ever are taking the Scholastic Assessment Tests, setting their sights on college.
The New York State Board of Regents created a similar momentum when it raised standards, requiring all students to pass Regents exams to graduate from high school. By disaggregating performance scores by race and economic status, the Regents hope to focus public opinion on the achievement gap in New York, forcing schools to work harder on minority achievement. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Sad Realities for Doctors

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The column "The Demise of Reflective Doctoring" (May 9) accurately describes the sad direction doctors are being forced to take by the need for fiscal stability.
This dangerous situation pervades both the university and the community. Solo practitioners and groups that would ordinarily spend quality time with patients must now spend it on increasing volume, filing forms and deciphering the coding. 
 The traits of the "clinical champions" that the authors feel are required to halt this downward spiral are indigenous in most medical students, but the realities of the economic environment, the predominance of poor role modeling and the need now to scramble for a living are causes for even the most optimistic of us to become cynical in thinking that any of our wishes will be achieved until such time that the practice of medicine is restored to its original luster.
 
DR. HERBERT DARDIK
Tenafly, N.J.
 
The writer is a vascular surgeon.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: PUBLIC OPINION;
Poll Shows Bush Ahead of Gore, With Leadership a Crucial Issue

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE with JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
While many Americans find Vice President Al Gore's stands on issues more appealing, he is not as well liked or considered as commanding a leader as Gov. George W. Bush, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
Mr. Gore's lackluster personal favorability ratings may help explain why Mr. Bush has emerged at this early stage as the preferred candidate across the demographic spectrum, including three critical groups that voted Democratic in 1996: Catholics, independents and Northeasterners. Voters polled, in fact, are so lukewarm toward Mr. Gore that he is widely perceived as a loser in November: by a ratio of nearly 2 to 1, they expect Mr. Bush to capture the White House. 
 Despite Mr. Bush's advantages six months before Election Day, Mr. Gore may be heartened that vice presidents are often overshadowed by the presidents they serve until they can distinguish themselves on a national stage at their nominating convention. In fact, at this time 12 years ago, Mr. Bush's father, then the vice president, trailed Michael S. Dukakis by 10 points, but went on to a lopsided victory in November.
And the survey illuminated potential rough patches for the Texas governor. For one thing, voters polled had qualms with his plan, which he outlined yesterday, that would allow workers to invest part of their payroll taxes in private accounts. Most of those polled said the stock market was a perilous place to invest.
Voters also seemed skeptical of Mr. Bush's proposed tax cut of $483 billion over five years -- a measure that Mr. Gore has condemned as a "risky tax scheme." Even 57 percent of people who said they planned to vote for Mr. Bush were uncertain of the effect of that proposal.
Mr. Bush will also have to cautiously navigate roiling factions in his own ranks. Three of every 10 Republican voters polled said that if the governor picks a running mate who supports legalized abortion they would be less likely to support him. About a third of all voters said religious conservatives carry too much influence in the Republican Party.
The nationwide telephone survey was conducted last Wednesday through Saturday with 947 adults, including 716 registered voters. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3 to 4 percentage points.
Perhaps the most promising news for Mr. Gore was that he scored well with voters on issues they said were at the top of their agenda, like health care, education and Social Security. He was also seen as more caring than Mr. Bush, despite the governor's slogan that he is a "compassionate conservative."
Given that his issues are popular and that the economy seems hearty, the nagging difficulty that has confounded the vice president's advisers and many Democrats is why his overall ratings are not more competitive with Mr. Bush.
Among all voters, Mr. Bush led Mr. Gore by 8 percentage points, 47 to 39. Mr. Bush held a wide advantage among men, 50 to 36 percentage points; among women, Mr. Gore drew 42 percent, Mr. Bush, 44 percent.
The vice president's lagging ratings appear to have more to do with personality than policy. Mr. Gore was seen favorably by 34 percent of registered voters and unfavorably by 36 percent. By contrast, Mr. Bush was seen favorably by 40 percent and unfavorably by 28 percent.
A related problem that has dogged Mr. Gore is that Mr. Bush is viewed as more of a leader. Fifty-three percent of registered voters in the new poll said Mr. Gore had strong leadership qualities; 63 percent said the same thing about Mr. Bush.
The contrast is striking, particularly since Mr. Gore has been an elected official since 1976, when he was elected to the House from Tennessee; Mr. Bush was elected governor, his first office, in 1994. That said, Mr. Gore has spent the past seven years in the shadow of a president who consistently draws high ratings for the job he has done in office.
Several people who responded to the poll explained in follow-up interviews that there were not specific issues on which they split sharply with Mr. Gore. Rather, they often cited more intangible personal factors.
"Gore has not really shown a lot of leadership qualities or abilities to be in a position to run our nation," said Ken Bogler, 27, a labor representative from Somerset, N.J., who is an independent. "It's a presence, really. The way he carries himself, the way he speaks, does not seem presidential."
He added, "Issues don't play a big part in my support. Nine times out of 10, the candidates change their positions once they get into office any way. He may have the experience, but if you don't have the confidence and the abilities of someone who can handle the job, you don't give him the job."
Vera Jeane, 71, a retired nurse from Bay City, Tex., who is a Democrat, put it this way: "Al Gore acts as if he's not sure what he's thinking, as if he doesn't have a mind of his own. He doesn't seem to be strong enough in his opinions and as a leader to be president. Bush seems to be a stronger man with more definitive opinions. And I think he would make a better leader."
Tony Coelho, Mr. Gore's campaign chairman, said he was not discouraged by such critiques and insisted that voters would defect from Mr. Bush when his policy stands are articulated in detail.
"You take the issues that are out there today," he said. "As we get to the general election, we're going to be forcing a debate."
Citing how Mr. Gore has inched up in the polls since last year, Mr. Coelho added: "We've made up a lot of points with George Bush. I'm not worried about George Bush at this point."
With fewer than 3 in 10 voters saying they were paying a lot of attention to the campaign, the candidates have not yet been able to fully define themselves to the electorate.
Mr. Bush, in particular, has made little headway in trumpeting his programs for cutting taxes and overhauling the Social Security system. Only 9 percent of registered voters in the poll said they knew a great deal about Mr. Bush's tax blueprint; 58 percent said they had no idea whether his plan would help or hurt the economy.
By a ratio of 4 to 1, those polled preferred using any budget surplus to shore up Social Security rather than to cut income taxes -- even as a majority said it might be possible to do both.
In a finding that raises questions about the Social Security proposal Mr. Bush discussed yesterday, those polled were closely divided over whether individuals should be allowed to invest portions of their Social Security taxes on their own.
When asked to put aside their presidential preferences and focus on issues, Mr. Gore was considered more capable in tackling Social Security and education, traditional Democratic strengths.
But the candidates were viewed about evenly in handling gun control, which has long been viewed as a Democratic issue, and taxes.
Voters also identified stark ideological differences between the candidates. For all the efforts by Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore to court moderates, voters did not see them as moderates.
Forty-three percent of registered voters said they thought of Mr. Bush as a conservative while 34 percent said they thought he was a moderate. Similarly, 43 percent cast Mr. Gore as a liberal, while 30 percent said he was more a moderate.
Mr. Bush has been unable to shake the idea advanced by gun control advocates that the National Rifle Association would wield considerable influence in a Bush administration. Voters were three times more likely to say that Mr. Bush would be influenced greatly by the N.R.A. than Mr. Gore would.
In the follow-up interviews, some voters, citing character considerations, lamented that Senator John McCain, who was defeated by Mr. Bush in the Republican primaries, would not be on any ticket. In fact, Mr. McCain has maintained far more impressive favorability ratings than Mr. Bush or Mr. Gore: 46 percent have a favorable view of him; 14 percent hold an unfavorable view.
"I don't see in Gore or Bush that clear definitive leadership quality that McCain had," said Tim Olkar, 22, a student in Wheaton, Ill., who is an independent.
Speaking of Mr. Gore, he said: "He seems kind of wishy-washy as a candidate and seems to be running a negative campaign. Bush seems a little more genuine to me."
Beyond the candidates themselves, the Democratic and Republican parties are now seen more favorably than less so by voters. The Republican Party, in particular, has rebounded to its standing before the impeachment proceedings against President Clinton, which took a toll on the party.
There was no upswing for the Reform Party, which seems poised to nominate Patrick J. Buchanan as its standard bearer. The party is seen twice as negatively as positively.
 
"How the Poll Was Conducted"
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Wednesday through Saturday with 947 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 716 said they were registered to vote.
The telephone exchanges called were randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges in the United States.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to account for household size and the number of telephone lines in the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than four percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by talking to all registered voter in the United States.
For smaller subgroups, the margin of sampling error is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error. Variations in the wording and order of questions, for example, may lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Tread Dread: Solving The Mystery of Tires

BYLINE: By TIM MORAN; Tim Moran writes on the automotive business from Grosse Pointe Park, Mich.

 BODY:
IT is common to feel foolish at the tire store. What should you ask for? Should you stay with the kind of tire that came with the car, or try something different, maybe sportier? Is it O.K. to go for low-cost tires, or do you sacrifice safety and handling? Can buying top-of-the-line tires turn your station wagon into a roadster?
Though many replacement tires are sold -- 184 million passenger car tires and 30.5 million light-truck tires in the United States in 1998 alone -- tires are an enigma to most people. Throw in a raft of technological innovations (even tires will have computer sensors soon) and coding systems that seem to combine algebra and Urdu, and it is clear why the humble tire is so mysterious. 
 Here is a starting point: the tire chosen for a new American passenger car is carefully engineered to do a good job at sometimes conflicting tasks.
* It must last 40,000 miles. That is what buyers expect.
* It must have low rolling resistance to save gas and help the car company meet its fuel-efficiency mandates.
* It must offer a comfy, quiet and slightly road-deadening ride. (Most Americans do not like to "feel" the road.)
* It must provide decent traction in all weather conditions on a variety of surfaces.
Those are the criteria the builders set when they mate a car with its first set of tires, and for most driving the choices remain good. The car's suspension is tuned to the weight, size and rolling resistance of those tires.
"The tire is a product of -- I'll say compromise," said Donald L. Botka, a vice president at Continental General Tire in Charlotte, N.C. The company takes at least two years to design and fine-tune its products, working with a manufacturer.
What makes a tire appealing to automotive engineers may not be what a performance-oriented driver wants. Or it may not even appeal to a driver who does not live in a part of the country where weather changes significantly by season.
While premium tires may not necessarily make your staid sedan stand up and howl, different tires do change the ride. Up to 20 percent of a car's noise, vibration and ride harshness can be attributed directly to tires, engineers say. If your sedan's tires tend to squeal during turns, a stiffer sidewall may cure the condition. Some drivers may want more road grip, better mud-and-snow traction or a longer life span for tires.
"The replacement market is a different animal," said Robert Carroll, the vice president of original equipment marketing for Michelin. "What you're looking at is trying to service a customer to meet his consumer needs."
Getting a grip can mean sacrifices, Mr. Carroll and other tire experts point out. Speed-oriented tires may compromise fuel efficiency, tread life and all-season traction in favor of dry-pavement performance. To gain the latter, such tires often have more rigid sidewalls than their cushier brethren, meaning a harsher ride.
"Comfort is what Americans crave," Mr. Carroll said. But he also noted that Americans are very image-conscious. A fast driver may try to buy his way up the performance-tire chain but find himself sorely disappointed by what he gets. "The normal American, who is buying that tire for image, perhaps, would find that car so nervous when he's driving down the highway that he couldn't even have a cup of coffee because he has to have both hands on the wheel," Mr. Carroll said.
For the driving enthusiast who wants total road feel and catlike traction, the cost of high-end performance tires, like the $145-a-tire Goodyear Eagle F1, makes sense. Such a buyer may own a multiseason set of tires, and a winter set, perhaps Firestone's $80 FT 70 C cold-weather tire, with its special rubber compound, mounted on separate wheels.
At the opposite end of the spectrum, customers who are looking for extremely long-lived tires -- those that guarantee 80,000 or even 100,000 miles of tread wear instead of 40,000 miles, or those that can run for miles even after the air has leaked from them -- may not realize they could be trading away handling and gas-mileage advantages by paying a premium for peace of mind.
Michelin's X-1 tire shows one trend in long tire life: for $120 a tire, the company guarantees six years of driving with no mileage limit.
Some tires may complicate driving in the name of safety. Take the case of what manufacturers call extended-mobility tires, commonly called run-flats. Such tires have been appearing recently in luxury cars; Chevrolet's Corvette comes with them. Extended-mobility tires are designed so that for 50 miles or so, the sidewalls can hold the weight of the car even after air leaks out.
"I don't think the problem has been with them working," said Lloyd Stoyer, the editor of Modern Tire Dealer, a trade magazine. "The problem has been with cost, the cost of the sensors needed to tell you when the tire is flat.
"These tires are not as fuel efficient," Mr. Stoyer continued. "They don't handle as well. On the off chance that you have a flat, you drive on a tire that is not as efficient."
Some manufacturers are hailing breakthroughs in new, lightweight materials as a sign that run-flat tires are improving and will become the norm. Tire dealers are not jumping on the bandwagon just yet. Equipment to install and service $2,000-to-$3,000 run-flat tire systems is costly, and there are not enough of these tires on the road to make them standard items at any dealership.
"Run-flat requires special everything," said Darin Ode, the general manager of Ode Tire and Service in Warren, Mich. "When you get the flat, you know what's happened, but you don't know how far it's going to be before you can find a distributor who can replace your tire."
At the opposite end of the price spectrum, four-tires-for-$100 campaigns have appealed to thriftier buyers.
IS low price sufficient reason to buy a particular tire?
"Why are people willing to spend more for a pair of sneakers than for tires when their life depends on the tires' performance for thousands of miles?" a tire engineer asked at a recent online automotive forum.
His point is well taken; it is all too easy to get wrapped up in price without thinking about what the tires cost over their life span. But if buying tires at rock-bottom prices is a big issue, be sure to check the Uniform Tire Quality Grade traction and temperature ratings molded into sidewalls. (Every tire company assigns an "A," "B" or "C" grade to its products, with "A" being the highest.)
Tires can be inexpensive because the cost of their materials has fallen markedly over the last five years, new automated assembly methods have been introduced, which have cut labor costs, and fierce competition between retailers has slashed margins to the bone. Tire technology has matured to the point that competition is based more on price than on manufacturing advances.
But the industry thinks it is on the cusp of a new era in technology. More functions may soon be packed into tires beyond traction and handling abilities. Continental Teves Inc. introduced its "intelligent tire" last fall with test-track demonstrations for the Frankfurt Auto Show in Germany.
The tire uses magnetic stripes molded into the sidewall to send traction information to sensors mounted near each wheel.
"When you drive a car, when you accelerate, brake or turn, basically what's allowing you to do that is friction or forces between the tire and the road," said Philip Headley, the chief engineer of advance technology at Continental Teves's North American headquarters in Auburn Hills, Mich. "What the 'intelligent' tire does is actually allow us to measure those forces."
Mr. Headley said that the tire's feedback could tell the onboard car computer whether a tire was skidding or slipping, or about to skid. The tire could replace more expensive sensors in electronic stability systems that help drivers avoid accidents.
At Michelin, the Pax tire system changes the entire wheel, clamping a tire onto a precision wheel, which includes a rubber insert ring. The ring and the rim provide more than 100 miles of run-flat ability. Michelin is seeking to license the technology and make it an industry standard. Pax has recently appeared on "concept" cars, like the Cadillac Evoq, designed and built but not ready for mass production.
Such complex tire-wheel systems may run at much higher inflation pressures than current tires do -- more than 50 pounds a square inch, rather than the 32 to 35 pounds common today -- to increase fuel efficiency. They could also include pressure- and temperature-sensing technology to give drivers early warning of changing tire conditions, prompting drivers to maintain tires and thereby extend tire life.
Eventually, tires may also change shape, morphing from a wide, cushy "boulevard" ride at 35 miles per hour to a tough, thin freeway mileage-maker at 65 m.p.h.
That is an automotive generation away, though. For drivers who must replace their radials today, Mr. Stoyer suggests being prepared to answer three questions at the tire store: "How long are you going to keep the car? What kind of driving do you do? And what do you expect of a tire? If they listen to the answer to those, any type of tire dealer ought to be able to give you a tire you're going to be happy with."

HEADLINE: Cars You Drive for Just a Little While, Then It's Their Turn

BYLINE: By BILL DONAHUE; Bill Donahue, a correspondent for Outside magazine, has also written for The New York Times Magazine.

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.

 BODY:
"NICE car," said a man in a black T-shirt, walking past the little European sedan at a conference here last month on transportation and the environment. "Is it yours?"
It was the sort of comment that usually stokes the male ego. But Conrad Wagner, the 40-year-old Swiss entrepreneur who was standing beside the car, was not stoked. He rolled his eyes in exasperation and launched into a little discourse. 
 "No, it's not mine," said Mr. Wagner, who started the world's first successful car-sharing program in 1987, in Lucerne. "Owning a big piece of metal -- that is Iron Age. It is much better for the environment -- it is much more cool, you know -- to rely on a number of transportation modalities: the bus, the train, a fleet of shared cars."
The guy in the T-shirt walked away unconvinced. But throughout Europe and Canada, and in small green-minded enclaves in the United States, people are beginning to buy Mr. Wagner's idea.
Four American cities -- Portland, Seattle, Boston and Traverse City, Mich. -- now have programs inspired by Mr. Wagner's Mobility CarSharing Switzerland, which has 1,600 vehicles available for sharing in hundreds of places throughout the country. These businesses are essentially short-term car-rental agencies with a public purpose: reducing car ownership and, by extension, fuel use and pollution.
The companies park their cars in residential neighborhoods, so that they can be used -- and returned to their designated parking slots -- by members, who usually pay annual dues plus hourly and mileage fees. Each car must be reserved.
Boston and three smaller American cities also have a variant known as station cars, in which small electric vehicles are parked at rail stations. Commuters take the train to the station, then hop into a station car, drive it to their workplace and park there; the car is then available for participants returning to the rail station, and the reservation system assures that the first driver will find a car to take back to the station.
While Seattle's car-sharing program, Flexcar, is considered the nation's most ambitious, the soul of American car sharing lies here in Portland, a vast city whose four-lane thoroughfares and serpentine residential streets were built for the auto, but which has lately become preoccupied with anti-sprawl planning and green living.
In 1998, David Brook, a home-energy-conservation specialist, opened a car-sharing enterprise here, down the street from People's Food Co-op. His business, CarSharing Portland, now has 17 vehicles, mostly Dodge Neon sedans; the cars are shared by 275 drivers, who pay dues of $100 a year, plus $1.50 an hour and 40 cents a mile.
Members tend to be young professionals who don't need a car to get to work. Kassim Ferris, a 31-year-old patent lawyer who bikes to his office, said that he uses the service only three or four times a month, when he needs to "pick up dry cleaning, say, or drive to a concert that's far away."
Xander Patterson, a CarSharing member who is the co-chairman of the Pacific Green Party, also drives as little as he can. "Usually," he said, "I tow my golf clubs to the course in a cart attached to my bicycle."
But not all CarSharing members spurn the auto. Some are couples who use shared cars rather than buy a second car, and some are frequent drivers who don't own a car.
Bud Erland and Lisa Morrison, who are married, use the white Neon parked two blocks from their home about three times a week -- to carry groceries and garden supplies, and to shuttle their 7-year-old son, John, to Little League. When Mr. Erland's mother died last month, they rode to the funeral in a shared car. "We don't have to hassle with car ownership," said Ms. Morrison, a hospital worker. "We don't have to think, 'Where can we park it? Is the car being broken into?' "
It does not necessarily save them money. Mr. Erland, a meticulous recordkeeper, calculated that car sharing cost them $2,268 for 2,965 miles driven last year -- 76 cents a mile. When they owned a 1970 Volvo station wagon, they spent an average of $2,620 a year, which included gas, maintenance, repairs, depreciation and insurance, and drove an average of 9,755 miles -- 27 cents a mile.
Still, Mr. Erland, a city bus driver, said that not owning a car "feels right -- even if, economically, it proves that we're fools." And it has certainly kept their total mileage down. "We didn't have a car out in the driveway," he said with pride. "So, yeah, we didn't drive as much. We didn't, say, pop out to the grocery store for a quart of milk."
Mr. Brook, CarSharing's president, said that is just the point. "I don't want to make car use too easy for people," he said. "If you make driving a little less attractive, people will walk; they'll take the bus." He cited a Swiss study indicating that after people joined CarSharing, their total fuel consumption decreased 55 percent.
Some experts doubt that car sharing will catch on in the United States. Kenneth Orski, editor of Innovation Briefs, a Washington newsletter focused on transportation, said it was far more suitable for Western Europe. "In the crowded, medieval cities there," he said, "it's very hard to park a car; gas is extremely expensive. In the United States, though, gas is cheap and everything is spread out. People want to drive; they want to own a car."
The urge is profound even in the greenest of Portland homes. On a recent evening, as Lisa Morrison was washing the Earth Day mug in which she had just served chamomile tea, 7-year-old John Erland spoke up.
"Ever since I saw this ad on TV," he said, "I've been wanting a car -- a Chevy minivan with a TV right inside! I want one of those cars, real bad."

HEADLINE: From Moscow to Malaysia, a Look at What's on the Road

BYLINE: By RICHARD FEAST; Richard Feast is the editor at large at Automotive World magazine in London.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
THE wave of consolidation that has swept over the auto industry has been accompanied by much verbiage about the need to achieve economies of scale. The message is clear. Competition among automakers has never been tougher, so they must work together to share costs.
In the process, they are creating more global products. This makes economic sense, of course, but there is a problem: a car is not a Coke. 
 The Ford F-Series pickup truck may be the best seller in the United States, but its size and fuel consumption dictate that it will never find much favor among European buyers, who live in medieval cities with narrow streets and have to cope with startlingly high gasoline prices. In Japan, the best-selling model is a Suzuki minicar that could almost be popped into the cargo hold of a Lincoln Navigator.
Not that global cars do not already exist; they do, and have for years. Henry Ford's Model T, which did so much to bring mobility to the United States in the 1920's, was manufactured around the globe. Volkswagen's original Type 1 -- the Beetle -- was conceived in the mid-1930's with a similar mobility goal for Germany. When it went into production after World War II, the Beetle became a best seller worldwide.
Today, specialized market producers like Porsche and Ferrari sell the same models around the world. So do some prestige automakers like BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Jaguar, although in many instances their suspensions and specifications are adjusted to suit local tastes.
And in cars, those tastes can be quite pronounced. For example, Europeans favor passenger cars with diesel engines, which have never made much of a dent in the United States market. They now account for a quarter of all new-car sales in Europe and appear to be headed higher. The popularity is a reflection of the diesel engine's economy and the generally lower prices for diesel fuel.
Europeans also like hatchbacks, while Americans prefer sedans. That can be seen in last year's sales figures for the Volkswagen Golf hatchback and its sedan equivalent, known in Europe as the Bora and in the United States as the Jetta. In Europe, the Golf is the most popular model, outselling the Jetta 6 to 1. In the United States, the Jetta four-door sedan is nearly seven times as popular as the Golf hatchback.
Automatic transmissions, the norm in the United States, are comparatively rare in the most popular models in Europe, where manual shifting still seems to be regarded as a symbol of virility.
Big-volume automakers know, then, that choosing a car is a complex exercise influenced by regional culture and national pride, and by more fundamental local issues like road space, tariff and trade barriers, taxes, currency exchange rates and household income.
It is difficult to categorize all national markets, but they fall into three broad types: those like, say, Finland, which are completely open; those that favor local production by placing heavy taxes on imports (South Korea, for example); and those that are the exclusive preserve of local producers, like China.
Although firm sales figures are not yet available, a random tour of the globe shows how these influences and realities affected consumer buying patterns last year.
 
China
In a country like China, where consumer credit is tight, buying a big-ticket item like a car is not done lightly. Volkswagen -- Germany's "people's car" -- is now China's people's car. The old Volkswagen Santana model, a sedan version of the 1980's Passat hatchback, was the most popular car there last year, followed by the Santana 2000, a long-wheelbase version of the same car. Both are made in conjunction with a local producer, the Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation. The Daihatsu Charade hatchback, VW Jetta sedan and Citroen ZX hatchback are other popular models, each made in collaboration with a local partner.
Michael J. Dunne, the president of Automotive Resources Asia Inc., which has offices in Beijing and Bangkok, said the Chinese bought about 571,000 new passenger cars last year, and a total of 1.83 million vehicles of all types.
VW dominates the car market, with 55 percent, for several reasons: it got an early start in China, in 1985; it offers good value for money; and it has strong local partners. But it is facing new competition. "VW's leadership will be challenged by new entrants like Toyota with its Vitz model, Honda with the Accord and G.M. with its Buick Century and Opel Corsa," Mr. Dunne said.
 
India
Like Volkswagen in China, the Suzuki Motor Corporation has a tight grip on the closed Indian market because it pioneered local production in the early 1980's in association with Maruti Udyog Ltd. Today, as any traveler to India can observe, Maruti sells two-thirds of all cars, with Suzuki-based economy models known as the 800, Zen and Omni occupying the top three sales slots.
But that may change in time. Ford, General Motors and Hyundai of South Korea have focused on India for expansion. So has Telco, an Indian company that is part of the large Tata Group, which is developing a car line. There are already indications of the challenge Maruti is facing in India: the Hyundai Santro and Tata Indica were fourth and fifth best sellers last year.
 
Russia
Russia is much more open these days than in the old Soviet days, but local products still dominate the market. The devaluation of the ruble in August 1998 instantly made imports a great deal more expensive without affecting the prices of Russian-made cars; Western and Asian importers, which had been making good progress, suddenly found their cars priced out of the market.
So Russian manufacturers sold 955,000 new cars last year, and importers only 79,000, some of them locally assembled. On the other hand, secondhand cars imported into Russia accounted for an estimated 400,000 registrations, said Dmitri O. Choulga, a General Motors spokesman in Moscow.
Russia's most popular model last year was the Riva, a boxy, rear-wheel-drive sedan based on the old Fiat 124 and made by AvtoVAZ, the country's largest automaker. Nearly 282,000 were sold. The same company's Samara, a front-wheel-drive hatchback, was the runner-up with 201,000, followed by the Volga 3110 sedan made by AvtoGAZ.
 
Far East
As in Russia, importers do precious little business in South Korea. Three local brands dominate the market there. The Hyundai Sonata/Marcia midsize sedan was comfortably the best seller last year, with 122,600. It was followed by the Daewoo Matiz, a minicar; the Daewoo Nubira midsize sedan; and the Kia Carnival minivan.
For American and European manufacturers, South Korean trade is something of a sore point. In theory, the South Korean market is open to foreign cars, but in fact only 2,400 imports were sold there last year. By contrast, South Korean producers sold 1.1 million cars and light trucks locally and exported 1.5 million more.
"The forces of protectionism are alive and well in Korea's domestic market," says a joint statement issued by the Automotive Trade Policy Council in Washington and the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association in Brussels.
The issue has taken the pressure off Japan, which used to be the favorite "unfair trade" target for American and European automakers. In fact, car imports accounted for 6.5 percent of the Japanese market last year, and Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz, the two leading importers, sold nearly 50,000 cars each.
The real automotive sales successes in Japan, though, are those of the Japanese producers. But the best sellers are not the cars, like the Toyota Camrys and Honda Accords, that Americans immediately associate with Japan. The best seller last year was the tiny Suzuki Wagon R, which looks like a narrow, boxy cross between a minivan and a station wagon, followed by the Daihatsu Move and Honda Life.
They all belong to a peculiarly Japanese segment known as minicars, which have engines with displacements of no more than 660 cubic centimeters and are about 134 inches long by 58 inches wide. By comparison, a Ford Taurus four-door sedan, one of the most popular cars in the United States, has a three-liter V-6, and a body that measures 197.6 inches by 73 inches. An estimated 60 percent of the minicars, which miraculously seat four or five, are bought by women in their 20's.
Outside the minicar segment, the Toyota Corolla was Japan's most popular car last year, followed by the small Toyota Vitz (a hatchback version of the Echo) and the large Toyota Crown sedan.
The influence of Japan's automakers is evident right across the rest of the Far East. Thailand is a good example. It wants to become the major automotive force in Southeast Asia, and since 1995, it has attracted $1.5 billion worth of new factories from G.M., Ford, Honda and Toyota.
The country's best sellers, however, are all locally made Japanese models. And what Thai buyers prefer -- even more than American buyers -- are pickup trucks. They accounted for 56 percent of Thailand's total sales of 218,000 vehicles last year, with models from Isuzu, Toyota and Mitsubishi leading the list.
Even in Malaysia, which is trying to forge an indigenous automotive industry through daunting tariffs on imports, all the most popular models are based on Japanese designs. The best seller last year was the Proton Wira, a locally made Mitsubishi Colt, followed by the Perodua Kancil, a version of the Daihatsu Mira. Other Protons and Peroduas accounted for the next most popular sellers.
Singapore, with no domestic manufacturers to protect, takes a totally neutral view of all imports -- and then turns them into some of the most expensive cars on earth through quotas and taxes. At the same time, Singapore has invested heavily in public transportation, which is cheap and efficient, while it levies tolls for driving downtown at certain times. The result is a remarkably congestion- and pollution-free atmosphere.
Singapore's best seller in 1999 was the Nissan Sunny, which achieved a market share of 18 percent on sales of a mere 6,600. Other top sellers were the Toyota Corolla, Mitsubishi Colt/Lancer and Honda Civic.
 
Other Points
South Africans, too, prefer Japanese-based products, all of which are assembled locally. The Toyota Hilux pickup was the best seller last year, with the Toyota Conquest sedan second. There was a more even spread in popularity in Israel last year. Various Mazdas led the Volkswagens and Hyundais.
European and United States automakers hold more sway in South America. The best seller in Brazil, the continent's biggest national market with just over one million sales last year, was the VW Golf, with nearly 231,800, followed by the Fiat Palio, Chevrolet Corsa, Fiat Uno and Chevrolet Astra. In Turkey, the Renault R12, Megane and R19 outsold models from other local assemblers.
 
Europe
Predictably perhaps, sales across Europe were dominated by European producers and by G.M. and Ford, whose long presence in the region effectively makes them local producers. Over all, VW's Golf was the leader in Western Europe, with more than 707,000 sold. General Motors' Opel/Vauxhall Astra was not far behind, followed by the Renault Megane/Scenic, Ford Focus and Renault Clio.
With strong local industries in several countries, there were obvious national differences in buying patterns. The Golf and Astra were comfortably top sellers in Germany last year, and the Megane/Scenic and Clio were well ahead in France. Assorted Fiats held sway in Italy. British buyers favored Fords above all else, a reflection of the company's nearly 90 years as a local producer.
Similarly, in Eastern Europe, the companies that invested in local production are now reaping the rewards. In Poland, for instance, the country's best sellers last year were the Fiat Seicento and Daewoo Matiz, both economy models made in Poland. A few weeks ago, G.M. also began making its European economy model, the Agila, in a new Polish factory. That is bound to influence local buying patterns in the future.
But for less partisan views of European preferences, it is instructive to turn to the sales returns from a couple of countries with no tradition of vehicle manufacturing. In Finland, the two most popular models were G.M.'s Opel Astra and Ford's Focus. Toyotas and Volkswagens also sold well.
And in Greece, the top model was again the Astra, followed by the Hyundai Accent, Citroen Saxo and Toyota Corolla -- a truly international group.

HEADLINE: Lovable Sore Thumb In Bedford Hills' Eye

BYLINE: By ABBOTT COMBES 

 BODY:
THE commuter parking lots at the Bedford Hills train station are lease-to-lease with cars right out of the promised land -- you know, the ones that can climb mountains, ford streams, ferry soccer leagues, shake traffic, repel mud and after all that drop off a couple of beautiful people at the Plaza.
The makes and models are showroom perfect for a New York suburb that doesn't mind wearing its affluence pretty much everywhere it can: Audi, Acura, BMW, Caravan, Expedition, Grand Cherokee, Infiniti, Jaguar, Land Rover, Lexus, Mercedes, Outback, Pathfinder, Saab, Suburban, Volvo. . . . And then there is that 1982 Chrysler LeBaron convertible. 
 Know my station car, know me. If you are what you drive, I am a machine who has gone a certain number of miles and seen better days but keeps on making it up the hills and around the corners, somewhat the worse for wear but able to catch an eye or two, dented but not bowed, still bound for glory even if bound by duct tape.
A few particulars, though not too many, because the past isn't always an ideal prologue. Moby, as my daughter christened the LeBaron four years ago when it became mine (she knows a great white whale when she drives one), was purchased from a friend's son for $100 cash and the assumption of a $360.97 garage bill. It has a 2.2-liter engine, an automatic transmission and four cylinders. The odometer, which rolls when it feels like it but hasn't felt like it lately, says 111,746. (Maybe it's the number's third time around, making it the real charm.)
The top goes up and down, with help (arms). It keeps out rain and snow, also with help (duct tape, strategically and stylishly placed). The power windows work. The original rear window does not. The once-clear vinyl became so opaque that the blurs were blurry, and the canvas trim securing its zipper rotted so badly that there was no cloth left to restitch, much less hold the safety pins reinforcing the thread. A piece of heavy plastic, ingeniously attached with Velcro, has taken the guesswork -- and some of the fun -- out of reverse and thus far has resisted most of the elements.
The heater, defroster and (unnecessary) air-conditioner operate just fine; their fan does not. The back-seat floor is, to put it delicately, brittle. There is a broken-off key in the driver's-side door.
As to the essentials, engine and chassis, the car starts and it goes, and as long as it does I don't go out of my way to lift the hood or crawl under the body. It creaks; I creak. When we do, we find Mario Chiacchia at Haines Road Servicecenter or Dave Zasso and his son-in-law, Rob Cantisani, at Meineke, and they make things right.
The third essential, the radio-tape deck, is groovy enough for a middle-aged guy who won't grow up.
Moby, ersatz mean machine that it is, is also something of a fop and does not go quietly into the parking lot, literally or figuratively. When in doubt, accentuate the negative. For example, when the trim on the doors, a hideous vinyl-and-chrome concoction, began to fall off, I replaced it with a wood crown molding stained mahogany. Having long railed against vanity plates, I got them myself (AKA KIT -- you figure it out) and encased one of them in a bejeweled license frame so tacky that the manager of the auto-parts store didn't want to sell it to me.
The back bumper is prime promotional space, of course, and I've tried to add to Moby's, and my own, mystique. There is a 1978 Red Sox sticker (one disappointing year is as good as the next) and one for the Washington Redskins. The Ivy League is represented by my daughters' schools, and one of my own, Dartmouth and Princeton, which is another reason I couldn't drive a fancier car even if I wanted to. A Grateful Dead sticker tells everyone that "my other car is a tour bus."
My favorite, though, which I have to duplicate periodically, broadcasts how The Washington Star (where I worked) has hijacked "Doonesbury" from The Washington Post. (The Star, alas, was hijacked right out of existence shortly thereafter, 18-plus years ago, and "Doonesbury" hurried right back to The Post.) Rounding out the mobile bulletin board are the Beastie Boys, the Bahamas National Trust and the 1995 women's America Cup team, a trio that definitely wasn't made for one another but get along famously here.
INSIDE, not quite as public but hanging from the mirror for all to see, are a disco ball and a religious medal. (The medal is supposed to be St. Christopher, but may in fact be St. Francis, left over from a blessing-of-the-pets church service. Whoever -- what's good for the traveling goose must be good for this gander.) Completing the interior design are Pearl Jam and Mountain Dew stickers, which came with the car; a remnant of red carpet around the gearshift; and a doormat welcoming the Publisher's Clearing House check bearer, which no one wanted at home because he never came.
That's Moby: what you see is what you get, or maybe less, shoddily presentable yet decrepit enough to quell any passing fancy of restoration. (A new top, installed, would cost $700, which would lead to bodywork, which wouldn't make sense without a new motor, which would. . . .) Unlike most of his neighbors occupying the other 157 parking spots in Lot 4 at the Bedford Hills station, Moby cannot climb mountains, ford streams, etc. What Moby can do, and do faithfully, is get me to the train and home again five days a week, and on the weekends through my appointed rounds. Hitting on three of four speakers, he can also help me reacquaint other joy riders with the great rock 'n' roll and folk artists of ages past, the likes of Bill Haley, Carl Perkins, Buddy Holly, the Kingston Trio, Clyde McPhatter, Darlene Love, Freddy Cannon, Cat Stevens, John Fogerty, John Mellencamp (with and without Cougar), Meat Loaf. . . . So many tunes, so little driving time.
I am by no means the first to note the demise of the station car, but even in an area like upper Westchester County, showcase as it is to the rich and richer (and some others), it continues to mystify. My fellow travelers, many of them friends, insist that their late-model transports are not meant to bespeak prosperity, status, but merely to ensure reliability: why should they put up with question marks when they can afford exclamation points? (Even the relatively pedestrian cars, the Fords and the Chevys, the Hondas and the Toyotas, all seem to be as shiny as a dealer's brochure.) These commuters have outgrown the rattletrap station cars of myth, they say, and then they inevitably add their own tearful remembrances of clunkers past. Right. It certainly is a sign of modern maturity to leave a $40,000 machine, which can climb mountains, ford streams, etc., in a parking lot where its only job is not to get stolen.
On the other hand, almost no one is crass enough to offer a truly discouraging word in Moby's presence. In my town, surface politesse rules. Behind all the eyebrows that Moby raises, however, I wouldn't be surprised to discover disdain. Where I see resourcefulness, economy and individuality, others probably see shallowness, stinginess and erosion of community values. They also see, we would both agree, someone who doesn't have more money than he knows what to do with.
There may also be some regional differences working here. (Remember the Red Sox sticker?) In Massachusetts, when I grew up there, new cars were never a distinguishing characteristic of the aristocracy. Old money tended to be cheap, so that it didn't give away any to the new money. Frugality was what counted, and the more miles you got for your buck, the better. New York, on the other hand, has always been a lay-rubber, flash-your-wad kind of place. It's the difference between believing that getting there is what counts and believing that how you get there is what counts.
Well, as far as this transplanted New Englander is concerned, Moby gets me there, and he gets me there in style. Our journeys together have not always been bumpless. There have been collisions between my optimism and his obstinance; he always wins, and I always pay: axles, cylinders, starter, radiator, gas tank, muffler, rotors, brake shoes, brake drums, coils, battery, tires, ignition switch, rear-view-mirror glue. . . . And I must confess, having just finished with a calculator and receipts, that Moby's welfare has helped the local economy more than I might have wished (as some naysayers warned from Day 1). Total investment, from purchase to crown molding and all geriatrics in between: $6,106.93. Not exactly a bargain, but what price enlightenment? Amortizing it over four years, that's only $4.23 a day. As a Zen master would say, be happy with your paradoxes.
And so I am. My station in life may well leave something to be desired, but my station car does not.
