HEADLINE: G.M. Plays a Wild Card in France

BYLINE: By JACK SMITH; Jack Smith, a Pennsylvania writer, is connoisseur at large for The Robb Report.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
IT is easy to lose one's way when driving through the neighborhoods of this city, especially in those hours before dawn when the street signs above the corner tabacs, boulangeries and patisseries fade into darkness. The new Cadillac Seville that had cruised so majestically down the Champs-Elysees the night before now crept tentatively through the narrow, deserted streets while the driver rehearsed his supplicative refrain: "Excusez-moi de vous deranger, Monsieur; ou est la rue. . . . ?"
Up ahead, a figure emerged from a small hotel lugging cartons to the street and the car slid over to the curb. But before the driver could utter a word, the grinning hotelier approached to ask, in perfect English: "Hi. Are you lost?" In a manner of speaking, yes. But, how could he tell the driver was American? 
 "Ah, that is easy," said the hotel man, who introduced himself as Mory Mirza, the night manager at the Hotel Britannique. "Who else would be driving around Paris in a brand-new Cadillac but an American?"
That was a good question, and there are billions of dollars riding on the answer, as slumping sales at home have prompted General Motors, the maker of Cadillac, to explore markets overseas.
According to G.M.'s plan, there will soon be thousands of well-heeled French citizens rolling through the tonier arrondissements of Paris behind the leather-wrapped steering wheels of gleaming new Sevilles, and tens of thousands more Cadillac owners motoring across Europe, Asia, the Middle East, Africa and the Caribbean.
Ultimately, G.M. intends for 1 in every 5 Cadillacs to be sold through a dealership outside the United States. General Motors is revamping the overseas distribution network that John Smith, a former Cadillac general manager in Detroit, once described as a "loose, spontaneous confederation" and converting importers to factory-franchised dealerships, of which there are currently 87 in Europe and 700 in 70 countries worldwide.
The model charged with revitalizing Cadillac's sales overseas is the Seville, which, with its more compact wheelbase (more so, at least, than the DeVille) and its understated styling, was anointed Cadillac's "world car" upon its debut in 1998.
Soon to come, though no date has been announced, is the sleek, supercharged Evoq roadster; the two-seater has been such a hit on the auto show circuit that it has spawned yet another concept car, the Imaj, an aluminum-bodied, four-wheel-drive sedan with a Northstar-based, 425 horsepower V-8, designed with the high-performance European market in mind. Next month, Cadillac will return to the 24 Hours of Le Mans for the first time in a half-century with a Scott Riley-built prototype powered by a twin-turbo version of the Northstar engine; a Seville will serve as pace car for the race.
Heady stuff, and if Mr. Mirza's reaction to the Seville is any index of the car's appeal overseas, Cadillac's prospects of cracking the European market should not be underestimated. "The French cars are nothing, next to this," Mr. Mirza exulted, running a hand along the car's flanks. "This is gorgeous."
There was just one catch: "Too bad I can't afford one," he sighed. "I guess I'll go on driving my old Mercedes."
These days, every Cadillac sale, at home or abroad, counts. General Motors' global ambitions notwithstanding, Cadillac registrations in all of Europe dipped to 984 in 1999 from 1,259 in 1998.
But nobody said it would be easy. "Our first job is to erase the prejudice against big American sedans," said Michael Klaus, G.M.'s marketing director for North American Vehicles, Europe. "Seville has the design, the handling and the power to do this. Our fuel economy is competitive, too, considering the car has a big V-8 engine. But it's going to take several years; the European market just doesn't know the product."
Indeed, a sense of wonder pervades French reviews of the car, as if the metaphysics of the Seville's very presence on European soil outweighed petty technical considerations. According to Paris Match, the car "emanates a sense of stately grace,which certain European lines might envy."
The automotive weekly L'Argus observed that General Motors "possesses in its fishpond of marques a true treasure: Cadillac." Accompanying these raves was some minor grousing about the car's handling on the back roads, the lateral support of the seats, the styling and the way the car downshifted.
In the greater scheme of things, however, Cadillac's problem is not so much those who do not know the product, but rather those who know it best -- American car buyers.
IN 1998, slumping stateside sales spurred Cadillac to fabricate the figures needed to claim pre-eminence in the domestic luxury market, a position it had enjoyed for 49 years. When the figures were revised and cars still standing on Cadillac dealers' lots were subtracted, Lincoln emerged as the 1998 luxury champ, with sales of 187,121 compared with Cadillac's 182,570.
In 1999 Cadillac's malaise was compounded when the marque slumped to third place in the luxury arena, with sales of 178,507, tailing Mercedes's 189,437 and Lexus's 185,890.
"The problem is, Cadillac has lost sight of what it stood for," said John Grace, director of Interbrand, a Manhattan-based brand consultancy. "In the 1940's, 1950's and 1960's, everyone aspired to own one; it made a statement about the owner. Since the 1980's, its values have faded into ambiguity.
"Everybody knows what Mercedes stands for: uncompromising quality and reliability. BMW is the ultimate driving experience. But there are no Cadillac values any more. It's been driven by expediency; it's chasing the demographic-of-the-month."
Whatever it stood for before, Cadillac's descent on the slippery slope of ambivalence accelerated in May 1981 with the introduction of the Cimarron; behind that gold Cadillac crest, car buyers found a Chevy Cavalier econobox with an underpowered four-cylinder engine.
In 1994, with gas lines gone the way of mood rings, Cadillac introduced the Concours, a slab-sided, fender-skirted, six-passenger behemoth with a 270-horsepower V-8 beneath the hood. The Concours was designed to woo baby boomers with sporty performance in a car that looked like what their grandparents were driving; after four years it joined the Cimarron in memory.
The incongruities mounted in 1996 when Cadillac boasted the most powerful engine ever in a front-wheel-drive production car: the 300-horsepower Northstar. This contradicted the luxury market's preference for the comfort and performance of rear-wheel-drive, which is why every other upscale carmaker -- Mercedes, BMW, Jaguar, Rolls-Royce, Bentley, Audi and Lincoln -- eschews front-wheel-drive in its most expensive sedans.
Nonetheless, Cadillac abandoned the full-sized, rear-wheel-drive paradigm at the end of the 1996 model year, and eliminated the Brougham from the lineup.
About the same time, the carmaker unveiled its new Catera, a rear-wheel midsize sedan based on the German-made Opel that evoked echoes of the Cimarron. "We told G.M. the Catera would have made a great Saturn," said James Hossack, the senior vice president at Auto Pacific, an automotive product and market research firm in Orange County, Calif., whose clients include General Motors. "But it makes a terrible Cadillac. Who wants a luxury car with a six-cylinder engine and no more horsepower than a Honda Accord?"
In 1998, Cadillac clambered aboard the sport-utility-vehicle bandwagon with the Escalade, a $46,900 version of the $28,520 Chevrolet Tahoe. "Funny," Mr. Hossack said. "The Tahoe got a new, improved platform for 2000 while the far more expensive Escalade retains the old one."
If Cadillac's luxury lineup is bemusing, most people in the automotive industry consider its advertising of recent years a disaster. Cadillac executives turn apoplectic when reminded of 1997's "Catera Duck" campaign with its tag line, "The car that zigs." Now playing in prime time is Cadillac's new theme, "The power of &."
"It says absolutely nothing," said Mr. Grace, of Interbrand.
On the other hand, Mr. Hossack observed: "How can you advertise a lineup that includes a six-cylinder luxury car and a luxury truck based on an outdated Chevy platform? And who wants a front-wheel-drive, full-size luxury car?"
Well, the French might. "We've grown up with front-wheel drive; we know how to handle it," said Jean Claude Dutailly, who conforms precisely to the demographic profile projected for the Seville. Mr. Dutailly, 53, is general manager of the battery division of Saft, a division of the French conglomerate Alcatel, and as such drives a company car, a Peugeot 605. "When you are an executive in France, it's expected that you will drive a French car," he said, while wheeling the Seville through the Paris traffic on a test drive.
"This is really very nice, very comfortable," he continued. "It feels like you can drive it 500 miles and still be fresh. And compared to the Mercedes S Class or the BMW 7, it is a bargain. And the guarantee, you can keep it 10 years without much trouble, non?"
So, would he buy a Seville? "With all that it offers," he said, "the style, the ride, the performance, the comfort -- yes. Oh, not as long as I'm working in France. But if I lived in the States, definitely."

LENGTH: 1191 words

HEADLINE: In Automobilia, a Yearning for the Days of Youth

BYLINE: By CLIFF ROTHMAN; Cliff Rothman writes on culture from Los Angeles for Vanity Fair and The Nation.

 BODY:
LEILA DUNBAR remembers the family outing to search for old tin automotive signs at the antiques fair in Brimfield, Mass. It was 1973, and she was 12. "We slept in a borrowed van, right on the side of Route 20, the tractor-trailers rolling by and causing the van to sway all night," she said.
They would spend the two-day fair scouring the field for the handful of road signs for sale, like those for Champion Spark Plugs or Mother's Root Beer. Her dad, she remembers, paid maybe 50 cents for the 1-by-2-foot artifacts from the 1930's and 40's. 
 Brimfield now comprises 15 to 20 shows over eight days, with vast sections devoted strictly to automobilia, as the artifacts have come to be known. And those tin signs? They are about $175 to $200 each.
Ms. Dunbar, who is the director of collectibles and a senior vice president at Sotheby's in New York, has automobilia in her blood. She is not alone. According to Mobilia magazine, a niche publication, an estimated three million fans and collectors are into everything pertaining to the culture of cars, motorcycles, even tractors: toy and die-cast car models, signs, gas station maps, original workshop car manuals and John Deere equipment.
Industry sales figures for 1998 are estimated at a billion dollars, not including untabulated transactions that involve private sellers, flea markets or garage sales.
A strong economy and baby boomers, who grew up as the car culture hit its stride, are the twin spark plugs that ignited the hobby, which has exploded since the mid-90's, said Eric Killorin, the publisher of Mobilia. The magazine, a monthly, began as a newsletter with 3,000 readers in 1992 and has grown to more than 88 pages, with 59,000 readers and a popular Internet auction site that recently attracted $6 million in venture capital. The Web site (www.mobilia.com) was introduced in January 1999 with 2,000 items, and within a week had 17,000 items for sale. It now has about 20,000.
Driving the craze, however, is something less tangible and more potent than potential profit or equity: dreams. "We're not selling cars; we're selling memories, bringing collectors back to a gentler time in their lives," said Lewis Checchia, who develops and markets die-cast miniature cars as director of marketing for the Franklin Mint, which has issued more than 300 castings since the early 1980's. "They might remember when they were out with their brother, saw a '63 Corvette on the sales lot for the first time and went crazy."
Bob Knudsen, a potato farmer in American Falls, Idaho, started collecting full-size vintage Pontiac Super Duty cars. He then bought a closed-down car dealership to house his cars. Then came showroom paraphernalia -- and a new mania. "I wanted some signs, so I bought some neon, a Pontiac sign with the big Indian, which goes way back to the 30's and 40's," Mr. Knudsen said. He said that he has spent about $400,000 in the last five years on signs.
Stephen Babinsky, who restores antique cars in Bernardsville, N.J., experienced a similar quantum leap. He said he started out with porcelain signs and trinkets. "Then I got into rarer signs, like car manufacturers from the 1920's, like United Motors, a General Motors subsidiary," Mr. Babinsky said.
His prize? A Cadillac LaSalle authorized sales and service sign from the late 20's, one of only three such signs known in the United States. He still relishes this "steal" -- misidentified as a reproduction at a Christie's auction three or four years ago. "Even back then, it was worth, maybe, $7,500," Mr. Babinsky said. "I paid $2,000." The sign is valued at $10,000.
Objects that once beckoned travelers or children have gone beyond collectibles to objets d'art. The Museum of Miniatures, across from the Los Angeles County Museum of Art on Wilshire Boulevard, features a 396-piece exhibition of die-cast miniatures from the Franklin and Danbury Mints, on loan from a collector. The collection, with an estimated worth of $64,000, takes up an entire room.
"Men just love it," said Carole Kaye, a cofounder of the museum. "Actually, women, too. They really study them."
But automobilia has humbler roots than the Miracle Mile district of Wilshire Boulevard. "The original stuff came from gas stations and dealerships that were boarded up," Ms. Dunbar said. "Signs and cans would be stored in people's attics or basements." Collectors, she said, "would scour junkyards and scrap yards, abandoned dealerships and gas stations, and often would be given the items." Or they would take them.
But when items started turning up at yard sales, flea markets and at auctions, a market was created. "Once it was determined that these pieces had value, less and less were out there for the taking," she said.
Car-memorabilia collecting has been through five cycles, said Ms. Dunbar, who has published three books on the hobby. "The first generation of collectors were in the automotive business, former dealers, repair or auto-body shops, or worked for a large car company," she said.
The first wave, she said, came in the late 60's and early 70's, when the bulk of collectibles was miniature cars and vintage memorabilia. The second cycle appeared in the late 70's, after the oil embargo. Collectors, Ms. Dunbar said, welcomed to their ranks lawyers, doctors and self-employed business people with disposable income and a passion for automobiles. Toys also entered the mix.
The third generation, from 1983 to 1985, experienced an influx of collectors, flush with Wall Street money, who drove up prices. As the hobby gained recognition, the next generation, 1988 to 1991, may have exhibited "the biggest leap in prices," Ms. Dunbar said.
Automobilia was quiet from 1991 to 1995, Ms. Dunbar said. But in 1995, it entered its fifth cycle, and has been rising steadily since, she said.
Today, collectors are "anyone from Joe Six-Pack to a doctor," said Evie Black-Dykema, a senior industry analyst with Forrester Research, a market research firm in Cambridge, Mass. "Most prevalent is the lower-than-average-income collector," she said. "They may be willing to spend a few thousand in a weekend that reminds them of their youth."
The nostalgia epicenter is the baby boomers, who grew up as cars came into their own as a mass-market, affordable entity. "Thirty-something is when people start collecting," said Mr. Checchia, of the Franklin Mint.
As collectors age, the epicenter shifts. "And the next generation will want its own artifacts," Ms. Dunbar said. Maybe they will covet replicas of farm equipment.
Farm collectibles took off at the start of this decade. A leading player is Racing Champions-Ertl, based in Iowa and known for its high-end replicas of the John Deere tractors, balers and such. The company sells about 500 models at any one time. Prices range from $5 to $150, based on size.
Then there is Nascar collecting. Mr. Killorin, of Mobilia, said he estimated that it constitutes a third of the market. "It's gone from a standing start to the checkered flag," he added. "I have a 9-year-old boy who cares about Nascar, motorcycles and pickup trucks. I know he's not alone."

LENGTH: 1420 words

HEADLINE: More Speed? Power? Now Drivers Can Have It Their Way

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE; David J. Wallace is a Boston writer who covers business and technology.

 BODY:
ONE winter several years ago, Jim Conforti of Bonneville, Utah, had trouble getting his BMW 325i to start. At an altitude of 4,000 feet, the pre-programmed fuel mixture flooded the car's spark plugs when temperatures hovered near 32 degrees.
Mr. Conforti, a software engineer, was puzzled and set out to chart the fuel mixture programmed for the car. He adjusted it to a leaner setting, and the car started up promptly thereafter. Eventually, Mr. Conforti decided to open a sideline business, Bonneville Motor Werks (the German spelling is deliberate), to create and sell high-performance parts for BMW's that are "reverse engineered" from factory specifications. 
 Bonneville is one of dozens of companies, along with uncounted individual motoring enthusiasts, that are fine-tuning engines to meet personal needs -- that is, redoing or undoing the work of car manufacturers.
Such tinkering is growing, thanks to the On-Board Diagnostic II system, known as O.B.D.-II, a computer the size of a paperback book that has been installed in every car sold in the United States since 1996.
As happens so often with new technologies, O.B.D. has spawned an industry of its own. Reprogramming cars by tweaking the computer's chips has evolved from a hobby to a multimillion-dollar business. Companies like Dinan Motorsports in Mountain View, Calif., tout high-performance chips. Web sites provide detailed instructions on how, for a few hundred dollars, car owners can swap the chip boxes themselves and turn their sedan into a speed demon.
Where shade-tree mechanics once adjusted carburetor fuel mixtures and timing by working under the hood with hand tools, now any computer equipped with the proper programs can read, reprogram and change a car's performance.
By remapping some data points, torque settings can be reprogrammed, horsepower can be increased, and top speeds, limited electronically at the factory, can be extended. On the other hand, a parent might want to control speed, not increase it to prevent, say, a teenager from exceeding 55 miles per hour. One man in Michigan, who bought a Ford Mustang police car programmed for high-performance highway driving, recently asked an online chat group how to reset the car for a calmer ride.
"In some cases, people will have a drivability issue they want to solve, not just more power," said Mr. Conforti, who has a patent application pending on a small device that can change BMW settings from normal to high performance and back again. "One car has a tendency to slowly decelerate when you hit the clutch and it hangs -- the idle control valve seems to open or electronic throttle takes over -- which makes for smooth shifting. But for people who have to hold the clutch, it can be annoying waiting for the revs to match up. For those drivers, maybe the problem can be tuned out."
Factory settings are designed to be forgiving, accommodating a wide range of drivers and behaviors. For example, some drivers do not use the proper high-octane gasoline when prices rise; others don't change the oil on time. Factory presets allow the car to compensate for such variables. But reprogrammed cars can lack that flexibility, causing the engine to be damaged by seemingly innocent corner cutting.
Michael Vaughn, a spokesman for the Ford Motor Company, warns that changing settings could void a car's warranty and affect engine durability. Reprogramming a car can also strain its brakes, tires, suspension and other parts.
Nonetheless, there is nothing illegal about changing a car's performance, as long as the vehicle passes state inspection and emissions tests, and reprogramming is not likely to render a car unsafe. In fact, car company engineers are watching the so-called aftermarket carefully for solutions to problems they might not have considered, or improvements for ambitious drivers. All this makes for an uneasy truce between car manufacturers and those who want to change their hard work.
At heart, O.B.D.-II is the car's brain: it monitors various systems to ensure peak performance, and has become a crucial diagnostic aid for mechanics.
The system was originally intended to control emissions. In the mid-1980's, carmakers began using electronics to manage engine functions that affect emissions, like idle settings and fuel mixture. California was the first state to mandate use of the O.B.D. system, recognizing the benefit of controlling pollution through computerized controls. National standardization of O.B.D. by the federal Environmental Protection Agency followed in 1993.
Oxygen sensors, knock sensors and other tiny tools let the car "learn" how well its pollution-control system is working. The engine then adjusts to different temperatures, altitudes and other conditions to ensure optimal emission control, fuel economy and overall performance.
To most dashboard watchers, the O.B.D. system is apparent only when the red or orange "Check Engine" light glows. After a few miles, it might go out, just as unexpectedly as it came on. Problem solved: the car's sensors reported a change in operation and corrected it by adjusting a setting. Sometimes, however, when a part is wearing out or already broken, the "Check Engine" light is stubborn.
The computer tucks away a few kilobytes of data about the problem that caused the light to go on. It will then divulge details about the vehicle's operation to a mechanic with a scanning tool. Depending on the car manufacturer, the diagnostic tools and the system itself, up to 300 facts can be stored about a car, including the maximum speed it was driven, the engine's peak r.p.m. level, emission levels and the condition of sensors throughout the vehicle. Mechanics can plug a sensor into a small jack near the driver's seat, download a file that taps the O.B.D.-II chip's memory and use the data to locate, identify and repair what is wrong.
The increasingly intricate electronic connections throughout cars are making replacement parts more expensive, and the sophisticated O.B.D. system has complicated the mission of more than a few manufacturers -- from NAPA Auto Parts, which makes basic replacement-part items, to makers of high-performance exhaust, fuel injection and air filter systems.
"Now that we're monitoring performance of parts or systems through the emissions system, they're concerned their part may not be compatible and cause the 'Check Engine' light to come on," said John Trajnowski, principal engineer with vehicle and environmental engineering at Ford.
Original-equipment manufacturers are cautiously sharing engineering details, without drawing the curtain too wide. They are keen to know where chip tuners are able to improve performance and eager to capitalize on the market.
"We've set up a system where aftermarket part manufacturers work through a third party, enabling them to make parts that comply without giving up proprietary information," Mr. Trajnowski said. "They can market their part, and our trade secrets won't get out to G.M. or Toyota -- things like how we run the engine, how we do the monitoring, control timing, fuel, etc. We wouldn't want that leaked to our competitors."
Security has also been an issue for car owners. Paul Olsen, an electrical engineer with B&B Electronics Manufacturing Corporation in Ottawa, Ill., which builds the diagnostic tools that read the chips, recalls the conspiracy theories that bubbled up when the O.B.D. system first came out.
Motorists feared that mechanics would invade their privacy by sharing information about driving habits with manufacturers, who might void their warranties, or with law-enforcement officials, who might note the driver's need to speed. The fear has apparently not been realized.
"People were concerned about privacy and Big Brother, but now look at it more favorably," said Mr. Olsen, who has created a Web site devoted to O.B.D. (www.obdii.com) for mechanics and curious car owners. But Bob Redding, a lobbyist for the Automotive Service Association, which represents auto repair businesses, wrote an article recently for its Web site about one Orwellian possibility. He pointed out that the technology exists to monitor the onboard computers of eight lanes of traffic traveling, theoretically, bumper to bumper at 100 m.p.h. By remote, computers could scan each car for the code indicating excess emissions.
Drivers with cellular phones, he posited, might then receive a call telling them the bad news: they had just flunked an emissions test.

HEADLINE: Caught Between Payday and Principle

BYLINE: By EVE TAHMINCIOGLU 

 BODY:
When she was a securities broker in Florida for the NationsBank Corporation in the early 1990's, Catherine Hovis knew that the elderly clients she was selling mutual funds to did not have the financial or emotional means to take on risky investments. One couple, both in their 70's, were living on Social Security and wanted something as safe as a certificate of deposit but with a better return -- maybe 7 to 8 percent.
Ms. Hovis convinced the couple that the bank's mutual funds were safe and, at her bosses' urging, reassured them they had made a smart investment even after the value of the funds declined. 
 Today, Ms. Hovis, 43, acknowledges that she had begun to suspect the mutual funds were not as solid as bank management had led her to believe. Yet, she continued to sell them to risk-averse elderly clients because, she says, she was doing what her bosses told her to do. She was also motivated by her supervisor's praise, a six-figure salary, financial bonuses and a free trip to the Cayman Islands, becoming one of the top 25 sellers of the funds for NationsBank, now part of Bank of America.
"Money makes people do very strange things," Ms. Hovis said. "As a single mother, I was willing to do what I had to do." Besides, she added: "I'm human. I wanted to be a team player."
The practice of pressuring the elderly to buy mutual funds, which Ms. Hovis said was pervasive throughout the bank, led to a $29 million class-action settlement by NationsBank in 1997 with people who had been sold the funds. Despite the settlement, the bank vigorously denied the assertions in the suit. Last week, bank officials declined to comment on Ms. Hovis's assertions.
As she describes it, her moral plight was unusually stark. But the basic choice she faced between her paycheck and her principles is one that most workers eventually encounter. And with hordes of people now fixated on stock market riches and million-dollar game shows, ethicists warn that ordinary Americans are having an even harder time holding on to their moral bearings.
The transgressions that tempt them can be as seemingly trivial as fudging an expense report and as troubling as lying to law enforcement officials to protect their boss. Sometimes, they make headlines, as happened this year when Christopher M. Davidge, a former chief executive of the Christie's auction house, was said to have told government investigators that Sir Anthony Tennant, a former chairman, had ordered him to carry out a price-fixing scheme.
"Most people just go along with what other people do and respond to the expectations of those around them," said David Vogel, an ethics professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley. "This encourages and permits ethically dubious behavior."
Paradoxically, the tight labor market -- which logically ought to diminish worries about job security -- might actually encourage ethical lapses, some experts say. "In a rising economy, you don't want to be left out," said William Lundin, author of "When Smart People Work for Dumb Bosses" (McGraw-Hill, 1998). "To be at the big table and play with the big guys, you take chances and risks, and bend your ethics."
Many companies have adopted codes of conduct and other ethics programs in recent years. Yet, a new survey by the consulting and accounting firm KPMG shows that unethical behavior is still rife in the workplace. The survey of 2,300 workers in a broad range of industries was conducted in 1999 and released last week. More than three-quarters of the respondents had witnessed illegal activities or breaches of company rules over the previous 12 months, and 38 percent said they believed that senior managers would "authorize illegal or unethical conduct to meet business goals." Factors that they said encouraged unethical behavior included the pressure to meet unrealistic production and earnings goals.
"We're still seeing fairly significant levels of misconduct," said Richard Girgenti, KPMG's national director of investigative and integrity management services. "Ethics programs need attention and nurturing."
Crossing certain ethical boundaries may be endemic to certain industries. In a recent survey by the trade journal PR Week of 1,700 public-relations executives, 25 percent acknowledged lying on the job, 39 percent said they had exaggerated the truth, and 44 percent said they had ethical qualms about tasks they had been asked to perform.
A common catalyst for wrongful behavior is common to every industry: blind devotion to a boss. Nan DeMars, an ethics consultant in Minneapolis, cited an Atlanta secretary who, trusting her boss, notarized a document for the sale of his wife's car without witnessing the wife's signature -- a breach of the law -- because he insisted it was hers. It wasn't, the wife said in a lawsuit, and the secretary ended up with a felony conviction.
Richard O. Mason, head of the Maguire Center for Ethics and Public Responsibility at Southern Methodist University in Dallas, said that people guilty of ethical missteps usually have a "moment of truth" in which they either decide to rationalize their behavior or try to make amends.
Ms. Hovis is trying to make amends. "I paid for the blood money," she said, fighting tears. "All the calls and cries for help" from clients gave her sleepless nights, she said, and led to occasional heavy drinking.
She decided in 1994 she did not want to sell the funds anymore and soon left the bank. Since then, she said, she has cooperated with federal and state regulators, including testifying to the Securities and Exchange Commission. On top of the $29 million class-action settlement, in 1998 NationsBank agreed to pay $6.75 million to settle charges by the S.E.C. and other regulators that it had misled investors about their investment risks. NationsBank neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing.
"It's the least I can do to repay my part of what I did," said Ms. Hovis, who is now trying to make a career out of teaching financial education. "When I'm dead and gone, at least my son will say, 'My mom tried.' "
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: Catherine Hovis says she regrets selling risky securities to elderly risk-averse clients. (Scott Martin for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "The Ethics Audit"
Five questions you should ask yourself if your boss wants you to do something that doesn't seem quite right:
 
1. Would you be ashamed to tell your spouse or children you did it?
2. Would you mind if the local newspaper reported that you had done it?
3. Would you be upset if somebody else did it to you?
4. Is it legal?
5. Are you tempted to seize on rationalizations like "Everyone else is doing it" and "It won't hurt anyone?"
 
(Source: Nan DeMars, author of "You Want Me to Do What? When, Where and How to Draw the Line at Work" Fireside, 1998 )

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Civic Theater: Shakespeare, O'Casey And Ventura

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, May 14

 BODY:
Last weekend Austin, Minn., a pleasant, if not exactly mythical city of 22,000, two hours south of here, had a visit from a number of sprites, fairies, gods and foolish Athenians, as the Guthrie Theater's traveling production of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" ensconced itself in the high school auditorium.
It was the penultimate stop on a 17-city tour through the northern Midwest, the first time the Minneapolis-based Guthrie, one of the nation's most prominent regional theaters, had toured a show since the mid-1980's, when funds from the National Endowment for the Arts dried up. It provided a rare opportunity for Austin, which proudly declares itself Spamtown U.S.A., a homage to its leading corporate citizen, Hormel Foods. And the locals took advantage; nearly a quarter of Austin's population attended the four performances. 
 The production, staged by the Guthrie's artistic director, Joe Dowling, and featuring a number of young actors the Guthrie has developed in its summertime pre-professional program, was no skimpy road show. It was a three-hour extravaganza, full of inviting theatrics: colorful sets, gaudily witty costumes, lighting wizardry, gymnastic choreography, Shakespearean verse set to doo-wop and disco music, and not least, in a broad satire that no one in Austin (or anyone who has seen the film "Fargo") could fail to appreciate, the commoner craftsmen, Shakespeare's goofy, would-be thespians, done up as dimwitted Minnesotans.
O.K, it wouldn't have played so well at Lincoln Center. The acting was uneven -- a lot of youthful overenthusiasm there -- and the overall concept, which placed the denizens of Theseus' palace in modern dress and the denizens of the forest in outfits that would have made them comfortable in the "Star Wars" wookie bar, took "anything goes" as its through line. Most egregiously, the "Pyramus and Thisbe" skit was milked for far too much slapstick and for far too long. But at least two young performers, Cheyenne Casebier as Helena and Randy Reyes as Puck, had the glow of genuine talent, and Shawn Hamilton, an experienced actor in regional theater, provided authoritative ballast as Theseus and Oberon.
Mr. Dowling has a gift for moving actors effectively around the stage, and his purpose in emptying his substantial bag of tricks was wonderfully achieved: to make the theater a place of welcome, with Shakespeare the friendly host and teacher. It would be hard to imagine better theater in a high school auditorium. And to judge from the lusty standing ovation at the end of Friday night's show, it was much appreciated. Indeed, the show's reception in Austin couldn't have been a more timely demonstration of popular support for the Guthrie, whose ambition is currently both on display and at issue.
Best known for its full-throttle productions of classics in its home theater -- its current show, "The Plough and the Stars" by Sean O'Casey, is exemplary -- the Guthrie, founded in 1963, has, since Mr. Dowling arrived in 1996, reached high-water marks, with more than 32,000 current subscribers and nearly $50 million in endowment, making it one of the nation's healthiest theater companies. But it has been restricted by its building, which is attached to the Walker Art Center and has only one performance space, a 1,300-seat auditorium with a thrust stage. It has been unable to compete in the ever more necessary enterprise of developing new work, and its lack of a proscenium stage has limited its ability to transfer shows to commercial houses or engage in co-productions with other regional companies.
Plans for a new, three-theater building have been in the works for several years. Now the search is about to begin for an architect for a site on the banks of the Mississippi in Minneapolis that had once been considered by the city for a new baseball stadium. But for months the Guthrie has been the focus of a political debate over whether the public should help pay for a project estimated at $100 million.
The Guthrie expects to complete the building for the 2004-2005 season, with or without government money. But its initial request to the state for $25 million was whittled down by legislators wary of Gov. Jesse Ventura's antipathy toward government spending on the arts and by newspaper polls that indicated public opinion was uncertain about whether the Guthrie, a nonprofit institution, was of statewide value -- more worthy than, say, a private enterprise like the Minnesota Twins -- or merely a crown for the arts-rich Twin Cities. A bonding bill that would have provided the Guthrie with $3 million in state funds was delivered to Governor Ventura by legislators on Friday. He struck that provision in a line-item veto on Monday; a legislative override is still possible.
It's an odd position for an arts institution to be arguing for itself in the political arena. But Mr. Dowling, an Irishman who is a former artistic director of the Abbey Theater in Dublin, admits to an obsession with politics; he and his wife have applied for citizenship, he said, in the hope of voting in November. He has been busy with the Guthrie's own campaign lately, pointing out, in interviews, meetings with legislators and letters to the editor, the economic benefits to the state from the construction project and noting that 100,000 children attended Guthrie performances free or with privately subsidized tickets last year.
Governor Ventura has never been to the Guthrie for a performance; he's not a theater guy, though there is a musical in the works based on his life as a wrestler turned populist politician, a production of which, Mr. Dowling joked, might help the Guthrie in its fund drive. Had the governor attended over the weekend -- he was fishing -- he would have seen what Mr. Dowling has been up to in his spare time, directing "The Plough and the Stars," O'Casey's portrait, both acrid and affectionate, of Dublin's working class during the turbulent days of the failed citizens' revolt of 1916 against the ruling British, known as the Easter Rising.
Viewing "Midsummer" and "Plough" on consecutive nights, one gets a sense of Mr. Dowling's expansive notion of theater as well as his directorial style. The set for "Plough," by Mr. Dowling's longtime collaborator, Frank Hallinan Flood (he also designed "Midsummer"), is magnificent, a sooty brick tenement front stretching across the back of the thrust stage, with windows lighted and laundry dangling on clotheslines.
An archway between the two wings of the tenement forms a proscenium of sorts, beneath which actors enter from the surrounding Dublin neighborhood in some scenes; for others, whole interior sets -- two apartments and a barroom -- emerge from it on rollers. Behind it the revolt itself, which fills the play's second half, is replete with the light and sound of gunfire, as though a Hollywood movie were being shot just out of view. Mr. Dowling is not stingy with effects.
O'Casey's tenement is aswarm with neighborly conflict, both personal and political, already simmering in poverty and ready to boil in the crucible of imminent revolution. In scene after scene Mr. Dowling sets his large cast -- there are nine principal roles and a substantial company -- in perpetual motion. They dance, threaten, fight, embrace, rally round the flag -- or flags, since one character, has a son serving the crown in World War I -- as their loyalties to one another shift in an increasingly violent milieu.
The cast, alas, is uneven, many with a tenuous hold on the Irish accent that gives a particular poignancy to O'Casey's characteristic poetics. (The contemporary playwright that comes closest to O'Casey's vernacular music of a particular time and place is August Wilson.)
Mr. Dowling has emphasized the hardness of these people, the beleaguered quality that makes them prone to aggravated selfishness, and as a result the American actors often miss the aching romanticism that lies moribund in them but not dead. This is particularly true of Michelle O'Neill and Lee Mark Nelson as Mary and Jack Clitheroe, the young married couple whose once-enviable romance has withered with the rise of Jack's call to patriotism. A climactic tug of war -- when a pleading and pregnant Mary tries to pull Jack away from a wounded comrade -- is staged to squeeze the heart, but the actors don't seem as agonized as they do argumentative.
Happily the show is anchored by the weight of real Irish -- Milo O'Shea as the carpenter Fluther Good, whose live-and-let-drink approach to life has hardened into a sad and self-deluding pride, and the superb Rosaleen Linehan as Bessie Burgess, a bitterly lonesome British loyalist whose humanity is forced to the surface when the revolution visits her living room.
In the production's most affecting scenes, each takes command. Just before intermission Mr. Dowling stages a barroom waltz between Fluther and the prostitute Rosie Redmond (a stirring character turn by Derdriu Ring), which wends its way into the street into the last moments of a political rally that has been commandeered by a demagogue's call to arms. The drunken dancers, unsuited to each other except out of fear and loneliness, twirl obliviously about Jack Clitheroe, whose face is fixed in soldierly anger. Mr. O'Shea's yearning for a private peace brings the lights down with a sweet dream that is clearly a portent of doom.
At the end of the play, when that doom finds Bessie in her own home, O'Casey's tragedy is complete. She bleeds from a gunshot, calling out for help to Mary, who has gone mad; it is a moment of purposefully high melodrama. Ms. Linehan conjures Bessie's death, not with dignity or fear but with sadness and resentment, understanding that she, a worthy woman, is a victim of senselessness. It's a sensational sequence that highlights an actor's probing and craft, a textbook example of subtle thinking and precise performance that makes an audience feel, snapping down the benevolent jaws of the theatrical trap. And that, after all, is what Mr. Dowling and the Guthrie wish to accomplish.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: Return of the Native Executive;
Many Repatriations Fail, at Huge Cost to Companies

BYLINE: By JOBERT E. ABUEVA 

 BODY:
At the height of the Asian financial crisis in 1998, Scott Fedje, an art director for a Fortune 500 apparel manufacturer, returned to his company's headquarters in the northwestern United States from a five-year stint in Hong Kong. Even though he got a promotion and a pay increase as a reward for his overseas performance, Mr. Fedje resigned a few months later to take a job with a design-consulting firm in San Francisco.
"I felt lost," said Mr. Fedje (fed-GEE), who asked that his former employer not be identified. "Most of us who returned went from a position of high responsibility and a dynamic environment to a cubicle, a project and a whole month to make a single decision." He missed old colleagues who had moved on, he said, and he longed for the kind of cultural stimulation he had found in Asia. So when he was offered work in the Bay Area, he grabbed it, and now he heads the retail design division of the firm, Landor Associates. 
 Call it the exodus of the returned expatriates. Every year, thousands of executives like Mr. Fedje arrive home from foreign postings and bolt to greener pastures, often at a cost to their employers of $1 million or more that was invested in training and overseas expenses. Dr. J. Stewart Black, managing director of the Center for Global Assignments, a consulting firm based in San Diego that works with executives going and coming from abroad, said that two-thirds of the returning executives and their family members he had interviewed described repatriation as a more wrenching experience than the overseas postings themselves. "It's a staggering statistic and problematic for employers," he said.
Just as alarming for corporations is the defection rate of returning managers. Twenty-five percent leave within a year, double the proportion of departures by those who never go abroad, Dr. Black said. And the returned managers who leave typically go to the competition.
Dr. Black cited an extreme case of a company that over a two-year period lost every manager it had sent on international assignments within 12 months of their return -- 25 people in all. The company "might just as well have written a check for $50 million and tossed it to the winds," he said.
The biggest shock for managers fresh from foreign postings appears to be the change in their status from a big frog in a small pond to a small frog in a big one. Many also discover that the skills they acquired overseas, and the acquaintances they cultivated, are of little use to them now.
"It has left me depressed," said an executive at a large transportation company who came back to the United States at the end of last year after spending four years in Southeast Asia. The executive, who insisted on anonymity, added that he now felt like "just another cog in a bureaucratic wheel."
Family members can also go through reverse culture shock, compounding the pressure on the breadwinner. When her husband was sent back to the United States after two years in Tokyo for a small semiconductor company, Sylvia Dickinson of Menlo Park, Calif., felt out of sorts and concerned about her daughter's adjustment to American schools.
"People did not want to hear about our life abroad after two seconds," she said. "It's difficult to simply shut out a life-transforming experience like that. You don't just pick up where you left off either."
Her husband, Tom, worked on ad hoc projects until he was recruited away by Cirrus Logic, a competitor that she said now capitalizes on his international background. She has capitalized on it, too, starting Dickinson Consulting, a firm that counsels outbound and returning executives and their families. "Having been there and back, I can offer an empathetic ear," Ms. Dickinson said.
So, what do companies do to hold onto their talent? Robert Greenleaf, executive director at TMC, a consulting firm in Princeton, N.J., that specializes in preparing executives for overseas posts, says rule No. 1 is to write down, in clear terms, what they expect the departing executives to achieve abroad and what they expect them to do when they come back.
Dr. Black cited companies like Monsanto that start thinking about next assignments for expatriates three to six months before they return. At Monsanto, two senior officials with international experience assess the skills that the overseas executive has gained on the tour of duty and review the job openings that are available. At the same time, the returning executive writes a report, assessing his skills and describing his career goals. The three then meet to decide his future.
Paul Kocourek, a senior partner at Booz, Allen & Hamilton, knows about repatriation. He went through it three times, after stints with the Peace Corps in Thailand in the 1970's, Bain & Company in Tokyo in the 80's and Booz, Allen in Australia in the late 80's and most of the 90's.
His familiarity with the process enabled him to draw up a short list of hints for making a successful re-entry. The returning expatriate, he said, should try flying home a number of times during the final stages of the overseas stay to cement relationships with people in the home office, meet with clients and discuss a future role in the company. And the executive should ensure that clients and projects are properly handed over to the overseas successor.
"Maintaining one's network and having a mentor or sponsor back at headquarters to keep tabs on you helps," Mr. Kocourek said.
Re-entry can be especially wrenching if the home office has more or less forgotten about you. That is what Deborah Burks, a 37-year-old Chicago executive, said happened to her. Ms. Burks was dispatched to Hong Kong in 1998 to build a regional presence for the digital-media division of a Fortune 500 chemicals company based on the West Coast. But despite what she said were significant inroads that she had made, the company decided to halt its expansion effort there.
"There was neither a contingency nor any accountability within the division or company," Ms. Burks said.
She returned last year to Chicago, where she had been posted before -- except that now she ended up in an office with little to do. She had sold her Chicago home, believing she would be away for an extended period, and had to shop for a place to stay. Her company told her of jobs available in a small town in Ohio, but she decided not to pursue them. In the end, she found a job as a director for new business development at R. R. Donnelley & Sons. She is not bitter, she said, and in fact believes that her international experience taught her invaluable skills in coping with changes in the corporate world.
"I would still do it over again but be more mentally prepared for the risk," she said.
As for employers, the best thing they can do to keep returning stars is to keep channels of communication open even long after an overseas assignment has been completed.
"If an executive is feeling unease, he should be able to speak up and have a nonthreatening forum to do so in," said Dennis Kaminsky, who spent two tours of duty in Japan for the plastics division of the General Electric Company.
"Coming home is always a wonderful feeling," Mr. Kaminsky said. "It's having the environment to express this and any other feelings that can make a world of difference."

WHEN CONSIDERING AN OVERSEAS ASSIGNMENT
 
Ensure you are technically qualified and have the patience and flexibility to work and live abroad
 
Discuss the potential relocation with your family from the beginning and make sure you have their enthusiastic support

HEADLINE: Profit Up at 2 Retailers, but Penney Drops

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A robust economy kept shoppers in the buying mood in the first quarter, lifting sales and profits at two big retailers that reported results yesterday.
But the J. C. Penney Company reported sharply lower profits before charges amid trouble at its department stores. Nonetheless, its results beat Wall Street estimates. 
 The Target Corporation's earnings topped expectations, fueled by strong demand at its discount stores, while a strong housing market increased Home Depot's profits as shoppers bought supplies to renovate their homes.
J. C. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., said its profits from operations fell 51 percent, to $82 million, or 28 cents a diluted share, compared with net income of $167 million, or 67 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
Analysts had expected the company to earn 23 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
The operating profit did not include costs associated with the closing of about 40 Penney and 289 Eckerd drugstores. Including those and other special charges, the company lost $118 million, or 48 cents a share.
Sales rose to $7.7 billion from $7.5 billion.
The earnings slide comes as the retailer struggles to get its business back on track. Penney has closed many underperforming stores, sold some noncore businesses, overhauled merchandise buying and hired more outside executives.
"We don't expect a meaningful pickup in sales until the first quarter of 2001," Vanessa Castagna, the company's chief operating officer, told analysts.
Shares of J. C. Penney fell 37.5 cents, to $18.375.
At Target, based in Minneapolis, profit rose 23 percent, to $239 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $194 million, or 41 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
The results topped Wall Street estimates of 49 cents a share.
Sales at the company, which changed its name this year from the Dayton Hudson Corporation, rose 8 percent, to $7.61 billion from $7.03 billion.
Sales at its Target discount stores open at least a year, an industry gauge of performance, increased 4.7 percent, while comparable-store sales at the department stores dropped 4.9 percent and 1.8 percent at Mervyn's.
Shares of Target rose 43.75 cents, to $71.4375.
Earnings at Home Depot, based in Atlanta, gained 29 percent, to $629 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with $489 million, or 21 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
Sales rose 24 percent, to $11.1 billion from $8.95 billion.
The company's results met Wall Street estimates.
Shares of Home Depot fell $2.9375, to $53.50.

HEADLINE: Statement by Fed Panel

 BODY:
Following is the text of the statement by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to raise short-term interest rates:
The Federal Open Market Committee voted today to raise its target for the federal funds rate by 50 basis points to 6 1/2 percent. In a related action, the board of governors approved a 50 basis point increase in the discount rate to 6 percent. 
 Increases in demand have remained in excess of even the rapid pace of productivity-driven gains in potential supply, exerting continued pressure on resources. The committee is concerned that this disparity in the growth of demand and potential supply will continue, which could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's outstanding performance.
Against the background of its long-term goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information already available, the committee believes the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future.
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, Cleveland, Richmond and San Francisco. The discount rate is the rate charged depository institutions when they borrow short-term adjustment credit from their district Federal Reserve Banks.

HEADLINE: Saudi Reports $1 Billion of Investments

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, May 16

 BODY:
Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia said today that he had spent $1 billion buying shares in 15 American companies, including Amazon.com, WorldCom, Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and AT&T.
"We bought all these companies, which are here for the long run, after their share prices had collapsed by as much as 70 percent," Prince Walid said. "We are not old economy; we are not new economy; we go everywhere there is value and growth potential." 
 Prince Walid, who is a nephew of King Fahd and one of the wealthiest people in the world, regularly makes investments in companies with strong brand names and lagging share prices.
The prince spent $200 million on WorldCom shares, the single biggest investment, followed by AT&T with $150 million.
The remainder was divided into $50 million portions and shared among Coca-Cola, PepsiCo, McDonald's, Walt Disney, Ford Motor, Gillette, Procter & Gamble, Amazon, eBay, Internet Capital Group, Priceline.com, Infospace and DoubleClick.
"Between December 1999 and February 2000, everyone deserted old-world stocks and went into the Internet, causing all these old established companies to crash, and I emphasize crashed, so I bought slowly but surely," Prince Walid said. "In April and May, everybody abandoned the Internet stocks and went back into the old world. Then Internet shares crashed, so I went in there."
The purchases increase the prince's technology, media and telecommunications portfolio to $7.8 billion, with technology amounting to $2.814 billion; media to $3.869 billion; and telecommunications to $1.115 billion.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Fed's Rate Increase Fails to Dampen Rally on Wall St.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks held onto early gains yesterday after the Federal Reserve announced its sixth interest-rate increase since last June. Investors snapped up stocks on the hope that the Fed is succeeding in keeping inflation under control, although market analysts warned that rates would continue to rise.
The Fed raised interest rates by half a percentage point, the steepest increase in five years, saying the rapidly growing economy "could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's outstanding performance." 
 The rate increase was widely expected, so after a brief tumble in the wake of the Fed's announcement, stocks resumed a "relief rally." The Dow Jones industrial average rose 126.79 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,934.57.
Broader stock indicators also closed higher. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 109.92 points, or 3.1 percent, to 3,717.57. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 13.68 points, to 1,466.04.
Yesterday's rally was the fourth consecutive day of market gains as investors have convinced themselves that a half-point rise would bring the Fed close to the end of a long run of rate increases.
Richard McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch, argued that many investors were also hoping to capitalize on a pattern of market rallies in the sessions after previous rate increases.
"The market has been improving since last Thursday on very little fundamental good news," he said. "Volume has been low and the broadness of the advance has not been that great, so that raises questions about the rally's staying power."
Stocks rose from the start of trading after the Labor Department offered some evidence that the five previous rate increases may be succeeding in holding inflation down. The Consumer Price Index, after rising sharply for two months, held steady in April as energy prices posted their first decline in almost a year.
The report raised hopes on Wall Street that the Fed would not have to raise rates sharply throughout the rest of this year. Analysts were less sure.
"The Fed was on the verge of falling behind the curve," said Chris Conkey, chief investment officer at Evergreen Investment Management in Boston. "This is a great step in terms of getting ahead of the curve, but we foresee more increases later this year."
Analysts said stocks of every sort, from new-economy technology companies to old-economy industrial and consumer stocks, will face pressure if interest rates continue rising.
Higher rates threaten corporate profits by making it more expensive to borrow money.
What is more, with six weeks before the Fed's next meeting and about two months before most companies report second-quarter earnings, investors may struggle to find reasons to buy stocks, analysts said.
"We may be laying ground for a better rally in June or July, but I don't think we're at the starting point for that yet," Mr. McCabe said.
The stock market drew some additional strength from Abby Joseph Cohen, chief investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs, who told an Economic Strategy Institute conference that she anticipates "good returns, not necessarily abnormally large returns" from the stock market this year.

Treasury Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after the Federal Reserve suggested further interest rate increases may be necessary, even as it raised its target rate to a nine-year high of 6.5 percent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 19/32 , to 102. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.10 percent from 6.15 percent on Monday. The price of the 10-year Treasury bond rose 5/32 , to 100 19/32 . The bond's yield fell to 6.42 percent from 6.44 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Sicuani Journal;
An Outsider in Peru, but at Home in the Inca World

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: SICUANI, Peru, May 13

 BODY:
Alejandro Toledo, running an uphill campaign for president of Peru, has been lagging behind President Alberto K. Fujimori among Indian women, despite his strong Indian features.
So when Mr. Toledo arrived in Sicuani, a town 12,000 feet high in the Andes known for its Indian markets for llama skins and alpaca wool, he warmed up the crowd in the central plaza by handing the microphone to his wife, Eliane Karp. 
 As a strawberry blond, Belgian-born, naturalized American, Ms. Karp seems like an odd campaign weapon in Peru. But she speaks the ancient Inca language of Quechua and she is one fiery speaker.
"There has not been a good government for 500 years!" Ms. Karp bellowed, in a blanket attack on every ruler of Peru since the Spanish conquered the Inca empire in the 16th century. "Do not be fearful and do not listen to the liars. With the force of the Inca, Alejandro can create a great government!"
The crowd cheered wildly, seemingly not caring that Ms. Karp's Quechua, like her Spanish, is inflected with her native French. Ms. Karp looks more like a tourist than a Peruvian, but few Peruvians know their country's traditions and its Huayno folk dances better than she does. All of this makes her one of Mr. Toledo's potent political assets.
Peruvian politics tend to be highly idiosyncratic and unpredictable, and the current election has been no exception with all its charges of fraud and extreme nastiness in the news media. But perhaps the most unusual ingredient of the campaign so far has been Ms. Karp, a 46-year-old anthropologist who says she found her political identity in her Jewish roots.
"My vision of Judaism is one of light and justice that is totally impossible to reconcile with dictatorship," she said in an interview, adding that one turning point of her life was her becoming interested in indigenous cultures while studying at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem in the early 1970's. "I learned in Israel that you don't take no for an answer," she said.
The other turning point in Ms. Karp's life was meeting Mr. Toledo in 1975 when they were students at Stanford University. They have had a stormy marriage marked by years of separation but finally a firm political alliance. "Alejandro and I think together on the pillow at night," she said, "just as we did in university when we used to go to the pinball machine to figure things out when I had problems with my dissertation."
Now she says she plans to break the mold of Peruvian first ladies. She wants to use the experience she had as a consultant for the World Bank and the United States Agency for International Development to remake agricultural production in Peru, using many of the techniques that have made the Israeli desert bloom.
Ms. Karp's open ambition and her outspoken criticism of machismo and espousal of feminist causes have opened her up to charges that she is a foreign interloper and a wild-eyed leftist. Newspapers that support Mr. Fujimori have written much about their marital problems, contending that she and Mr. Toledo are actually divorced -- a charge she denied. "She shouldn't intervene in Peruvian politics," said Francisco Tudela, Mr. Fujimori's vice presidential running mate. "She is not a Peruvian."
But whenever Mr. Toledo is in trouble, he turns to his wife. When a report surfaced two months ago that he had an illegitimate daughter whom he refused to support, it was Ms. Karp who denied the charge on a television talk show, saying, "I know the man I am sleeping with."
In the days after the first-round vote on April 9, as charges of fraud mounted, Mr. Toledo and Ms. Karp spoke to the masses from the roof of a Lima hotel. Her words were particularly explosive, with a reference that recalled the defiance of protesters in 1988 in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. "I will stand by my husband and we will not move," she said. "Let the tanks roll!"
More recently, Ms. Karp came forward with the fantastic claim that government intelligence agents had twice kidnapped her husband and filmed him in compromising circumstances. So far the videos have not surfaced, but political analysts say she probably took away their shock value if they are released in the final days leading up to the May 28 runoff.
Ms. Karp has been compared to Eva Peron for her populist touch and Hillary Clinton for her ambition in an outpouring of press coverage. The press has found her so fascinating that they published articles about how her father fought against the Nazis in the French Resistance before he was captured by forces led by Klaus Barbie and how her mother was chosen as a beauty queen of a Jewish club in Belgium. "Without Eliane Karp," said Hernan Chaparro Melo, a leading pollster, "Toledo could not have produced a solid image to become an alternative to Fujimori. By speaking Quechua and dancing Huayno, she sent a message that she is with the people."
Still, Ms. Karp is not universally accepted. In one recent poll, 43 percent of 512 people questioned said they did they not approve of the political role she was playing.
Here in Sicuano, however, Ms. Karp donned a red-embroidered flat-top Indian hat and displayed the power of having a common touch. A group of Indian dancers reached for her hand to dance the Quinuoa Saruch, a folk dance that marks the planting of potatoes, and Ms. Karp roughly knew the three-step and smiled widely as she was twirled from one dancer to another.
After dancing, students surrounded Ms. Karp to plead their case for the government to build a science laboratory for the local college. Without consulting her husband or his advisers, she agreed to their request on the spot -- leading to joyful cheers.
"Her word is believed," said Maribel Regina Quispes, 22, one of the students. "She may not be a Peruvian but she speaks Quechua and she is more identified with our culture than many Peruvians."
Then a local radio reporter pulled her aside for an interview, asking her if Peruvian machismo stood in the way of her acceptance.
"It's part of a long educational process," she conceded. Then taking advantage of the open microphone to promote a cause close to her heart, she added: "The woman works just as hard as the man in the house and the fields and is paid less. That should change."

HEADLINE: Behind the Rate Hike

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve aggressively raised interest rates yesterday, and Wall Street cheered. The textbooks say that higher interest rates are supposed to draw investors out of the stock market and into the bond market. Yet the Dow Jones stock market index rose more than 125 points yesterday.
The reason appears straightforward. Investors were worried that inflation is beginning to creep up and that the Fed might be waiting too long to push it back down. They feared that if inflation keeps rising, the Fed might be forced to crack down hard in the future, a reaction that would knock the economy off its high-growth path. So Wall Street reacted warmly when the Fed raised short-term interest rates by half a percentage point, double the size of each of the five previous rate increases. 
 Investor reaction is as much psychological as financial. A quarter-point rate increase carries about as much economic wallop as a half-point increase. What is really going on is a signaling game. By choosing the larger of two possible rate hikes, the Fed signaled to businesses, workers and investors that it intends to clamp down on inflation.
The economy remains strong. Unemployment has fallen below 4 percent. Spending rose by more than 8 percent at the beginning of the year, a pace few economists believe can continue without creating shortages and a burst of inflation.
What worries the Fed are the first signs that inflation is rising above 2 percent a year, a beneficial target. Consumer prices have risen by 3 percent over the past year. Even subtracting out energy and food, two volatile sectors, prices rose slightly more than 2 percent. There is nothing alarming about these numbers -- indeed, producer price inflation remains low -- but fears remain that rapid growth is beginning to drive up prices.
The shocking fact is how slowly wages are rising in the face of severe labor shortages. Indeed, only in the past few years have wages risen faster than prices. The best way to create room for wages to rise further is to keep the economy growing. For that to happen, the Fed believes it must convince everyone that inflation will remain under tight control. That is what the Fed said it would do yesterday. Wall Street believed what it heard.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
The Fed Administers Dose No. 6 of Its Sedative for the Economy

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, still believes that his medicine -- higher interest rates -- will reduce the economy's feverish growth. But it appears that the medicine is much weaker than he thought just a year ago, and that much higher doses will be needed to have the desired effect.
Last June, when the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee raised interest rates for the first of what has now become six times, the committee's minutes reflected a general expectation of "appreciable moderation in the trend" of economic growth in the months ahead. 
 At that time, a divided Fed decided not to signal that there would be future interest rate increases. This was despite warnings by some members that the lack of such a signal could be interpreted as meaning that no further raises in rates were likely. In fact, that exact interpretation took hold as financial markets rallied on the news.
Since June, the economy has behaved in a way that few if any would have expected. The boom has continued, and economic growth has accelerated. Housing starts, industrial production and inflation are up, while unemployment is down.
Yesterday, when the Fed announced its sixth rate increase -- and the first in that series to bolster the federal funds rate target by half a percentage point, not the usual quarter-point rise -- it went out of its way to warn that it was still worried about inflation, and to hint that more increases would come unless and until the economy began to cool.
"Increases in demand have remained in excess of even the rapid pace of productivity-driven gains in potential supply, exerting continued pressure on resources," the Fed said in its report yesterday. "The committee is concerned that this disparity in the growth of demand and potential supply will continue, which could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's outstanding performance."
Translated, said Robert Barbara, the chief economist at Hoenig & Company, "the Fed said we will be more aggressive in our attempts" to slow the economy.
The Wall Street reaction this time was a bit confused and hesitant at first. Stock prices had been up sharply for the day, amid hopes that the expected half-point increase might be accompanied by language hinting that the Fed's series of rate increases was nearing an end. Most of the gains evaporated in the 30 minutes after the Fed's announcement, a reaction that did not seem surprising given the relatively strong language.
But the immediate alarm soon faded, and it appears that many small orders came in for stocks, which rebounded to end the day near the highs set before the Fed acted.
If the market's action indicates that many investors believe the good times will continue, that is understandable. The Fed's efforts to slow the economy have proved unsuccessful, and even if they do succeed there is a general expectation that Mr. Greenspan will ride to the rescue to prevent any kind of economic calamity. That is what he has done in the past, and the confidence that he will do so again makes it harder for the Fed to put a drag on the torrid pace of economic activity.
Perhaps the most surprising economic statistic now relates to housing, an industry that historically has been among the most sensitive to changes in interest rates. The data available to the Fed last June showed housing starts were running at a strong annual rate of 1.65 million over the previous three months. Six rate increases later, the figure is 1.7 million.
The stock market still thinks housing will weaken. The Standard & Poor's index of home builders is down 24 percent since last June, even though profits for most of the companies the index comprises have continued to rise. Many other stocks that are viewed as being sensitive to economic cycles have suffered during the period, reflecting the expectation, at least, that the economy will slow.
But the performance of those stocks was offset by the surge in many technology stocks, as enthusiasm for the new economy heated up. That enthusiasm peaked in early March, and although the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index is down 26 percent since then, it is still up 41 percent since June 29, 1999, the day before the first rate increase.
One reason that the Fed's efforts to slow the economy have not worked very rapidly is that market interest rates have not cooperated. The Fed directly controls the federal funds rate, which is the rate banks charge on loans to one another. That rate has climbed 1.75 percentage points, to 6.5 percent, since the Fed began tightening.
But the rate on three-month Treasury bills is up only 1.33 percentage points, to 6.02 percent, during the same period. And the yield on 10-year Treasury bonds has risen by just under half a percentage point, to 6.42 percent. Rates on corporate bonds, which may have a greater impact on economic activity, have risen more than the rates on Treasury securities but still not by as much as the federal funds rate.
There are always lags in the economic response to the Fed's moves, but the failure of the Fed to have any apparent impact so far remains surprising. One explanation for the economy's persistent strength is the wealth effect -- the feeling of many investors that they are richer after years of big rises in stock prices. Another is that the United States continues to draw in heavy foreign investment, which is reacting both to the healthy stock market and the buoyant economy.
Nonetheless, it is likely that sometime this year the Fed's medicine will begin to take effect. When it does, that will slow the growth in corporate profits and rein in corporate plans to invest in new productive capacity. The dollar may also come under pressure as investments here look less attractive.
But for now, the economy is booming, and investors seem to have no fears that the Fed will do serious damage to an economic expansion that is already the longest in American history.

HEADLINE: Retail Prices Unchanged Last Month

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Consumer prices were unchanged in April and the construction of new homes rose, government figures showed today, signaling that the economy was expanding with little to no inflation.
Declines in the cost of gasoline, clothing and air travel offset increases for medical care, food and housing last month, the Labor Department said. The flat Consumer Price Index came after a 0.7 percent jump in March and was the first report since last June's to show no change. The so-called core index, which excludes food and energy, rose 0.2 percent, half of March's 0.4 percent increase. 
 Housing starts rose 2.8 percent in April, to an annual pace of 1.663 million units, led by an increase in apartments and other multiple-unit developments, Commerce Department figures showed. That partly reversed March's 11.2 percent decline and put housing starts 6.5 percent higher than in the month a year earlier. At the same time, building permits fell, a sign of possible cooling ahead.
A separate Labor Department report showed that average weekly earnings adjusted for inflation rose 0.7 percent last month, after falling 0.5 percent in March. That is good news for home builders, which are counting on rising incomes and low unemployment to outweigh the effects of higher mortgage costs.
The consumer price report showed that retail prices increased 3 percent in the last 12 months. While that is less than the 3.7 percent annual rate in March, it exceeded the 2.7 percent increase for all of 1999.
Energy prices, which account for about a tenth of the Consumer Price Index, fell 1.9 percent in April after increasing 4.9 percent in March.
Transportation costs fell 0.7 percent, the largest decline since May 1997, and included a 0.5 percent drop in air fares. Apparel costs fell 0.5 percent, after rising 0.3 percent in March. Compared with April 1999, clothing costs were down 1.4 percent.
The cost of medical care increased 0.3 percent in April after rising 0.5 percent in March, and prescription drug prices were up 0.4 percent. Compared with April 1999, medical care costs were 3.9 percent higher and drug prices up 4.9 percent.
Food prices, which account for about a fifth of the Consumer Price Index, rose 0.1 percent in April, the same as in March. Housing costs increased 0.1 percent April, after a gain of 0.4 percent in March.
At the same time, the Commerce Department housing report showed that building permits fell 1.4 percent in April, to 1.574 million units at an annual pace, the third consecutive monthly decline. Permits have been issued for 504,800 housing units in the first four months of the year, down 4.2 percent from 526,800 in the first four months of 1999.
