HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Sweeping Overhaul To Fix Peacekeeping by U.N.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 16

 BODY:
Richard C. Holbrooke, just back from an extended peace mission in Africa, called today for a sweeping overhaul of the United Nations peacekeeping operations and for more money from member nations to make the operations effective.
"Peacekeeping must be fixed in order to be saved," Mr. Holbrooke, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, said at a meeting on the organization's budget. 
 The debate on the cost and future of United Nations peacekeeping opened at a critical moment. The United Nations is on the defensive for its performance under fire in Sierra Leone, and is and in the midst of a painful self-examination -- and some trading of accusations -- about what went wrong and why.
United Nations peacekeeping is stretched almost beyond capacity, with substantial military and administrative operations in East Timor, Kosovo and Sierra Leone, where a renegade rebel, Foday Sankoh, and his Revolutionary United Front took about 500 peacekeepers hostage.
A risky mission is about to be sent to Congo and, by July, the Security Council will be faced with a call for a large force on the Lebanese-Israeli border to move in after the withdrawal of Israeli troops.
Today Mr. Holbrooke recommended expanding the peacekeeping department significantly and allowing Secretary General Kofi Annan more flexibility in staffing it. That matter is a constant battle here, where staff allocations of all kinds are micromanaged by the General Assembly.
Mr. Holbrooke also asked countries that have been given discounts on peacekeeping bills for more than a quarter of a century to offer to pay more as their economies grow. All the organization's member states pay a proportion of the total peacekeeping costs.
For the first time, five nations answered the appeal and said they would pay more: Cyprus, Estonia, Israel, Hungary and the Philippines. Mr. Holbrooke said in an interview that he hoped to see at least four or five more on the list.
In his speech, Mr. Holbrooke announced that a high-level review over how to contribute better to peacekeeping was under way in the Clinton Administration, which many diplomats and officials here say badly let down the United Nations in Sierra Leone. Mr. Holbrooke backed the establishment of a rapid-deployment unit at United Nations headquarters to work with a roster of available military, police and civilian experts to be called on as needed.
Most diplomats here, stung by humiliation in Sierra Leone, would not fault the conclusion that peacekeeping needs to be rethought.
But not all are happy to let the United States take the lead, saying that decisions in Washington, including a vote by Congress to lower American peacekeeping assessments in violation of international agreements, have caused much of the problem.
Ambassador Michael Powles of New Zealand, speaking today for his country as well as Australia and Canada, told the budget assembly that "some countries have been presenting the problems associated with peacekeeping financing as if they were solely the making of the United Nations and attributable to the fact that the peacekeeping scale has not been revised since it was created in 1973."
"This is not the whole story," he said, making a direct reference to the United States position. He blamed debt defaulters instead. The United States owes more than $1 billion.
In Sierra Leone, attacks on peacekeepers began when they were being deployed in rebel strongholds, especially diamond-mining areas. The attacks and abductions changed the character of the United Nations operation overnight.
What happened in Sierra Leone provokes debate -- and some name-calling -- at several levels.
On the ground in Freetown, the United Nations has had problems with both its military commander, Maj. Gen. Vijay Kumar Jetley of India, and the Secretary General's special envoy, Oluyemi Adeniji, a retired Nigerian diplomat.
General Jetley, who has commanded the peacekeeping force since it was sent to Sierra Leone, is popular with civilian United Nations officials there, and his Indian troops when fully deployed will make up a third of the total force. A second contingent of Indian troops began to arrive today, with a full battalion of 1,000 soldiers expected in the next few days. The reinforcement raises the United Nations peacekeeping force to 9,150 members.
General Jetley has been criticized by leaders of several contingents from other nations taking part in the peacekeeping mission, among them the Zambians and Kenyans. They describe him as high-handed and uncooperative, and there are serious discussions about replacing him, some officials say.
Mr. Adeniji has also created problems by running his own show without keeping officials, including Mr. Annan, informed. Little useful analysis of what was happening in rebel-held areas was ever collected or forwarded to New York, officials complain, although relief organizations say they knew a great deal.
On Sunday, Mr. Adeniji went to Monrovia, Liberia, to negotiate with President Charles Taylor for the release of more than 130 hostages, since the Liberian president continues to influence at least a part of Mr. Sankoh's rebel force, the Revolutionary United Front. But he did not tell Mr. Annan or other officials here of his freelance mission. United Nations headquarters found out through an African-based journalist who got a tip about a hostage release.
Replacing either man, however, would not be easy. India has already taken umbrage at official criticism of its commander, and has threatened to abandon the mission.
Nigeria, which had its own forces in Sierra Leone under a West African regional operation before pulling most of them in recent weeks, appears to have an interest in having a free hand in the affairs of Sierra Leone. The Nigerians had put pressure on the Secretary General to name a Nigerian as special representative.
A more fundamental problem for the United Nations is that it was never party to the Lome agreement last year that created the now-sabotaged peace deal in Sierra Leone.
"In the Lome agreement the U.N. were not supposed to be the peacekeeping force," said Bernard Miyet, the undersecretary general for peacekeeping, who briefed the Security Council on Monday after returning from Sierra Leone. "We were supposed at the beginning to have a few dozen military observers."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Team in Sierra Leone
 WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said that an Air Force team arrived in Sierra Leone today to assess the security of the airport outside the capital, Freetown.
Mr. Annan has criticized Washington for refusing to send American peacekeepers into Sierra Leone. But Mr. Cohen said the United States is continuing to work with Nigeria to figure out how to help that country if it sends in peacekeepers.
"We have in fact been in contact with the Nigerians to see how and if they can participate in a very active role and what will be required to support their efforts," Mr. Cohen said today at a Pentagon briefing.
The United States may provide some equipment to the Nigerians, as well as transportation, according to Kenneth Bacon, the Pentagon spokesman.
"The problem isn't people willing to be part of the United Nations or regional forces," Mr. Bacon said. "The issue is to get them to be effective."

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Printer Is Moving, to Aid Both Itself and Landlord

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Astoria Graphics is a financial and commercial printing company that has been operating in buildings owned by Trinity Church Real Estate for the last 50 or so years. And it will continue to do so as a result of an unusual deal under which it gave up space at an extraordinarily favorable rental rate in one building in return for space in another Trinity location at a higher, but still favorable, rate.
Astoria, a family-owned company in its fourth generation, is fortunate compared with other companies, many of which have been forced out of Manhattan by rising rents and the desire of landlords to replace manufacturing with office tenants. But more than good fortune was involved, executives on both sides agree. Astoria has substantially converted from traditional methods to new forms of electronic printing that have little of the noise and vibration that make office tenants reluctant to share buildings with printers. 
 "We are a digital manufacturing company," said Ronald D. Koff, the president of Astoria. "We do not have heavy, vibrating equipment."
Steven D. Heyman, director of commercial leasing for Trinity Real Estate, which is owned by the Parish of Trinity Church, said: "Office tenants can't live next to or above the noise of a conventional printer. But Ron is in the brave new world of printing, and he doesn't make much noise."
Mr. Koff said he had grown up in Trinity-owned buildings, first at 435 Hudson Street and later at 75 Varick Street. But great change has come to 75 Varick, which Trinity is marketing as 1 Hudson Square. Responding to the strength of the office market in Manhattan, the church has invested nearly $70 million to convert it from light manufacturing to Class A offices.
With asking rental rates in the building now topping $50 a square foot annually, Trinity officials were eager to retrieve the 15,000 square feet occupied by Astoria, all the more because the company was operating under an old lease and paying just $6 a square foot.
Mr. Koff said he was willing to move because he needed more space. But he said he was intent on staying in Manhattan and not following the printing companies that had departed for New Jersey and the city's other boroughs.
"We thought it was prudent to stay in Manhattan," Mr. Koff said. "Clients like to see the plant, even if they only spend a few minutes walking through it. It's good to be close to your customers."
The changes in Lower Manhattan, particularly the influx of dot-com companies, Internet service providers and telecommunications companies, provided a powerful incentive to stay, said Mitchell Koff, Ronald's brother and co-president of the company. "They have enveloped the area and are a big part of our business."
In addition, he said, the presence of the high-tech companies meant that there was a high-capacity telecommunications infrastructure already installed in the area, which is important to printers who now receive much of their source material as electronic files over the Internet.
But finding suitable space in Manhattan proved to be difficult. "Landlords want new-economy companies such as dot-coms, not printers," said Andrew P. Sachs, a director of Insignia/ESG and the broker for Astoria.
After failing to find what the company was looking for, Mr. Sachs said, he went back to Trinity's managers and asked if there was a way for Astoria to stay in the church's portfolio of 5.5 million square feet of space. Although its property was once occupied almost entirely by industrial tenants, Trinity has in recent years converted much of it to office use.
Eventually, the three parties worked out a deal that included buying out the last three years of Astoria's deeply below-market lease at 75 Varick Street and having the company move to 30,000 square feet of space in another Trinity-owned building at 225 Varick Street.
Since buying out the old lease would have required a substantial payment by Trinity to Astoria, the value of that payment was transferred to 225 Varick. As a result, the printing company is paying $18 a square foot for 10 years in a building where asking rents are in the range of $40 a square foot.
"It was a huge benefit for Trinity to get Astoria out of 75 Varick without having to write a check," Mr. Sachs said. And the printing company benefits from getting below-market rent. "This is a good deal for both sides," Mr. Sachs said.
Ronald Koff said the company was now planning for the move north on Varick Street, which will take one to two weeks. "It's not something you want to do very often," he said.

HEADLINE: In Boom Times, the Have-Nots Influence the Dominican Vote

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 16

 BODY:
Dominicans turned out in large numbers on Tuesday to elect a president -- either one who would build on the current government's policy of economic liberalization or one who wants to reconsider some of the changes to help the poor and rural residents who say the boom years have overlooked them.
While this Caribbean nation has enjoyed four years of robust and unprecedented growth, dissatisfaction among the poor has been great enough to drive the candidacy of Hipolito Mejia of the left-leaning Dominican Revolutionary Party. Mr. Mejia, an agronomist and businessman who was a cabinet official in the 1970's, has campaigned on a platform of increased social spending, aid to farmers and a reassessment of the current government's privatization policies. Preliminary results based on 27.7 percent of the polling places were giving him 49 percent of the vote early this morning. 
 But the same sentiment has also propelled the unlikely candidacy of former President Joaquin Balaguer, who is seeking his eighth term in office. Mr. Balaguer, an autocrat who was close to the dictator Rafael Trujillo, is 93 and blind. In his infrequent stump speeches, he has had to be helped to the podium by aides.
Nonetheless, his Social Christian Reformist Party was garnering 26.7 percent of the vote. The third main candidate, Danilo Medina of the governing centrist Dominican Liberation Party, known as the P.L.D., has vowed to continue his party's economic policy but with an eye toward having the benefits flow to the neediest sectors of society. This morning, he had 23.6 percent of the vote.
If no candidate wins a majority, a runoff is scheduled for June 30. While some polling places experienced delays, the vote proceeded without disruptions or conflict.
The current President, Leonel Fernandez, a lawyer educated in the United States, has been praised by international groups for having enacted economic changes that have stimulated a growth rate of approximately 8 percent and attracted considerable investment here. Mr. Fernandez, who is prohibited by law from a second consecutive term, also focused on improving transportation and roads.
"This has been a fairly progressive government by Dominican standards," said a diplomat here.
Supporters of Mr. Medina, who was a top aide to Mr. Fernandez, said the recent economic growth -- which last year made the Dominican Republic's economy the fastest growing in Latin America -- should continue under their party's supervision. They said that the country's stable currency and finances would improve the country's ability to invest in schools and health services.
"If you want to work, you can work," said Idelfonso Cora, as he waited to vote for Mr. Medina. "I support Danilo because of the growth under the P.L.D. has been the best.
But the governing party's economic changes and capital projects have not played as well among some poor and rural voters, who feel the initiatives have done little to improve their circumstances. There are continuing complaints about high food prices and a lack of jobs.
"People still have to get on boats and go to Puerto Rico because there is not enough opportunity here," said Samuel Collado, a security guard who was waiting to vote for Mr. Mejia. "We want a government that will help the poor, not just the rich."
He and others have been especially rankled by the government's privatization of state-run sugar and electrical production industries. In Guerra, about 15 miles outside Santo Domingo, voters said the privatization of the sugar company had a devastating effect on their town.
"Sugar cane?" Maria Altagracia Lebron said. "Don't even talk about that. We used to live from that, but not anymore. There is no cane or anything, because the government privatized it. And who does that favor? The millionaires who have the money."
While Mr. Mejia said he would review the privatization policies, he may have no choice but to continue, a diplomat said, because he is also enough of a businessman to know that it was ultimately the only choice the country had.
In some respects, both he and Mr. Medina tout similar promises of helping those who have been left out.
"This is about personality," a diplomat said. "There is also a more direct connection between the parties and the people. The concept that one candidate might do good for the whole nation is alien. It's what can you do for me?"
Perhaps the master of that retail political strategy has been Mr. Balaguer, who has honed it over decades, dispensing jobs, food and favors. "The people who support him got things -- a job, a school or a building," a diplomat said. "I also think there is some sort of nostalgia for the caudillo, the strong leader. They feel they want a society where they do not have much chaos."
The campaign season was seen by many as among the most tranquil in years. Nonetheless, there were disquieting incidents of violence.
In late April, two supporters of the governing party were shot and killed by Mr. Mejia's bodyguards during a campaign swing in the town of Moca. Although the bodyguards said the two were suspected of planning to attack Mr. Mejia, the police dismissed that motive. Several suspects were arrested.
And recalling the violence that racked this nation during Mr. Balaguer's rule, the family of a journalist who was killed by a death squad linked to the military in 1975 tried to block Mr. Balaguer's candidacy, accusing him of complicity. The Central Electoral Council declined to pursue the case, saying there was not enough evidence.
Mr. Balaguer's supporters, in turn, accused the governing party of plotting to assassinate him, saying that his age and frail physical condition made him vulnerable.
Mr. Balaguer could still be in a position to exercise influence should his party come in second in the vote. It is expected that Mr. Mejia could face a challenge from a united front forged by his two opponents. At the same time, Mr. Mejia's supporters say their candidate's strength among the poor and rural voters has not been reflected in the polls.
"He is a good candidate," said Alfonso Bolque Brito, a street vendor. "He is the only one who can put food in the mouths of those who are unhappy."

HEADLINE: Putting the Clamps on Consumers Accustomed to Borrowing Freely

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Consumers will quickly begin to feel the pinch of the Federal Reserve's half-point rate increase as borrowing -- from home equity loans to car and truck financing to credit cards -- becomes more expensive. Rates on fixed-rate mortgages, however, have already climbed and may even retreat some from their current level of about 8.5 percent, specialists said.
And consumers with money to invest will most likely benefit from the Fed's action yesterday, though the rates that banks pay on investments like certificates of deposit and money market accounts tend to rise less fully or with a lag, depending on various factors, including the amounts involved. 
 "People aren't going to wake up tomorrow and find their rates a half-point higher," said James E. Glassman, a managing director at Chase Securities, said yesterday. "But it's progressively growing more expensive" to borrow for millions of consumers whose aggregate personal savings rate, as a proportion of disposable income, has dwindled to virtually nothing, he said.
Indeed, while few real estate deals already in progress are likely to be jeopardized, some consumers in New York and elsewhere who are stretching to buy houses before prices go up further may find prospective lenders increasingly shy about committing to very large loans. An increasing number of buyers lock in financing before shopping for a home.
Michael LaCarrubba of Jersey City, who plans to buy an apartment in Lower Manhattan, expressed the uncertainty of many consumers after learning of the Fed action. "It's kind of scary right now; it's a race against time to get a rate locked in before they rise too much," he said. "It is unnerving because you don't know what to expect."
A financial analyst for Towers Perrin, Mr. LaCarrubba was aware that mortgage money is still relatively cheap compared with what it has been over most of the last 30 years. But he added that the difficult "issue is that prices on properties are so high that you may already be extending yourself." But he was undeterred.
"I guess you just have to find the properties you like and know that there could be a $100 to $300 difference" in higher monthly payments.
In general, the highest borrowing rates -- typically on credit cards for those with subpar incomes or repayment histories -- will be hit relatively lightly because the cost of money is a lesser part of the rate than the lenders' cost of administration and write-offs of uncollectible accounts.
But there will be some direct effect. Citigroup's Citibank, for example, ties its credit card rates to the prime rate, which it raised a half-point yesterday, to 9.5 percent, in lock step with the Fed, as has become the pattern in recent years. The bank's policy is to review these rates on the last business day of the month, meaning that its card rates will rise for July payments on purchases made in June, said Susan Weeks, a spokeswoman.
Deposit rates, governed by competition as well as the costs of gathering the money, are set by the bank each Thursday and are in effect from the following Tuesday through Monday. Preferred money market accounts now yield 4.59 percent, up from 4.45 two weeks ago. Six-month C.D.'s yield 5.35 percent, up from 5.21. The bank gave no indication what it would decide this Thursday.
Chase Manhattan also reviews deposit rates each week; its six-month C.D. rate was 5.40 percent yesterday.
Based on information from the 10 biggest depository institutions in the 10 biggest metropolitan markets, a six-month C.D. was paying 4.99 percent yesterday, compared with 4.12 percent a year ago, and a one-year C.D. was paying 5.39 percent, compared with 4.37 percent.
As for mortgages, which are subject to monthly examination, rates for adjustable loans at Citibank are tied to Treasury bills while fixed-rate loans fluctuate with bills or other benchmarks.
But in housing, said Kory Bockmann, economist at the National Association of Realtors, the Fed's move may not be translated into higher rates except in particular circumstances, like for barely qualified or overreaching buyers.
"There's probably not going to be too much of an impact," he said, "We may actually see a decline in the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage," which is hovering at about 8.5 percent. Rates have already climbed, Mr. Bockmann noted, and by raising short-term rates the Fed may have reassured the markets that it will keep control of inflation, expectations of which over the next decade or so largely determine rates for long-term mortgages.
Bert Ely, a banking industry consultant in Virginia, said, "If anything, mortgage rates ought to hold constant or tick down a little bit." At the same time, he added, the Internet is helping consumers shop for better rates on both savings accounts and loans. "We are starting to see a more national market for deposit-taking."
Rates on small savings deposits and service-intensive products like checking accounts are relatively low and largely impervious to changes in market rates.
According to Sung Won Sohn, economist at Wells Fargo, one of the biggest real estate lenders, many consumers are expressing a belief that the rise in rates may be approaching an end, a view the seemingly shared yesterday by the stock and bond markets.
More than one-third of current mortgage applications are now for floating rates, he said, compared with just 5 percent to 10 percent several months ago. "More and more people are betting that mortgage rates will go down," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE PERSONAL FINANCES;
Gore Has Not Bought Stocks for Decades

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
When E. F. Hutton talks, Al Gore doesn't listen.
The vice president does not invest in the stock market. He told reporters yesterday that he had shied away from the market for nearly 25 years because he was worried that as a public official, any investments might look like a conflict of interest. 
 "Twenty-four years ago, when I ran for Congress, for good or ill, I made the decision that in order to avoid even the appearance of any conflict of interest, on the many subjects that would come up for votes, I decided as a matter of personal policy I would not invest in stocks," Mr. Gore told reporters yesterday at a news conference in New York.
"Now, missing the bull market is not the greatest thing in the world, financially," he said a little sheepishly. "But for me, it was the right decision."
The issue came up after Gov. George W. Bush asserted that Mr. Gore had a "substantial amount of his money invested in the stock market." Mr. Bush made the statement Monday in promoting his plan to allow people to invest some of their Social Security payroll taxes in the market. Mr. Bush may have thought it was a safe assumption, given that half of all American households are invested in the market.
Financial experts suggested they would have made the same assumption. David G. Dietze, president of Point View Financial Services, an investment advisory firm in Summit, N.J., said it was highly unusual for someone of Mr. Gore's age (52) and income ($171,500 a year) not to be invested. "There's probably only one chance in 100 that someone of his ilk would not have investments in the stock market," Mr. Dietze said.
A 1998 examination of Mr. Gore's finances by Fortune Magazine concluded that Mr. Gore's assets were dwindling and questioned how he could hope to run the United States economy as president with such a dismal track record with his own finances. Fortune said Mr. Gore had a small amount of money in I.R.A.'s, but that most of his money was in checking and passbook accounts or tied up in property.
"This potential president could be a financial dolt," Fortune wrote, noting that in addition to his salary, the vice president had earned more than $1 million from his book "Earth in the Balance."
"This is a family in dire need of a money manager," the magazine wrote.
